webTitle: Wenger promises no retreating in Moscow

fields.headline: Wenger promises no retreating in Moscow
fields.trailText: Group C Arsenal will be missing Gilles Grimandi and Patrick Vieira for a daunting 75,000 sell-out match on which "the prestige of the whole of Russian football" rests, to say nothing of Arsène Wenger's ambitions.
fields.body:
Almost two hundred years after Napoleon Bonaparte was driven from this city, Arsène Wenger hopes to restore the pride of French leadership in freezing conditions here tonight.

This evening begins a crucial five days which could shape Arsenal's season. A trip to Leeds on Sunday follows this opening second-phase match against the Russian champions, which is a 75,000 sell-out and is so savoured by Spartak's fans that £4 tickets have been selling for £60-£100 on the black market. Somehow, President Vladimir Putin has a seat.

"At stake is not only Spartak's reputation," said their coach Oleg Romantsev, "but the prestige of the whole of Russian football."

Arsenal will have to improve on recent showings to spoil their night. They have managed one point and not a single goal from their past three matches and must cope without their central-midfield partnership of Gilles Grimandi (suspended) and Patrick Vieira (injured). Wenger admits the French pair's "defensive stability" will be missed against opponents who like to strike through the middle. Ray Parlour and Nelson Vivas are expected to deputise.

A draw would be a fine result against a side who beat Bayer Leverkusen, Sporting Lisbon and an already qualified Real Madrid here in the last round, though Wenger stressed a defensive approach was out of the question. "We have to go with a positive mind and try to win the game," he said. "They are a very good team, with good passing and very mobile. That's why if we try only to defend we have no chance. They are too good going forward."

Spartak's attack is led by two Brazilians: Marcao, who had a short and unsuccessful spell in Serie A with Torino, and Robson. Yegor Titov, a 24-year-old Russian international, is also a regular source of goals.

All that amounts to a significant test for Arsenal's stand-in goalkeeper Alex Manninger, who looked nervous on his return from a knee injury at Everton on Saturday. "After that first game he will be more relaxed," Wenger said, and the restoration of Tony Adams should help.

After their capitulation in the freezing surrounds of Donetsk a fortnight ago, Arsenal would surely have chosen a sunnier destination in which to begin the second phase. This is the last home game Spartak will play until February, having wrapped up their eighth domestic title in nine years this month.

But Wenger stressed that this is a very different situation to the meaningless game at Donetsk. "If I had left the choice to the players for Ukraine I would have travelled alone," he said. "Here that isn't the case. The team wanted to come because there is something at stake."

Even so the Russians' attitude is the colder the better. The temperature is expected to be around -2C (29F), although undersoil heating means the pitch is likely to be wet rather than white. "If the frost strikes, Spartak won't be afraid of it," said their assistant manager Vyacheslav Drosny, "but Arsenal will."

Spartak Moscow (probable, 3-5-2): Filimonov; Tchuisse, Ananko, Bushmanov; Kovtun, Kalinichenko, Titov, Baranov, Bezrodny; Marcao, Robson.

Arsenal (probable, 4-4-2): Manninger; Dixon, Adams, Keown, Silvinho; Ljungberg, Parlour, Vivas, Pires; Kanu/Wiltord, Henry.

fields.headline: Scholes double disguises doubts
fields.standfirst:
Sheringham 48; Scholes 81, 90 | Karagounis 64
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: If Sir Alex Ferguson wanted to make a statement of intent last night, the message was anything but loud and clear. Panathinaikos called Manchester United's bluff here and the English champions can count themselves fortunate not to be playing a game of Champions League catch-up.
fields.body:
If Sir Alex Ferguson wanted to make a statement of intent last night, the message was anything but loud and clear. Panathinaikos called Manchester United's bluff here and the English champions can count themselves fortunate not to be playing a game of Champions League catch-up.

As always, Ferguson's team seem intent on doing things the hard way, opting for the tightrope every time.

This was a subdued, vapid United and with 10 minutes remaining it seemed as though Valencia's defeat of Sturm Graz would see the Spaniards take the early initiative in Group A.

But not for the first time, United found something from within, courtesy of two late goals from Paul Scholes.

Life at Old Trafford is anything but dull.

Having been bewilderingly maladroit in the first phase United had scarcely been able to conceal their sense of exaltation at being drawn against Pana, Valencia and Sturm Graz. To fail now would be seen only as capitulation.

Only their continued good health at Old Trafford had seen them through the first stage. But with Ryan Giggs conspicuous only by his absence, having succumbed to his irritating hamstring problems once again, United were strangely one-paced throughout the opening exchanges.

Indeed they were fortunate to find themselves still on level terms in the 10th minute, when Nikolaos Liberopoulous, the Greek player of the year, was sent scurrying clear by Igor Sypniewski's back-heel. Fabien Barthez was swiftly off his goalline to block with his legs. The Frenchman richly deserved all the subsequent back-slapping, but United's defending had once again been as reliable as a Virgin train.

It was an audacious opening from the Greeks and before the midway point of the first half United had Barthez to thank once again. This time Fernando Galetto threaded an exquisite pass through the centre of United's defence and, even at 36, the Polish striker Krzystof Warzycha still managed to make Wes Brown look sluggish.

It was United's good luck that the third highest all-time scorer in Greece could not concoct a finish worthy of the build-up.

By now the small but raucous gathering of Greek supporters had increasingly good cause to be tempted by thoughts that they might just be capable of bringing United's 35-match unbeaten sequence at Old Trafford to a wholly unsatisfactory close.

United's best moments in a decidedly uncomfortable opening half were few and far between. David Beckham almost embarrassed Antonis Nikopolodis with a shot from 20 yards, as well as crossing for Teddy Sheringham to head just over, but all in all there was precious little else from the best that English football can offer.

Instead, Pana continued to carry an air of potency in attack and the final attack of the half saw Liberopoulos nutmeg Brown only to be denied by Barthez's legs for a second time. The 18-time Greek champions had proved that they were more than just a good Scrabble score. One could almost hear the breaking of chinaware in United's dressing room at half-time.

But two minutes into the second half United went route one and had immediate success. Dwight Yorke got a decisive flick to Barthez's long punt and Sheringham held off the challenge of Ioannis Goumas before rifling in a first-time shot from the edge of the penalty area. It was probably the most important of his 14 goals this season.

The goal invigorated Ferguson's team and settled those players who were showing the first, albeit uncharacteristic, signs of edginess. But just as they were taking command, Pana hit back. Gary Neville gave away a free-kick 30 yards from goal and when the ball was touched into Giorgis Karagounis's path he produced the type of curling effort Beckham might have thought was his copyright.

But write United off at your peril. Mickael Silvestre burst into the penalty area and when his drive was beaten out by the goalkeeper it fell perfectly for Scholes to knock in the rebound.

Scholes added a second in the last minute, when he escaped on the right and struck a sweet chip over the goalkeeper from the edge of the area. A happy end to a trying night.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; P Neville, Brown, G Neville, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Butt; Sheringham, Yorke.

Panathinaikos (4-4-2): Nikopolidis; Henriksen, Goumas, Vokolos, Fyssas; Galetto, Basinas, Karagounis (Vlaovic, 66min), Sypniewski (Olivares, 79); Warzycha (Kiasso, 74), Liberopoulos. Referee: D Messina (Italy).

• You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Italian faces assault charge
fields.trailText: Massimiliano Ferrigno, former captain of the Serie C side Como, will face charges of causing GBH in connection with the alleged punching incident that left an opponent in a coma.
fields.body:
The Italian footballer alleged to have punched an opponent in a post-match incident, resulting in him going into a coma, will appear before a magistrate next Tuesday.

Massimiliano Ferrigno, captain of the Serie C side Como, will face charges of causing grievous bodily harm and not offering help to the injured Francesco Bertolotti, Ferrigno's lawyer Raffaele Della Valle said.

Ferrigno is alleged to have punched Bertolotti, Modena's midfielder, after Como's 1-0 victory on Sunday.

Doctors at Lecco's Sant'Anna hospital said yesterday that the 33-year-old English-born Bertolotti's condition remained very serious but that he had managed to move his limbs slightly.

The Italian Football Federation has suspended Ferrigno indefinitely and Como's president confirmed he would not play for the club again. "His behaviour is indefensible and unpardonable," said Enrico Preziosi.

Anders Limpar, the former Arsenal winger, is the target of fan violence in Stockholm. Fanatical AIK fans wrecked a bar he part-owns, because he recently moved to their city rivals Djurgarden. The fans spat at him, called him a traitor and smashed large windows.

fields.headline: Cafe complete
fields.standfirst: Joy Francis  on the launch of Britain's first Alzheimer's cafe, a meeting place offering far more than tea and sympathy
fields.trailText: Joy Francis on the launch of Britain's first Alzheimer's cafe, a meeting place offering far more than tea and sympathy
fields.body:
In the unlikely setting of St Peter's parish centre in Farnborough, Hampshire, history was made last week when more than 200 people turned out to witness the launch of Britain's first "Alzheimer's cafe". On the same day, a damning report from the commission for health improvement outlined a catalogue of cruelty and degrading treatment of dementia patients at the former Garlands hospital in Cumbria. Patients had been tied to commodes, shouted at, sworn at and deprived of food.

The coincidence of these dramatically contrasting events shows that dementia care remains shockingly inconsistent. A disease of the brain that attacks memory, speech and perception, dementia is a painful reality for 700,000 people in Britain, but is still poorly diagnosed and dealt with.

At first glance, the concept of the Alzheimer's cafe seems remarkably simple. Once a month, people with dementia, their carers, relatives and social care professionals will meet in a cafe environment to socialise, unwind and, possibly, carry out an initial assessment leading to a much-needed service.

Bere Miesen, the Dutch psychiatrist who pioneered the idea, says: "The Alzheimer's cafe is an informal way to make contact with each other, to receive a consultation and feel at home. In the Netherlands, patients feel they have a place to just be. This way the patient and their family don't have to deny or avoid the illness."

When Miesen launched the first cafe in Holland, in 1997, it was housed in a lecture room at Leiden University. The next month, it moved to a hotel. Finally, it arrived at its current resting place - a room in a nursing home in Warmond.

Each month, the trailblazing cafe is attended by between 100 and 150 people, including psychotherapists, nurses, priests and social workers. With assistance from up to 10 volunteers, guests pay two guilders (about 66p) each for refreshments, listen to music and take part in discussions on the disease.

Miesen says the cafe system is more developed in the Netherlands because of a history of robust multi-disciplinary working and more than 30 years of visible work on dementia, which affects an estimated 250,000 people in the country. There are now 10 Alzheimer's cafes in Holland and one in Belgium.

Kandy Redwood, carers' support worker for social services in the Alton and Aldershot area, is determined to alter Miesen's perception of Britain's backwardness. As the driving force behind the new initiative, she first heard about the Dutch scheme from a neuropsychologist last June. "I thought it would be great to pursue," she says. "I asked social services to agree to the idea and they were on board from the very start, sanctioning my visit to Holland to attend a course and meet Miesen."

On her return she made a number of presentations - to the local Alzheimer's Society, health and social services - and received an enthusiastic response. Professionals agreed to devote two hours of their time to the cafe every month.

And no one complained about footing the annual cost of £7,000, split between Rushmoor and Hart primary care group and Hampshire social services department. Most of the money goes towards the cost of hiring the centre, administration and paying care assistants to provide extra support.

The scheme could not have come soon enough for the 200 carers who are supported by Redwood. More than two-thirds of them care for a relative with Alzheimer's disease. The majority are elderly themselves and feel stigmatised by the condition. In some cases, Redwood is the only person they will have seen in two months. "It is very difficult for carers to get time for themselves, recharge their batteries or receive respite support," argues Redwood. "The isolation they experience is sometimes unbearable. People in stage one dementia can drive their carer crazy as they follow them around constantly for reassurance."

Joan James, 67, understands this. She tirelessly cares for her 70-year-old husband, Albert, who has Alzheimer's, and is preparing herself for the day when he no longer remembers her.

Married for 47 years, Joan noticed that something was wrong with her husband nine years ago when they were living in Bethnal Green, east London. "I used to give him his dinner, which he would take upstairs to eat in front of the television," she says. "This time, when I gave him his dinner he turned it over without realising it."

Soon after, Albert found it difficult to put on his tie or button his shirt. A visit to the GP gave the condition a name. But apart from a short trip to a day centre, Joan has largely cared for Albert single-handedly.

When it started to get too much, the couple moved to Farnborough to be near their two sons, who help alleviate some of the burden. Now Joan's health is also under threat. She sleeps only two hours at night and describes herself as "a bag of nerves". Albert, who utters fully formed sentences amid indecipherable ones, says he "doesn't like having dementia".

Joan and Albert have already experienced the benefits of attending the Alzheimer's cafe, during two test runs held earlier this year. Albert reports: "I like it." His wife says: "When I come here, I feel more relaxed. I don't have to worry about him for two hours."

The cafe can already boast successful cases from the earlier trials. In one instance, the behaviour of an elderly man who attended a day centre run by social services was proving difficult for the staff. It was clear he needed to be assessed. He was brought to the first cafe trial by his family. Also there were the health consultant, manager of the mental health day service and Ed Thompson, service manager responsible for commissioning services for older people.

Thompson explains: "I was able to network and, within 24 hours, we got him into a health service for an assessment. That would normally have taken us a week to do."

In another case, a distressed woman caring for her husband was at the end of her tether, despite having day care support once a week. On the basis of one visit to the cafe, the consultant psychiatrist and service manager worked out an extra day's support for her within 20 minutes.

With an enthusiastic endorsement from Harry Cayton, chief executive of the Alzheimer's Society, the Hampshire-based cafe is already being promoted as a beacon of good practice. With the government expected within the next month to announce a national service framework for older people, the initiative could find itself a focus of attention.

webTitle: Plans to prevent bed shortages in the NHS this winter could be undermined

fields.headline: Block busters
fields.standfirst: Plans to prevent bed shortages in the NHS this winter could be undermined by the lack of residential and nursing home places.  John Cunningham  reports
fields.trailText: Plans to prevent bed shortages in the NHS this winter could be undermined by the lack of residential and nursing home places. John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
Chippenham in Wiltshire has a model community hospital. There are minor injuries and maternity units; beds for elderly mentally ill patients and for hospice care; beds for patients of local GPs and beds for consultants' referrals. Come spring, there will be a new unit for stroke victims.

The hospital fits the town's re-found prosperity. With a big Dutch gable over its archway entrance, it seems more like a private housing scheme and you certainly wouldn't recognise it as the former local workhouse. Clinical and nursing care are generally held to be excellent.

There is, though, a downside: through no fault of the hospital, at least a quarter of its patients are stuck in a benign servitude, more like Victorian times than the present. These are elderly men and women who, though assessed as medically fit for discharge, could not manage on their own and so await transfer to nursing or residential homes. In the ugly jargon, they are "bed-blockers".

Wiltshire social services does not have funds to satisfy the demand for residential places. For months, the trapped patients lie or sit or shuffle in hospital wards; talking, fretting or dreaming of release. The beds they needlessly occupy cost the NHS £166 a day; yet for less than a third of that - about £350 a week - they could be in residential care.

This bottleneck delays admissions in Chippenham and causes ripples in hospitals in other small towns and in Bath. And it is by no means unique: in similar hot spots across the country, the government's best laid plans for keeping the NHS show on the road this winter are threatened by a shortage of social services funding for residential and nursing home care.

Anne Keat, a sister at the Chippenham hospital, is "desperately concerned". She says: "Several patients have been waiting since early summer. Hospitals have no entertainment; there's nothing for them to do. We're having patients who die before they get to a nursing home. We've had several in the last few months."

Nick Whyatt, head of a local, seven-partner GP practice, has a patient who's been waiting since January for a move from hospital to nursing home. Whyatt describes the knock-on effect of bed-blocking. "Two weeks ago, a deeply unconscious old lady was found by a neighbour," he says. "Normally, I'd admit her to a GP bed. Our beds were blocked; she wasn't really fit for a long ambulance journey but we had to send her 13 miles to St Martin's [Bath]. She took their last bed, so their next patient would have to go to the Royal United [also in Bath], where one of their acute medical beds would have to be used for the next elderly patient."

Patient flow has been "buggered up" by lack of social services funding for nursing and residential homes, says Whyatt, who stresses that he sympathises with social workers' dilemma. Wiltshire social services, he asserts, has a policy of only paying for one new client when two clients come off its books.

According to Keat's estimate, 36 out of 89 beds in Chippenham were blocked earlier this month. The position fluctuates, but she and Whyatt fear what will happen as winter takes its toll.

A graver picture of the whole county - 119 bed-blockers in early November - comes from Dick Barton, who chairs Wiltshire Registered Care Homes. And his figure, he maintains, does not include those waiting for medical assessments.

What is alarming in Wiltshire is that, for all the planning and cooperation between health and social services, and for all the government's extra NHS funds, the next four months are going to be tricky. Just how tricky is open to interpretation.

Jeremy Hallett, chief executive of Wiltshire health authority, says there are problems, but, thanks to extra funding and several new initiatives, "this winter we'll be in a better position than in previous winters".

But Phil Day, a general manager of Wiltshire health care trust, insists: "The situation is worse than it was at last winter's peak, and unless social services can find the funding, it will get worse."

There are different takes on what causes it too. The first reason Hallett mentions for bed-blocking is that patients, or their relatives, do not accept the first offer of a residential place if it is too far away. Funding shortages he ranks second.

And Ray Jones, Wiltshire's director of social services, says the waiting time for such a place is "up to about three months". If any elderly person has had to wait in hospital since the beginning of the year, he maintains, it is not because of financial limitations: social workers cleared the backlog at the start of the financial year in April.

Many of the complexities of the circumstances in Chippenham have necessarily been condensed. It is not quite accurate to describe the social service policy as "two out, one in", as Whyatt does. Jones prefers this description: when any money is freed up, 50% goes to offset the department's deficit, and 50% is available for spending.

What is undisputed is that all professionals are advancing the best case - as they see it - to ameliorate the difficulties. Chippenham, with its hospital serving a town of 32,000 and a rural catchment of 70,000, is a microcosm of the much vaunted, albeit patchy, moves to integrate systems of social and health care.

The theory is fine: step up domiciliary support, and more of the elderly will not need long stays in hospital, or in care homes. A rapid response rehabilitation team covering Chippenham and two small market towns nearby, was set up two years ago and is being expanded this winter. Extra support staff are being trained to work in physiotherapy and occupational therapy, under the supervision of qualified professionals. Where there is a need for night sitters, to relieve carers, volunteers trained by Help the Aged will be brought in.

All of this is on the horizon. For some, however, it will come too late. Every day, Fred Barrett, a 74-year-old former farm worker, visits his wife, Violet, 85, in the Chippenham hospital.

"She can't walk about; she can't do nothing," says a stoical Barrett, as he waits by the phone for news that a place has been found for his wife in a local nursing home. He's been waiting now for six months.

Electoral risk of catching a cold

Unprecedented steps are being taken to try to stave off an NHS winter crisis. The danger for the government is that trouble in the hospitals could jeopardise victory in a spring general election.

The Department of Health says it is spending an extra £630m in anticipation of winter pressures, including £150m on critical care. An extra 343 critical care beds should be open in England. In addition, £63m is being invested in "step down" or "intermediate" care for patients ready to leave hospital but unable yet to cope at home. Some £12m of this has gone on additional staff.

For the first time, flu immunisation has been available free to all people over age 65. Local winter planning groups have been set up across the country and their plans have been vetted by the department. Central monitoring arrangements are in place, with advice teams of health and social care professionals ready to swoop on trouble spots.

webTitle: New survey reveals  positive legacy of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry

fields.headline: Forward march
fields.standfirst: Britain still has a long way to go in eradicating racial harassment, but a new survey reveals a positive legacy of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.  Raekha Prasad reports
fields.trailText: Britain still has a long way to go in eradicating racial harassment, but a new survey reveals a positive legacy of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. Raekha Prasad reports
fields.body:
If he were still alive, Stephen Lawrence would be 26. In the eight years since his death, the botched murder investigation by the Metropolitan police and the bungled prosecution of the white men accused of his killing have created the potential for a sea change in British race relations.

The investigation into neglect of duty by the police led to Sir William Macpherson, who chaired the inquiry, adopting the language of Stokely Carmichael, an American black activist, in concluding that institutional racism was to blame. The report defined institutional racism as "the collective failure of an organisation to provide an appropriate and professional service to people because of their colour, culture, or ethnic origin".

Since then, the government has put anti-racism on the mainstream agenda. Institutions from the Royal College of Nursing to the Home Office itself have rushed to declare themselves institutionally racist. But how much has this shift in understanding affected the experience of black and Asian people?

In the most thorough investigation of racial harassment in Britain, a survey funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation has found that reporting of incidents has significantly increased since Macpherson's report. His acknowledgment that racism affects all aspects of black and Asian people's lives appears to have laid the foundations for them to come forward with more confidence that they will be taken seriously. In addition, the findings suggest, the police are more likely to record any racial motivation than they were previously.

Despite Macpherson's assertion, the survey report, Racial Harassment: Action on the Ground, acknowledges that black and minority ethnic people are not all equally likely to be racially attacked. It cites statistics from the 1995 British crime survey, which found that 4% of black people, 5% of Indians and 8% of Pakistanis and Bangladeshis experienced one or more racist crimes, compared to 0.5% of white people.

The Rowntree survey, conducted by researchers Lemos & Crane, found that racist attacks tend to occur more frequently in crime "hot spots" such as particular housing estates and poorer multi-racial neighbourhoods.

Lemos & Crane interviewed more than 250 contacts in the police, local authority community safety and housing departments, housing associations, specialist and voluntary agencies in the 67 local authority areas in the UK identified by the 1991 census as having the highest numbers of black and minority ethnic residents.

Examining levels of harassment, which range from murder in the most extreme cases to attacks on individuals and property and racist abuse, the survey found that the number of incidents reported varies hugely between areas, with 10 London boroughs, Birmingham, Leicester and Glasgow each reporting more than 1,000 separate incidents in 1999-2000. However, most agencies said under-reporting was still a problem, with incidents often not receiving the appropriate response because the racial motive was not taken into account.

So although the message has gone out to black and ethnic minority people that they no longer have to put up with racial harassment, the survey found that the mechanisms to record, and respond to, their experiences are often far from established.

Fewer than a third of the areas studied had a 24-hour helpline for victims and fewer than 40% provided in-depth counselling. Although more than half the areas had third-party reporting centres - including places of worship, doctors' surgeries and schools - which pass information on to relevant agencies, many staff were not trained in report taking.

Most councils provide alarms, stronger locks, doors, fencing and improved lighting for tenants experi encing harassment, the survey suggests. But less than half the councils and housing associations had rehoused families because of racial incidents, arguing that it allowed perpetrators to drive tenants from "white" estates. Other councils considered the victim's security to be paramount and rehoused families if they requested it. In Ipswich, one of the areas singled out by the survey for its good practice, council tenants are rehoused at the expense of the council if they ask to be moved.

Meanwhile, Waltham Forest, in east London, has set-up Alert, a special agency to run a 24-hour emergency line as well as compile a monitoring database, provide counselling and a specialist lawyer for victims.

Gerard Lemos, author of the study, says that "lack of clarity, rather than lack of commitment" is behind much of the frustration that agencies described to researchers. He is calling for a national strategy to deal with racial harassment.

This would include a national helpline where victims could seek immediate advice and support and then direct callers to local agencies. In addition, the researchers propose to standardise training and competence for police, landlords and other agencies dealing with victims of racial harassment.

But Lemos & Crane's most radical proposal is perhaps a national programme, possibly led by probation services, to change the offending behaviour of racist perpetrators.

Action against perpetrators is still rare, the survey shows. Only 10-15% of reported incidents had resulted in criminal action and only a small proportion of councils had taken out injunctions or eviction orders against perpetrating tenants.

The report cites Thames Valley police's use of restorative justice in racial harassment cases as something the rest of the country could follow. The method is most suitable for cases involving neighbours. A trained officer chairs a meeting between the perpetrator and their victim, who confronts the offender with the impact of the harassment with the intention of making him or her accountable to the victim.

Lemos says: "I'm not against enforcement and am not proposing this is appropriate for the most serious racially motivated crimes, but the current agenda is entirely about locking people up. We need to be thinking about positive ways to change the offending behaviour."

Leeds leads the prejudice-busters
Martin Wainwright

It may be muttering at work; it may be a brick through a window; it may be nastiness in the secret, don't-grass-to-teacher world of the classroom. Whichever, the likelihood in Leeds is that racial harassment, in all its crude and subtle forms, will eventually end on the desk of Shakeel Meer and his team of local prejudice-busters.

Singled out in today's Joseph Rowntree Foundation report as an example of best practice, Leeds Racial Harrassment Project was born six years ago out of frustration at repeated persecutors evading justice.It now runs courses for companies, the police and professionals, including lawyers.

"The Stephen Lawrence inquiry probably marked the greatest step forward in our work," says Meer, whose appointment as director three months ago marked another stage in the project's growth. "Institutions like the police came forward and held up their hands and said: 'Yes, we do have a problem.' Acknowledging that is more than half the battle."

Leeds has a typically British record of kindness and coldness in racial affairs. Its university nurtured the Nigerian Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka, but some of its landladies shut their doors in his face. Kindness usually wins; Soyinka acknowledged that when he came back two years ago to premiere his new play, the Beatification of Area Boy, at the city's West Yorkshire Playhouse. But the unpleasant undercurrent is still there.

Hence, Meer and his team's busy schedule advising families who have been targeted by racist neighbours, loaning closed circuit TV (the source of several succesful prosecutions) or installing alarms. Project staff act as advocates for individuals who have decided to fight back, and they have a reputation for novel ways of getting the message across - such as Grass, a playlet written and produced by the local Blah Blah Blah theatre company. A youth officer, financed by Comic Relief, edits a sparky newspaper for kids, with a video-making sideline, and Meer says: "Getting the message across to young people is having a striking effect."

If racism isn't cool, it's also kept on the run in Leeds by the project's independence, thanks to a catholic range of funders, including the Home Office and the national lottery charities board. As a fledgling, the project was under the wing of Leeds city council - a blessing but also a threat in the longer term. "Genuine independence is essential," says Meer, "because then there's no danger of us holding back if the council or any of its agencies figure in a case."

Success has not brought complacency in Leeds; as word spreads of the project's effectiveness, so more people come to use its services. Shakeel and his colleagues are not going to twiddle their thumbs after a year which has already seen 31 personal alarms installed in frightened homes and 28 other tenants referred for rehousing because of local spite.

"And we now have the challenge of asylum seekers," says Shakeel. "Leeds has done well to take so many in, but there are lots of problems on the ground. It hasn't been at all obvious to the victims where to find help if they're harassed. We're letting them know that we're here."

 Racial Harassment: Action on the Ground is available at £9.95 plus £1.50 p&p from 01752-202301. A summary of findings is at www.jrf.org.uk

fields.headline: Marketing round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 23.
fields.trailText: November 23: Vodafone has hired senior Coca-Cola executive David Haines as its first global brand chief.
fields.body:
Vodafone Group has hired senior Coca-Cola executive David Haines as its first global brand chief.

Holsten is launching a nationwide promotional campaign in its first sustained bid to leverage its sponsorship of Premier League football club Tottenham Hotspur.

ITV has radically changed the job specifications for its new chief executive and is thought to be targeting chief executives of FTSE 100 companies as potential candidates.

Lord Hollick's United Business Media is thought to be using proposals to raise Channel 5's programming budget as a bargaining chip as its seeks to raise the price of its 35% stake in the broadcaster.

AXA, the title sponsor of the FA Cup, has signed a two year deal to sponsor talkSPORT's radio coverage of the competition.

Coca-Cola has appointed Mother to create its first local work for Dr Pepper outside the US.

ICI Paints has hired senior Unilever marketer Dr Kerris Bright to take the top marketing job on its Dulux paint brand.

Gordon's Gin is launching a new campaign featuring well-known personalities doing something they are famous for and failing miserably. Cricketer David Gower and rower Matthew Pinsent are among them.

Eurostar has hired TBWA for its £15m European advertising account.

Beating Bowel Cancer, the charity set up by former Watchdog presenter Lynn Faulds Wood, is launching a major awareness drive and is seeking sponsors to pay for an irreverent new ad campaign.

MG Rover has handed its e-commerce and relationship marketing accounts to M&C Saatchi.

Land Rover has hired its first dedicated web marketing chief. Nina Larsen becomes global e-marketing manager as the company looks to boost its world-wide online activity.

fields.headline: Filling the gaps
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham visits a council already working on the vision provided by the government's urban white paper
fields.trailText: John Cunningham visits a council already working on the vision provided by the government's urban white paper
fields.body:
As towns and cities grow, they pick up untidy habits: wedges of land left unused alongside railway tracks; empty living quarters above long parades of shops; allotments abandoned now that supermarkets have become giant greengrocers. Last week's white paper on urban regeneration promises to shower councils with powers and initiatives to transform these wastelands into habitable areas. But once the glow generated by John Prescott's announcement has faded, it will be a painstaking, piecemeal business to change the gritty face of urban communities.

Enfield, tucked under the northern rim of the M25, is a London borough that has anticipated some of deputy prime minister Prescott's proposals - and begun to act on them. Though far from the inner-city chaos of the capital, it has its problems. It has sized up one of them - the homeless - and come up with a solution that, in theory, should be a perfect fit.

Enfield has 2,000 homeless families, the fifth highest total of any London authority. It has surveyed every bit of waste land in the area and listed about 100 sites - 40 acres in total - on which exactly 2,000 dwellings will be built in what is billed as the biggest "infill" housing programme in the country.

Families already in poor council houses will be moved into these new dwellings; their homes, in turn, will be offered to those managing in temporary accommodation. It's the familiar notion of houses as hand-me-downs: the new dwellings going to those who have been council tenants longest; the oldest, which they vacate, being allocated to the late-comers. That's the way the architectural fabric of any town or city is used.

One part of the borough, Edmonton, where many small sites have been identified for new homes, shows the mix and muddle we live with. There are terraces of small Victorian villas following the expansion of the railways; endless council estates (even though Enfield has sold 10,000 properties, it still has 13,000 to rent); and a vast, blowy shopping precinct squatting right in the middle. It is already dated - now we build malls - but it has the virtue of being central, includes a huge fruit and veg section and is a hub of activity.

It would be foolish to suggest - and Enfield does not - that the housing problem will be eradicated by spending £150m over five years, most in grants from the housing corporation. After all, new names will be added to the homeless register; there will be difficulties with some sites; and costs will spiral.

But that does not mean that progress cannot be made in utilising a surprising amount of sterile space.

The first scheme involves pulling down 60 garages on an estate in Edmonton. Too many were provided for residents' needs when nearby flats were built in the 60s. The garages have long been empty and vandalised and will next year be replaced by six three-bedroom homes.

Of the total £500,000 required to finance the project, some £295,000 will come from the housing corporation, with the Christian Action Housing Association - a partner the borough plans to involve in several other developments - raising the rest.

Neil Aves, Enfield council's lead member for housing, says the abandoned garages head a long list of recyclable sites. "On some estates, there are vast open tracts; windswept, barren areas which no one uses. Then there are car parks, used for dumping cars and setting fire to them; there are communal drying areas which residents don't use because their washing is stolen; and there are 'remote gardens' - too far away from flats to be used by residents."

The biggest windfall is a disused access road - 350 metres (1,150ft) long and 11 metres (36ft) wide, and 32 houses will be built on it. "We call it the micro-lite runway," says Steve Wright, the borough's head of housing management.

The stockpile of sorry sites, Wright points out, has accrued from the mistakes and changes in direction of architects, planners and the commercial sector. He says: "The vast acres of grass provided for estates in the 60s have become dangerous places, with no sense of ownership." Those distant gardens were a planning vogue in the 50s. At the other end of the scale, there are pram sheds and store sheds which are lying empty.

The matter of under-used premises - shop owners who no longer need to live above their businesses - has being going on for decades, unnoticed as the shopkeepers individually prospered, but representing a considerable cache of potential flats (at least 215). They have the advantage of being situated on the long, secondary shopping streets which run through Enfield, and many are on bus routes.

It will take at least five years for the patchwork of sites to be transformed. Aves speaks of a revolutionary initiative, which local people, the federation of Enfield's community associations and council staff are all passionate about. And with housing corporation backing, they feel they are on the right track. "There can be nothing better than turning derelict garages into new homes," he says.

They feel they are doing a lot more than just removing a few blotches on the face of the borough. Enfield may never become the most handsome of places, but it is determined to make the most of its assets.

fields.headline: Hackney council is improving
fields.standfirst: Hackney's fall from grace followed the election of a hung council. Only now Labour and the Tories are working together is progress taking place, writes Labour group leader Jules Pipe
fields.trailText: Comment: Hackney's fall from grace followed the election of a hung council. Only now Labour and the Tories are working together is progress taking place, writes Labour group leader Jules Pipe
fields.body:
Before Hackney became a hung council in 1996, the Labour-run authority attracted £1bn of outside investment for its regeneration strategy - a nationally acclaimed programme that has seen more than a dozen tower blocks demolished and replaced with thousands of high-quality homes.

It was Hackney's apparent failure to replicate that success in the provision of day-to-day services that often propelled it into the news in the mid-90s. Already perceived as mediocre, things were about to get worse for Hackney.

"Financial meltdown", unsustainable pay structures and the catastrophic failure of services have not just happened over the last month. The seeds were sown in 1997, when an anti-Labour coalition of the smaller parties led by the Liberal Democrats voted for "transforming Hackney", a management change that devolved the authority to spend money to departments - without putting in adequate central controls and monitoring.

So if today's headlines are really the story of the past four years, what is happening now?

At the Labour group's suggestion, the Local Government Association's Improvement and Development Agency (IDeA) visited in November. They found an unresponsive monster of local government, and rightly put much of the blame on a lack of political leadership, resulting from no overall control. They said the council would have to create a consistent majority for both a set of policies and a budget if it was even to fill the year-long vacancy for managing director, let alone turn the council around.

As a result of the IDeA report, the main parties came together to discuss a way forward and produced both policies and a budget that all could sign up to. Such an achievement should not be underestimated. "Coalitions" are much derided by the press and public as "unholy alliances" and viewed with suspicion. Yet maintaining a non-cooperation policy regularly attracts media headlines such as "battling councillors continue party in-fighting." Within weeks the Liberal Democrats fell by the wayside.

Until recently, the Labour and Conservative groups in Hackney had little in common except a shared interest in regenerating the borough and a healthy dislike for each other's national politics. These huge political differences will always exist, but have been put to one side since April, in order to tackle the legacy of the last four years.

As a result, we have appointed an outstanding managing director, seconded senior officers from successful authorities, and have received invaluable help from the IDeA. It is through their hard work, in a politically stable climate, that the true state of the finances has been revealed.

The council has gaping holes in its finances because it spends far more on providing poorer levels of service than other boroughs, not because of a lack of central government support. It is not the role of government to bail the authority out and reward failure - Hackney must put its own house in order to stop the whole rotten cycle beginning again. It is down to councillors to make decisions that will improve our council's parlous finances

The new climate in Hackney has also seen the appointment of extremely able officers, including an education director who will build on the significant improvements that have been made in the department. These achievements were sadly overshadowed by Ofsted's comments last week that dwelt upon the past failings of the corporate centre of the council.

If there is a lesson to be learnt from Hackney, it is that weak local government fails both the people it is there to serve and evades being held to account for that failure. The government's plans for modernising local government have a remedy for authorities whose councillors fail to deliver political leadership - a directly elected mayor who can be held accountable by the public.

If Hackney remains a hung council, and people find opposing parties working together for the common good not to their taste, it may be time for the borough to consider that option.

webTitle: Racial equality skills are needed in all jobs

fields.headline: Racial equality skills are needed in all jobs
fields.standfirst: Staff should be trained in the competencies needed to achieve racial equality as awareness training is not enough, says Sir Herman Ouseley
fields.trailText: Staff should be trained in the competencies needed to achieve racial equality as awareness training is not enough, says Sir Herman Ouseley
fields.body:
For over two decades, the issue of racial harassment has been identified by local and national agencies as a priority for action through relevant policy and practices. The police, local authorities, housing associations, community organisations and action groups have all focused on action to help victims of harassment and racially motivated attacks. In many parts of the country, they have joined forces in multi-agency arrangements to tackle these problems more effectively.

Yet today, in spite of much progress, including the use of legislation to prosecute perpetrators and evict tenants in breach of housing conditions, it is suggested that Britain is in urgent need of a "race support line" to tackle racist attacks and combat racial harassment.

The call for a national helpline is made in a new report from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, following a survey of over 250 agencies in 67 districts of England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. The researchers concentrated their study in those areas where the majority of black and minority ethnic people in the UK live.

It is not all bad news because the report highlights over 20 examples of innovative practice, which, along with other examples of good practice, will be publicised early next year on a government-funded web site.

Some of the good practices identified include school and community awareness campaigns against race and hate crimes; the use of cable TV to encourage victims to come forward; local "one-stop shops" and hotlines for reporting incidents; a planned refuge for victims; witness support schemes; police and probation schemes to change the behaviour of perpetrators; and a restorative justice project making perpetrators more accountable for their victims.

None of the agencies, particularly local authorities and the police, can claim to be unaware of the issues or indeed the action needed to counter this form of social terrorism. Yet, they continue, in the main, to be ambivalent in their total commitment to eradicate this scourge from our society. Although the authors of the report state that it is more a lack of clarity, coherence, and purpose among the social agencies which undermines their good intentions and strongly expressed commitments, there must remain huge question marks about why this is the case.

Complacency is one of the main contributory factors for the present situation. Many local authorities do not see anti-racism policy as a mainstream core activity. They put their representatives onto multi-agency panels from their education, social services and housing departments and leave it to them. Racism is often forgotten except when high profile cases emerge. The police and local authorities often leave it to community organisations and local activists to agitate on behalf of the victims of racial attacks and harassment.

Most significantly, the regulatory bodies, such as the Audit Commission, OFSTED and Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary, have failed to monitor the standards and performance of the statutory agencies in dealing effectively with racial harassment and violence within a framework in which good practice features as part of codes of conduct.

Overarching bodies, such as the Local Government Association, have not taken responsibility for giving guidance to member authorities on the policies and practices to be pursued. Overall, the Home Office and the Department for Environment, Transport & the Regions have not combined their efforts to ensure coherent action locally and regionally. Unless the key national agencies and government bodies act together anti-racism policy will be bedevilled by ambivalence and complacency.

At the local level, the report suggests that under-reporting is still a major problem. Many victims do not complain because they do not believe the problems will be resolved and have little or no confidence in the key agencies. They also live with the fear of further victimisation.

Under-reporting will persist, unless all local agencies can market their services with better publicity and are able to convince victims that they will be fully protected when they complain and alert perpetrators continually that they will always be challenged and dealt with through formal procedures.

Perhaps the most significant recommendation is to introduce national standards of training and competence for police, landlords and the other main agencies involved in the handling of racial harassment cases. The police are developing a competency-based framework which will take time to implement. For all staff involved in public services in multi-cultural Britain today, it must be an essential requirement to be competent in handling equality, equity, diversity and fair treatment issues as part of their jobs. The quicker this becomes a key competence for all staff in all public services, the more likely we are to see race-related training being made relevant with fit-for-purpose, competency-based training on offer instead of discredited race-awareness training programmes.

Finally, a key recommendation is made for a national programme of work - possibly led by probation services - to educate and change the offending behaviour of racist perpetrators. While that is welcome, the examples of good behaviour and acceptable conduct must emanate from people's homes and be promoted vigorously, through education in our schools and other places of learning.

fields.headline: From Beaverbrook to Asian Babes
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: From left-wing daily to Asian Babes stablemate, the Express's sale to Northern & Shell has made history, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Northern & Shell's purchase of the Express has made history on two counts - not only is it the first time a national newspaper has been owned by a magazine, but it's the first time that one has been owned by a group founded on pornography.

The ascendancy of OK! publisher Northern & Shell into the major league of newspaper ownership highlights the growing influence of magazine and showbiz culture in newspapers.

The Express's chequered history has taken it a long way from the right-wing empire created by Lord Beaverbrook, the archetypal press baron said to be so ruthless that Fleet Street was strewn with the bodies of his editors.

The merger in 1996 of Lord Hollick's MAI media empire with Lord Stevens's United News happened in the days when the phrase "socialism businessman" was considered an oxymoron.

Eyebrows were raised at the time as to whether Express's acting editor, Richard Addis, formerly of the Daily Mail, could run Britain's only left-wing tabloid.

Importing Rosie Boycott from the Independent was Lord Hollick's bid to create a tabloid for a new core readership of New Labour readers, an aim that was partially successful in finding a new editorial niche.

But under Ms Boycott's leadership this never translated into the sales that the company so desperately needed. This year's ABCs saw the Daily Express losing 47,000 in circulation and the Sunday title down 140,000.

Now the Express becomes part of the Northern & Shell publishing empire.

Northern & Shell got into trouble earlier this week when the Press Complaints Commission upheld complaints against OK! magazine, after it printed photos of Prince William taken on his gap year in South America.

Sources at the PCC noted that this year it has ruled on more privacy or press ethics complaints made about magazines than newspapers.

fields.headline: Is Tarrant's time up?
fields.standfirst: He may have found his first millionaire this week, but adventurous Aries will soon be urging the show's host, Chris Tarrant, to seek pastures new.
fields.trailText: November 22: He may have found his first millionaire, but adventurous Aries will soon be urging host Chris Tarrant to seek pastures new, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
With its first millionaire winner, where does ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? go now? Its horoscope (first broadcast 8pm, September 4 1998) shows a quizzical, encyclopaedic Virgo with a mass appeal that comes from generous Jupiter rising in sympathetic Pisces.

This is a classic good-luck placing, reflecting the dream prizes that are worth playing for and the show's ethos of a benevolent universe in which no one is a loser and no one looks a complete idiot.

Judith Keppel's million-pound win on November 20 times to Saturn's transit by square of the horoscope's Venus in regal Leo, a classy, well-connected lady, but there is a darker symbolic undercurrent at work.

ITV bosses are said to be furious at accusations that the questions were slanted to allow the show to deliver a knock-out blow against the much-trailed final episode of BBC1's One Foot in the Grave, and it's not surprising to find such suggestions, given the movement of shady Pluto square to the show's Sun last week.

Pluto is lord of the underworld, ruler of the dead, signifier of the unconscious and the hidden, and the striking Sun-Pluto symbolism now is an Ariadne thread, drawing together apparently unrelated elements. What does it reveal?

The show was recorded the night before, on SUNday, and the story leaked to the Sun. This ensured maximum impact for its 9pm slot against One Foot in the Grave (Pluto), showing Victor Meldrew's demise (Pluto). Now look at the million-pound question: "Which king was married to Eleanor of Aquitaine?"

As an earl's grand-daughter herself and a relative of Camilla Parker Bowles, it was somewhat fortuitous that Judith Keppel should be asked a question about the consort of an English king (Sun). Ms Keppel revealed that, by chance, she had visited Eleanor's tomb (Pluto) this summer, so the image of the grave lay at the heart of the final question.

It is also the million-pound moment which the show's presenter, Chris Tarrant, has been waiting for.

With all the charm of a benign, attentive Libran, Tarrant was born on a Full Moon in pioneering Aries, with a dose of ironic Scorpio and pukka Saturnian timing (7.20pm, October 10 1946, Reading).

His horoscope shows that this is the benchmark moment he needs to allow him to move on, and it looks as if his time on the programme is up.

Whatever millions ITV might offer to keep him, Neptune crossing his career point at the start of next year heralds a longing to escape, and by March, if contracts allow, his impatient and adventurous Aries will be urging him to move on. The show could then enter a Plutonic half-life, a karmic kick-back for seeing off One Foot in the Grave.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

Judith Keppel's million-pound win on November 20 times to Saturn's transit by square of the horoscope's Venus in regal Leo, a classy, well-connected lady, but there is a darker symbolic undercurrent at work. ITV bosses are said to be furious at accusations that the questions were slanted to allow the show to deliver a knock-out blow against the much-trailed final episode of BBC1's One Foot in the Grave, and it's not surprising to find such suggestions, given the movement of shady Pluto square to the show's Sun last week. Pluto is lord of the underworld, ruler of the dead, signifier of the unconscious and the hidden, and the striking Sun-Pluto symbolism now is an Ariadne thread, drawing together apparently unrelated elements. What does it reveal? The show was recorded the night before, on SUNday, and the story leaked to the Sun. This ensured maximum impact for its 9pm slot against One Foot in the Grave (Pluto), showing Victor Meldrew's demise (Pluto). Now look at the million-pound question: "Which king was married to Eleanor of Aquitaine?" As an earl's grand-daughter herself and a relative of Camilla Parker Bowles, it was somewhat fortuitous that Judith Keppel should be asked a question about the consort of an English king (Sun). Ms Keppel revealed that, by chance, she had visited Eleanor's tomb (Pluto) this summer, so the image of the grave lay at the heart of the final question. It is also the million-pound moment which the show's presenter, Chris Tarrant, has been waiting for. With all the charm of a benign, attentive Libran, Tarrant was born on a Full Moon in pioneering Aries, with a dose of ironic Scorpio and pukka Saturnian timing (7.20pm, October 10 1946, Reading). His horoscope shows that this is the benchmark moment he needs to allow him to move on, and it looks as if his time on the programme is up. Whatever millions ITV might offer to keep him, Neptune crossing his career point at the start of next year heralds a longing to escape, and by March, if contracts allow, his impatient and adventurous Aries will be urging him to move on. The show could then enter a Plutonic half-life, a karmic kick-back for seeing off One Foot in the Grave. Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Onedotzero: first among equals
fields.standfirst:
From humble beginnings at London's ICA, onedotzero has become one of the world's best digital film festivals. As a retrospective of the event's best work begins in London, Sean Dodson explains what it's all about, and offers his guide to the highlights.

fields.trailText: From humble beginnings at London's ICA, onedotzero has become one of the world's best digital film festivals. As a retrospective of the best work begins in London, Sean Dodson explains what it's all about and offers his guide to the highlights.
fields.body:
Since hosting its first event at London's Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) back in 1996, onedotzero has become something of a global phenomenon. Over the past five years this touring digital film festival has successfully promoted the best of UK film and design in 25 cities worldwide. The festival has travelled from Taipei to Barcelona, Stockholm to Melbourne, and although much of the work on display originates from the US and Japan, it is UK digital creativity that lies at the festival's heart. Having began life on the avant garde fringe, onedotzero now finds itself with a government endorsement: last week's Berlin-based event was sponsored not by Nike or Orange, but by the British Council.

The place where digital film and new media collide, onedotzero is the event where the once disparate disciplines of computer games, experimental film, pop promos and website design meet and converge. Thanks to new technologies, definitions of what constitutes film are under an intense process of reappraisal. This past year has already seen the likes of Mike Figgis, Ken Russell and George Lucas experiment with new forms of digital film, and do away with the mass majority of their crew in the process.

In today's upside-down climate, many computer games have a budget bigger than the films we see at the cinema. The best, most exciting animation is no longer the sole property of Disney or Warner Bros. New media design agencies producing animation for a wide variety of corporate clients are instead competing for that distinction. It is all this, and more, that onedotzero is recontextualising, and displaying on a cinema screen as part of the festival exhibit.

Former film critic Matt Hanson and Shane Walter, a sometime theatre producer, founded onedotzero in 1996. Realising that the emerging digital medium was receiving minimum coverage in the UK, the pair approached the ICA with their idea: a short programme celebrating the various strands of digital moving image.

"Digital moving image has totally revolutionised our entertainment landscape, explains Hanson. "When we started, there weren't many people working in a cross media sense. I think we were quite lucky and in a unique situation because we were in the UK and that was really happening at the time. And I still think that the UK rocks."

True, digital film is a catchall term that can include conventional films shot by digital means. But don't expect to see many Dogma-influenced movies at the onedotzero events.

Instead, the festival serves up a freeform exploration of digital moving image that moves seamlessly between computer graphics, avant garde shorts, flash animation and cutting-edge 'time-based' design (ie moving images).

Admittedly much of the work on show falls between two spools. But what is not in doubt is that the festival has already proved a breeding ground for digital film-makers. Previous onedotzero entrants include Jonathan Glazer whose first feature, Sexy Beast, was premiered last week at the London Film Festival to critical and popular acclaim, and music video and commercial director Chris Cunningham, whose work is currently on show at the Apocalypse exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London. Cunningham is now poised to follow in Glazer's footsteps - making his directorial debut with an adaptation of William Gibson's cyberpunk novel Neuromancer.

onedotzero can also claim the distinction of being the first people in the UK to showcase Spike (Being John Malkovich) Jonze's work - when he was a fledgling music video maker.

Although the work on display is not yet available online (the UK's narrow bandwith restrictions proving thus far too much of a deterrant), onedotzero is a festival for the internet generation, and speaks to the legions who now work in the world's fastest growing industry. The availability of cheap desktop-editing software has empowered a generation of film-makers, designers, architects and programmers to cross disciplines and produce innovative and exciting work.

Between November 24 and 20, the festival holds its first ever retrospective at the ICA. onedotzero_reprise is - as the name suggests - a revisiting of the best events held at the ICA and Lux Gallery earlier this year. For those of you who haven't made it to any previous festivals, or perhaps have considered the concept of a digital film festival uninspiring or the premise of geeks only, this is the opportunity to ditch your prejudices and explore what's on offer. Particular highlights include J-star, a collection of Japanese work rarely seen in the west, as well as Julian Hanshaw's warped Church of the High Weirdness, and the acclaimed US animated short, Roadhead.

Finally, maybe there is something else afoot at ondotzero. Something reminiscent of the brief period in the 1970s when visual art and performance produced a marriage of avant garde movies that eventually led to the new discipline of video art. It's still early days, even for a festival that is nearly five years old, but if the old distinctions between film and design and computer graphics continue to blur, then maybe people will look back one day and say that onedotzero was really where it was really at.

Highlights

Jonathan Glazer: From Radiohead to Sexy Beast (Saturday November 25)
Acclaimed pop promo director Jonathan Glazer has just released his first feature, Sexy Beast, due for release early next year. Here he discusses his work with clips of the movie (though sadly not the whole thing) as well as his award winning music videos for Radiohead and UNKLE.

Extended Play (Saturday, Sunday November 25 & 26)
A collection of short films and mini-movies. Includes Richard Kenworthy's Littlest Robo, celebrated US animation Roadhead and Julian Hanshaw's truly warped Church of the High Weirdness and many more.

J-Star (various dates)
Onedotzero's ability to find and exhibit the best Japanese animation is second to none. For the reprise, they will be showing the work of Morimoto, the lead animator of Japanese Manga classic Akira. You can also sample artist Tokitama Hussle, whose beautifully rendered work has led to a reputation as one of Asia's finest animators.

Lens Flare (Monday November 27)
Not strictly speaking film, rather the very best in full motion video sequences from computer games. That said, the pieces best exemplify how notions of film are changing. High-budget moving pictures, many with a large cast of actors and complex narratives will be shown on cinema screens for the first time. Expect scenes from Tomb Raider and Tekken as well as some exclusive previews of PlayStation2.

Full details of the onedotzero reprise can be found the ICA's website.

webTitle: Human rights the UK won't give

fields.headline: Human rights the UK won't give
fields.standfirst: The UK should ratify protocol 12 of the European Convention on Human Rights prohibiting all forms of discrimination, argues Stephanie Palmer
fields.trailText: The UK should ratify protocol 12 of the European Convention on Human Rights prohibiting all forms of discrimination, argues Stephanie Palmer
fields.body:
This month in Rome there was a celebration to mark the 50th anniversary of the signing of the European Convention on Human Rights. In honour of the occasion, Protocol 12, prohibiting all forms of discrimination, was officially opened for signature. It was signed by 25 of the Council of Europe's member states - but the UK was not among them. It is puzzling that a government committed to the legal protection of human rights should hesitate to take this step.

The new protocol is an important addition to the rights and freedoms guaranteed by the convention now secured in our own Human Rights Act. In many ways the convention is an outdated instrument and the weak protection of discrimination is a serious flaw. Article 14 states that "the enjoyment of the rights and freedoms" set out in the convention (for example, respect for private life, family life, freedom of expression and religion), shall be secured without discrimination on any grounds including sex, race, religion, political opinion, property birth or other status. The snag is that article 14 does not guarantee a free-standing right to equal treatment without discrimination. It complements the other substantive convention provisions but has no independent existence.

The general principle of equality and non-discrimination is recognised as a fundamental human right. It is also very similar to the recently agreed discrimination provision in the charter of fundamental rights of the European Union.

Although the government states that it is, in principle, in favour of an independent anti-discrimination right, it is not prepared to sign the new protocol at present. The government claims that the right is "too general and open-ended". Yet protocol 12 is no more open-ended than the discrimination guarantee in the international covenant on civil and political rights, or in similar rights set out in the written constitutions of the US or other Commonwealth and European countries.

The government has also expressed concern that the protocol "does not follow the case law of the European court of human rights in allowing objective and reasonable justified distinctions". They have clearly grasped the wrong end of the stick. The pre-amble of the protocol accurately reflects the approach already adopted by the Strasbourg court. Indeed the explanatory report accompanying the protocol makes it clear that it was not considered necessary to include a restriction clause since not every difference of treatment amounts to discrimination: it would only be discriminatory if it "has no objective and reasonable justification". The protocol would not prevent a government from taking positive measures to reduce inequality.

Perhaps an underlying fear of the government is that an equality provision will draw the judges into examining social issues, perhaps with cash implications. Yet the judiciary already deal with highly sensitive and complex issues of social policy and frequently exercises restraint and the structure of the Human Rights Act ensures that the judges could not strike down any acts of parliament. Why then shouldn't it be possible to challenge a public authority if its actions discriminate without justification?

We have anti-discrimination legislation but it operates in clearly demarcated areas. The current domestic legislation is outdated, inadequate, inconsistent, and at times incomprehensible. Arbitrary exclusions such as age, sexual orientation and religion or belief (apart from Northern Ireland) are not protected at all. The operation of the legislation has led to anomalies: the Race Relations Act has been interpreted to include some religious groups such as Jews and Sikhs, but Muslims as a religious group are excluded. Where groups are not protected by domestic legislation, it will be more difficult, if not impossible, to obtain a remedy if they suffer discrimination: for example, if employment were refused without justification on the basis of age.

In order to meet our international and European legal obligations radical legislative reforms are needed. For too long our discrimination laws have developed in a piecemeal fashion. There should be a single equality act covering all the main grounds throughout the UK. A coherent regulatory framework would mean that domestic law would be well placed to meet the standards required by the new protocol.

The refusal to sign the protocol does not send a positive message to the new European democracies that are members of the Council of Europe. It is not too late for the government to reconsider its position .

 Stephanie Palmer is a law fellow at Girton, Cambridge.

fields.headline: Key sciences get £250m
fields.trailText: The government is to pump £252m in the next three years into three key scientific fields on which tomorrow's industrial empires will be built.
fields.body:
The government is to pump £252m in the next three years into three key scientific fields on which tomorrow's industrial empires will be built.

A total of £110m will go into the new world of genomics - to start turning hard-won knowledge of the machinery of life into diagnostic tests , drugs, vaccines, agricultural products, environmental care, industrial processes and new materials. One £20m strand of research could involve DNA samples from 500,000 volunteers - who will then be watched for the rest of their lives, to help researchers link genetic inheritance to the health and lifespans of individuals.

A total of £98m will go to what the government calls e-science - the handling of awesome quantities of data involved in scientific co-operations around the world. One international project, a giant nuclear collision experiment at Cern in Geneva, will in 2005 begin to generate enough data to fill a four-mile high stack of CD-Roms every second. Another will be a huge "virtual observatory" to share images from land and space-based telescopes among a global network of scientists.

And £44m will go to "basic technology" - the hardware and processes needed to make tomorrow's sensors, detectors and nanomachines. These could involve technology measured in millionths of a metre, or driven by quantum computers, or used in bioengineering or fitted in underwater robots, or in orbiting spacecraft.

These three - all collaborations between the research councils that allocate science spending - are just the plums in a feast of measures unveiled by the trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers. The government had already introduced a £1bn programme, with the Wellcome Trust, to improve the infrastructure of science, and the government earlier this year announced that the science budget would grow on average by 7% per year in real terms. Yesterday the research councils learned that they would also share an additional £100m to spend in their own fields. The challenges for science spring from the human genome project - the completion, earlier this year, of most of the DNA "alphabet" of the human genetic code. In addition, scientists are racing ahead to decode the genetic secrets of dozens of other organisms, including mice, zebra fish, fruitflies, a nematode worm, a little thalecress plant and many bacteria. The next step is to discover what the genes do, and identify and examine the proteins they code for. The pay-off could be new ways to detect and prevent diseases, rather than merely diagnose and treat them. But genomics could be the basis of a host of other industries.

"In due course, it will almost certainly affect the environmental sciences, where there are huge applications of genomic knowledge," said Lord Sainsbury, the science minister. "Just put yourself back in 1990, trying to predict what would be the situation in 2000, on IT and the internet. The one thing you can be certain about is that you can't predict." But he said, in both genomics, e-science, and basic technology, there would be massive developments which would affect the competitiveness of industry.

With the new money, Britain will aim to join the European Southern Observatory, which will give British scientists access to four 8-metre ground-based telescopes, and the environmental scientists will begin studies of the consequences of rapid climate change in north-west Europe. This research will focus on the ocean current that flows north from the equator to keep Britain 5-10C warmer than might be predicted from its northern latitude. This current delivers to north-west Europe the heat equivalent to a million nuclear power stations - but there are fears that the it could be weakened or switched off by global warming.

Research council bosses welcomed the boost. Ian Halliday, chief of the particle physics and astronomy research council, said the new money would keep Britain at the frontiers of international research. "And the UK economy will also benefit through the provision of highly-trained people and the resulting advances in IT and commercial spin-offs," he said.

fields.headline: Flo 'yes' to Rangers
fields.trailText: Rangers will finally complete the Scottish record-breaking £12m signing of Tore Andre Flo tomorrow morning.
fields.body:
Rangers will finally complete the Scottish record-breaking £12m signing of Tore Andre Flo tomorrow morning.

The Chelsea striker flew into Glasgow today for discussions at Ibrox and underwent a stringent medical this afternoon.

A few minor details are yet to be ironed out, but chairman Rangers David Murray is confident of unveiling the 27-year-old Norwegian striker at a press conference tomorrow.

A statement tonight said: "Rangers chairman David Murray confirmed that discussions had progressed satisfactorily with Tore Andre Flo and Chelsea Football Club, and all contractual matters will be resolved this evening.

"The player has undergone a medical, and again everything appears to be in order. But the results of a few tests are awaited. Completion of the transfer of the player's registration will take place tomorrow morning.

"The £12m Scottish record transfer will see Flo join Rangers on a four-and-a-half year contract. Our fans will understand that the club must take proper time and due consideration in all aspects of this signing. The player will train with the team in the morning, and a press conference will be held in the early afternoon."

webTitle: Carlton and Sainsbury's appoint chief with Taste

fields.headline: Carlton and Sainsbury's appoint chief with Taste
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Carlton and Sainsbury's have hired Antony Ellis to head up TV and internet joint venture, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications and Sainsbury's have appointed Antony Ellis as chief executive of their TV and internet food and drink joint venture.

The two companies have also confirmed that the company, which will incorporate Carlton's Carlton Food Network pay-TV channel and SimplyFood website, is to be called Taste Network.

Carlton Food Network is to be rebranded tasteTV, while SimplyFood will be merging with Sainsbury's website, tasteforlife, to create a new online destination, taste.co.uk.

Both services will be relaunched next spring.

Mr Ellis is joining Taste Network from WPP Group subsidiary Clever Media, where he was managing director.

Forty staff will move from Carlton and Sainsbury's to the Taste Network.

Mr Ellis said: "Taste Network represents a unique partnership, bringing the very best brands together in television, web, food and drink.

"We will be merging Carlton's strength in multimedia entertainment with Sainsbury's unrivalled food and drink knowledge."
