fields.headline: Nigel Crisp's CV
fields.trailText: Nigel Crisp - CV
fields.body:
Nigel Crisp - CV

Age 48, married with 2 children

Educated at Upingham School and St Johns College, Cambridge.

Career History

1999 to date London Regional Director, NHS Executive and Deputy Secretary in Department of Health
1997 to 1999 South Thames Regional Director, NHS Executive and Deputy Secretary in Department of Health
1993 to 1997 Chief Executive, Oxford Radcliffe Hospital NHS Trust
1988 to 1993 General Manager, later Chief Executive, of Heatherwood and Wexham Park Hospitals NHS Trust
1986 to 1988 General Manager, East Berkshire Mental Handicap Unit
1981 to 1986 Director, Cambridgeshire Community Council
1978 to 1981 Production Manager, Trebor plc
1973 to 1978 Community Development Officer, Halewood Community Council

Current Post

London Regional Director, NHS Executive and Deputy Secretary in Department of Health - 1999 to date
40 Eastbourne Terrace, London, W2 3QR, Tel: 020 7725 5425

I was appointed to manage the largest and most complex of the 8 NHS regions when the London Region was formed in January 1999. It brings together great institutions, services and history with inner city populations of enormous need, major health issues and a high political profile.

As Regional Director I am accountable to the NHS Chief Executive, am a member of the NHS Executive Board and work closely with the Secretary of State and other Ministers. I am responsible for :
 leading and managing a wide ranging programme of change
 the delivery of services, education and R&D through 16 Health Authorities and 57 NHS Trusts
 managing 135,000 staff and revenue budgets for services of £5.5bn, education £600m and R&D £250m as well as capital investment of £3.5bn
An important part of the role is in representing the NHS and the government, engaging with the most senior people in organisations and institutions across London, working with many parts of the government including No.10 and the Government Office for London and dealing extensively with the media. This has increased in importance in the last few months in the run up to the election of the Mayor and the GLA.

I was appointed to the new Region with a specific brief to tackle its underlying problems, improve services and develop new approaches to partnership, staffing and service delivery. Over the last 18 months I have done so through :
 stabilising the position and improving services
 introducing increased management rigour and discipline into NHS organisations and beginning to hit performance targets, for example, producing the biggest fall in waiting lists in the country and significant improvements in the financial position
 developing strategies and shared plans: for example, creating a Health Strategy, developing cancer networks and introducing a mental health strategic plan which covers all local authorities as well as health services
 making strategic investments to support these plans, for example, through overseeing the development and management of several very large and complex projects such as the redevelopment of Guy's and St Thomas's, University College and St Barts Hospitals and planning the integration of services from a number of teaching hospitals into the development of two new hospitals in the Paddington Basin
 developing strategic partnerships with, for example, London First (representative of London Business), the Association of London Government (representing the London Boroughs) and the Medical Schools
 beginning to change the culture of the NHS in London: to become more focused on patients and their needs and to operate more effectively as a single organisation. This has involved, for example, introducing new systems for common practice and clinical networking across Trusts; bringing together GP's into Primary Care Groups to focus on the needs of their neighbourhood and supporting change with a series of learning partnerships, collaborations and demonstration projects
 enabling the NHS to play its part as a "corporate citizen", the largest employer in London: most recently this has meant developing a relationship with the Mayor and GLA.
At a national level, I have taken a lead role in NHS Board activity around education and training and quality.

Earlier Career

South Thames Regional Director, NHS Executive and Deputy Secretary in Department of Health - 1997 to 1998

As South Thames Regional Director I performed a similar role to that of London Regional Director for an area running from the Thames to the south coast. The Region disappeared in the reorganisation at the end of 1998.

Chief Executive, Oxford Radcliffe Hospital NHS Trust - 1993 to 1997

I was the first Chief Executive of the major teaching hospital in Oxford, one of the leading academic medical centres in the country, which is linked to Oxford University and serves the specialist needs of 2m people.

It has 5,000 staff and a budget, at today's values, of more than £220m. In this post I :
 successfully managed major organisational and cultural change, merging teaching hospitals and leading the resulting organisation into becoming a semi-autonomous NHS Trust able to operate effectively within the NHS internal market
 developed the range and quality of services in the hospital and took a personal lead in promoting radical change in some services eg, the development of a ground breaking trauma service and the creation of a new breast service
 dealt with very difficult operational, personnel and financial issues in order to ensure that targets were hit and firm foundations were laid for future development

General Manager, later Chief Executive of Heatherwood and Wexham Park Hospitals NHS Trust - 1988 to 1993

I ran this busy district general hospital which serves Slough, Maidenhead, Windsor and Ascot for 5 years leading it through a merger and the process of becoming an NHS Trust. During this period the Trust developed new services and established a viable position in the new NHS internal market.

General Manager, East Berkshire Mental Handicap Unit - 1986 to 1988

I joined the NHS in 1986 at a time when general management was being introduced and ran this unit in Bracknell for 2 years.

Director, Cambridgeshire Community Council - 1981 to 1986

I worked in Cambridgeshire for a charity involved in the development of the voluntary sector, the promotion of rural communities and rural life and the delivery of services in association with public authorities.

Production Manager, Trebor plc - 1978 to 1981

In 1978 I became a Production Manager in a new factory in Colchester which was designed to break up traditional production lines with the introduction of semi-autonomous working groups. I was responsible for running the first production unit and setting in place the new systems. The factory was successful in achieving production targets and an evaluation by Sheffield University demonstrated improvements in job satisfaction, recruitment and retention of staff.

Community Development Officer, Halewood Community Council - 1973 to 1978

I worked for 5 years for this local charity engaged in community development in Liverpool. I evaluated the success of the project whilst registered within the Department of Social Administration at Lancaster University.

 This CV is reproduced with the original spelling and punctuation, courtesy of the Department of Health.

fields.headline: PPARC campaign pays off
fields.trailText: Under the banner of the 'UK's strategic science investment agency', the campaign for more government funding mounted by particle physicists and astronomers appears to have paid off. The Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council will receive an extra £48.4m over the next three years following the latest Whitehall spending review.
fields.body:
Under the banner of the 'UK's strategic science investment agency', the campaign for more government funding mounted by particle physicists and astronomers appears to have paid off. The Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council will receive an extra £48.4m over the next three years following the latest Whitehall spending review.

It will play a major role in the development of e-science - the creation of powerful computing networks enabling researchers to handle large amount of data (a system which could pave the way for the next generation Internet).

Participation in the European Southern Observatory in Chile meanwhile is now guaranteed.

Professor Ian Halliday, PPARC's chief executive, said: "This new funding will ensure our physicists and astronomers remain at the forefront of international research - leading in discoveries that push back the frontiers of knowledge - and the UK economy will also benefit through the provision of highly trained people and the resulting advances in IT and commercial spin-offs."

Taking inflation into account, the council's budget will rise by 6.4% over three years.

Perhaps the only disappointment for the council in the funding settlement is that no funds have been ring-fenced for the development of basic technologies, an area open to applications from all research communities.

The council will receive £26m over three years to spend on two major e-science application projects. There is also an uplift of £22.5m over its baseline budget during the next three years - enabling it to sign up to the European Southern Observatory, and pay increased stipends to PhD students.

Researchers funded by the council are the e-science experts. They are currently developing the computing technologies which will process, transport, store and mine the massive amounts of data from the Large Hadron Collider particle smashing experiment located at CERN, the European particle physics centre. A second e-science project - the 'Astro-Grid' - involves creating the computational network for a 'virtual observatory'.

These new technologies will have applications across the sciences, including genomics and environmental research.

UK membership of the European Southern Observatory meanwhile will open up unforeseen opportunities for the country's astronomers. Joining ESO will cost £12m per year plus around a £70m joining fee. Of all the government's six research councils, PPARC depends most on large international research collaborations.

Of the £44m allocated by the government for basic technology across the entire science sector, Halliday said: "I fully expect PPARC scientists to make aggressive bids into this pot. They have a track record in developing ground-breaking technologies which have applications beyond our own science needs, as evidenced by spin-offs into medical imaging."

fields.headline: Increased science research budget unveiled
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair said today that £252m of new government funds for genome research, 'e-science' and basic technologies over the next three years would help the country stay at the forefront of scientific innovation in the 21st century.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair said today that £252m of new government funds for genome research, 'e-science' and basic technologies over the next three years would help the country stay at the forefront of scientific innovation in the 21st century.

The government released the detailed allocations for research councils over the next three years, alongside a document setting out general investment plans for the public sector.

The science budget will grow by an average of 7% year-on-year in real terms over the next three years.

During a Downing Street briefing, Mr Blair said that the science investment would enable the country to remain one of the leaders of scientific innovation. He conceded that science investment as a proportion of GDP still lagged behind other countries, but said that the government had to make a start.

The prime minister also said that R&D investment by businesses was improving.

"In 1997 Britain spent less than half the global average on R&D, and as a result the economy we inherited was one of the least productive of any major country," said Mr Blair. "Last week we saw that spending on R&D by British business was up 10% last year. Still too low; but getting better."

The three crosscutting themes - genome research, 'e-science' and basic technologies - will benefit all the six research communities represented by the governmentÕs research councils. Genome research will receive £110m, 'e-science' £98m, and basic technologies £44m over the three-year period.

The medical research council and the engineering and physical sciences research council are the two councils gaining most.

The MRC will receive £53m over three years for post-genomic science- the analysis of way genes function. One research programme will study the links between the genetic and environmental factors associated with major diseases.

The EPSRC meanwhile will receive £32m for research on areas where communication via internet is now an essential tool. The council will also receive £41m to develop basic technologies - the sensors and detector underpinning the work of researchers.

Treasury officials turned down proposals for another crosscutting programme on environmental science. But director of the research councils, John Taylor, said that environmental researchers would still benefit from the new funding arrangements.

fields.headline: MRC to launch genetic study
fields.trailText: The Medical Research Council it to contribute £20m to unprecedented study into how genes, lifestyle and environmental factors interact to affect people's health, by taking DNA samples of half a million volunteers.
fields.body:
The Medical Research Council it to contribute £20m to unprecedented study into how genes, lifestyle and environmental factors interact to affect people's health, by taking DNA samples of half a million volunteers.

The UK population biomedical collection is one of the main beneficiaries of the extra £89m announced for the council over three years as a result of the government's spending review. The council also plans to inject extra research funds into mental health - the second biggest national health cost after health disease.

The council received nearly half of the £110m set aside by the government for a cross cutting programme in genomics. By 2003-04 the council's budget will be just over £387m. In real terms the MRC budget will increase by 6.2% over three years.

The biomedical collection, which promises improvements in the prevention and treatment of common illnesses such as heart disease and cancer, is being jointly funded by the MRC, Wellcome Trust and government health departments.

The only London based research council has to be particularly aware of potential collaborations in funding new biomedical science projects. Wellcome's £600m annual research budget exerts a huge influence on the biomedical research community, but more often than not complements MRC schemes.

The MRC and Wellcome have undertaken initial qualitative research to better understand people's views and concerns about this type of research. The results are published on the MRC website.

MRC chief executive, Professor Sir George Radda, said: "The recent publication of the first draft of the human genetic code is just the first step in understanding more about the human body. Scientists are now looking for possible links between particular genes and health and diseases. Working out the functions of these genes is key to designing new approaches to detecting illness early and to preventing and treating diseases. The collection promises to be one of the most exciting scientific initiatives of recent times."

The council has been allocated £12m in capital funding for the study of genes in immunobiology, neuro-degeneration and neurobiology, and the analysis of proteins revealed by genome sequencing.

There is also £8m from the government's e-science initiative - focusing on the huge number crunching effort needed to manage the streams of genetic data emerging from the genome sequencing project.

fields.headline: EPSRC captures coordinating role
fields.trailText: The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council has emerged as the self-styled council for basic science and basic technology, after two Whitehall spending reviews under the Labour government.
fields.body:
The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council has emerged as the self-styled council for basic science and basic technology, after two Whitehall spending reviews under the Labour government.

The coordinating role of the council was stressed by its chief executive, Richard Brook: "Each of the research council's has had good results and I believe that EPSRC can look forward to the next three years with confidence in view of the continuing support for the science and engineering agenda from central Government."

It is, on the face of it, an impressive settlement for the council with the biggest budget among the government's six research councils. With an extra £110m over the next three years the council's budget will be just under £500m by 2003-04. This amounts to an increase of 7.5% in real terms over three years.

But any euphoria among engineers, chemists and physicists should be tempered by the fact that the council is only managing the deployment of £40m of basic technology grants on behalf of all six councils. The science minister, Lord Sainsbury wants those developing cutting edge instruments - sensors, detectors, imaging tools - to enjoy the same esteem experienced by those at the forefront of pure research.

Head of communications at the council, David Leech said the basic technologies scheme will "be operated in an open and transparent way". He stressed that funding had not been ring-fenced for any particular research area: "People in the research communities need not be aware of the research councils they are applying to."

In fact without the injection of funds from all three cross cutting research councils themes - on genome research, e-science and basic technologies - the council would have faced a real terms cut in core funding.

The council has received £13m over three years for post genomic research - building on the life sciences budget it won after the last review. The point is that life scientists alone will not be able to make full use of the huge quantities of genetic information now being amassed - physicists, engineers and information scientists all have a central role to play. The council is aiming to encourage more researchers in engineering and the physical sciences to work at the interface with the life sciences.

The council says it will also "play a key role in supporting the next e-revolution". It will receive £32m over three years under the e-science programme, which aims to exploit new powerful computing networks to help researchers suffering from data-overload - a common problem across the sciences.

The council next year also breaks away from long the standing tradition of awarding research students broadly similar grants. Universities will be allocated 'training packages' allowing them for the first time to determine the level of PhD stipends, currently about £7,000 a year.

fields.headline: Biotechnology gets healthy return
fields.trailText: The spending review has not yielded the shift in funding from physical sciences to the life sciences called for by some officials, but the funding settlement for the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council remains a healthy outcome for the next three years.
fields.body:
The spending review has not yielded the shift in funding from physical sciences to the life sciences called for by some officials, but the funding settlement for the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council remains a healthy outcome for the next three years.

Following the government's spending review the BBSRC budget will increase to £250m by 2003-04, up by 20% in cash terms. When inflation is taken into account, the budget increase comes to 11.5%.

Professor Ray Baker, BBSRC's chief executive. said the settlement represented "a real step change for research in the biological sciences".

While the Medical Research Council retains a larger proportion of the cross-council programme for post genomic research, the BBSRC has received the larger percentage boost in funding.

The two councils will work closely on genomics research. Indeed, the growth of biomedical science has raised the question of whether MRC and BBSRC should be merged to form one single council covering the area. This issue is one of several being raised by the government's quinquennial review of research councils, looking at their future structure and role.

BBSRC has received £33m over three years for research into genomics - to help understand how genes and their products interact to produce the complex behaviour of cells and tissues. The work will enable scientists to identify the function of genes, in all types of organisms, "about which we currently know nothing."

The council has been allocated £8m from the government's e-science programme to develop the computational models needed to store and retrieve the rapidly growing data from genomics and structural biology research.

There will also be £16m over three years to increase PhD grants to £9,000 a year. This is a particular reward for the most vocal campaigner among councils for boosting stipends. BBSRC faces tough competition in the training market: Wellcome Trust funded students in the biomedical sciences can expect double the grants of research council supported students.

The prime minister this month personally championed biotechnology, speaking in front of industry leaders. But covering areas such as spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) and biotechnological science, the BBSRC is the council most sensitive to public opinion. Perhaps signaling the future direction for all research councils, it recently launched an on-line consultation seeking the public's opinions on research priorities.

Multidisciplinary research combining the biological and physical sciences, will be another priority for council over the next three years. It will be working with the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council to develop new technological tools for researchers in nanotechnology, biomaterials and tissue engineering.

fields.headline: Environmental sciences face 'hard choices' ahead
fields.trailText: Despite the rejection of a proposed new overarching research programme on sustainable land use, the Natural Environment Research Council will receive an additional £39m in cash terms over the next three years following the government's spending review.
fields.body:
Despite the rejection of a proposed new overarching research programme on sustainable land use, the Natural Environment Research Council will receive an additional £39m in cash terms over the next three years following the government's spending review.

While greeting the funding settlement, there was also a cautionary note from Professor John Lawton, the council's chief executive: "There will be a few hard decisions to make for NERC's own funding priorities," he said.

The council's budget will be £216.75m by 2003-04, a real terms increase of 5.3% compared with this year's budget.

One area where the council is leading the way among the research councils is the move towards more open and accountable procedures. The first ever board meeting open to the public is now planned for next year.

Predicting the 'earth system' remains a key priority for scientists over the coming decades - as the floods and storms which have recently ravaged the UK have highlighted.

One area singled out by the council for extra funds is a programme investigating the rapid climate change in North Western Europe. The UK is currently between 5ºC - 10ºC warmer than expected for a country this far north. But there is evidence that the 'conveyor belt' that brings warm surface water northwards across the Atlantic could be switched off by global warming effects, causing temperatures in the UK to plummet.

The council will benefit in some way from each of the three cross cutting research council themes - genomic science, e-science and basic technologies.

The council will allocate £7m over three years to the develop the sophisticated computer models needed to predict topics such as climate change. A new generation of computing technologies, both hardware and software, is needed to handle the complex datasets mapping the environment. A new virtual centre will be developed to bring together in a more coherent way UK atmospheric sciences.

As part of the joint research council genome programme, the council has received £6m to investigate how the behaviour of genes relates to the environmental services, such as air and water quality, provided by communities of plants, animals and microbes.

The council is also investing £10m over two years for buildings and equipment for the council's research centres.

fields.headline: Social scientists receive business boost
fields.trailText: The Economic and Social Research Council will receive £5m over three years to invest in management and business research following the government's spending review. The ESRC will see its total budget increase by 17.7% in real terms over three years - the biggest proportional increase among all the research councils.
fields.body:
The Economic and Social Research Council will receive £5m over three years to invest in management and business research following the government's spending review. The ESRC will see its total budget increase by 17.7% in real terms over three years - the biggest proportional increase among all the research councils.

Chancellor, Gordon Brown, and other Treasury officials have for some time been bemoaning the lack of world class university business schools in the UK. The funding for an ESRC-led 'management science' programme will add to the government's efforts to create a more innovative and entrepreneurial business environment in the country.

Brown's surprise announcement of the £65m Cambridge-MIT partnership this year (now officially part of the science budget) is also intended to tap into the US entrepreneurial spirit which created coorporate giants such as Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard.

ESRC chief executive, Dr Gordon Marshall, said: "The ESRC sees this as a major challenge for both the Council and the research community as a whole. The ESRC believes it is the right time to take up this challenge and I think it is extremely far-sighted of the Office of Science and Technology to make funds available for this."

The allocation of new money to the ESRC totals £29.7m over three years. The council's 2000-01 baseline budget is £73m. Over the three-year period, the new funding represents an average increase of 13.6% per year. By 2003-04 the council's new budget will be £92m. After the pariah years under Tory rule, social scientists continue to prosper under the New Labour administration.

The council is not an obvious winner from the three cross cutting initiatives - post genome research, e-science and basic technologies - announced for the research councils after the spending review.

Yet a total of £5m has been allocated over the three-year period for research into the social and economic consequences of genomics. The work will cover the areas of health, risk and governance.

The council will be part of the new cross council post-Genome co-ordinating committee, established by the government. Other members will be the Medical Research Council, the Biotechnology and Biological Science Research Council, the Engineering and Physical Science Research Council and the Natural Environment Research Council.

The council is also receiving £6m over three years for large-scale datasets, such as the British Household Panel Study and the Millennium Cohort Study. The household study will improve samples in Scotland and Wales and extend the study to Northern Ireland. The first phase of the Millenium study will run from June 2000 to December 2002. It will monitor the educational, employment, income, family and medical developments of people at various ages.

An extra £5m over three years will underpin increases for PhD student annual stipends to £9,000 by 2003-04.

About £9m of additional funding has been provided to protect the existing ESRC research programmes.

At any time, the council currently supports 2,000 researchers in universities and research policy institutes.

webTitle: More Oxford rejection for Spence head

fields.headline: More Oxford rejection for Spence head
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The headteacher whose prize pupil Laura Spence was famously rejected by Oxford University told its students last night that they owed it to future generations to reform the admission system that had got them there.
fields.body:
The headteacher whose prize pupil Laura Spence was famously rejected by Oxford University told its students last night that they owed it to future generations to reform the admission system that had got them there.

Paul Kelley, head of Monkseaton community high in Whitley Bay, Tyne and Wear, stepped into the lion's den of the Oxford union debating chamber to argue: "The admission system has lost the confidence of some applicants and some schools.

"It's because as a system it doesn't work well... what system on earth is so perfect that it cannot be improved?"

In May, Chancellor Gordon Brown provoked a national furore when he criticised the decision of Magdalen College, Oxford, to reject Miss Spence for a place to read medicine.

Mr Kelley, speaking for a motion that "this house believes that the Oxbridge admission system is biased against comprehensive schools", said the old selection procedures reflected a time when far fewer pupils got several A grades at A-level. The system had to reform. He told the students: "You hold within this room the ability to make a statement."

But the students rejected his argument by 411 votes to 89.

Opposing him in the debate was Anthony Smith, president of Magdalen, who attacked the comprehensive system, which he said had brought the proportion of state school entries to Oxford plunging since the days of direct grant and grammar schools.

"Oxford can no longer continue to accept the political blame for what is a social condition, one which is obviously not of our making. It's not our job to eliminate it," Mr Smith said. "The state sector is simply not producing a high enough proportion of potential Oxbridge students."

He said that in the 1960s, 70% of Oxford students came from state schools. Now it was around 50%.

"Oxford and Cambridge happen to be perhaps the only bits of the system trying to alleviate the injustice."

Several speakers, including the lead student speaker for the opposition, Steve Hickey from St Peter's College, argued that the problem was simply that not enough state school students were applying.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said Mr Brown had made "a monstrous charge" that had triggered a fall in the number of state school applicants to Oxford this year".

The Labour MP for Harlow, Bill Rammell, speaking for the motion, said he would not defend Mr Brown's use of the Spence case but added: "It probably was taken out of context but that doesn't mean there isn't a problem with the system".

webTitle: The CV that got Nigel Crisp the top job in the NHS

fields.headline: The CV that got Nigel Crisp the top job in the NHS
fields.standfirst: In the words of one health service manager, it is the CV "to die for".
fields.trailText: In the words of one health service manager, it is the CV "to die for". Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
In the words of one health service manager, it is the CV "to die for". It helped its owner, Nigel Crisp, recently land the biggest management job in the public sector, the post of NHS chief executive. But does his resume cut the mustard?

What did it tell health secretary Alan Milburn about its owner when it landed on his desk tucked inside the application form for the top job? Is the CV as slick, professional and technically proficient as Crisp himself?

"It's not a bad CV, but not neccessarily a good one," says Douglas Fraser, managing director of search and selection specialists KMC international.

"It manages to stack up his skills and achievements. But it is too long and wordy. As a general principle, a CV is basically a selling document and it's got to be direct. If the purpose of the CV is to grab someone's attention, you need something on not more than two pages of A4."

John West, head of Kingston Smith executive selection, disagrees. "It's absolutely brilliant. It does not give me an impression of power; I get an impression of professional achievement, good political antennae and experience managing big numbers and resources."

Both experts praise the way Crisp cleverly makes every job he has had appear to be a dry-run for the kinds of decisions he will be expected to make as an NHS chief executive in charge of radical organisational change.

Thus when he is production manager at a Trebor sweets factory in Colchester between 1978 and 1981, he is not merely making sure mints and jelly babies taste nice and are packaged correctly; more profound endeavours are going on.

As the CV puts it: "The new factory was designed to breakup semi-autonomous working groups. I was responsible for running the first production unit and setting in place the new systems. The factory was successful in achieving production targets and an evaluation by Sheffield University demonstrated improvements in job satisfaction, recruitment and retention of staff."

Introducing flexible working, breaking up staff demarcations, re-engineering the delivery process, improving productivity, introducing evidence-based decision-making, and keeping staff happy - Trebor Colchester, it appears, was a mini-NHS plan, 20 years before the event.

Further on in his career, as director of the NHS London region, he lists his achievements using language which is astutely calculated to hit all the right buttons among New Labour ministers. Thus, he "enables the NHS to play its part as a corporate citizen" (held meetings with London mayor Ken Livingstone); he supported NHS change with "a series of learning partnerships" (persuaded GPs to address the health needs of their local population).

The resume also makes it clear Crisp is a man of substance. Says West: "Look at the breadth and scale of the jobs. He's given them all a good whack, it says he's not an opportunist or a flitter. This is a good CV."

There is even what appears to be a deliberate mistake. Crisp fails to correctly spell the name of the exclusive public school he attended (he spells it "Upingham").

Fraser is worried about this blemish: "It is a minor irritation - there's a question of how meticulous he is."

But West is much more sympathetic: "I wish I had a pound for every grammar school boy who could not spell grammar!"

 Mr Crisp's CV was provided by the Department of Health

webTitle: Leeds are taking a huge gamble

fields.headline: Leeds are taking a huge gamble
fields.trailText: Let's get one thing straight: you don't get the likes of Franco Baresi eulogising about your defending, or Barcelona and Bayern bidding millions for your services, unless you can bring something to the table. And Rio Ferdinand is armed with more than most. Pace, poise, panache and passing ability - he's got the lot
fields.body:
Let's get one thing straight: you don't get the likes of Franco Baresi eulogising about your defending, or Barcelona and Bayern bidding millions for your services, unless you can bring something to the table. And Rio Ferdinand is armed with more than most. Pace, poise, panache and passing ability - he's got the lot

But if, as expected, Ferdinand completes his £18m move to Elland Road before the weekend, David O'Leary will have taken an almighty gamble.

It is a gamble that will smash the British transfer record and make the turn the Peckham lad into the costliest defender in the world. That's quite something for a 22-year-old player who isn't even an England regular (and we all know how good they are).

Contrast this with the previous record outlay of £15m that Newcastle spent on Alan Shearer. For that money they were buying one of the top strikers in Europe. Ditto Chelsea when they spent the same amount on Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink this summer. Meanwhile Leeds are buying mostly potential. And potential is a hell of a lot to be risking £18m on.

The fact is that Ferdinand is not yet a great player - even if he does ooze promise. Instead he is stuck in a footballing halfway house: yes, he can defend, but he's no Jaap Stam or Marcel Desailly. And yes, he can pass the ball, but as a sweeper he's not fit to stand in Matthias Sammer's shadow. If Ferdinand is worth £18m, how much would Stam or Alessandro Nesta fetch in today's market?

And there''s another puzzle. Why have Leeds made their move now, with the transfer market swirling in a purple haze of uncertainty? Unless chairman Peter Ridsdale has a direct line to Mario Monti, the EU competition commissioner, he has taken another a huge risk - for the present transfer system could be scrapped by Christmas.

In its place Uefa have talked about imposing a minimum one-year duration on contracts. In that case Leeds could lose Ferdinand - as well as millions of pounds - if Real Madrid or some other European giant decide to spirit him away to the continent.

Of course Leeds supporters will hope for a different scenario, one where Ferdinand fulfils his potential and, under the tutelage of O'Leary, becomes the new Bobby Moore. Or Lucas Radebe. They will also expect him to help pay off his astronomical fee by helping Leeds to qualify for the Champions League - the El Dorado of modern football - for the next two or three years at least.

And all their hopes might well come true. But at the same time you can't help thinking that part of this transfer isn't about football at all. It's about Leeds making a £18m gesture - a signal that they are back among the big boys again. After all, it was only three years ago that the Whites were a below average Premiership side, finishing behind Sheffield Wednesday and Wimbledon in the Premiership. Now they've come into a bit of money and success, you can't blame them for flaunting their wealth. Whether it will be enough to turn them into a leading force in Europe - as Ridsdale obviously hopes - is another matter, however.

webTitle: Murdoch's Star TV to launch in UK

fields.headline: Murdoch's Star TV to launch in UK
fields.trailText: James Murdoch's Star TV to launch two new channels in the UK, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Star TV, the Asian satellite broadcaster owned by Rupert Murdoch's NewsCorp, is to launch two channels aimed at the UK's Asian communities in January.

Hindi language entertainment channel Star Plus and 24-hour English/Hindi language news service Star News will be distributed via BSkyB's Sky Digital platform.

NewsCorp also owns 40% of BSkyB.

fields.headline: Blair attacks Conservative 'Euro scare'
fields.trailText: A passionate Tony Blair today attacked the Conservatives for conjuring up a "Euro scare" over the planned commitment of British troops to a European rapid reaction force.
fields.body:
A passionate Tony Blair today attacked the Conservatives for conjuring up a "Euro scare" over the planned commitment of British troops to a European rapid reaction force.

Speaking at prime minister's questions, he dismissed claims from the opposition that the force was a building block in the construction of a European superstate, and that it would harm the nation's ability to defend itself.

"There is no proposal for a European army," said Mr Blair. "There is a complete British veto".

Repeating his recent attacks on Conservatives and the euro-sceptic press, he said "the idea that British troops are going to be marched off by the European commission is just a euro-scare".

His comments came in response to a strongly worded attack on the plans by William Hague. He described the plans as "a milestone on the creation of a united political Europe."

"Shouldn't we put our faith in someone who led from the front in the Gulf war, rather than people who ran from the front in the Cold War?" asked Mr Hague, citing criticism of the plans by General Sir Peter de la Billiere, commander of British forces during the Gulf War.

In response, the prime minister cited international support. "Nato have supported this, the US president, the secretary of state for defence and the secretary of state Madeleine Albright have all supported it.

"The idea that this undermines Nato or the US relationship, when Nato has supported it and the US Government has supported it, is a proposition that could only come from you."

He poured scorn on Mr Hague's pledge to withdraw troops from the new force if the Conservatives win the next election. "It would be absolutely disastrous if they went to a European summit and said they were going to withdraw."

Citing recent attacks on the plans by Baroness Thatcher, he claimed that the opposition leader's motto was simple: "Lady Thatcher, you lead, I'll follow".

fields.headline: Wanadoo confirms Freeserve talks
fields.standfirst: Nov 22: Freeserve in merger talks
fields.trailText:
Internet service provider Wanadoo is talking to Freeserve about buying out Dixons' 80% stake in the company, writes Amy Vickers.
Nov 22: Freeserve in merger talks
fields.body:
Wanadoo, the France Telecom-owned internet service provider, has confirmed that it is talking to Freeserve about buying out Dixons' 80% stake in the company, and is close to a clinching a deal.

However, the company left a question mark over the acquisition by saying it was talking to a number of other companies as part of its plan to become Europe's number one ISP.

It is rumoured that Wanadoo is also talking to LineOne, United News & Media and BT's joint venture ISP, which has recently been put up for sale.

However, a deal with Freeserve would give Wanadoo a market leading position in the UK. It would buy into more than 2m ISP users and more than 3.6m unique visitors to the portal each month for an estimated bargain price of £1.8m.

LineOne, on the other hand, is said to be worth about £400m and has around 1.3m registered members.

Italian ISP Tiscali is also rumoured to have been in acquisition talks with Freeserve.

John Pluthero, Freeserve's chief executive, refused to elaborate further on this morning's statement, which said Freeserve had resumed talks with an undisclosed company regarding the share-sale of Freeserve.

Mr Pluthero said talks were going well but wouldn't give details of who it was or how long they would take to reach a conclusion.

"I can't say anything more than the statement we put out this morning as we're in an offer period," said Mr Pluthero.

A deal with Wanadoo, which was launched in 1996 and runs the Voila portal, would lead to a closer working relationship between Freeserve and Britain's largest cable TV group, NTL, which is partly owned by France Telecom.

The two were linked together in the summer but no deal materialised.

Shares in Freeserve have fallen back to around 140p after climbing to more to than 155p in early trading this morning.

webTitle: Fatal car bomb blasts Israeli bus

fields.headline: Fatal car bomb blasts Israeli bus
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A powerful car bomb has exploded next to a bus in the northern Israeli town of Hadera during evening rush hour, killing at least two people and wounding 35.
fields.body:
A powerful car bomb has exploded next to a bus in the northern Israeli town of Hadera during evening rush hour, killing at least two people and wounding 35.

The bus was hurled into a storefront, setting nearby stores on fire.

Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak called the attack "barbaric" and held Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat ultimately responsible. Barak said Arafat has released dozens of Islamic militants in recent weeks and has encouraged his people to carry out attacks on Israelis.

"The state of Israel will settle accounts with the perpetrators and those who sent them," Barak said in a statement.

The blast went off around 5:20 pm in Hadera's crowded downtown shopping area, a working class town just 30 miles north of Tel Aviv.

The bus had just left the Hadera central bus station when it passed the car, which was parked in front of a pizza restaurant, witnesses said.

"The whole bus flew in the air from the explosion," a witness, identified as Shmuel, told Israel radio. "The whole floor of the bus buckled."

"People were cut. I saw people on the ground, covered with blood," Shmuel said.

Thick smoke rose into the air. The blast turned the rigged car into a twisted pile of smoking metal and blew out the windows of the bus. Several nearby stores caught fire.

Dr. Meir Oren, director of Hillel Yaffe hospital, said there were two dead at his hospital, and four wounded seriously. He estimated about 35 people were wounded altogether. Israel TV reported four dead. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

Israel has been on high alert for terror attacks by Palestinian militants since the recent violence began at the end of September. In the past, the Islamic Jihad and Hamas groups have carried out car bombings in hopes of wrecking Israeli-Palestinian peacemaking.

The blast came just hours after Israeli soldiers tracking a local Palestinian militia commander opened fire on two cars in the Gaza Strip, killing four people including the wanted man, the army said.

Palestinians said the soldiers had fired without provocation. The windshield of one of the cars was riddled with dozens of bullet holes. The Palestinian security chief in Gaza, Mohammed Dahlan, called the attack a "barbaric" assassination.

On November 2, two Israelis were killed in the packed Mahane Yehuda market in central Jerusalem when a car bomb exploded on a nearby side street. Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for the attack.

In Hadera, six people were killed in a suicide bombing in 1994 that was claimed by Hamas. A string of bombings in 1996 killed scores of Israelis.

webTitle: Child protection experts hope debate follows TV programme

fields.headline: Child protection experts hope debate follows TV programme
fields.standfirst: Child protection experts have described a TV report on sex abuse in the family as 'shocking', but fear public debate will not last, writes Linda Steele
fields.trailText: Child protection experts have described a TV report on sex abuse in the family as 'shocking', but fear public debate will not last, writes Linda Steele
fields.body:
Shocking. It was the word that came up time and time again. Shocking.

Child protection professionals were among the 2.2m who tuned into Newsnight on Monday. They saw secretly recorded video footage of a 71-year-old man talking about having oral sex with a young member of his family. He admitted to BBC cameras that he started having sex with one stepdaughter when she was 10. One adult stepdaughter - who videoed him secretly for Newsnight, having spent years trying to persuade the authorities to listen to her claims - told how he had sold his stepchildren to other men for sex. Another stepdaughter said she thought he would abuse again.

The first response of those professionals who saw the programme was that it was shocking. "It was shocking to hear [the abusers] talking about children as promiscuous. It showed how difficult it was for children to come forward, when the abuser was their father or someone they see as their father," said NCH Action for Children senior public policy officer Annie Mullins. Even for hardened professionals, it was hard to watch, she says.

But Mullins' view, and that of other professionals in the field, is that it was a responsible and important attempt to raise the issue of long-term child abuse within the family. "It was immensely valuable, in that it revealed, in a very powerful way, that these people are affable - people trust them. He seemed like a loving grandad [to his toddler stepgrandson] but you wondered if it was a form of grooming," she says. "It showed the clear dichotomy of [one abused relative] who wanted to bring him to justice and [another] who loved him and wanted to protect him. It showed the way victims react in different ways and take the blame, feel shame."

The programme has led to the arrest of two elderly men by Merseyside police. (The police, along with social services, came in for implicit criticism in the programme for their seeming inaction over many years.) And it probably has the latest claim to water-cooler television status. Only, unlike other talk-provoking programmes, such as Big Brother or Ally McBeal, this one was real life. But, points out Childline chief executive Valerie Howarth: "The problem with child abuse is people don't want to sustain a debate. The general public has 48 hours of shock horror and then want to forget."

How long the discussions will last depends, in part, on the public's willingness to face what is a terrible and almost unbelievable truth - that most sexually abused children (89%) are not victims of the unknown paedophile, lurking in a park wearing a dirty mac. They are buggered and raped and assaulted by friends and relatives.

It was a point made explicit in the programme and welcomed by Tink Palmer, Barnardo's development officer. "A lot of people still believe that 'stranger danger' is the problem," she says. "The one message is that it happens on people's doorsteps and within their homes and within their families more than anywhere else."

Mullins is hopeful that this could be the start of a public debate on familial abuse. "I listened to people on the train the next day and they were shocked that someone could wield that power in a family."

Tackling the power of an abuser is key. Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, sums it up as: "How do you make children able to tell their stories if the most important person in their life is abusing them? Children are often frightened to tell because they think that their family will be broken up." But she says that professionals are learning "the way in which abusers operate and developing practice in the light of that."

Good inter-agency working is vital to create a safety net for children. "There need to be strong local networks, which can create relationships of trust between schools, police and social services, that can consistently reach out to very vulnerable children," she says. "And these kind of cases require consistent attention."

But, for children to be safe, local communities need to be alert to danger signals - and prepared to act on them. "We've got to have a public education campaign," says Palmer. Non-abusing carers, friends and neighbours need to understand how paedophiles "groom" children and gain their trust. They need to be made aware of how "gradual, abusive attitudes" develop.

The Home Office has recently announced £50,000 in funding for a public awareness campaign, Stop It Now UK and Ireland, run by the Faithfull Foundation and the National Organisation for the Treatment of Abusers. From the evidence shown on British television screens, it would seem there's a long way to go before children can speak out about abuse and be heard by our society.

fields.headline: Race harassment complaints up nearly 100%
fields.standfirst:
Victim support groups record big rise in reported incidents in year of Macpherson report but say many victims are still staying silent

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Victim support groups record big rise in reported incidents in year of Macpherson report but say many victims are still staying silent.
fields.body:
Under-reporting of racial harassment is widespread despite the number of recorded incidents soaring since the inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, according to a survey released today.

Almost all the organisations questioned in the study, which examines levels of harassment reported to police, councils, housing associations and community groups, said the number of black and ethnic minority people reporting harassment had risen since the 1999 Macpherson report on the Metropolitan Police's handling of the Lawrence case.

Imran Khan, solicitor for the Lawrence family, said the Macpherson report had emboldened more to come forward and "engendered a huge expectation" that the police would respond. But he added: "The police have taken much of the credit for increased reporting, claiming that they have won trust, but that is not reflected by the number of clients who come to me disgruntled with the police response and the number of complaints, on grounds of race, against police officers."

However, the survey found that most agencies considered under-reporting and under-recording of harassment still a big problem, with asylum seekers identified by several respondents as the group least likely to report harassment.

The research, by Lemos and Crane for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, focused on the 67 local authority areas with the highest concentration of ethnic minorities. More than 1,000 incidents were reported in 10 London boroughs, Birmingham, Leicester, and Glasgow, from 1999 to 2000. Newham, in east London, received more than 2,000 reports, the highest number in the country. Eight boroughs, mostly in rural areas, recorded fewer than 100 incidents of racial harassment in the past year.

In total, the agencies received almost 42,000 reports of racial harassment between April 1999 and March this year, compared with 23,000 racial incidents recorded by all British police forces in the previous year.

A spokeswoman for the commission for racial equality said: "The increase in reported incidents can be attributed to the fact that we now have the statistics - now the problem is fully recognised individuals may feel more confident in reporting harassment."

The survey, which also examined the support available for racial harassment victims, found that almost 80% of the boroughs had forums - typically in surgeries, schools, churches and advice centres - to tackle the problem. But less than a third of the areas had a 24-hour helpline and few offered counselling. Most councils provided extra security for worried tenants.

The survey found that less than half of the councils and housing associations had rehoused families after racial incidents, arguing that this move let perpetrators drive tenants from "white" estates.

The survey also looked at what action had been taken against perpetrators. Possession proceedings had been taken by more than half the boroughs surveyed, but anti-social behaviour orders were used to deal with racially motivated harassment in only three areas.

webTitle: Big money, Short flight, and Long haul

fields.headline: Big money, Short flight, and Long haul
fields.trailText: HIS NAME IS RIO, AND HE COSTS TEN ZILLION GRAND
fields.body:
HIS NAME IS RIO, AND HE COSTS TEN ZILLION GRAND

If the Fiver was to ask our readership: "Who is the world's most costliest defender?" you would no doubt respond in North Korean-like unison: "The Argentine Walter Samuel who joined Roma for £13m in June." And you would be right. Well, for the next 17 hours or so. But after that you might be wrong, because Walter's record is about to scratched out by Ayia Napa's resident summer scallywag Rio Ferdinand, who is poised to complete an astonishing £18m move to Leeds.

Not surprisingly, the Leeds chairman Peter Risdale was in a cheery mood when the Fiver grabbed him by his ginormous wallet this afternoon. "Rio's agent is flying in from Israel for the negotiations tomorrow, and I am hopeful a successful conclusion can be reached," he beamed. And then something strange started to happen. His eyes went cloudy, colour returned to his hair and he started to sound remarkably like Tony Blair.

"Agreeing a fee which is not only a British record but also a world record for a defender demonstrates unequivocally our determination to become a leading force in both the Premiership and in Europe," he thundered. "Often in the past we have been criticised for not backing the desires of managers with money. No longer can that accusation be levelled."

At that point the Fiver dashed back to 'Arry's 'Appy Motors, where we found the proprietor in reflective mood. "It's an offer, from a business point of view, that you can't refuse," he admitted. "It's £18m for the football club - and if the transfer system falls apart in a couple of months we're going to look very foolish, so I can understand where the chairman is coming from." But even so he was still holding on to the slim hope that Ferdinand will stay. "It won't be easy for him to make his decision," he claimed. "In fact I wouldn't bet on him leaving, but it's his decision now. No one is pushing him either way - it's his decision and his life," he continued, crying into his carburettor.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FOWL-UPDATE

Thanks to you all for your messages of concern for the welfare of Jon "Which button should I press? I dunno, I'll decide after my nap" Fowler. The Fiver passed them on last night, only to be informed that, since an unexpected fire gutted his luxurious home, nobody had seen him.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FLY FIVER!

Perk your ears up, it's Squadron Leader Fiver here! Can't talk long, got a lot to be getting on with, but let me make it clear that when there's passengers to be flown, no one does it like old Fiver. So it will come as no surprise to find that I wasn't bally well surprised when Chelsea gave me a tinkle and asked if I could escort a young Norwegian to Glasgow. "What do you think I am?" I asked (not being particularly sure myself you understand). "About £200 an hour," they replied. Which, by sheer bally coincidence, was the right answer.

So here I am tootling my way to Prestwick with some young Tory in the back. Looks like a nice chap, if a bit leggy, but he's as nervous as a cat in a cloth sack near the sound of rushing water. Says he's off to join the Rangers, but didn't know if it was the Connaught or the Queens! I told him Snorty Templeton spent 10 years in the Queens and had as much fun as a dog in an open sewer. He didn't pay much attention though - insisted I lend him my calculator instead (dashed versatile things, digital watches) to work out what 52 times £20,000 was.

Apparently, as soon as he lands the poor chap's off to hospital for a check-up. Don't blame him myself, you never know where those Sweaties have been do you? Still, I wouldn't spend too much time in the crock shop - leaves a man dwelling on the big D. Not that Tory's going to have much time to hang around, says he's off to do battle with some Celts on Sunday. It's a hard life in the forces, but somebody's got to do it. Anyway Tory, best of British to you, the door's over there. If you count to ten then pull the cord, you'll be down in no time.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's simple. If Bruges win their 34 games, I will join a nunnery."

Anderlecht defender Bertrand Crasson warns of the consequences if rivals Bruges keep up their astonishing run (13 matches, 13 wins) in the Belgian League.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SVENNIS ENVY

It's good to know that for all the stick the British press has been handing out, they're not alone in finding Svennis a menace. There have been Serie A-side rumblings too, with both press and Lazio-owning tycoons suggesting that, now he's sold his soul to Adam Crozier, Svennis is no longer interested in the boring job of coaching the most expensive side in the world.

Indeed some wags have even suggested that Svennis ought to be given the boot rather than drag the Serie A champions into Anglo-Saxon mediocrity. This is an opinion that the club's general director Massimo Cragnotti, son of president Sergio, did nothing to discourage when he publicly took Svennis' tactics to task following Lazio's 1-1 draw with Milan at the weekend. He said that Svennis' decision to play only one up front was not clever. Svennis, meanwhile, didn't think Massimo was being too smart.

"It is not very intelligent to talk outside of the dressing room about problems that need to stay inside," Svennis was quoted as saying in the Italian press today. "In general in football there is a search for a culprit to condemn when you lose, but at Lazio however, it seems that same process happens when we draw. Maybe someone is getting nervous." When asked if he would play two up against Anderlecht in Big Cup tonight, he said: "It is completely my decision of course. No one has the right to interfere with my work." Jeff Powell must be salivating already.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Charlton Athletic are lining up South African striker Shaun Bartlett, according to Planet Football. The website claims that 28-year-old is set to move on loan for the rest of the season, with a view to a permanent £2m deal in the summer. "The deal is almost complete," said the FC Zurich president, Sven Hopz. "We would just like to keep him for a couple of weeks until our winter break begins."

Barry Ferguson is reported to be the latest transfer target for Arsene Wenger. The Gunners have been watching the 22-year-old tough-tackling midfielder all season, and will make an £8m offer for him if Rangers get knocked out of the Uefa Cup.

Southampton want to sign 15-year-old Russian striker Andrei Perepletkin, who has been recommended to the club by Marian Pahars' agent, reports Teamtalk.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Arsenal's Big Cup match against Spartak Moscow will go ahead at 5pm tonight after the pitch passed a late inspection by Italian referee Pierluigi Collina.

John Gregory has failed in his latest bid to sign Celta Vigo striker Benni McCarthy. The Spanish club rejected the undisclosed offer, believed to be £9m yesterday morning, because they value the striker at £14m.

Charlton are confident their Premiership match against Sunderland on Saturday will go ahead as scheduled. Greenwich council's building control team today agreed a programme of work on the Valley's East Stand, which should allow it to be used as normal.

Modena midfielder Francesco Bertolotti, who has been in a coma since being punched by a rival player last weekend, open his eyes briefly today, doctors said.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live (7pm) Leeds United v Real Madrid. For some reason ITV have decided to show the biggest game of the night live. What's gone wrong?

The Big Match (11.30pm) Fortunately Barry Venison and Andy Townsend are on hand to bring us back to earth.

ITV2: The Big Match - Live! (4.30pm) Spartak Moscow v Arsenal. For those Gooners who haven't taken the afternoon off work to head to the frost-bitten wastes of the east (ie Aldgate).

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mondial (7pm) If all the world's a pitch, is Norway the stansion?

You're on Sky Sports! (10pm) Concern for the duckies mounts as it turns out that Rob McCaffrey is now concentrating his attention on "ongoing and pending projects in seismology and geodesy" at New York's Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

ONSPORT 1: ON goals (7pm) "Oh goals, goals/ Thou art so great/ Even when a 32-pass move sets them up on a plate". More soccer odes from the country's foremost poets. Or something.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.30pm) "Let's see that again! Oops, sorry, we can't." Spanners.

Midweek 6-0-6 with David Mellor! (10pm) Ironically, this programme benefits from a lack of visuals.

fields.headline: No safety in numbers for black and Asian families living in Newham
fields.trailText: A stroll in East Ham, in the London borough of Newham, would leave visitors with the impression that ethnic minorities are not merely visible but a celebrated asset.
fields.body:
A stroll in East Ham, in the London borough of Newham, would leave visitors with the impression that ethnic minorities are not merely visible but a celebrated asset.

They would not be wrong. More than 30 different communities co-exist in the borough. At 56%, black and ethnic minority residents outnumber white residents - the result of 80 years of movement into the area.

But, research released today confirms what community workers have long known: sheer numbers have not guaranteed safety. The borough had more reports of racial harassment than any other local authority in the past year, said the Rowntree Foundation. Agencies, including the police and the council housing department, recorded 2,451 incidents.

According to figures, the incidents are mainly carried out by whites and concentrated in areas where black and Asian people are visibly in the minority. Estates in Canning Town, Beckton and East Ham are particular hotspots with reports ranging from the fire-bombing of an Asian family's car to the blackmailing of a black pub landlady.

Angela Mpofu, of Newham borough council, said that the harassment was linked to a perception by white residents that they were "losing out" to ethnic minorities.

She added that neighbour harassment is largely perpetrated by children.

In Canning Town, Ola has reported 30 incidents of racial harassment in the past two months. Her children, now aged three, 10 and 11 were attacked by groups of white boys. She gave up her catering job because she could not oversee her children's school run.

She has been threatened with a baseball bat. She reported the incidents but no action was taken. Ola and her children were stoned by youths as they tried to leave their flat.

The family, which is one of just three black households in a block of several hundred people, has also received death threats.

Ola is waiting for Newham to rehouse her. "If the police had helped and arrested someone I would feel reassured but I'm frightened. I can't be a prisoner in my own home."

fields.headline: Race harassment complaints up nearly 100%
fields.trailText: Under-reporting of racial harassment is widespread despite the number of recorded incidents soaring since the inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, according to a survey released today
fields.body:
Under-reporting of racial harassment is widespread despite the number of recorded incidents soaring since the inquiry into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, according to a survey released today.

Almost all the organisations questioned in the study, which examines levels of harassment reported to police, councils, housing associations and community groups, said the number of black and ethnic minority people reporting harassment had risen since the 1999 Macpherson report on the Metropolitan Police's handling of the Lawrence case.

Imran Khan, solicitor for the Lawrence family, said the Macpherson report had emboldened more to come forward and "engendered a huge expectation" that the police would respond. But he added: "The police have taken much of the credit for increased reporting, claiming that they have won trust, but that is not reflected by the number of clients who come to me disgruntled with the police response and the number of complaints, on grounds of race, against police officers."

However, the survey found that most agencies considered under-reporting and under-recording of harassment still a big problem, with asylum seekers identified by several respondents as the group least likely to report harassment.

The research, by Lemos and Crane for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, focused on the 67 local authority areas with the highest concentration of ethnic minorities. More than 1,000 incidents were reported in 10 London boroughs, Birmingham, Leicester, and Glasgow, from 1999 to 2000. Newham, in east London, received more than 2,000 reports, the highest number in the country. Eight boroughs, mostly in rural areas, recorded fewer than 100 incidents of racial harassment in the past year.

In total, the agencies received almost 42,000 reports of racial harassment between April 1999 and March this year, compared with 23,000 racial incidents recorded by all British police forces in the previous year.

A spokeswoman for the commission for racial equality said: "The increase in reported incidents can be attributed to the fact that we now have the statistics - now the problem is fully recognised individuals may feel more confident in reporting harassment."

The survey, which also examined the support available for racial harassment victims, found that almost 80% of the boroughs had forums - typically in surgeries, schools, churches and advice centres - to tackle the problem. But less than a third of the areas had a 24-hour helpline and few offered counselling. Most councils provided extra security for worried tenants.

The survey found that less than half of the councils and housing associations had rehoused families after racial incidents, arguing that this move let perpetrators drive tenants from "white" estates.

The survey also looked at what action had been taken against perpetrators. Possession proceedings had been taken by more than half the boroughs surveyed, but anti-social behaviour orders were used to deal with racially motivated harassment in only three areas.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Charlotte Church is the UK's highest-paid teenager, but she gets just £50 a month pocket money. How much control should children have over their own money?
fields.trailText: The Question: Charlotte Church is the UK's highest-paid teenager, but she gets just £50 a month pocket money. How much control should children have over their own money?
fields.body:
Richard Jenkins Member of the Exodus Collective and father of one
The Exodus Collective in Luton where my family lives is founded on sharing and cooperation. There are so many negative influences on children these days; I wouldn't let my daughter get involved in an environment where she was going to earn so much. If you think of what a man who has worked down a mine for 40 years earns, it is preposterous that teenagers can earn millions. I think the whole environment is a corrupt one. Having a lot of money isn't what makes you really rich. We give our daughter the most important thing of all - 100% love and comfort.

Paul Duffin General savings manager, Halifax building society
As the father of three teenage children and the head of the largest savings institution in the country, I believe it is important to give teenagers experience in managing money of their own. Whether they are earning money from part-time jobs or given some by their parents - a bit of both in my case - managing money is an important lesson to learn early. Mine learned quickly that they couldn't always get everything they wanted right now, and they actually had to save and plan when they wanted to buy something special. This comes as a new concept for a lot of teenagers.

Wendy Elmes Mother of three
With sums of up to £100 per month, children should be left to take care of their own finances. All three of my children have bank accounts with Solo cards and have control over their money. Pocket money goes into their accounts on the same day every month, and they know that's all they have to last them unless they work to earn extra. It gets them used to the principle that money runs out quickly. If one of them was suddenly to earn a lot more than the others, I would have to control, invest and, to an extent, share out the money to avoid sibling rivalry.

Greg Hadfield Father of internet entrepreneur
Tom set up the Soccernet website when he was 12 and became an internet millionaire, but it is only now that he has turned 18 that he is getting a salary from it. We have never spoiled him rotten. I think it's sensible that young people should be given greater independence and responsibility for looking after their own finances. When our financial fortunes changed dramatically three years ago, we didn't put the money into a trust for Tom, but formed a family holding company. I think it's right that money should be rationed to children and young people.

Kate Osamor Office manager and mother of Ishmael, a young footballer
My son Ishmael is a promising football player. There's a good chance he could go professional, which might mean earning lots of money at a young age. If that happens, I would do what Charlotte Church's parents have done and put his money away until he was mature enough to know what to do with it. I don't think you gain that sort of maturity until about 25 - it's so easy to be influenced by friends. I think he'd be fine on an allowance of £50 a month, but I'd have to maintain a certain lifestyle for him and make sure I bought him all the right clothes and trainers.

Laurence Oates Official solicitor to the supreme court
I look after the interests of vulnerable children where there is no parent or other member of the family who can act as a trustee. Money can be held in trust for these children. If a child is earning the money themselves and a bank or building society lets them open an account, my policy is to encourage a child to do this because it teaches them how to manage a budget. What often happens is that I look after the capital for them in a trust fund and give them an allowance. I'm very much in favour of what Charlotte Church's parents have done.

fields.headline: American mom
fields.trailText: If you don't see the connection between your child's improved reading scores and a fleet of army tanks, then you clearly are not a Silicon Valley parent. In Portola Valley, just outside San Francisco, parents not only see the connection, they foster it.
fields.body:
If you don't see the connection between your child's improved reading scores and a fleet of army tanks, then you clearly are not a Silicon Valley parent. In Portola Valley, just outside San Francisco, parents not only see the connection, they foster it.

Parents on both sides of the Atlantic know that a well-funded school will, on average, produce better-educated children. More money translates into more computers and specialised teachers, which in turn translates into little Jane getting into Cambridge one day. But what are parents to do when the state school their child attends is struggling to make ends meet? Forgo all dreams of progeny who know their Picasso from their Play-Doh? Or hold a bake sale and raise the cash themselves?

The parents of Portola Valley, listed by Worth magazine as the 49th wealthiest town in the US, have chosen option b). Except that nobody is going to bake cakes and knit booties to buy computers. At a recent auction to raise money for the two state schools in the area, items donated included a bungalow holiday in Hawaii, a four-day ranch getaway in Colorado, a Michael Jordan-signed basketball, a sleepover at San Francisco Zoo ("Find out if llamas wear pajamas... wake up to roaring lions while you enjoy breakfast!" boasts the auction circular) and, incredibly, a visit to the largest private collection of army tanks in America. "Have you always wanted to drive military vehicles? Indulge your fantasy. Grab your hardhat and let loose!"

Mark Mordell, the Portola Valley Schools Fund co-chairman, says they expect to raise $325,000 from the event. Pity the poor parents in hard-luck school districts who do spend all week baking cakes and barely raise $325.

The Portola parents are so well heeled that a group of them have promised to match the $325,000 raised at the auction. All monies will be donated to the school foundation's endowment fund and used to pay for new computers, reading specialists and more classes in art, music and foreign languages.

"The district's total expenditure per pupil is still barely above the national average, even including state funds, the annual foundation donation, and the 1994 Parcel Tax," said Mordell in response to the raised eyebrows when the auction list was made public. "The needs for quality education are getting higher, and so are the costs."

But a day in a tank in exchange for a French teacher? A night at the zoo for art supplies? When it comes to fundraising, the key word in San Francisco is big-ticket glamour. Bake sales are for amateurs.
