webTitle: Parents: Martin Kelner describes being a mature dad

fields.headline: The family silver
fields.standfirst: David Jason is to be a father at 60. Mature dad  Martin Kelner  offers him some advice
fields.trailText: David Jason is to be a father at 60. Mature dad Martin Kelner offers him some advice.
fields.body:
Good on you, David. As an old dad myself, I feel a bond with the actor David Jason, who is to be a father at 60. Naturally, I am not able to see this event from your girlfriend's point of view or the child-to-be's, but for you, David, it is the best possible news. Without your impending parenthood, there was a danger you might have slipped into comfortable retirement, but this new little commitment means you will have to carry on working. And is there anything an actor relishes more?

With estimated TV earnings of £1m a year, it is your duty now to continue to serve your public with quality drama, if only so that you can give the little one a proper start in life. My earnings as a freelance journalist are, according to latest estimates, somewhat lower, but I must admit the comfortable retirement bit had me worried for a while.

I had been watching with increasing distaste those adverts for building societies, where a sprightly grey-haired couple skip along a beach in some exotic, long-haul destination, all because they have been wise enough to put their savings in the Leicester and Chester. It was not so much their prudence that irritated me as their bloody smugness. Do I really want to pass my twilight years on a coach with these people, gawping at the Grand Canyon?

Well, no need to worry now. Ruth, born three weeks ago (sister to David, aged 16, Anna, 13, and Martha, 10) is our guarantee we will avoid that fate - at least for the foreseeable future. With roughly 15 years of college fees to think about, no timeshare winters in Tenerife for us, thank goodness!

Not that our late baby was entirely a product of sage forward planning. Nor was it intentionally a homage to our glorious leader (I am 50 and my wife Janet is 43, so by coincidence our family fits the Tony-Cherie mould almost exactly). It was more a case of what the Americans, I believe, call "slipping one past the goalie".

However, had we both realised what a joy a baby was going to be at this stage in our lives, we would have planned it. When you are younger, you tend to get caught up in the negative aspects of the new arrival: the sleepless nights, the restrictions on your social life, the endless nappies full of what Robin Williams called "part Velcro, part toxic waste". But when you have been through the process three times and emerged relatively unscathed, you tend to take a more relaxed view.

For you, David, I gather it is the first time, so you will never have had to deal with the mewling and puking, but you have worked in television, and I imagine that is much the same. For us, it is almost certainly the last time (we have signed a new goalie), and that helps concentrate the mind wonderfully on the glorious adventure of child-rearing - although rearing may be a slightly optimistic term for what has been going on between us and our children.

I am not sure what the recommended number of servings per day of fruit and vegetables is, but in 16 years I don't think we have hit the mark once, unless "large fries" counts as a vegetable. Our policy on television, meanwhile, owes little to any approved model of family life, apart from that recommended by the Simpson family.

But here's the thing: if our experience is anything to go by, however useless you are as parents, your children seem to grow up more or less undamaged. We talk to them a lot - both of us - and that covers a multitude of other omissions in my view. I write at home much of the time, and I am always happy for a little one's conversation to divert me from my important work of eating digestive biscuits and monitoring popular culture via daytime television.

There are real worries, of course. Are the nation's toddlers still in thrall to the evil Thomas the Tank Engine cult? Are they still using flashcards? Do little tiny shoes still cost twice as much as real ones?

I don't suppose the shoe issue will be a big one for you, David, but it is what lies behind my modest offer of advice. Sure, I feel guilty about treating the new baby as a freelance opportunity, but I explained the financial imperative to Ruth, and she dribbled some milk out of the corner of her mouth, which I took as assent.

See David, talk to them. It works. Read to them, too. And relax.

fields.headline: Little darlings
fields.standfirst: The pressures of life as a child star are well documented - the intrusion, the temptations, the tantrums. But are things any easier for the parents?  Julie Wheelwright  finds out
fields.trailText: The pressures of life as a child star are well documented - the intrusion, the temptations, the tantrums. But are things any easier for the parents? Julie Wheelwright finds out
fields.body:
An unfortunate incident this week has highlighted concerns about the thorny question of child actors. The BBC apologised after a Candid Camera-style prank used a child actor as a "homeless" African child who was left on the doorstep of a Hertfordshire child minder. Gillian Dumbarton, 49, answered the door to a man claiming he was collecting money for African children. When she donated a pound, a wooden box was unloaded and the child ran towards her. Outraged by the stunt's poor taste and the inappropriate use of the child, Mrs Dumbarton called the police to have the TV crew removed.

Child actors are back in the news following the phenomenal success of Billy Elliot, the forthcoming Harry Potter film and Macaulay Culkin's London stage debut. Culkin's transition from child to adult actor comes as a surprise after a trail of film flops in the late 1990s, a custody battle between his parents and his own public bitterness towards his father and manager, Kit. Culkin became the highest-paid child actor ever for the Home Alone films, but Kit was once dubbed "the stage father from hell". Himself a former child actor, Kit was held responsible for his son's plummeting career in 1996 after demanding huge fees for his son and a laundry list of conditions on film projects.

Culkin might be considered fortunate to have survived. The horror stories of young actors whose childhoods end in parental estrangement, drug addiction or suicide are enough to terrify any sensible parent into giving stage and screen a wide berth.

On the other hand, working in film or theatre can offer a child undreamed-of opportunities that it would seem churlish to turn down. Nicky Egerton's 11-year-old daughter, Tamsin Egerton Dick, is one of two child actors playing the lead role of Mary in the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of The Secret Garden. Egerton, who acts as Tamsin's chaperone, says that in the past year her daughter has gone from playing parts in a local youth theatre in Petersfield to completing her first film. The Mists of Avalon, which appears on American television in June, was shot in Prague, where Tamsin played opposite Anjelica Huston and Julianna Margulies. There were plenty of thrills during filming: limos to and from the luxury hotel, meeting famous film stars, and a fantastic costume.

"She particularly liked Anjelica Huston," says Egerton. "They'd sit and have a little tete-à-tete. She enjoyed every minute."

Egerton is adamant that Tamsin is acting only because she wants to; her parents see their role as helping her to achieve her goals. She says her daughter showed an interest in the stage from the age of three, when she volunteered to sing at the local panto: "She sang her little song and it didn't make her nervous, she enjoyed it." By the age of eight, she was performing with a local youth theatre when her name was put forward for a part in a children's television series. When she lost that role to a girl with more experience and an agent, Tamsin signed on with Sylvia Young.

Theatre work, says Egerton, is much more intensive than film. For The Secret Garden, there are daily rehearsals and three hours of schoolwork with an RSC tutor. If the run goes well, there is the possibility of a transfer to the West End - and other film work may come up, as feedback from Tamsin's American director has been positive.

But the experience is not always so rosy. Kate Evans, a casting director who auditions children for film, commercial and modelling jobs at Kate and Allie Casting, attests to the industry's more ruthless aspect. "Children are rejected all the time for parts," she remarks, "and I can't imagine what that does to them."

For parents, however, there is the very adult fear that if they turn down a job for their child, the next one will never come along. "What you worry about is that she'll have this intense period and then it all goes quiet," says Egerton. "Will she feel disappointed? What you don't want is for your child, aged 11, to feel washed out and empty."

According to Evans, it is worse when a child is wheedled into performing because they are living out the parents' unfulfilled ambitions. "I've seen bribery, all sorts of things go on to get a child to perform," she says.

The scenario where a child is cajoled into cooperating by a frantic parent with the promise of a Happy Meal afterwards is wearyingly familiar. "The better parents are the ones who are more relaxed, and that shows in the child's personality," Evans observes.

But the demands of managing a child actor's career can take its toll on family life. While Nicky Egerton was away with Tamsin for eight months, her 17-year-old daughter went through her A levels and fell in love for the first time. "She needed guidance and her mother was on the end of a telephone," says Egerton. "Inevitably, the rest of the family suffers."

Having a child doing the round of auditions is a major commitment: Evans says some will have four castings at various London locations in a single afternoon. Lorraine Mulraney, whose nine-year-old son James-Steven is with the Norrie Carr agency, agrees that it is a massive juggling act to get to auditions during lunchtimes and after school. If she had other children, she says, it would be impossible, even though casting directors try to arrange schedules around school hours and holidays. Mulraney says that she isn't bothered whether James-Steven gets the job he has auditioned for: "If you are the sort of parent that gets worried, then you're in the wrong business."

But James-Steven, like many children in theatre, finds it hard when someone else is picked for the part. "I just feel put down, I think, 'Oh, I didn't get it.' " And while his mother can shuffle her work schedule to fit in auditions, James-Steven says he groans at the thought of how long an audition can take.

Dr John Radford, a psychologist and author of Child Prodigies and Exceptional Early Achievers, says that what a child gets from acting depends on the decisions the parents make on his or her behalf. "They must decide how far they want their child to go," he argues, "and balance the advantages of their child earning money with the need to hold on to a normal course of development, while protecting them from too much publicity.

"Some children revel in public life and others find it a bit too much. The parents have to make that decision about how much they can cope with."

The other danger is that if a child is spending formative years learning lines and attending auditions, they may be neglecting other talents. Dr Radford cites the case of child mathematicians who become obsessed with calculus to the exclusion of other subjects, let alone play with their peers. "The problem with many child stars," says Radford, "is that you have to close off the options because you have to put in the hours of rehearsing."

Child stars must inevitably confront the problem that Macaulay Culkin is still tackling. Children sometimes grow out of what made them attractive in the first place: there is never any guarantee that they can make the transition to an acting career beyond childhood. Tamsin is now over 5ft tall; if The Secret Garden transfers to the West End, she may literally have grown out of the part.

 The RSC production of The Secret Garden opens on November 28 at the Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon

fields.headline: Three's a crowd
fields.standfirst: When Patricia Thompson's IVF treatment resulted, unexpectedly, in triplets, she sued the fertility clinic.  Simon Bebbington  and his partner had the same experience - but they were too busy coping with their terrible trio to go to court
fields.trailText: When Patricia Thompson's IVF treatment resulted, unexpectedly, in triplets, she sued the fertility clinic. Simon Bebbington and his partner had the same experience - but they were too busy coping with their terrible trio to go to court.
fields.body:
It sounds easy. If you end up with triplets through IVF, you can simply "reduce" the number of embryos to two. That was what a Sheffield fertility centre would have told its patient Patricia Thompson. She and husband Peter opted to implant only two embryos but, contrary to their wishes, the clinic put back three. As a result, she became pregnant with triplets. Having decided against any "embryo reduction", the couple made headlines last week when they successfully sued the clinic for - they hope - the £100,000 cost of bringing up the third child. My partner and I received the same advice about embryo reduction when pursuing similar treatment. But after we discovered that we were expecting triplets, life became such a harrowing succession of conflicting emotions, lack of information and a shrinking time frame, that making a rational decision became near impossible.

When we went for IVF, we had not contemplated the idea of triplets. One baby would do nicely, or maybe twins, we'd thought - probably much like the Thompsons. The fertility specialist advised us to have three eggs put back, to increase the chances of one taking (good for us, good for the clinic's success rating). It was unlikely all three would implant, we were told: only 1.6% of its pregnancies led to triplets. And if they did all take, we could reduce the number of embryos to increase the chances of taking home a baby. Simple.

So three eggs were put back. But if there is a percentage, someone has to be it: the scan at week eight showed it was us. Diane was incubating a trio of healthy egg sacs. Our joy imploded as the magnitude of our dilemma dawned on us. We had to decide whether to kill off one embryo to give the other two a better chance. Or not.

The argument for reducing is strong. Twins on the whole stand as much chance of having a birth defect or genetic abnormality as an average singleton baby. But triplets fare worse. They are always born prematurely (before 36 weeks' gestation), and only half reach the "safe" point of 29 weeks, when they are on a parity with singletons. Those born before significantly risk a disability ranging from dyslexia through cerebral palsy to a vegetative state. Or they may die.

Carrying three foetuses also increases the risk of miscarriage. But the reduction procedure itself - inserting a needle into the embryo's heart to stop it beating - may also induce miscarriage of the other foetuses.

We knew that any embryo showing a genetic abnormality would be selected for termination. The problem was that the usual blood and sampling tests would prove ineffective with so many babies. We had to wait in limbo until the ultrasound scan could pick up enough detail to show any defect. In week 12, all were healthy. One boy, one girl, one wouldn't open its legs. We mentioned reduction. The first available appointment with the consultant was in two weeks.

A fortnight later our consultant - a specialist in multiple births - said he would have no qualms about reducing our embryo count. Medically, it made sense to cut the chances of premature birth. He added that, if we kept all three, it was likely that they would be shipped to other hospitals for care during their first few weeks of life. NHS neonatal cots were funded, he said, on the natural rate of triplets, but IVF has nearly trebled that rate. The upshot is that the NHS has to fly vulnerable newborns to wherever incubators are available. Aberdeen was mentioned. We live in London. So he'd happily take away the easiest embryo to get at. To lessen the chance of miscarriage, he needed the decision by Friday. This was Tuesday.

We went home and wept. We talked over the arguments. All the embryos were fine. Could we live with ourselves if we killed off one for the sake of the others? How could we face the resultant twins knowing there could have been another? And how would we feel if the reduction procedure caused a miscarriage and we lost them all - after all the years of trying?

Then again, if we kept all three, they might miscarry naturally. Or come too early, with all the related risks. We knew triplets would be hard work, but could we cope if one was disabled? What was the chance of catastrophic brain damage rather than a learning disability? The obstetricians and multiple-birth groups did not know the answer: all the disabilities, from dyslexia to severe brain damage, were lumped together in one statistic.

On the Wednesday, I made a desperate call to the one hospital department I thought could help, but which no one had mentioned. I telephoned the neonatal unit and begged information. No one could come to the phone. By a stroke of luck, a wonderful nurse saw my message, pulled our file from the twins clinic, then set up a meeting first thing on Thursday with a senior nurse and the professor who headed the unit. They talked us through the risks and rates of disabilities and their treatability, then showed us around the unit full of red and ratty-looking premature babies. We searched our hearts. We went upstairs and told the obstetrician to keep his needle in the drawer.

Then life got really tough. Diane went into a catastrophically premature labour. Our hospital's neonatal unit was full so she was sent to the nearest with three incubators - fortunately, still in London. And then, as the Thompsons have attested, the real work began. Being home alone with three babies is an exhausting version of plate-spinning - you just finish with the third and the first needs attention again - with possets on.

When they first came home, they were feeding every three hours. As it took up to 40 minutes to change, feed and wind each one, that left one hour in every cycle to wash 18-plus bottles a day, make up formula milk, bathe, cuddle and entertain them, then feed yourself and do household chores. We ended up sleeping in shifts (five hours each) and became adept at bottle-feeding while still technically asleep.

We become a spectator sport for the general public when we go out, especially if they're in the quad buggy. The plus side is the adulation they receive; the down side is the dumb questions.

Most passers-by tend to blurt out an involuntary "Oh my God!" when they catch sight of the buggyful, while the standard I-wish-I-had-a-pound-for-every-time-I've-heard-that comment is: "Bet you've got your hands full." You don't say.

webTitle: Parents: Author  Andrea Ashworth on being abused as a child

fields.headline: When I was a little girl
fields.standfirst:
This week a survey found that 1m British children suffer violence at home. Author Andrea Ashworth, who was abused as a child, is at least glad it's out in the open
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: This week a survey found that 1m British children suffer violence at home. Author Andrea Ashworth, who was abused as a child, is at least glad it's out in the open.
fields.body:
When I was a little girl, my mother wore sunglasses a lot of the time - even when it was raining. Under the glasses, her skin would be swollen and sometimes cut. My sisters and I watched each bruise go through its sickening rainbow - scarlet, purple and yellow, green, black and blue - before her face was itself again.

My father had drowned when I was five years old, my little sister three. My mother married a new man, with whom she had a baby, and from that moment we lived in a terrifying, topsy-turvy world. My stepfather would hit us, about the head and in the face, for any reason or no reason at all: a splash of spilled water, a misplaced sock, even the sight of my sister or me reading a book. Occasionally, when he was especially careless, I would be thrown into a concussion. If my mother cried or tried to stop our stepfather from hurting us, he would turn on her. We regularly saw our mother being throttled, punched in the face, hurled against the wall or the floor and threatened with boiling water and knives.

After each explosion, my stepfather would thrust his hand over my face until I gagged. He whispered foul, graphic threats to let me know just what he would do if ever I, the eldest child, opened my mouth to tell. He made me terrified of confiding in my own mother about his private assaults on me. I never dreamed of telling the world what went on behind our stripy green curtains.

At school, my nickname was Smiler. I scooted around the playground, a vivacious child, giving my teachers no cause for concern. Even without my stepfather's threats and the clamp of his hand over my mouth, I would not have dared - back then - to appeal to a teacher or any "outsider" for help. I put my smile on, over the secrets, and waited for it to be knocked off again when I went home.

Why? Why didn't I say a word?

In the first place, although my sisters and I lived in daily terror, it never occurred to me that we could, or even should, expect anything different. Children can be marvellously, but also dangerously, elastic, adapting to adversity, growing to regard it as normal. As I grew up, I began to realise that what went on in my family was not normal but quite horrific. Seeing this, I was struck dumb by a deep sense of shame. Domestic abuse was not, in the 70s and early 80s, something to be discussed in public. I had never even heard of terms such as neglect or abuse, let alone imagined them being applied to my family. Moreover my mother and sisters and I suffered a sense of guilt about what was done to us, as if we deserved it. Like many victims, we were caught in a web of silence, woven from sticky strands of guilt and fear, desperate hope, shame and, stickiest of all, love.

Just before I left home at the age of 18, I climbed into a tiny aeroplane, took off into the clouds and turned green, going through loop-the-loops and barrel rolls on a sponsored aerobatic flight that helped to raise money for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. I wasn't sure why I was doing it, why I had chosen to support that cause, what that cause was exactly. I puked my insides out on the third loop and came down giggling, feeling drunk. I was still someone behind whose big smile lurked an agonising story.

Suffering in silence, my family and I went through experiences that are, in all ways, unspeakable. This shroud of silence, psychologically suffocating and literally lethal, was - and is - one of the most insidious aspects of domestic abuse. Especially for children whose voices are small. The NSPCC's latest survey reveals that child abuse is, as we ought to have known, and cared about, all along, shockingly widespread. Children desperately need to be rescued from daily torment and from futures in which they will recycle mental, physical and sexual abuse, painfully reliving it, and passing it on.

Thanks to the passionate and messy work of charities like the NSPCC, thanks to a salutary swing in the media's searchlights, thanks to our efforts to look at and understand ourselves as a society, stories like mine are no longer so shamefully suppressed. Families do not have to fester in secret. Smashing the silence is a crucial first step in smashing a cycle that we have lived with too quietly, too long.

 Once in a House on Fire is published in paperback by Picador at £6.99.

fields.headline: LA fights Hollywood split
fields.standfirst:
Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles on Tinseltown's planned secession

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles on Tinseltown's planned secession.
fields.body:
Nobody wins in a divorce, the deputy mayor of Los Angeles, Ben Austin, said this week. Nowhere in the world knows more about divorces than LA, where people get through them like frozen yogurts on a July afternoon.

So there is particular piquancy this week at the thought of what could be one of the city's biggest ever divorce cases: Hollywood is preparing to secede from Los Angeles.

This is a move that has been on the cards for some time, as Hollywood goes through the throes of seeking independence in a slightly less traumatic fashion than, say, the Balkans.

If all goes according to plan, Hollywood will have detached itself from LA by 2002. Then Hollywood would have its own government, police force and municipal services.

"The revolution is on," said Gene La Pietra, the chairman of the secession group Hollywood Voters Organised Towards Empowerment, which is leading the charge for independence. He was speaking this week in the wake of the news that 45,000 people out of a Hollywood population of 206,000 had signed a petition calling for the study which is the necessary prelude to secession.

If the study satisfies the criterion that neither Hollywood nor LA will be worse off after the break, then the secession will go before the voters in 2002.

To the rest of the world, Hollywood means the film industry, although - just as Fleet Street is no longer the home of newspapers in Britain, but is still used to describe the business - it has been many years since Hollywood was the actual home of film-making, with the exception of Paramount studios.

However, if Hollywood becomes a separate city, LA knows it will no longer be able to claim to be the capital of the world's entertainment industry - so battle lines are already being drawn.

The Hollywood secessionists argue that they will benefit from a smaller, less centralised government. The same arguments are also advanced by San Fernando Valley and the Harbour area, both of which seek independence in 2002.

If this all went through, it would leave LA as something of a shell - like London minus Soho, the southern suburbs and Docklands. "Hollywood is not just the city of the stars, it's the city of the people, too," says La Pietra.

Certainly Hollywood long since ceased to be a fabulously glamourous place and now has a distinctly tacky, Carnaby Street feel.

The secessionists hope that they will be able to improve on that image if they become independent. The mayor of LA, Richard Riordan, and his deputy, Ben Austin, are fighting the secession. "Part of the strength of LA is our rich cultural, ethnic and geographic diversity," said Austin after the petition was counted.

"Nobody wins in a divorce." Hollywood has many of the prerequisites of the modern city: its own sign (enough said), its own museum (Fredericks's of Hollywood Lingerie Museum) and its own ready-made twin city (Bollywood)

And one benefit of independence might mean that LA would finally be spared from being saddled with the dismissive and dated nickname of Tinseltown.

But surely there is a good Californian solution at hand: no divorce, but a sensible palimony agreement.

webTitle: Blair: time to move on from Thatcher

fields.headline: Blair: time to move on from Thatcher
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText:
Prime minister responds to attack from former Tory leader
Special report: European integration
fields.body:
Tony Blair today launched an all-out counter-attack against Baroness Thatcher after she hit out at his plans for Britain to sign up to a European rapid reaction force.

The prime minister used a Downing Street press conference to denounce what he said was Lady Thatcher's legacy of "boom and bust" economics, social division and chronic under-investment in public services.

Her policies on Europe had been wrong for Britain and that it was now time for the country to move forward into a new era, he said.

"I take nothing away from those things that were done in the 1980s that we have kept, but it really is time in my view that we move British politics beyond the time of Margaret Thatcher," Mr Blair went on.

"We are in a new era. Today we have to deal with those problems that we inherited from that time - the boom and bust economics, the social division, the chronic under-investment in our public services. "A sensible, modern attitude to Europe is what we need."

Baroness Thatcher, interviewed last night on the eve of the 10th anniversary of her departure from Downing Street, described the new European defence force as "monumental folly".

Lady Thatcher told the Sun: "The government's plans to create a new European army make no military sense at all. None to Britain, whose forces are already over stretched. None to Europe, which has even less chance of becoming a military power than of creating a sound currency.

"And none to Nato, which this proposal threatens to divide and destroy.It is a piece of monumental folly that puts our security at risk in order to satisfy political vanity."

Lady Thatcher's intervention in the political row over the new force came after the Tory leader, William Hague, said the party would seek to turn it into a general election issue, and committed a future Conservative government to pulling British troops out of the new structure.

Mr Hague insisted: "It is not too late for Mr Blair to change course and say we are going to bring this all back within Nato to meet all these concerns ... This will be a general election issue."

Lord Tebbit, formerly one of Lady Thatcher's closest allies, said today that mutual respect between her and Mr Blair had evaporated "a long time ago".

"She did not take that long to discover that what he was saying about his Eurosceptic and Thatcherite credentials was purely for electoral purposes," he told BBC Radio 4's World at One.

"I think he wanted to ride on her coat tails for as long as he could so perhaps it is only recently that he has felt bold enough to decide to desert that position."

fields.headline: Richard Desmond: the inside story
fields.trailText: 2.15:pm Richard Desmond has been thrust under the media spotlight by the bidding war for the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star. MediaGuardian.co.uk gives the low-down on the would-be newspaper tycoon. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Who is Richard Desmond?

The 49-year-old publishing tycoon was born in Edgware, north London, in 1951. He now lives in the ultra-posh London "village" of Hampstead, on Bishop's Avenue, a road known to locals as "Millionaire's Row".

He was 44th in the latest Sunday Times rich list, soaring 200 places in 12 months thanks to the success of his Northern & Shell publishing empire.

How did he start Northern & Shell?

Mr Desmond began his career in advertising sales. He used the money to open record shops and published his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974.

In 1983 he launched the UK version of Penthouse following a deal with Bob Guccione, the US publisher of the top-shelf magazine.

He produced a British version and his empire went on from there with titles from Mountain Bike to Asian Babes.

What is the most famous title in his portfolio?

OK! magazine is the bitter rival of Hello in the battle for top UK celebrity magazine. Launched as a monthly magazine in 1993, it went weekly three years later and is now one of the Britain's biggest selling titles with a circulation of more than 600,000.

Just last weekend he shelled out £1.2m for exclusive rights to Catherine Zeta Jones' wedding to Michael Douglas.

Why has he been dubbed the People's Pornographer?

His other titles include Forum, Asian Babes, Penthouse and Women on Top. The sexier titles are produced at arm's length from the Northern & Shell brand, by using the Portland Investments company.

Does that mean the Express is going to introduce Page 3 Babes?

Mr Desmond insists he has no intention of interfering with the editorial of the paper. However the Daily Star is likely to benefit from his top-shelf expertise.

The Express will also get much-needed investment showbusiness with regular tie-ups with OK! magazine. This will give the Daily Mail its first real challenge for celebrity pictures and stories in the middle market.

Why is Mr Desmond buying the Express titles?

He wants to bring greater prestige to the Northern & Shell brand before a £500m flotation. The presence of the Express and Sunday Express titles may convince doubtful investors to dig into their pockets.

fields.headline: Hindujas 'bewildered' as OK! closes in on Express
fields.standfirst: 9am: OK! nears Express deal
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The Hinduja brothers are bewildered by reports that Richard Desmond has beaten them in the battle for the Express titles, writes Dan Milmo.
9am: OK! nears Express deal
fields.body:
The billionaire Hinduja brothers are bewildered by reports that OK! magazine owner Richard Desmond has beaten them in the battle for the Express newspapers.

A spokesperson for the Hindujas said: "Nothing has given us any reason to believe that we are not in a serious position to acquire these titles, and we believe that we are still the most credible purchaser."

The Hindujas reacted to reports today that Mr Desmond, owner of OK! magazine, is close to tying up a £125m deal with Express owner United News & Media.

But the Hindujas' lawyers were also in talks with Lord Hollick's United yesterday and have every confidence that they will pull off a deal.

Industry sources said the Hindujas were surprised by the closeness of the race, as they were considered outright favourites until the beginning of this week, when Mr Desmond's hat was dramatically thrown into the ring.

The Hindujas do not own UK newspaper interests, and will therefore escape the clutches of regulators if their bid is accepted.

This scenario has contributed to the Daily Mail's retreat to the back of the chasing pack, as the United board would have to wait for the thumbs-up from watchdogs before closing a deal.

However, Mr Desmond also offers a speedy sale as he does not own any UK newspapers, and he is now set to trump his rivals in the bidding war.

He wants the titles to boost his publishing empire ahead of a planned £500m flotation.

Lord Hollick is also desperate to shot of the titles and considers them "a complete distraction" at a time when he is trying to transform his company into a business media concern.

One source said: "It is certainly a closer run race than the Hindujas originally thought, but this is not a normal bid process. Mr Desmond's negotiations are more advanced than expected, thoughthe Hindujas still feel a deal is far from closed."

Sources close to both bidders said the parallel negotiations have caused an unnecessary drag on the speed of the sale, and neither party knows if United is talking to other buyers.

fields.headline: Hindujas back in Express race
fields.standfirst:
10.45am: Hindujas 'bewildered"
9am: OK! nears Express deal
fields.trailText:
12.45pm update: The Hinduja brothers are firmly back in the race for Express newspapers after holding talks advisers to United News & Media boss Lord Hollick. By Dan Milmo.
10.45am: Hindujas 'bewildered"
9am: OK! nears Express deal
fields.body:
The Hinduja brothers are firmly back in the race for Express newspapers after holding talks this morning with advisers to United News & Media boss Lord Hollick.

The talks put paid to claims that rival bidder OK! magazine owner Richard Desmond had all but sealed a bid following intense negotiations last night.

Mr Desmond entered the bidding after lodging a £125m offer with vendor United, but the Hindujas have confirmed they are still in the race for the titles.

A spokesperson for the Hindujas said: "We are still very much in the running, and spoke to United News & Media's advisers an hour ago. It is business as usual, and we will be firming up the price shortly."

If the tussle for control comes down to money, the Hindujas will have to hit the top of their price range, which is reported to hover around £120m.

This morning's meeting with United's moneymen has taken the Hindujas a step closer to establishing their offer price, with Mr Desmond's bid upping the pressure.

United will want the maximum financial return for its shareholders, which places Mr Desmond's bid in the lead.

"The brothers are now at a stage where they can close in on a price," added the source.

The billionaire brothers are known to be interested in selling on the Daily Star, part of the Express group if they win control of the newspapers.

The Star would fit perfectly in the portfolio of Mr Desmond's publishing empire, which includes top-shelf titles such as Penthouse and Asian Babes.

webTitle: Matthew Freud sees Star hopes fade

fields.headline: Matthew Freud sees Star hopes fade
fields.trailText: 3pm: PR guru Matthew Freud admitted that the Daily Star was unlikely to be sold by Richard Desmond when he takes over Express newspapers. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
PR guru Matthew Freud has admitted that he is unlikely to buy the Daily Star following OK! boss Richard Desmond's acquisition of Express newspapers.

Mr Freud was set to team up with Virgin Radio owner Chris Evans and television producer Lord Alli in a bid for the Star if it became available.

However, he said today that Mr Desmond, owner of the Asian Babes and Penthouse magazines, will almost certainly want to keep the tabloid.

Mr Freud's consortium had hoped to buy the Star from rival bidders the Hinduja brothers, who were close to winning control of the Express and were keen on selling the paper.

"My guess is that of all the bidders, Mr Desmond would be the one most interested in the Star, so it's probably not a good thing for us," said Mr Freud.

He added that he talks to Mr Desmond "from time to time" and that he would be in contact with the publishing tycoon.

webTitle: Express sold to OK! at last

fields.headline: Express sold to OK! at last
fields.trailText: 4pm update: The Express newspapers will be a must-read for women under 34, says its new owner, OK! magazine publisher Richard Desmond. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
OK! magazine owner Richard Desmond has bought The Express newspaper group for £125m cash, it was confirmed today.

And the new owner of the Express has revealed plans to make the paper a hip and trendy publication for 18 to 34 year old females.

Speaking for the first time since the deal was clinched, Mr Desmond said: "The Express represents a vital part of Britain's press heritage of which Northern & Shell are proud to have the stewardship of in the 21st Century."

They said they were committed to "innovation and investment".

Mr Desmond added that the editors of the three papers in the group would report to Paul Ashford, who is editorial director of Northern & Shell, Mr Desmond's publishing empire.

He also put paid to fears that the titles would be exiled to the company's Docklands headquarters, assuring journalists today that they papers would remain at Ludgate House.

A panel of experts will be introduced to maintain the paper's editorial integrity and the paper will be "issue led" not "party led".

Mr Desmond declared that the papers would offer "powerful and passionate advocacy on matters of national concern".

However the papers showbusiness coverage, long seen as inferior to that of arch rival the Daily Mail's, will be stepped up immediately.

Mr Desmond declined to give details but said the paper would engage in "colourful celebrity coverage where appropriate."

Tie-ups with OK! magazine are expected on a regular basis.

The papers would engage in "colourful celebrity coverage where appropriate", he said.

Lord Hollick who has owned the Express titles since 1996 said: "The management and journalists of the Express and Star can take enormous credit for the success in strengthening both titles over the last few years. We wish the papers, and their new owners, all th ebest for the next phase of their development."

The cash deal gives Mr Desmond control of the three national newspapers, the Express, Sunday Express, the Daily Star and the highly lucrative Westferry printing plant.

webTitle: Desmond: the right CV for the job?

fields.headline: Desmond: the right CV for the job?
fields.trailText: So another rich entrepreneur with no experience of running newspapers - especially struggling newspapers - takes over the Express Group. By Peter Preston.
fields.body:
So another rich entrepreneur with no experience of running newspapers - especially struggling newspapers - takes over the Express Group.

Mr Desmond knows about celebrity and soft porn magazines: the departing Lord Hollick knew about television. But Lord Hollick quickly found - and Richard Desmond will find - that newspapers are different, posing utterly different challenges.

A magazine like OK! can carve a lucrative niche for itself on flair and a deep pocket. There is a market for film and TV stars selling their wedding (or divorce) pictures to a glossy magazine. Hello! showed the way: OK! followed.

But the crossover market with daily newspapers is strictly limited. The two Expresses, Daily and Sunday, have been losing circulation for over 30 years and both now stand on the brink of financial losses. The Daily Star survives as a modest profit maker because its cost structures depend on the whole Express stable.

Perhaps a red-top tabloid like the Star can survive and even prosper for a while through links with a men's magazine empire (though the preciptous decline of the Daily Sport would raise questions even there) but the Daily and Sunday Express stand scant chance of recovery unless they can compete at every level with the Daily Mail - and that means huge investment over many years.

Lord Hollick talked of the "synergies" between television and daily newspapers, but never developed those synergies. Now he's sold out to a bidder with no newspaper experience, and thus no problems under competition law. It is a rather shaming retreat from his previous policies and rhetoric. Maybe Richard Desmond, with his proven elan, will fare better.

But a newspaper needs more than the occasional celebrity picture spread. It needs good sports, good politics, good features and good news. It also needs to find a place for itself in a competitive market where those things, dearly bought, can be made gradually to count.

There are no miracles here - especially with a brand as depleted as the Express brand and a readership profile which is one of the oldest in Fleet Street.

Those of us who love newspapers will hope that this purchase turns out OK - but we won't, alas, be holding our breath.

webTitle: Byers pledges e-commerce help for deprived areas

fields.headline: Byers pledges e-commerce help for deprived areas
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has put tackling regional disparities in business startups and new technology at the top of the government's policy agenda.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has put tackling regional disparities in business startups and new technology at the top of the government's policy agenda.

Speaking at a Local Government Association regeneration conference in Liverpool, Mr Byers said action was needed to tackle the "digital divide".

He highlighted government figures showing that one in five north-east businesses do not have internet access, compared with just one in 20 in London. While a third of companies in London traded online, less than a quarter did so in the north-east and south-west.

Business startups were also lower in the north-east, with no part of the region hitting the UK average of 38 new firms per 10,000 residents in 1999. In Camden, London, the figure was 146.

Mr Byers said: "Action is needed at a local level to encourage new businesses to grow and to help existing and traditional industries in all of our regions to adapt to the new global internet economy. The UK simply cannot afford to allow the development of a digital divide."

Money from the government's £30m phoenix fund, aimed at helping new businesses get off the ground, will be directed at boosting e-enterprises in deprived areas, Mr Byers said.

The government has already announced a range of proposals to develop e-business. These include a team of e-commerce advisers and "internet incubator" projects to provide new online companies with support.

Mr Byers said, however, that the disparities were more complex than a simple regional divide. The government has always maintained that inequalities within regions are as significant as those between them.

As an example, Byers pointed to the low rate of startups in London's Greenwich - just 32 per 10,000 residents. On the other hand, the east midlands towns of Wellingborough and Mansfield had 90 and 23 start-ups respectively.

fields.headline: Jewish settlements must go
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian writer Daoud Kuttab makes a strongly worded plea for Israel to withdraw from Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian writer Daoud Kuttab makes a strongly worded plea for Israel to withdraw from Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
fields.body:
My brother-in-law Labib runs the Palestinian Bible Society. Its main office is in East Jerusalem, with others in Bethlehem, Ramallah and Nablus. A couple of years ago, the Society opened an office and a bookstore in the centre of Gaza city.

Like many things in the Palestinian territories during the past two months, work has come to a standstill, and there is now no one to run the bookstore. The manager from the West Bank has been home since the closure.

Last week, Labib thought he would go to Gaza to check that the store had not been damaged by recent Israeli shelling. Normally Labib, a resident of Jerusalem, is allowed into Gaza. This time, however, the Israelis at the Erez checkpoint would not let him in. They said that the army has issued a blanket order forbidding any Israeli from entering Gaza. As a resident of Jerusalem, Labib is technically considered an Israeli and was therefore refused permission to enter.

The ban was, of course, not limited to east Jerusalemites. Others, including Palestinian citizens of Israel, were also banned, as well as a delegation of Israeli Arab Knesset members. Ahmad Tibi, one of the Palestinians who helped broker the recent unsuccessful ceasefire agreement between Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, was among those forbidden entry. In defending the ban on the normally immune Knesset members, Israel Radio quoted an Israeli official as saying that the ban was for the safety of Israelis and that this applied to regular Israelis as well as Knesset members.

In times of conflict, it is customary for countries to issue travel advisories; they warn people not to travel to certain trouble spots, and, at times of high danger, they make it a crime for their citizens to travel to certain dangerous countries.

But what is curious is that this normally natural action of trying to safeguard your people is not implemented for the Jewish settlers living in the occupied Palestinian territories.

In 33 years of occupation, no Israeli official has ever advised Jewish settlers not to travel to the West Bank or the Gaza Strip. Certainly no Israeli government or military official has ever physically barred settlers from entering these "dangerous" areas. The Israeli army merely orders settlers to coordinate their travel schedules with them and, in times of danger, they provide them with military escorts.

In the propaganda war that parallels the shooting, bombing and shelling of Palestinians, Israel and its apologists continuously attack Palestinians for allowing children into the battle zone. Israeli spin doctors even go so far as to claim that Palestinian officials, and even parents, literally push their children to the front lines so that they can get killed and thereby rack up PR points for Palestinians.

Last week, in an interview with the father of a boy killed in Ramallah, the father explained how he was unable to keep his son locked up at home. He said he had brought him home ten times, only to have his son go back out every time.

Palestinian minister of culture and information, Yaser Abed Rabo, stated last week that the Palestinian police have been instructed to keep children under 16 away from the areas of confrontations. But Jewish settlers are not even asked to stay away, even though all the violence is taking place around the settlements.

Jewish leaders have often repeated the statement that it is better to save life than land. The futile defence of these Jewish settlements is a perfect example of life being wasted, for the protection of a few buildings surrounded by barbed wire.

Recently, the Israeli Peace Now movement called these settlements a burden on the Israeli army. In advertisements published in both Israeli and Palestinian press, they called on Israel's president Ehud Barak to withdraw from many of these settlements.

For 400 Jewish settlers in Hebron, 30,000 Palestinians have been placed under curfew for weeks. In Gaza, where 3,000 settlers are living on one third of the land, there is little logic in holding on to these settlements. In the Camp David II talks, Israel indicated that it planned to quit all the Gaza settlements. The time is now ripe for uprooting some of them as a gesture of good will

In the negotiations over the implementation of the Oslo Agreement, Palestinians pleaded with Israel's former president, Yitzhak Rabin, to withdraw from the settlements of Netzarim and Kfar Darom, but Mr Rabin claimed that he had promised not to withdraw from any settlements during the interim phase.

Now that that phase is over, there is no reason why these settlements, built provocatively in the centre of populated Palestinian areas, should stay.

If the Israelis do not want to look weak by simply leaving these settlements, they can opt to have them turned over to a neutral third party for safekeeping until permanent status talks produce a treaty dealing with the future of all settlements. But to keep Israeli soldiers protecting them, and to escort civilians under army protection in and out of them, is simply a formula for continued bloodshed.

The Israeli army merely orders settlers to coordinate their travel schedules with them and, in times of danger, they provide them with military escorts. In the propaganda war that parallels the shooting, bombing and shelling of Palestinians, Israel and its apologists continuously attack Palestinians for allowing children into the battle zone. Israeli spin doctors even go so far as to claim that Palestinian officials, and even parents, literally push their children to the front lines so that they can get killed and thereby rack up PR points for Palestinians. Last week, in an interview with the father of a boy killed in Ramallah, the father explained how he was unable to keep his son locked up at home. He said he had brought him home ten times, only to have his son go back out every time. Palestinian minister of culture and information, Yaser Abed Rabo, stated last week that the Palestinian police have been instructed to keep children under 16 away from the areas of confrontations. But Jewish settlers are not even asked to stay away, even though all the violence is taking place around the settlements. Jewish leaders have often repeated the statement that it is better to save life than land. The futile defence of these Jewish settlements is a perfect example of life being wasted, for the protection of a few buildings surrounded by barbed wire. Recently, the Israeli Peace Now movement called these settlements a burden on the Israeli army. In advertisements published in both Israeli and Palestinian press, they called on Israel's president Ehud Barak to withdraw from many of these settlements. For 400 Jewish settlers in Hebron, 30,000 Palestinians have been placed under curfew for weeks. In Gaza, where 3,000 settlers are living on one third of the land, there is little logic in holding on to these settlements. In the Camp David II talks, Israel indicated that it planned to quit all the Gaza settlements. The time is now ripe for uprooting some of them as a gesture of good will In the negotiations over the implementation of the Oslo Agreement, Palestinians pleaded with Israel's former president, Yitzhak Rabin, to withdraw from the settlements of Netzarim and Kfar Darom, but Mr Rabin claimed that he had promised not to withdraw from any settlements during the interim phase. Now that that phase is over, there is no reason why these settlements, built provocatively in the centre of populated Palestinian areas, should stay. If the Israelis do not want to look weak by simply leaving these settlements, they can opt to have them turned over to a neutral third party for safekeeping until permanent status talks produce a treaty dealing with the future of all settlements. But to keep Israeli soldiers protecting them, and to escort civilians under army protection in and out of them, is simply a formula for continued bloodshed. fields.headline: Name game
fields.standfirst: 'Community fund' to replace NLCB
fields.trailText: 'Community fund' to replace NLCB
fields.body:
When even your own cabinet minister mangles your institution's name, it's clearly time for a change. Which is one reason why the national lottery charities board (NLCB) will disappear in four months' time.

There is no need for the voluntary sector to tremble, though; the board's £280m a year grants, familiar staff and processes will carry on as usual, but from April they will be branded as the "community fund".

A hefty bill will no doubt follow for 18 months of focus groups and image advice by Brandsmiths consultancy, plus new stationery and sorting out of temporary client befuddlement. But champagne - or the modest third sector equivalent - is being cracked open at the quango's stately central London HQ, just off Trafalgar Square, at a change many staff have wanted since day one in 1995.

Paul Hensby, the board's chief press officer, says: "The name is confusing and doesn't help us get the money to small groups in particular." Colleagues elaborate that the first two words in the name have caused endless muddle with lottery operator Camelot or with controversial grants - the Royal Opera House, the Churchill papers - made by other distributors. The last two words, meanwhile, "smack of the lady bountiful or the grim-faced charity committees you get in Dickens", according to NLCB veterans sounded out as part of the name review.

Enthusiasm for something more contemporary had to be reined in, though, when at a relatively late stage in the process the thoroughly New Labour notion of the "people fund" was the frontrunner. Dummy logos had been prepared, but it was pointed out internally that people do not qualify for NLCB grants and, more seriously, that the name was alarmingly close to Sir Richard Branson's brand for the weekly gamble, should he win the franchise.

The new name, says Hensby, "will appeal to groups wanting lottery funds for community purposes, as well as larger charities". In that respect, it stands to chime with the way the NLCB has become the sole funder of some community sectors: women's refuges in Sheffield, for instance, are almost entirely dependent on lottery funding.

Culture secretary Chris Smith has already approved the change in principle. As one of the many who find the singulars and plurals in "national lottery charities board" all but impossible to master, he is expected to welcome "community fund".

webTitle: NHS cash boost for 'unsafe' buildings and equipment

fields.headline: NHS cash boost for 'unsafe' buildings and equipment
fields.trailText: Many NHS buildings and facilities are unsafe, of low quality, and provide poor and inefficient levels of care because of lack of investment, the government admitted today. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
Many NHS buildings and facilities are unsafe, of low quality, and provide poor and inefficient levels of care because of lack of investment, the government admitted today.

In a review of NHS capital spending, the government admitted that NHS care is often compromised because vital medical equipment is not of a high enough standard, is too old, and takes too long to be replaced.

Many GP surgeries and health centres are "too small and cramped to provide modern primary care", said the report, published by the Department of Health (DoH). Four out of five primary care premises are "below the required size" and 14% are "in cramped conditions". Three out of every five GP premises are over 30 years old, it estimated.

The poor standard of NHS buildings and equipment means that much of it is "not suitable for the purpose it is meant to serve". The cost of raising the condition of the NHS to what it calls a "safe and functional level" is £3.4bn.

Health minister Alan Milburn today launched a three year investment strategy aimed at addressing the problems by increasing spending on new hospitals, medical equipment and family doctor premises.

Mr Milburn said the strategy would improve access to care and reduce waiting times for treatment, deliver improvements in care in priority areas such as cancer, and make facilities more efficient and patient friendly.

The government intends to invest over £1bn over the next five years to reduce the £3.4bn backlog bill for essential renovation and maintenance to £2.1bn.

The investment will be partly financed by selling off surplus NHS land and buildings. NHS surplus estate has a value of £1.58bn, according to government valuations. This will be sold off over the next six years.

A legacy of underinvestment in NHS facilities throughout the 1990s is blamed for the problems. Each NHS trust needs to spend an average of £71 for every square metre it owns to bring facilities up to scratch.

"Capital investment has been on a drip feed basis with each hospital receiving small amounts of capital resource," said the report. "This history of piecemeal development has led to a patchwork quilt estate, where hospitals mix and match old and inefficient estate with modern facililities."

fields.headline: Blair unveils science investment
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair, today said that £252m of new government funds for genome research, 'e-science' and basic technologies over the next three years would help the country stay at the forefront of scientific innovation in the 21st century.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair, today said that £252m of new government funds for genome research, 'e-science' and basic technologies over the next three years would help the country stay at the forefront of scientific innovation in the 21st century.

The government released the detailed allocations for research councils over the next three years, alongside a document setting out general investment plans for the public sector.

The science budget will grow by an average of 7% year on year in real terms over the next three years.

During a Downing Street briefing, Blair said that the science investment would enable the country to remain one of the leaders of scientific innovation. He conceded that science investment as a proportion of GDP still lagged behind other countries, but said that the government had to make a start.

The prime minister also said that R&D investment by businesses was improving.

"In 1997 Britain spent less than half the global average on R&D, and as a result the economy we inherited was one of the least productive of any major country," said Blair. "Last week we saw that spending on R&D by British business was up 10% last year. Still too low; but getting better."

The three cross cutting themes - genome research, 'e-science' and basic technologies - will benefit all the six research communities represented by the government's research councils. Genome research will receive £110m over three years, 'e-science' £98m over three years, and basic technologies £44m over three years.

But the Medical Research Council and the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council are the two councils gaining most from the funding settlement.

The MRC will receive £53m over three years for post-genomic science- the analysis of way genes function. One research programme will study the links between the genetic and environmental factors associated with major diseases, such as cancer and heart disease.

The EPSRC meanwhile will receive £32m over the next three years for the e-science initiative - covering research where communication via internet is now an essential tool. The council will also receive £41m over three years to develop basic technologies - the sensors and detector underpinning the work of researchers.

Treasury officials turned down proposals for another cross-cutting programme on environmental science. But director of the research councils, John Taylor, said that environmental researchers would benefit from the new funding arrangements.

webTitle: Private sector to invest £2bn in public projects

fields.headline: Private sector to invest £2bn in public projects
fields.trailText: The government will this year facilitate nearly £2bn in private sector investment in housing and regeneration, and the total is expected to rise next year. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
The government will this year facilitate nearly £2bn in private sector investment in housing and regeneration, and the total is expected to rise next year.

The figures were unveiled today in an investment strategy from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, setting out how it will spend its capital investment budget over the next three years.

The strategy focuses the DETR's investment on modernising social housing, regenerating communities and improving energy efficiency in 1m buildings.

It also reveals the extent to which private money is becoming a key factor in public spending.

The £2bn, which is to be invested in government-backed projects, is partly raised through public private partnerships and private finance initiative (PFI) deals set up by regional development agencies and the government regeneration body English Partnerships. Between them, they account for £739m in private sector investment, while the Housing Corporation brings in £657m and sales of council housing estates to housing associations and local housing companies another £600m. The government expects these agencies to bring in an additional £300m in private finance in 2001-02 on top of the projected £2bn.

Adding in projects involving local authorities, the PFI alone will generate an average £1bn a year in private investment in public sector projects over the next three years, double the amount for the last financial year.

The DETR's own capital spending, announced in this summer's comprehensive spending review, will rise from £5.3bn to £7.1bn over the review's three-year cycle.

fields.headline: MacLaurin defends Stewart
fields.trailText: Wednesday 1 November
fields.body:
Wednesday 1 November

Alec Stewart denies taking money from an Indian bookmaker for information related to cricket matches. Stewart was one of nine foreigners plus five Indians named in the Indian CBI report published today. The report alleges that Stewart received £5,000 from bookmaker Mukesh Kumar Gupta (or "John") in exchange for pitch, weather and team information. The report said the two were introduced by Indian allrounder Manoj Prabhakar in 1993.

In a statement, the ECB said: "Alec Stewart has fully cooperated with the ECB over this matter, and has categorically denied to Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the ECB, and Tim Lamb, chief executive, that he has ever taken money from Mr Gupta or anyone else, for providing information related to a cricket match. In fact, he denies ever knowingly having met Mr Gupta." Meanwhile Stewart will not be suspended from the England team. The ECB also proposed that Sir Paul Condon, head of the ICC's anti-corruption unit, investigate the report.

The most shattering inclusion in the report is the allegation that Brian Lara was paid $40,000 for playing badly in two one-day internationals. Sri Lankans Arjuna Ranatunga and Aravinda de Silva were also accused of match-fixing. Ranatunga says he's never had any dealings with bookies and rejected the allegation that he had under-performed in a Test which India won six years ago. Sri Lanka's Cricket Board said it would "most likely" call for a criminal investigation into the allegations .

The report, however, adds that Prabhakar's attempt to introduce Gupta to another West Indies cricketer, Gus Logie, failed.

New Zealand's Martin Crowe was allegedly offered money in exchange for information, but he says he was tricked after Gupta posed as a journalist.

The report also claims that Mohammad Azharuddin fixed matches and performances for Gupta, with the help of Ajay Jadeja and Nayan Mongia. Kapil Dev is exonerated by the report. Instead, it concluded that his accuser, Prabhakar, was close to several bookmakers. Former international allrounder, Ajay Sharma, is the other Indian implicated.

Ex-Australia batsman Dean Jones, who was named in the report, also denied any involvement in match-fixing. Speaking on radio, Jones said it was common knowledge that he had been approached but said he had nothing to hide.

Hansie Cronje, Salim Malik and Mark Waugh are the other non-Indians named. Waugh was fined by the ACB in 1995 along with Shane Warne after the pair admitted accepting money from a bookie for pitch reports. The CBI report alleges that $US20,000 was paid to Waugh on a tour of Sri Lanka in 1994. Malcolm Gray, President of ICC, says that the game is facing its biggest problems since Australian tycoon Kerry Packer launched his World Series Cricket revolution in the 1970s.

Thursday 2 November
Stewart says he has not knowingly met bookmaker Mukesh Gupta and that he has never traded cricket-related information for money. He says he's been in a state of shock since the allegations were made, and that the day they broke was one of the hardest of his life.

Reports say Mohammad Azharuddin confessed to the CBI that he had fixed two one-day internationals - one against South Africa in 1996 and another against Sri Lanka the following year. He also admitted he had thrown a one-day international against Pakistan in Jaipur in 1999. But the Indian investigators are convinced he threw many more.

It is revealed Gupta - at the centre of the CBI report - knew nothing about cricket until he walked past a betting group in 1984. He then educated himself about the game through books and the media - including the BBC.

The allegations against Stewart are to be looked at by Sir Paul Condon's ICC anti-corruption unit. Condon reveals his team are assisting Indian police examining the CBI report and South African officials investigating the scandal in conjunction with the King Commission. The Australian Cricket Board have also asked the unit, along with their own special investigator, Greg Melick, to look at the allegations against Mark Waugh.

Martin Crowe denies that, contrary to testimony in the CBI report, he was visited at his home by Gupta in 1991.

The United Cricket Board of South Africa's life ban on Cronje comes into effect today. The disgraced captain is to be excluded from all activities under the control of the Board. However, the Board's president Percy Sonn gives Cronje a glimmer of hope by suggesting that if Cronje repents and makes an effort to rehabilitate himself in the game through, for instance, the coaching of youngsters, the position may be reconsidered. He hints that the UCB would require Cronje to serve at least some of the ban, though, probably between two and five years.

Sri Lankan Cricket Board president Thilanga Sumithapala writes to the President of the Board of Control for Cricket in India, Dr Muttiah, to demand a copy of the CBI report. Sumithapala says he is "perturbed" at the allegations against de Silva and Ranatunga. Ranatunga also releases a statement denying he has been approached by a bookmaker.

Willie Rodriguez, the president of Brian Lara's home club, Queen's Park in Trinidad, says the allegations against the former West Indies captain are "not the worth the paper they're written on". Lara categorically denies the allegations and says the matter is in the hands of his lawyers.

Pat Rousseau, president of the West Indies Cricket Board, says he is "appalled" that Gus Logie is mentioned by the CBI, even though the report does not implicate him but merely says he refused to co-operate with match-fixers when they contacted him by phone. Rousseau also says the allegations against Lara "lack credence" and that the WICB do not intend to take any action over the report and will leave the matter in the hands of the ICC anti-corruption unit. Logie says he's "extremely hurt" by his inclusion.

Friday 3 November
Stewart faces the media. He says: "I know in my mind I'm clear, but it's my word against Gupta's word, and now it's in Sir Paul Condon's safe hands." Stewart says he would not recognise Gupta if he walked into the room.

The Daily Telegraph reports that Azharuddin and Ajay Sharma are facing criminal charges. The former was captain of India and the latter is a groundsman at the Feroseshah Kotla ground so both could be considered government servants and be liable to prosecution.

The BCCI bans Azharuddin, Sharma, Ajay Jadeja, Nayan Mongia and Manoj Prabhakar from playing all cricket under its control after they have been tainted in the report.

Lord MacLaurin denies double standards over the allegations against Stewart, saying the reason the England vice-captain stayed on the tour was because he "co-operated fully" with the ECB. MacLaurin was reported to have said early in England's tour to Pakistan that players under suspicion should be banned although he says his words were taken out of context. He expresses regret at the reporting of those comments in the light of relations between the two countries.

Stewart is given the backing of chairman of selectors David Graveney who says: "He's a shining example of what is good in English cricket." He says Stewart's denial is "good enough" for him.

Saturday 4 November
Jadeja defends himself. He says: "At no time in my career have I been involved with match-fixing as defined in the CBI report. He says the allegations are based on "false and concocted evidence".

Mihir Bose in the Daily Telegraph says the captain of a touring international team offered to pay a county £15,000 to lose because the sponsors of the matches against the counties were offering £50,000 to the tourists if they beat all the counties. Bose says the story is "well-known in county cricket".

Nasser Hussain reveals his fears for Stewart. He says Stewart has been "hit hard" by the allegation and hopes his name will be cleared by the time the Tests start.

Imran Khan supports the ECB's position on Stewart. He says: "The ECB is right to keep Stewart in the team but the stance against the Pakistani players was ridiculous. The Indian report has created a stir but there is no concrete evidence against players." But former Pakistan captain Intikhab Alam and ex-fast bowler Sarfraz Nawaz say Stewart should be sent home.

West Indies captain Jimmy Adams says he does not think the corruption in the game will ever be removed completely. He says: "You will always have gambling. And that is the root problem. How do you remove that?" Meanwhile ICC investigators meet with the CBI.

Australia captain Steve Waugh reveals his upset for twin brother Mark. Allan Border also comes out in support of him.

Sunday 5 November
The Sunday Telegraph's Scyld Berry reports that the ECB has completed their secret inquiry into two matches between Essex and Lancashire in August 1991 and a police investigation is now likely. Former Essex seamer and Zimbabwe coach Don Topley alleged in newspaper articles in 1994-95 that Essex were set "a generous declaration" and subsequently won the Championship match between the two teams, giving them the title by 13 points. Topley alleges that the Essex team allowed Lancashire to win in the Sunday game, which helped them achieve the runners-up spot in the League.

Wasim Akram and Salim Malik were playing for Lancashire and Essex respectively and both have been implicated in the CBI report, but neither was involved here according to Topley.

Berry says doubts remain about Stewart, "partly because of what he said and did not say, partly because of the way he said it." He adds: "Not once in almost half-an-hour of questions and answers did he use the word 'truth'. An absence of righteous indignation, of passion, was notable, too."

Sir Garfield Sobers tells Week Magazine that the scandal is "the most terrible thing to happen in the game". He says: "I can't believe Azharuddin could do such a thing. I never expected former South Africa captain Hansie Cronje, too, to be involved in match-fixing."

Mongia expresses his dismay at the allegations against him. He says Azharuddin's version of events which incriminate him and Ajay Jadeja is totally false.

Monday 6 November
Azharuddin is facing a tax bill of millions, it is reported. The Revenue Office in New Delhi says it intends to file major income-tax demands to at least five players, including Azharuddin, in the light of the CBI report.

The Sri Lankan Board announces it has appointed the President's Counsel Desmond Fernando to look at the CBI report. He has been given 30 days to report back.

Lara says he is trying to convince his English legal advisers to allow him to speak about the latest allegations against him, otherwise he cannot comment.

The CBI denies groundsman Ram Adhar Chaudhury was beaten up so that he would confess to taking a bribe of 50,000 rupees to doctor a pitch for a Test between India and Australia in 1996.

Wednesday 8 November
Ram Adhar Chaudhury is suspended from his duties at the Feroseshah Kotla ground in New Delhi.

India's Telegraph newspaper, it is reported by Vivek Chaudhary in the Guardian, has published records of heavy mobile-phone traffic allegedly between Gupta and Ajay Jadeja during New Zealand's tour to India last year. The paper says that on November 13, the day before India lost to New Zealand in Guwahati to level the one-day series 2-2, Gupta made 48 calls to Jadeja's mobile. Then, the day before India clinched the series by winning in New Delhi on November 17, Gupta made 55 calls to Jadeja. Sri Lanka drop Aravinda de Silva, who was named in the CBI report, from their 16-man squad to tour South Africa.

Saturday 11 November

A lawyer, Shalendra Diwedi, has brought a case of treason against the five Indians and the former physio named in the CBI report. He is bringing a private prosecution in the Central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh because "they have sullied the name of his country".

Madhavan questions Jadeja, Mongia and former Indian team physio Ali Irani Ü Sharma is indisposed.

Monday 13 November

Wednesday 15 November
Dalmiya accuses the CBI of "harassment".

Thursday 16 November

Sri Lanka's Cricket Board said it would "most likely" call for a criminal investigation into the allegations . fields.headline: Express sold to OK!
fields.trailText: 3.30pm update: The Express newspaper group has been sold to OK! magazine publisher Richard Desmond.
fields.body:
The Express newspaper group has today been sold to OK! magazine owner Richard Desmond.

The publishing tycoon has already lined up a management team, led by Northern & Shell editorial director Paul Ashford, which is due to arrive at the paper's headquarters this afternoon.

"It was all down to price. Desmond trumped the Hindujas," said one source at the Express parent group United News & Media.

"We are very pleased to get rid of it. It's been a complete distraction."

Sources close to Mr Desmond say the £125m deal was agreed in principle after all-night talks between bankers and lawyers for both sides.

It is believed that United boss Lord Hollick chose Mr Desmond over rival bidders because he wanted a quick deal and because the OK! owner outbid the other main contender, the Hinduja brothers.

"The proposal is that the team arrives at Ludgate House shortly after 4pm to take over the management," a source added.

Officially Mr Desmond will say he hopes to work with Express editor Rosie Boycott and her incumbent team.

However, a huge shake-up in the newsroom is inevitable with changes implemented immediately by Mr Ashford.

Staff at the long-neglected Daily Star were delighted to severe links with Lord Hollick, who has starved the title of funds since he took over in 1996.

One source said: "The atmosphere here is jubilant. A cheer went up when Lord Hollick was seen on Sky News walking out of the building. We don't know what this will mean for the paper, but something has got to be better than nothing."

Rumours were circulating today that a shortlist of three editors has been drawn up by Mr Desmond and his team, none of them including Ms Boycott.

Ms Boycott has transformed the paper from a right-wing newspaper with a declining and ageing circulation into a left-wing title appealing to a younger and more upmarket audience.

However, her feminist and liberal ideologies are unlikely to fit in with Mr Desmond, who made much of his money from sleazy top-shelf magazines such as Forum, Penthouse and Asian Babes.

fields.headline: Desmond vows to 'build' Express
fields.trailText: Wednesday 5.30pm: "Everything is now okay at the Express," declared Richard Desmond as he arrived at the newspapers' HQ at Ludgate House, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
"Everything is now okay at the Express," declared publishing tycoon Richard Desmond moments after he entered the newspapers' headquarters at Ludgate House.

He has already installed Northern & Shell editorial director Paul Ashford as the editorial director of the Express, Sunday Express and Star.

And today both executives tried to reassure journalists that there would be no immediate changes.

Mr Ashford insisted he would not interfere in the editorial direction of the paper.

"The editors will edit it and we will build it," he said.

Mr Desmond, who was an eleventh-hour bidder for the titles, said that owning a national newspaper was "a logical next step" for Northern & Shell.

He said: "We plan investment. We are a British company. We build on what we have achieved over the last 26 years. We hope to, with investment in editorial, bring it back to where it once was."

Asked about the editorial stance of the paper, Mr Ashford said: "It will continue its legacy. It will continue in its tradition. It will still be a passionate advocate of causes. It will look like it does now, but with more panache."

Mr Ashford also said that there were no plans to get rid of editor Roisie Boycott.

"We haven't spoken to her yet, but we like continuity," he said.

 Rebecca Hardy, editor of the Scotsman, is being tipped as the new editor of the Sunday Express.
