fields.headline: Mixed reaction from staff as 'porn king' buys Express
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: Journalists at the Express and Star face uncertainty following the sale of the titles to OK! publisher Richard Desmond. By Lisa O'Carroll and Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Journalists at the Express and Star are still in the dark about their futures following the sale of the titles to OK! magazine publisher Richard Desmond.

And speculation is mounting that Express editor Rosie Boycott will be replaced sooner rather than later.

Rumours were rife that Mr Desmond will try to poach News of the World editor Rebekah Wade or Sue Douglas from the Scotsman as a replacement for Ms Boycott.

One journalist said: "It's complete chaos here. The journalists can harldy get in the building with the number of people who are camped outside.

"Nobody has told us anything. Rosie Boycott is still in her office and taking calls and seems perfectly okay."

The reaction of staff to the sale has been mixed. Journalists on the down-market Star believe Mr Desmond, whose magazines include top-shelf titles Penthouse UK, Forum and Asian Babes, could be a life-saver.

Staff on the Express are more anxious.

One journalist said: "The porn element of Desmond's business is worrying. Will he take it downmarket? It will be completely different to Rosie's regime of love and peace.

"She will never get on with him. It is obvious to everyone here that she couldn't work for someone who produces soft porn."

The fears of Express staff were fuelled by a spoof Evening Standard sandwich board erected outside its offices reading, "Porn King buys Express".

The London evening paper is owned by the Daily Mail & General Trust, who were excluded from bidding for the Express by owner Lord Hollick.

"We can't believe it's a porn guy not the Hindujas," said one incredulous journalist.

webTitle: Newsnight blamed for rape trial collapse

fields.headline: Newsnight blamed for rape trial collapse
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday abandoned the trial of a Merseyside man accused of raping his stepdaughter and sexually abusing his daughter because he feared the jury could be prejudiced by a similar case shown on Monday's BBC Newsnight
fields.body:
A judge yesterday abandoned the trial of a Merseyside man accused of raping his stepdaughter and sexually abusing his daughter because he feared the jury could be prejudiced by a similar case shown on Monday's BBC Newsnight.

The decision to discharge the jury on the second day of the trial will cost the taxpayer tens of thousands of pounds, the lord chancellor's department said last night.

David Clarke, Liverpool's most senior judge, abandoned the proceedings after seeing the programme in which a Merseyside woman claimed she had been sexually abused by her stepfather in the 1970s.

Judge Clarke, the recorder of Liverpool, told the jury there were too many similarities between the cases for the 54-year-old defendant to receive a fair trial and remanded him on bail to await re-trial next year.

The development could open the way for defence lawyers to use similar arguments to get the jury dismissed if media coverage of a case echoes their own.

The defendant had denied three charges of indecently assaulting his stepdaughter in the early 1970s beginning when she was seven and four offences of raping her when she was 15. He also denied two offences of indecently assaulting his 12-year-old daughter in the 1980s.

The BBC2 programme claimed a 71-year-old pensioner, named only as Stanley, regularly raped his three stepdaughters in Birkenhead, Merseyside, but was not on the Sex Offenders' Register.

When confronted by Newsnight he admitted that he started having sex with one of the children when she was 10. Another stepdaughter said she thought he was still capable of abusing children in the future.

The BBC said yesterday: "Newsnight decided to broadcast the film as it was a matter of huge public importance and public interest. Our film did not refer to any other case." Merseyside police said yesterday they had arrested two men in their 70s in connection with child sex abuse as a result of the broadcast and further investigations.

webTitle: Cheney in hospital with chest pains

fields.headline: Cheney in hospital with chest pains
fields.trailText:
The Republican vice-presidential candidate, Dick Cheney, was admitted to hospital in Washington DC today with chest and shoulder pains, the Bush campaign spokeswoman Karen Hughes said.
26 July: Profile: Dick Cheney
7 October: Duncan Campbell on the role of the vice-presidential candidates
2 August: Dick Cheney's speech to the Republican national congress
fields.body:
The Republican vice-presidential candidate, Dick Cheney, was admitted to hospital in Washington DC today with chest and shoulder pains, the Bush campaign spokeswoman Karen Hughes said.

Mr Cheney was taken to the George Washington hospital after complaining of pains. Ms Hughes said tests had revealed no abnormality and blood tests had shown that his cardiac enzymes were normal.

Ms Hughes said: "He is free of discomfort, but remains hospitalised for further tests and observation."

Mr Cheney, 59, had three heart attacks and quadruple cardiac bypass surgery before turning 50, but said recently that he now led an "extraordinarily vigorous lifestyle". He said he had given up smoking, exercised regularly and took medicine to lower his cholesterol.

Ms Hughes added that the Bush campaign chairman, Don Evans, had spoken to Mr Cheney by telephone in the hospital: the former defence secretary sounded calm and described himself as comfortable.

Ms Hughes said she was notified at 6.08am (1108 GMT) that Mr Cheney had just been admitted to hospital.

When Republican presidential candidate George Bush selected Mr Cheney as his running mate, he knew the former Wyoming congressman and White House chief of staff had a history of heart problems.

Jonathan Reiner, a cardiologist, said earlier in the presidential campaign that Mr Cheney's cardiac stress tests had been " stable and unchanged for the past several years".

Mr Cheney's first attack, when he was 37, was in 1978. He had a second in 1984 and a third in 1988. All were described as mild. In August 1988, Mr Cheney underwent bypass surgery because of arterial blockages.

webTitle: Cindy's face too old for Revlon

fields.headline: Cindy's face too old for Revlon
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Cindy Crawford has been dropped by Revlon after 11 years as its face, in favour of a younger image, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Cindy Crawford has been dropped by Revlon after 11 years as the face of the US cosmetics giant.

Revlon confirmed today that chief executive Jeffrey Nugent had decided to axe the 34-year-old supermodel.

Mr Nugent, who was brought in 11 months ago from rival Johnson & Johnson to turn around the fortunes of the troubled cosmetics company, has said he wants to give Revlon a younger image.

"I think she will continue to do some work for us but she will no longer be our premiere model, which is the most coveted position at Revlon," said a company spokeswoman.

"Jeff Nugent wants to update Revlon's image. We are in talks at the moment with various people who might replace Cindy and it will be someone revolutionary and exciting with universal appeal."

The familiar image of Ms Crawford wearing bright red lipstick has been deterring younger consumers, who are put off by her 80s look.

The old-fashioned image has had a major impact on the bottom line, and Revlon's value has dropped from $1.83bn in 1985 to just $320m today.

Mr Nugent has already started to make his mark. Earlier this year he hired country and western star Shania Twain to promote a range of products including Crème Lip Colors and Liquidlip.

Sarah O'Hare, wife of Lachlan Murdoch, is another new face at Revlon.

Mr Nugent is reportedly considering switching Revlon's advertising from traditional magazines, such as Vogue, to trendier titles such as Nylon and Wallpaper.

In January it will roll out a new range of cosmetics in its first major launch since Colorstay lipstick six years ago.

The company's fortunes are beginning to improve. When Revlon announced its third-quarter results earlier this year losses were lower than in the same period last year.

Mr Nugent attributed this to recent changes, including the launch of new products and the closure of unprofitable plants.

webTitle: In brief: Zeta-Jones and Douglas say no to Hello

fields.headline: Zeta-Jones and Douglas say no to Hello
fields.standfirst: Plus: Guy Ritchie and Madonna rumoured to be about to marry; Cameron Diaz leaves Prince Charles to dine with the other two Charlie's Angels; Alicia Silverstone gets grungy in indie flick; Tom Berenger given big screen opportunity in new thriller
fields.trailText: Plus: Guy Ritchie and Madonna rumoured to be about to marry; Cameron Diaz leaves Prince Charles to dine with the other two Charlie's Angels; Alicia Silverstone gets grungy in indie flick; Tom Berenger given big screen opportunity in new thriller
fields.body:
 Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas yesterday won a high court injunction against Hello magazine for publishing unauthorised pictures of their November 19 wedding. The business-savvy couple had already signed an exclusive picture deal with Hello rival OK for a reported $1m (£705,000). All seemed hunky dory until Hello spoilt the party and soured the beautiful occasion by publishing the snaps in this week's edition. The ruling in London's High Court ordered that 740,000 copies of the magazine should be pulled from the shelves.

 Fortunately, we can move on from the ashes of one slightly soiled wedding to the happy news of another one which seems to be pending. It appears that Guy Ritchie is set to marry long-term girlfriend Madonna next year and the pair will be settling in London's Notting Hill. Wednesday's Sun quotes Madonna as saying that, "Guy has asked me to marry him and I've said yes, but we haven't decided when yet."

 Still on a romantic topic, it looks as if the Prince of Wales was blown out last week when he asked There's Something About Mary star Cameron Diaz over for a dinner date. Charles had invited all three Charlie's Angels stars - Diaz, Lucy Liu and Drew Barrymore - to dine with him at St James' Palace, only for Diaz to back out citing "filming commitments". Insiders, however, claim that the real reason that Diaz gave the event a miss was because she had no escort for the night. Her current boyfriend, actor Jared Leto, is currently "finding himself" in a monastery in Portugal.

 Alicia Silverstone will join Peter O'Toole and Joan Plowright in the culture clash indie flick Global Heresy for director Sidney Furie. The film, which will be shot in locations in Toronto and the UK, tells the tale of a grungy rock band (Global Heresy) who find themselves in limbo at an English country manor after their frontman goes AWOL.

 The good news for Tom Berenger is that he has landed a starring role as a mysterious stranger in the new thriller, Watchtower. The bad news is that the movie begins shooting this Thursday in locations around wintry British Columbia, which will give Tom little time to pack, let alone learn his lines. But having peaked in the 1980s with the likes of Platoon and The Big Chill, Berenger has spent the last few years idling in straight-to-video country (anyone remember Takedown? Diplomatic Siege? An Occasional Hell?). Chances are he'll be on the first plane north, pausing only to send a bouquet of flowers to his agent.

webTitle: Airlines neglect passengers' health, says Lords report

fields.headline: Airlines neglect passengers' health, says Lords report
fields.standfirst: Air Travel and Health - House of Lords science and technology committee report
fields.trailText: The health of passengers on flights has been "woefully neglected", according to a parliamentary report published today.
fields.body:
The health of passengers on flights has been "woefully neglected", according to a parliamentary report published today.

There is a "current paucity" of data about any possible link between flying and the potentially fatal deep vein thrombosis (DVT) complaint, the report adds.

It calls for major changes in the regulation and management of the air travel industry if the health of passengers and crews is to be properly safeguarded. The report, from the House of Lords science and technology committee, urges research into where blood clots form, mainly in the deep veins of the legs.

The report, Air Travel and Health, says that DVT should not be seen as purely a phenomenon affecting cheaper travellers, and that the misleading term "economy-class syndrome" should be dropped.

The possible link between DVT and flying was highlighted last month when bride-to-be Emma Christofferson, 28 died from deep-vein thrombosis moments after getting off a long-haul flight from Australia.

The Lords committee said there was no available information on the contribution of air travel to the overall risk of DVT. But if there is an increased risk of DVT solely from flying it is small, the report says - "exceedingly small" for healthy people. "Although any additional risk [of DVT from flying] is likely to be small, it is not in doubt that risk factors of prolonged immobility and cramped seating are present in aircraft."

The report calls on airlines to give passengers more information about how flying might affect their health. Airlines should consider giving passengers more legroom and less alcohol, while the civil aviation authority should lay down "an unambiguous set of definitions for seat dimensions".

There should be small display cards at every ticket sale point and in every doctor's surgery asking: "Are you fit to fly?" Airlines should be required to give health briefings as well as the normal pre-flight safety briefings. And there was also a case for an independent air industry "ombudsman" to deal with passengers' complaints and concerns.

Lady Wilcox, who chaired the committee's nine-month inquiry, said: "Passengers intending to fly are not told enough to enable them to make informed choices about their air travel. While the health risks seem slight for the great majority - indeed, millions of people fly safely every day - we recommend urgent research and development of user-friendly information for passengers to reduce any further risks."

Welcoming the report, Eoin Redahan of the Stroke Association said: "The key to preventing clots forming in someone's leg during a flight is for passengers to move around regularly and drink plenty of water. If this makes it difficult for airlines to sell alcohol and duty free that is the price they incur to ensure that their passengers remain healthy."

Unidentified gunmen shot dead a former Spanish government minister in a car park in Barcelona last night in an attack that bore the hallmark of the armed Basque separatist group Eta, news reports said.

No group claimed responsibility for the shooting of Ernest Lluch but news of the attack came two hours after a car bomb blast blamed on Eta shook a residential area on the city's outskirts. No one was injured in the explosion.

News reports said police believe the car had been used by the gunmen to get away.

Lluch, a former socialist government health minister, was killed in the car park of the basement of the building where he lived, the national news agency Efe said. The shooting occurred at about 10pm local time, although his body was not found for nearly an hour and a half, the agency said.

Leaders of the Socialist party in the Spanish capital, Madrid, were to hold an emergency meeting, the private news agency Europa Press said.

Eta has claimed 20 killings, including politicians, police and journalists, so far this year and some 800 since it began fighting for a Basque independent state in 1968.

Yesterday's events began in the morning, when two grenades were thrown at a police station in the Basque town of Irun. The blast from one grenade damaged a civil guard officer's eardrum. The other fell into the gardens of a nearby school but did not explode.

Eleven hours later, a car bomb exploded in a waste lot on the outskirts of Barcelona, some 250 miles east of the Basque region. No injuries or damages were reported, Spanish National Radio said.

Blaming the separatist group Eta for the Irun attack, Carlos Iturgaiz, the head of the Basque branch of the ruling Popular party, said the group had "failed in its attempt to cause death and destruction".

After the attackers fled, police found a booby trap explosive in a car near the police station. The vehicle also contained several grenade-launching tubes, a grenade and timers. Police carried out a controlled explosion .

Earlier this month, 10 policemen were injured when a booby-trapped cache of grenade launchers exploded in San Sebastian.

Eta called off a 14-month ceasefire last December, claiming the peace process was making no progress in bringing about an independent Basque state.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: MARVELLOUS MARCEL?
fields.body:
MARVELLOUS MARCEL?

"What percentage of the games that Chelsea have lost over the last three seasons have they been without Marcel Desailly for? Surely he is the key link to this team's current success?" reckons Gavin Gray.

Oh no he isn't. As John Howard points out, so far this Premiership season Chelsea have lost five games, and Desailly has played in four of them. Worse still, Desailly played in seven out of Chelsea's nine Premiership defeats in the 1999/2000 season and all three of the games Chelsea lost in the 1998/1999 season.

"Chelsea were only without Desailly for 19% of the total number of league games they lost over the last three seasons. He played in 81% of the league games they lost," calculates John unnecessarily. "So I don't think that Desailly is the "key" link in their current success. On the other hand he has played in a significant number of games that Chelsea have either won or drawn since signing for Chelsea in June '98."

THE LEAST SUCCESSFUL FOOTBALL SIDE EVER

"Who are the least successful side in the history of the Football League?" asks Bob Cole.

"It's difficult to quantify the least successful Football League team," reckons a puzzled Gerard Sugrue. "Are you looking at the likes of Halifax or Hartlepool who have spent many years in the lowest divisions and, in the days before automatic relegation, racked up five or more re-election bids?"

"Or do you consider teams that only lasted a few years in the Football League like Glossop or Aberdare Athletic - long forgotten names now known only to the statisticians and football historians and other 'anoraks?'

Peter Dewey reckons it's the latter. "There was a team called Thames which played two seasons in the league (I think seasons 1930-1 and 1931-2)," he says. "They barely won a match and then presumably disappeared into the murky waters of the great river for which they were named."

We're still not sure, but perhaps an equation that takes into account the number of defeats, trophies won, and years in league might hit the spot. Any mathematicians out there?

GRANDAD WE LOVE YOU

I am trying to find the career history and any photos of J. Cantrell. I know he played for the Villa in the 1920s, asks Dave Cantrell.

Can't help you with the snaps, Dave, but we may be able to tell you a bit more about your great-grandad.

Jimmy Cantrell certainly played for Aston Villa, but not in the Twenties. In fact, the clever forward began his professional career with Villa in July 1904. Sadly, he wasn't a member of the team which beat Newcastle 2-0 in the following year's FA Cup Final, and was eventually moved on to Notts County in March 1908.

Cantrell's impressive performances at Meadow Lane - he averaged more than a goal every other game - eventually earned him a transfer to Tottenham, who paid a club-record £1,500 for him in October 1912. He immediately set about banging in the goals, scoring 13 goals in 25 games in his first season. Jimmy's FA Cup misery of 1905 was eventually forgotten in 1921, when the 39-year-old played in Tottenham's 1-0 victory over Wolverhampton Wanderers at a rain-lashed Stamford Bridge.

Cantrell had one more mark to make on the game. In April 1923, he made his final senior appearance for Spurs against Birmingham aged 40 years 349 days, becoming the oldest player ever to play for Spurs, a record which stands to this day. Jimmy scored 160 goals in 339 games for Aston Villa, Notts County and Tottenham Hotspur, an impressive tally. He died in 1960, aged 78.

PUTTING IT ON YOUR SHIRT

Last week Paddy Dwyer claimed that Roy of the Rovers were sponsored by Gola in the late 70s. However Justin Toland says that "Gola first sponsored Melchester during the 1981/82 season, when they won the 2nd division title by a country mile following their shock relegation the previous season." Paddy Dwyer was right about the Goal faux pas, however, he adds.

MORE SHEEP-STEALING FOOTBALLERS

"Regarding the footballer who won a cup medal in the early 1900s and was reported to have been hung for sheep stealing - I can narrow it down a little. It wasn't John Crelley! He was my husband's grandfather and he died under normal circumstances in 1946! We have the medal in our possession," says Helen Crelley.

Can you help?

"Has David Beckham ever taken a penalty in a competitive match? If not, why not, considering he is probably the best dead-ball specialist in the Premiership (and possibly Europe)?" asks Ben Homer.

"Has a player ever won two championship medals with two different teams in the same season, e.g. by being transferred mid-season from say the eventual Scottish champions to the eventual English champions" he asks Vic Ardern.

"It looks likely that John Jensen's side Herfølge, who won the Danish championship last season, are going to get relegated this season. Has that ever happened to any other team in Europe?" asks Peter Kargaard.

"Which two football players have played in a Liverpool, Manchester and Glasgow Derby?" asks Jane Beeton. Andrei Kanchelkis (sp?) is definitely one - does anybody know the other?

"Can you settle an argument that threatens to destroy the peaceful tranquillity of our workplace? 'Who (if anybody!) has scored a hat trick in an FA Cup final but still managed to play on the losing team?'" asks R. Mann.

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: View from Florida: The plastic surgery state

fields.headline: Florida: The plastic surgery state
fields.standfirst:
The electoral recount is not the only thing happening in the Sunshine State, writes Michael Ellison


Special report: The US election
fields.trailText: View from Florida: The electoral recount is not the only thing happening in the state, writes Michael Ellison.
fields.body:
Contrary to the impression you might have formed by reading elsewhere, things have been happening in Florida other than the longest non-election in the western world. For a start, quite a lot of plastic surgery has been going on.

The state does not just lead the United States in electoral malpractice, it also has the nation's highest number of "cosmetic procedures" and plastic surgeons per head of the population.

"People are very exposed here - girls are on the beach all year," says Dr Leonard Roudner, purveyor of "goddess breasts" at up to $8,000 a pair. "They're not clad up for eight months a year like they are in Chicago and New York."

This craftsman, known as Dr Boobner and named by W magazine as one of the world's best breast surgeons, is not making this up as he goes along. He doesn't need to. Our man is booked up for five operations a day until next March.

Dr Roudner is not the only busy practitioner in his line of work. The number of these "procedure" has risen by 275% in the past eight years, from 367,000 to more than a million last year.

The $3bn a year industry does not rely entirely on the self-obsession of youth. "When people retire, where do they go? North Dakota or Florida?" said Dr Dean Johnson, president of the Florida Society of Plastic Surgeons. "They've got a higher desire to spend money on themselves to look better. And they want to look good."

Florida is the cheapest of the top four plastic surgery states, undercutting, as it were, New York, California and Texas. So much for the good news. Women in Florida may well possess the finest breasts, faces and eyelids, but they are still underprivileged, at least according to the non-partisan Institute for Women's Policy Research.

A new study by the institute says that Florida ranks 44th in the league table of political and economic status for women. That's 44th out of 50 states, plus the District of Columbia.

The state was in the bottom third in four of the five indicators employed: reproductive rights (or abortion, as some people might call it); political participation; economic autonomy and health and well being.

Of course, Florida does have a disproportionate number of old people, who may not be in the best of health, even if they do all look wonderful. Still, it could be worse: you might be a woman in Mississippi, which ranks lowest of all, without even the benefit of a plastic surgeon on every street corner.

In fact, it could be much worse, and once was for some people. A civil rights memorial has been rededicated in honour of Johnnie Mae Chapman, a mother of ten who was shot dead in Jacksonville, Florida, 36 years ago, while she was walking to buy some ice cream. Until now her only memorial was a Drive Safely sign on the spot where she died.

"She died because of the civil rights struggle in America," says Lee Cody, a detective in the Jacksonville, Florida, sheriff's office at the time. "She died at the height of the struggle and she died because she was black and that's all."

Her death was not investigated until five months later and only one of the four white men charged was convicted. He served two years in jail and Mr Cody, who pursued the case, was fired for his trouble.

But we should not leave the women of Florida on such a sombre note. Let us return to electoral politics, though of a rather obscure brand.

When Elaine Bloom, a Democrat attempting to win a seat in the United States Congress from Fort Lauderdale, came within 600 votes of beating Republican Clay Shaw Jr, she was entitled to a recount.

Instead, she chose the course of grace and conceded in a brief and courteous phone call. Perhaps the Smirker or that fellow reminiscent of the Gary Sinese character in Forrest Gump might follow suit soon.

webTitle: Blair to double investment in public services

fields.headline: Blair to double investment in public services
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today spelt out the government's plans to more than double investment in public services.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today spelt out the government's plans to more than double investment in public services.

Launching a white paper on public services investment, the prime minister set out how over the next three years, net investment in the public sector would rise from barely £7bn to over £18bn.

Mr Blair said the government had inherited a "dire" situation in the public services when it came to power in 1997, with schools and hospitals that were too old, and a transport infrastructure not up to meeting the demands of a modern economy.

He told a Downing Street news conference that for years Britain had been "an under-invested in country", but added that it was the government's responsibility to improve the nation's infrastructure.

webTitle: Supreme court rules in favour of Gore

fields.headline: Supreme court rules in favour of Gore
fields.standfirst:
Judges say Florida recounts must go on

Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore's hopes of winning the White House rose dramatically early today when the Florida supreme court ruled decisively in his favour in his dispute with George W Bush over election recounts.
fields.body:
Al Gore's hopes of winning the White House rose dramatically early today when the Florida supreme court ruled decisively in his favour in his dispute with George W Bush over election recounts.

The seven-member court, in a late evening 42-page ruling in the state capital Tallahassee, voted unanimously that hand recounts in three heavily populated south Florida counties had to be included in official tallies to be certified by the state's Republican secretary of state, Katherine Harris.

The counties have until 5pm on Sunday to complete their counts and submit them to Ms Harris - or she could decide to accept them up until 9am on Monday.

The court said that "the right of the people to cast their vote is the paramount concern overriding all others".

After a nail-biting day of waiting for both presidential hopefuls and their legal teams, a court official appeared on the steps of the Florida supreme court building in Tallahassee just after 9pm local time (2am GMT) and said an "important announcement" would be made at 9.45pm.

Then, right on timetable, the court spokesman Craig Waters stepped into the floodlights and announced the court's pivotal 7-0 verdict.

The court's decision is a huge legal blow for Mr Bush, who still leads by 930 votes in the preliminary count of votes in Florida. After last night's decision, however, the doors have been kept open to enable Mr Gore every chance to claw back the advantage and per haps claim Florida's 25 electoral college votes.

Those 25 votes are now the absolutely decisive last piece in the arithmetic of the US electoral college system. With 270 votes required for victory, Mr Gore is now on 267, with Mr Bush on 246.

The two rivals both watched the crucial announcement on television at their official residences, Mr Gore in Washington and Mr Bush in Austin.

Earlier, Mr Gore's allies had signalled that the US vice-president was considering a quick decision to abandon his White House contest with George W Bush as early as today if the Florida Supreme Court had ruled in favour of Mr Bush.

Before yesterday's supreme court decision, Al Gore's allies had signalled that the US vice-president was considering a quick decision to abandon his White House contest with George W Bush if the Florida supreme court ruled in favour of Mr Bush on the two-week old disputed election in the state.

As all sides in the battle for victory in Florida tensely awaited the court's crucial ruling, a senior ally travelled to the state on Mr Gore's behalf to say that a judgment in favour of Mr Bush could mark the end of the road for the vice-president's efforts to take the 25 Florida electoral college votes that hold the key to the White House.

Senator Bob Kerrey, of Nebraska, a Democrat, said he had spoken to Mr Gore after Monday's court process in Tallahassee. He said Mr Gore had told him the process had been fair and that he was "optimistic that the court's going to make a judgment that both sides are going to be able to trust".

Senator Kerrey said that if the verdict went against Mr Gore, he would join fellow Democrats such as Senator John Breaux of Louisiana and former Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia in pressing the vice-president to end further legal challenges to the November 7 election.

Asked if a ruling against the Gore campaign in the supreme court should be the end of the challenges, Mr Kerrey replied: "I think that's good advice and I think that in fact the vice-president is thinking about that."

The issue, Mr Kerrey said, was whether allies of Mr Bush would do the same for their man if the court ruled Mr Gore's way. "He [Bush] has painted himself into a corner by saying that what's going on is election fraud, stealing the election, irresponsible statements about the military votes."

Mr Kerrey, a decorated Vietnam war veteran, accused the Bush campaign of "making reckless and wrong charges" about Mr Gore's fitness to be America's commander-in-chief after Bush aides at the weekend accused Democratic lawyers of trying to exclude overseas military votes from the recount process.

While the judges weighed up whether to instruct officials to await the results of hand recounts in three south Florida counties, the count continued.

Mr Gore had picked up 242 net votes compared with Mr Bush in the three recounts by late afternoon yesterday.

However, hundreds of disputed ballot papers remained uncounted in all three counties.

In Broward, with 606 of 609 precincts recounted, Mr Gore had gained a net 125 votes. In Palm Beach county, with 104 of 531 precincts counted, Mr Gore had a net gain of just three. In the third and largest county, Miami-Dade, Mr Gore's net gain was 114 with 99 of the 614 precincts counted.

Earlier, Mr Gore's allies had signalled that the US vice-president was considering a quick decision to abandon his White House contest with George W Bush as early as today if the Florida Supreme Court had ruled in favour of Mr Bush. Before yesterday's supreme court decision, Al Gore's allies had signalled that the US vice-president was considering a quick decision to abandon his White House contest with George W Bush if the Florida supreme court ruled in favour of Mr Bush on the two-week old disputed election in the state. As all sides in the battle for victory in Florida tensely awaited the court's crucial ruling, a senior ally travelled to the state on Mr Gore's behalf to say that a judgment in favour of Mr Bush could mark the end of the road for the vice-president's efforts to take the 25 Florida electoral college votes that hold the key to the White House. Senator Bob Kerrey, of Nebraska, a Democrat, said he had spoken to Mr Gore after Monday's court process in Tallahassee. He said Mr Gore had told him the process had been fair and that he was "optimistic that the court's going to make a judgment that both sides are going to be able to trust". Senator Kerrey said that if the verdict went against Mr Gore, he would join fellow Democrats such as Senator John Breaux of Louisiana and former Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia in pressing the vice-president to end further legal challenges to the November 7 election. Asked if a ruling against the Gore campaign in the supreme court should be the end of the challenges, Mr Kerrey replied: "I think that's good advice and I think that in fact the vice-president is thinking about that." The issue, Mr Kerrey said, was whether allies of Mr Bush would do the same for their man if the court ruled Mr Gore's way. "He [Bush] has painted himself into a corner by saying that what's going on is election fraud, stealing the election, irresponsible statements about the military votes." Mr Kerrey, a decorated Vietnam war veteran, accused the Bush campaign of "making reckless and wrong charges" about Mr Gore's fitness to be America's commander-in-chief after Bush aides at the weekend accused Democratic lawyers of trying to exclude overseas military votes from the recount process. While the judges weighed up whether to instruct officials to await the results of hand recounts in three south Florida counties, the count continued. Mr Gore had picked up 242 net votes compared with Mr Bush in the three recounts by late afternoon yesterday. However, hundreds of disputed ballot papers remained uncounted in all three counties. In Broward, with 606 of 609 precincts recounted, Mr Gore had gained a net 125 votes. In Palm Beach county, with 104 of 531 precincts counted, Mr Gore had a net gain of just three. In the third and largest county, Miami-Dade, Mr Gore's net gain was 114 with 99 of the 614 precincts counted. fields.headline: Blair spells out spending priorities
fields.trailText: The government has spelled out how it will double capital investment in public services over the next three years in order to bring hospital buildings, GP surgeries, and social housing up to scratch.
fields.body:
The government has spelled out how it will double capital investment in public services over the next three years in order to bring hospital buildings, GP surgeries, and social housing up to scratch.

All 23 government departments today published three year investment strategies outlining their plans to disburse the increases in capital spending announced by chancellor Gordon Brown in July.

Prime minister Tony Blair launched the investment plans, saying the government had "a vital responsibility to maintain and improve the nation's infrastructure".

Spending plans include £1.4bn a year to repair the health service's crumbling infrastructure and replace "unsafe", outdated, and inefficient medical equipment and facilities.

Nearly £2bn is to be generated from the private sector this year in order to invest in upgrading social housing, regenerating communities and improving energy efficiency in 1m buildings.

Blair said the government would double the proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) committed to public investment in the next three years in order to tackle the "dire" situation it inherited in 1997. But he also accepted some blame for public sector underinvestment.

"I accept that because we were taking the action necessary for laying stable economic foundations, in our first two years we were unable to get in as much investment as we know our public services need," he said.

Investment plans include:
 A £1.4bn increase in NHS capital spending. This will include: 100 major new hospital projects by 2010; 250 new scanners; and modernisation of more than 3,000 GP premises;
 Half a million houses to be brought up to a "decent" standard by 2004 - cutting by a third the number of families living in poor social housing. All social housing will be "decent" by 2010.

A Treasury white paper published simultaneously today outlines a new framework by which each department's spending will be monitored, inlcuding the introduction of commercial accounting techniques.

Each department will be required to update and publish their investment strategies, while all large capital projects will be put through a "rigorous process of scrutiny" by the new Office of Government Commerce.

webTitle: Kodak and Freeserve digital photo deal

fields.headline: Kodak and Freeserve in digital photo deal
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Freeserve and Kodak have teamed up to provide an online digital photo service. Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Freeserve has signed an exclusive deal with Kodak to add an online digital photo service to its portal.

Visitors to the soon-to-launch Print@Kodak section on Freeserve will be able to develop and store digital pictures online.

The service will offer online picture processing and storage of photos originated either on film or digitally, with users encouraged to use the service like they would a normal photo processing shop.

A unique PIN number password will allow members to access their pictures at any time and to share photos worldwide via email.

The deal gives Kodak exclusivity over all photographic services on Freeserve sites and is backed by promotional support and distribution of digital photo products through Dixons Group stores.

Revenues from online orders are to be split between the two parties. Longer-term, the partnership is to be extended to other platforms such as mobile internet, personal digital assistants (PDAs) and internet on TV.

The deal places Freeserve in a territory which high street retailer Boots is hoping to dominate. In June this year, Boots said it was investing some £9m into an online photo service, bootsphoto.com.

webTitle: What the Florida papers say: 'Let me know how the election turns out - I've got a turkey to cook'

fields.headline: 'Let me know how the election turns out - I've got a turkey to cook'
fields.standfirst:
While some Florida papers have welcomed the supreme court ruling on the recounts, others merely wearily look forward to more legal dithering, writes Derek Brown

Special report: The US election
fields.trailText: While some Florida papers have welcomed the supreme court ruling on the recounts, others merely wearily look forward to more legal dithering, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
At the centre of the electoral storm, the Florida papers have generally welcomed the state supreme court ruling that the manual recounts in Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade counties are valid.

The Miami Herald, in its latest update of the recounts, reports that George W. Bush's lead is now down to a nail-biting 652. But the Palm Beach Post has dispiriting news for the Al Gore campaign, along with the latest on that curiosity, the dimpled chad: "With 12% of Palm Beach County's ballots recounted, the news for Vice President Al Gore is not encouraging. He has picked up precisely one vote, according to the latest tallies released Monday. Hoping to reverse the tide, Democrats began a new offensive to force the county's canvassing board to count dimples -those ballots that are indented but not punched all the way through."

In the state capital, the Tallahassee Democrat heaps praise on the seven supreme court judges who ruled that the recount is valid: "They asked more than 125 questions, drilling down to the essence of the conflict before them, seeking information essential to harmonise the statutes, case law, administrative procedures and political hunches that have converged into one of the most breathtaking legal dramas in history.....However this court rules, its dignity, intelligence and integrity are beyond repute (sic)."

In a rare front-page editorial, the Democrat vigorously defends the voters of Florida, and chides the politicians and lawyers for squabbling over the outcome: "Here at the epicentre of our nation's presidential crisis, we have seen more than enough wild accusations of stealing votes, bending laws or subverting the will of the people. In a seemingly endless 'tit for tat in Tallahassee,' political partisans are calling our citizen volunteers and public officials liars and cheats who are stupid enough to try to pull a swindle in front of witnesses from both parties and the national media. That is grossly unfair."

The Orlando Sentinel wearily looks ahead to more legal dickering: "As the impact of the ruling sank in, signs pointed to an almost certain round of more legal battles everywhere from the counties where votes are still being recounted to the U.S. Supreme Court. And it appeared increasingly possible that the Florida Legislature or the US Congress could step in to play a role in selecting the next president." In a stinging rebuke of the Florida court's ruling, former US Secretary of State James Baker, representing Bush, said the justices had overstepped their bounds and unfairly changed the rules of the election. He said the Bush campaign would "consider whatever remedies we may have" - clearly laying the groundwork for a legal appeal.

The paper's cartoonist Dana Summers has a witty take on tomorrow's Thanksgiving holiday, showing a turkey with its neck on the block and Gore and Bush on either side, with axes held high. "Sheesh, a turkey could die of old age around here," says the bird.

On the same theme, perhaps the pithiest comment of all is offered by David Grimes, writing in the Sarasota Herald-Tribune: "Let me know how the election turns out; I've got a turkey to cook."

fields.headline: Hello! fights injunction
fields.standfirst: Nov 21: OK! takes legal action against Hello!
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Hello! magazine has rushed to court in an attempt to overturn yesterday's injunction stopping distribution of this week's issue. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
Hello! magazine has rushed to court today to try to overturn yesterday's injunction stopping it distributing this week's issue.

More than 10,000 early copies of the magazine had to be withdrawn from London shops yesterday because of a legal row with arch-rival OK! magazine over pictures of Catherine Zeta Jones' wedding.

OK! has paid the Hollywood couple £1m for exclusive photographs of their wedding in New York last Saturday and was furious when it learned Hello! had picked up pictures from a secret camera used at the reception.

If Hello! loses at the high court today, it will be forced to pulp the 755,900 copies that were frozen yesterday at newsagents around the country.

At the court case yesterday, Hello! said the cost of the ban was "unquantifiable".

Hello! publishing director Sally Cartwright said today: "I hope we can resolve this as soon as possible. I can't comment any further than that."

OK! magazine staff and Northern & Shell were unavailable for comment.

In court yesterday, the lawyer acting for OK! acknowledged that "spoilers" were commonly used in the magazine industry, but added that what Hello! had done was "in deliberate and wholesale disregard for the law".

Although OK! dismissed the pictures as badly taken, those that have seen the magazine say they are of reasonable quality.

The rogue pictures included one taken from behind the official OK! photographer. But Hello! argued that the dispute was a purely commercial one, and that Mr Douglas and Ms Zeta Jones's privacy had not been invaded.

fields.headline: The Postman delivers for Channel 5
fields.trailText: 11.45am TV overnights: Kevin Costner movie The Postman may have failed to impress the critics but it proved a ratings success for Channel 5. Jason Deans reports.
fields.body:
Kevin Costner's post-apocalyptic epic movie, The Postman, may not have impressed the critics on its cinema release, but the movie still pulled in the punters for Channel 5 last night.

The terrestrial premiere pulled in 2.2m viewers and a 14% share from 9pm on Channel 5, according to unofficial overnights. The film helped the channel to a respectable 6.7% viewing share across all hours yesterday.

Channel 5's property makeover show, House Doctor, also had a good night, averaging 1.6m and a 6% share from 8pm. But it didn't do as well as BBC2 leisure show Home Front, which took 3.3m from 8-9pm.

The Weakest Link continues to dominate the late afternoon ratings battle between BBC2 and Channel 4, but is not making the smoothest switch to BBC1 peak-time.

Yesterday the quiz show and its rude host, Anne Robinson, pulled in 5.4m on BBC2 from 5.15-6pm, while on Channel 4 US talk show Ricki attracted only 1.5m.

But Weakest Link: Champions League averaged only 600,000 more pairs of eyeballs, with 6m from BBC1 from 8.25pm, at a time when several million more viewers were watching TV.

fields.headline: Melanie Griffith turns web diarist
fields.standfirst: Melanie Griffith is writing a weekly internet diary about her struggle to overcome drug addiction
fields.trailText: Melanie Griffith is writing a weekly internet diary about her struggle to overcome drug addiction
fields.body:
Most stars go into hibernation when struggling to fight off drug addiction. Melanie Griffith, by contrast, is writing about it in weekly diary instalments that will be coming soon to a website near you.

As reported in our earlier story, the 43-year-old star of Working Girl and the upcoming Cecil B. Demented (pictured) apparently became addicted to painkillers and sleeping pills after suffering from a neck injury. Currently undergoing treatment at the Daniel Freeman Hospital in LA, she has taken the novel tack of telling us about it on OneWorldLive.com - a health and beauty website which Griffith co-founded.

In the first instalment of what could become a ratings-grabbing virtual soap, plucky Mel confesses that: "I was and still am addicted to barbiturates and opiates. This is my first message and I am still a little shaky, but I feel it is important to share this with you, because drug addiction to prescribed pain pills can happen to anyone and you have to be cheerful."

Log on next week to discover how Mel's battle with the pill bottle is progressing. This one, we feel, could run and run.

fields.headline: Heinz text messages buyers
fields.trailText: 11am: Heinz Tomato Ketchup is to launch a new label carrying amusing text messages to customers, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
First they turned it green, now they're messing about with the wording.

Heinz Tomato Ketchup is to get a makeover with the launch of a new label carrying a series of amusing messages about the nation's favourite sauce.

Designed to look the same as the traditional label, the messages will appear on the 570g glass bottle and the 700g plastic bottle of Heinz Tomato Ketchup from the end of this month.

The messages include, "Are Your French Fries Lonely?", "A Mate On Your Plate" and "Go On You Know You Want Some".

Sharon Ellis, Heinz category manager for Tomato Ketchup, said: "Heinz Tomato Ketchup is a brand with a great, strong personality, attitude and a sense of humour.

"You don't expect groceries to speak to you when you go shopping so the new labels will certainly make people stop and look twice."

Heinz Tomato Ketchup already commands 58% of the UK's £100m ketchup market, according to independent industry figures.

webTitle: Four Palestinians killed in Israeli tank attack

fields.headline: Four Palestinians killed in Israeli tank attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Four Palestinians, one reportedly a woman, were killed by Israeli troops near a Jewish settlement today. The deaths came as the Egyptian ambassador to Israel headed home in protest over a rocket attack on the Gaza Strip earlier this week.
fields.body:
Four Palestinians, one reportedly a woman, were killed by Israeli troops near a Jewish settlement today. The deaths came as the Egyptian ambassador to Israel headed home in protest over a rocket attack on the Gaza Strip earlier this week.

Israel and the Palestinians gave conflicting accounts of the shooting near the Jewish settlement of Morag at the southern end of Gaza.

Palestinian security officials said Israeli troops fired without provocation from tank-mounted machine guns at two cars with Palestinian civilians passing by Morag.

The army said a Palestinian car drove toward the Morag junction at high speed, and that soldiers fired at the vehicle. An army spokesman added that it was not clear whether shots were first fired at the troops from the Palestinian car.

Khaled Abu Ola, a Palestinian liaison officer based in Jerusalem, said Israel informed Palestinian police that four Palestinians were killed in the shooting.

The shooting was the latest incident in a new spiral of violence set off on Monday by a bomb attack on an Israeli school bus. In retaliation for that attack, Israeli helicopters blasted Palestinian security offices in Gaza, killing two Palestinians in what the United States has said was a show of excessive force.

In response to the rocketing, Egypt recalled its ambassador to Israel, Mohammed Bassiouny, and the Jordanian prime minister, Ali Abu-Ragheb, said his country's new ambassador to Israel would not present his credentials "until Israel ends its attacks."

Mr Bassiouny, who has been in Israel for two decades, left the Egyptian embassy in Tel Aviv this morning, saying farewell to the staff, and then headed to the Israeli-Egyptian border by car, embassy officials said.

Also today, Israeli tanks and armoured personnel carriers were brought into the Gaza Strip, cutting it in two and preventing Palestinian traffic between its northern and southern parts.

The military build-up came in response to the fatal shooting yesterday of an 18-year-old Israeli from a Gaza settlement by a Palestinian sniper.

The killing of the Israeli came just hours after Israeli soldiers killed a Palestinian security officer nearby. They said he was approaching their position suspiciously.

Israeli army bulldozers cleared Palestinian orchards and buildings away from a Gaza intersection near the isolated Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom, where the Israeli was shot, following a pattern of securing Israeli-held areas of the violence-shattered territory by flattening large swaths of land.

webTitle: Doctor 'let neglected girl go back to aunt'

fields.headline: Doctor 'let neglected girl go back to aunt'
fields.trailText: A cut and bruised girl was released by a London hospital's child protection officer back into her aunt's care seven months before she died, a court heard yesterday
fields.body:
A cut and bruised girl was released by a London hospital's child protection officer back into her aunt's care seven months before she died, a court heard yesterday.

Anna Climbié, eight, was said to have endured months tied up by her hands and feet in a binbag and left to sleep and eat in the bath, before dying in February of hypothermia and neglect. She had been sent from the Ivory Coast into her aunt's care so she might have a better life. A postmortem examination showed 128 injuries, including cigarette burns.

A jury at the Old Bailey was told the aunt, who moved Anna to Britain from France, admitted beating her.

Avril Cameron, a bible studies graduate, told the court the aunt, Marie Thérèse Kuoao, became "very annoyed" when she found out Ms Cameron had taken the child to hospital because she was covered in cuts and bruises. On a previous occasion Kuoao had said the cuts and blisters on her fingers were bug bites.

At Central Middlesex hospital the child was seen by Ruby Schwartz, a consultant paediatrician and the hospital's named child protection doctor, and released. The court had earlier heard Kuoao told the hospital the girl had inflicted the injuries on herself.

Kuoao, 44 and unemployed, and her boyfriend, Carl Manning, 28, a bus driver, of Tottenham, north London, deny murder. Kuoao also denies child cruelty and manslaughter. Manning admits child cruelty but the prosecution refuses to accept his plea of guilty to manslaughter.

Yesterday a relation of Kuoao's told of seeing the child. Grace Quansah, a teacher and former social worker, said: "She seemed very thin ... my son was four, and she was the same height and very frail."

webTitle: Deathbed book a first for China

fields.headline: Deathbed book a first for China
fields.trailText: A Chinese journalist in the last stage of cancer, who has published extracts from his diary on the web, hopes to live to see the entire work go on sale within the next week.
fields.body:
A Chinese journalist in the last stage of cancer, who has published extracts from his diary on the web, hopes to live to see the entire work go on sale within the next week.

Lu Youqing, 37, has already attracted national publicity by recording his feelings on a local literary website as he approached death.

"People should choose their own way of accepting death," he explained. "I only want to leave something memorable for my family."

Last week Mr Lu, now in the last stages of stomach cancer in a Shanghai hospital, was shown the first copies of the book, A Message of Life, by his publisher.

He wept with relief, it was reported, and inscribed the first copy to his wife and daughter: "You have given me all that you can, and this is all that I can give you."

Mr Lu's public reflections on human mortality are unusual in a country where conventional literature portrays most deaths as heroic or a natural consequence of old age.

He has compared the arbitrary nature of life to the experience of a child going to nursery school: "God gives you toys and other good things in the morning and in the evening he takes them all back ... I am just a boy who has dropped out of kindergarten earlier."

The diary Mr Lu posted on www.rongshu.com has attracted hundreds of messages of support. "The word death scares me and I never thought about it before," reads a comment from Beijing. "But after reading your stories, I accept it as part of life."

Many messages praise his bravery and thank him for setting an example. One writer says he has contemplated suicide. Another appeals for help on behalf of a young man with leukaemia.

A few offer friendship or suggest naively that Mr Lu may after all recover. One contributor has promised to post a joke daily on the website to cheer him up.

Confessional literature is no longer unknown in China on previously taboo subjects such as personal relationships and sex. Candid accounts by young Chinese of work and travel abroad are popular - particularly if they have spent time in the US. But this is thought to be the first book in the genre to deal with death rather than life.

Afflicted by secondary tumours on his neck, Mr Lu found that writing became very taxing. Several hours of massage were needed before he could write for a short while; later he dictated into a tape recorder.

The diary entries include a piece of fine lyrical writing in the Chinese san wen essay tradition.

In this passage, Mr Lu recalls an idyllic trip with friends 20 years ago to the lower Yangtze valley, a peaceful swath of countryside at the time, where heavy rain kept them stuck for several days. A local girl looked after them, listening quietly as they talked about poetry and the world and drank local wine with dried beancurd.

Mr Lu was captivated by her innocence and purity, but was too shy to go any further. Now he muses on what might have happened if he had stayed and married her.

"What would I be now? Maybe a teacher in the town's primary school?" He wonders too whether he would have contracted the cancer. "Is life like a chess competition, where with one wrong move we change the result completely?"

Mr Lu has been interviewed by a TV station and several newspapers. "The problem", he writes, "is that the reporters' questions are usually so 'big'."

"They will ask the meaning of life and death. They make me feel I should be given a doctorate if I can answer just one question right."

Mr Lu has asked his publisher to burn some books on serious subjects at his grave instead of offerings of paper money: "Then I will have enough time to digest them."

fields.headline: Reformers target private education
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour ministers can no longer duck the need to reform private schools in order to create a level playing field with the state sector, a think tank has warned.
fields.body:
Labour ministers can no longer duck the need to reform private schools in order to create a level playing field with the state sector, a think tank has warned.

A pamphlet published today by the left-of-centre Fabian Society claims that independent schools remain a barrier to Labour's aim of achieving educational equality in Britain, yet under Tony Blair's government they "have been left largely unmolested".

The author of the report, Harry Brighouse of London University's institute of education, called for a new relationship between the sectors to ensure that the benefits of private education - more money, better resources and good academic results - are more widely distributed for the benefit of all pupils.

Professor Brighouse recognised in the pamphlet, A Level Playing Field: The Reform of Private Schools, that abolishing private schools was not feasible.

He said Labour should instead consider three main reforms for a second term in government - stripping private schools of their right to select pupils; providing incentives for state school children to be admitted to Oxbridge; and setting a timetable by which spending in the state sector would match spending in the private sector.

Around 6.5% of pupils in Britain are educated privately yet more than half the undergraduates at Oxford come from fee-paying schools. Prof Brighouse pointed out that Labour's 1997 election manifesto "was silent about private schools", apart from a pledge to phase out the Tories' assisted places scheme. This provided government funding for bright children from families who could not afford private school fees.

Adrian Harvey, research director at the society, said: "The government has done much to improve the educational achievement of the least advantaged. But despite this excellent start, it will not realise its aim of delivering educational opportunities for all unless it reforms private schools."

The Independent Schools Information Service said: "Independent schools achieve excellence in many ways, some through rigorous academic selection, others not. But the ability to control its admissions policy and its curriculum are fundamental aspects of a school's independence."

The Department for Education said the government was making a sustained effort to raise standards in the state sector, with record increases in spending per pupil since the election.

fields.headline: Y&R wins £50m Land Rover account
fields.trailText: 11am: Land Rover has awarded its £50m global advertising account to Young & Rubicam, ending one of the most hotly contested pitches this year. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Land Rover has awarded its £50m global advertising account to Young & Rubicam, ending one of the most hotly contested pitches this year.

A long list of agencies, including HHCL & Partners, Wieden & Kennedy, J Walter Thompson and Grey, was drawn up in May.

The list was whittled down to just two, as Young & Rubicam and Grey Worldwide went head-to-head in a final shoot-out.

A senior source at Land Rover said this morning: "All the pitches have finished and it is fair to say that Young & Rubicam's was the best that we saw."

He added that while a final appointment is yet to be sealed, the negotiations centre around the contract with Y&R and not future discussions with Grey.

Separately, WPP sister agency Ogilvy & Mather is understood to have picked up more than £100m of European business from the Y&R network, reinstating it as Ford's lead agency in Europe.

This is thought to include advertising for the Fiesta, Ka, Focus and Galaxy brands.

fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip says: "Rio? Schmio."
fields.trailText: The Sun believes it knows the identity of Rio Ferdinand's replacement at Upton Park, 22-year-old Paris St Germain centre-back Sylvain Distin. The paper claims that the Hammers are also interested in PSG's French international defender Frederic Dehu, but that the club are unlikely to let him leave. However, the paper has managed to confuse the ages of the two players so it could be that Dehu and not Distin is the man the Hammers are after.
fields.body:
The Sun believes it knows the identity of Rio Ferdinand's replacement at Upton Park, 22-year-old Paris St Germain centre-back Sylvain Distin. The paper claims that the Hammers are also interested in PSG's French international defender Frederic Dehu, but that the club are unlikely to let him leave. However, the paper has managed to confuse the ages of the two players so it could be that Dehu and not Distin is the man the Hammers are after.

The Mirror marks Rangers star Barry Ferguson as the latest transfer target for Arsene Wenger and Arsenal. The paper says the Gunners have been watching the 22-year-old tough-tackling midfielder all season, and will make an £8m offer for him if Rangers get knocked out of the Uefa Cup.

The Mirror also insists that Tore Andre Flo is on his way to join Rangers, in time to make his debut in this weekend's Old Firm match at Ibrox. They claim the Norwegian will sign a £2m-a-year contract in Glasgow, but that Chelsea could soon look to spend some of the £13m transfer fee on the Gers' influential midfielder Giovanni van Bronckhorst.

Charlton will attempt to sign South African captain Shaun Bartlett after their move for John Hartson fell through. The Sun says the Addicks will take the 28-year-old on loan for the season with a view to bringing the £2m-rated player to the Valley fulltime next season.

The latest in the long line of central defenders to be linked with a move to Newcastle is Finnish international Hannu Tihinen. The Daily Star believes that Bobby Robson will pay £1.5m for the Viking Stavanger defender who partners Sami Hyypia in the Finnish defence.

fields.headline: Rio Ferdinand Factfile
fields.trailText: 1978: Born 8 November in Peckham.
fields.body:
1978: Born 8 November in Peckham.

1995: Turns professional with West Ham after coming through the youth ranks where he is a member of the side which wins the South-East Counties' Championship in 1996 and collects an FA Youth Cup runners-up medal.

1996: Makes his debut as a second-half substitute in the 1-1 draw with Sheffield Wednesday at Upton Park in May. Loaned out to Bournemouth in November and makes 11 appearances for the Cherries.

1997: Scores his first goal for the Hammers in the 2-1 defeat at Blackburn in February and makes 14 appearances for his club that season before making his full international debut against Cameroon at Wembley in November.

1998: Named in the England squad for the World Cup finals. Although he does not play in France, he goes on to start the games against Luxembourg and the Czech Republic the following season.

1999: Makes his 100th Premiership appearance against Leicester in January and plays for England against France, Hungary and Sweden.

2000: Comes on as a substitute against Argentina at Wembley in February, but is left out of the England squad for Euro 2000.

August: - Tabloid rumours suggest that both Leeds and Barcelona have tabled multi-million-pound bids for him.

September - West Ham manager Harry Redknapp reveals the club have turned down two offers from Leeds for Ferdinand.

November 20 - Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale confirms a £15m bid for Ferdinand is still on the table.

November 22 - West Ham finally accept Leeds' increased bid of £18m.

webTitle: Ferdinand will complete £18m transfer to Leeds tomorrow

fields.headline: Ferdinand will complete £18m transfer to Leeds tomorrow
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand is on the verge of becoming the world's costliest defender after West Ham confirmed they have accepted a £18m offer from Leeds.
fields.body:
Rio Ferdinand is on the verge of becoming the world's costliest defender after West Ham confirmed they have accepted a £18m offer from Leeds.

Ferdinand will also break the British transfer record if, as expected, he agrees personal terms with Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale tomorrow. His Leeds debut is planned for Sunday's televised home game with Arsenal.

A West Ham spokesman confirmed this morning: "It is true that Leeds came back in and made an £18m offer which has been accepted by this club. Rio has not signed for Leeds yet. They have a very big Uefa Champions League match to play tonight, so he will travel up tomorrow to talk to them. Then it is up to him."

Leeds will make Ferdinand the highest-priced player in the English game, his fee eclipsing the £15m record held jointly by Alan Shearer and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Ferdinand will also shatter the world record for a defender, the £13m paid by Roma for the Argentine Walter Samuel in June.

This morning Ridsdale said he did not wish to comment further until meeting with Ferdinand tomorrow, but Leeds' assistant manager Eddie Gray said he welcomed the move. "The boy is a top-class player and if we could add to the squad at the present time, it would be very helpful," he told BBC Radio 5 Live.

"He played very well on Saturday, there is no doubt the boy has tremendous ability," he continued. "It is a lot of money, but all great things start at the back and we have got one or two defenders at the club who are top class. If we can add to that, then all's well and good."

It is believed Bayern Munich's late intervention, with the German champions ready to offer £16m, prompted Leeds to improve their offer to one that simply could not be refused. West Ham have always been reluctant to sell their most prized asset to another Premiership club and believed they could prise even more from the likes of Barcelona and Roma.

West Ham manager Harry Redknapp has admitted to having mixed feelings over the proposed deal - but uncertainty over the future of the transfer market, plus the sheer size of the fee, appears to have finally broken the club's resistance.

"With the transfer system what it is at the moment, it could all fall to pieces in a month's time and he could be walking away for next to nothing," Redknapp told the club's official website.

"I don't want to lose Rio, he's a fantastic player and will go on to be one of the best in Europe. I've never changed my opinion about that, but £18m breaks all sorts of records really and it's a difficult one to turn down.

"Resources are resources; it's a small ground, and you can't keep everybody. If the transfer system falls apart in a couple of months we're going to look very foolish, so I can understand where the chairman is coming from.

"Anyone who thinks I don't want to keep him is a fool," he continued. "But we're not Arsenal, Manchester United, or Liverpool - we're West Ham. But don't think I'm going to go home and sleep easy knowing a player like that is going to leave.

"At the end of the day everyone has got their price. The chairman, who asks me about everything, is as good as gold - and £18m is a lot of money for someone who might walk away for £5m. How can that be sensible?

"We dug our heels in at the offer of £15m and that extra £3m is a lot of money to a club like West Ham."

Redknapp has pledged to use the money generated from Ferdinand's proposed transfer to strengthen the squad, but insisted that he would resist the temptation to make one or two big signings.

"I have to keep wheeling and dealing," he said. "Hopefully I can go out and find another bargain like Freddie (Kanoute). I was told one paper said someone wants to pay £8m for him - I only paid £3.5m.

"Without blowing my own trumpet I keep picking up bargains like that and I've got to try and find another couple now with Rio's money - if he goes," he added. "To be honest, I probably want to wait and see what happens with the transfer system."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Could Peru's ex-president be Japanese?
fields.standfirst: Alberto Fujimori has fled to Tokyo in a cloud of suspicion, reports Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: View from Tokyo: Alberto Fujimori has fled to Tokyo in a cloud of suspicion, reports Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
After resigning earlier this week as president of Peru, Alberto Fujimori's decision to seek indefinite refuge in Tokyo has turned the spotlight on to Japan's race-based immigration policy and raised new doubts about whether the South American strongman was ever entitled to stand for office.

Mr Fujimori arrived in Tokyo on Friday on an unannounced visit that was arranged in haste. The previous day his opponents had taken control of the Peruvian congress and begun impeachment proceedings against him.

Despite initial claims by the Peruvian embassy that the president was in Japan to request economic aid, and later, medical treatment, it became apparent after his resignation on Tuesday that he sees the country as a potential retirement home.

"I am visiting on a diplomatic passport, and now I am no longer a president but a common citizen," the former president said at the New Otani hotel. "I have not decided yet how long I will stay in Japan."

Tokyo is a natural refuge for Mr Fujimori, whose parents were born in Japan before they emigrated to Peru during the depression of 1934 to work as cotton pickers. His son, Hiro, lives here and his sister is married to the Peruvian ambassador to Tokyo, Victor Aritomi Shindo.

During an often tumultuous 10-year presidency, Mr Fujimori has always been able to rely on economic aid and diplomatic support from Tokyo, even while other countries have complained about the human rights abuses that took place under his rule. When he was elected to his third term last August, the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, was one of the first world leaders to congratulate him, despite complaints in many other nations that the election was rigged.

But it is blood rather than good relations that is likely to give Mr Fujimori the option of living in Tokyo on a long-term basis.

Japan has one of the tightest immigration policies in the world. A mere 1.2% of the population are non-Japanese and citizenship is primarily based on one's family rather than one's birthplace.

To maintain the country's ethnic purity, which is often cited by ruling party conservatives as a factor for the country's low crime rate, Japan has slammed the door on economic and political refugees. Sadako Ogata, the outgoing United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said the fact that her home country had accepted less than 10 refugees in the past two years was shameful.

A senior foreign ministry official said that Japan had a policy of rejecting asylum requests, but in Mr Fujimori's case this will probably not be necessary.

Although the former president has refused to reveal his intentions, he would be given preferential treatment in applying for citizenship by dint of the fact that he is a "nissei" - a generation removed from Japanese nationals. The government has allowed tens of thousands of South American nissei into Japan during the past decade - usually to do the dangerous and dirty hard-labour jobs that the Japanese are unwilling to do themselves.

According to lawyers, the process of acquiring Japanese nationality usually takes between six months and a year. This would present no problems to Mr Fujimori, who has a one-year diplomatic visa. According to the Japanese foreign ministry, this will remain valid despite his resignation from public office.

According to a Reuters report, Mr Fujimori may already have a Japanese passport. Officials in the small town of Kawachi, in Kumamoto Prefecture, told reporters that the former president already holds Japanese nationality because his parents are listed on the local ancestral register.

If this proves to be the case, it would cast doubt on the legality of Mr Fujimori's entire presidency, because only Peruvians are entitled to stand for public office and Japan does not recognise dual nationality once people turn 20.
