fields.headline: Hollywood starts spinning for Oscar
fields.standfirst: Film-makers are putting in early - and costly - bids for Academy award glory
fields.trailText: The studios have started opening their wallets and bankrolling their favourites, and over the next few months millions of dollars will be invested in seeking the elusive nominations
fields.body:
The signs are already here. "Oscar-worthy performances," says an ad for the feel-good film Pay It Forward. "Electrifying Oscar-winning performances by Gooding and De Niro," says an ad for a new drama, Men of Honour.

Like the first cuckoo of spring, the magic word "Oscar" attached to film publicity heralds the arrival of the annual Academy awards spin season, even though the voting is still four months away.

Just as an American presidential election campaign starts years before the actual vote - and in some cases goes on after it - so the film industry believes that it is never too early to start positioning your film and its stars as worthy of consideration for an Oscar.

This year, with the field still wide open, the studios have just opened their wallets and started bankrolling their favourites and over the next few months millions of dollars will be invested in seeking the elusive nominations.

If a critic for any small radio station or obscure magazine wants to see his or her name in print, now is the time to write "Oscar-worthy" in a review, guaranteeing the author's blessed words an appearance on newspaper ads for the film.

Publicity

Men of Honour, which stars Robert De Niro and Cuba Gooding Jr, and Pay It Forward, which stars Kevin Spacey, Helen Hunt and Haley Joel Osment, are just two of the films already being presented for the attentions of the academy members.

"Suddenly Joan Allen, Gary Oldman, Jeff Bridges and Rod Lurie's screenplay are Oscar contenders," says a review for The Contender, the story of a vice-presidential candidate and a sexual scandal, presumably in the hope that America has not had too much of vice-presidents in elections to last it until awards day on March 25. "Ellen Burstyn's performance is of Oscar calibre," says a review attached to Requiem for a Dream.

"It definitely gets more intense every year," says Patrick Goldstein, who writes the Big Picture column in the LA Times. "There is as much spinning going on in the Oscars as in what has been happening in Florida after the presidential election."

The publicists have already started to try to "plant things in our ears", says Goldstein, and the LA Times and the New York Times are the places where they place their highest hopes.

The promoters of Gladiator will doubtless be pleased to see that a still from their film appears next to an article on the Oscars in the New York Times, despite the fact that the film appeared early in the year and was seen as sound and enjoyable rather than prize-winning stuff.

Another procedure being adopted is the re-release of films that failed to attract a large audience when they first appeared but are felt by studios to be worthy of consideration. The latest to get this treatment is Wonder Boys, starring Michael Douglas and directed by Curtis Hanson: both of whom are previous Oscar winners.

Next month come the first of the critics' awards, with special attention again paid to LA and New York, and the Golden Globe nominations made by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

Not to be outdone, the British Bafta awards have been moved forward to January so that they become part of the process rather than a postscript.

Publicists now have the delicate task of promoting their hopefuls without alienating directors, producers and actors who are not to be so favoured. Budgets purely to promote an Oscar bid, which may include persuading the actors to go on the publicity circuit again, run from a minimum of around $500,000 (£350,000) to more than $3m, the cost of a small film.

So what films are really in with a chance in what is effectively the primary season for nominations? Julia Roberts will almost certainly get a best actress nomination for her role in Erin Brockovich, as may Renée Zellweger for Nurse Betty.

Quills, directed by Philip Kaufman and starring Geoffrey Rush, Kate Winslet and Michael Caine, is highly tipped for various honours provided the subject matter of the Marquis de Sade does not make the 6,000 or so academy member voters too squeamish.

Contenders

The Perfect Storm must be a favourite, for special effects at least, and the Denzel Washington film Remember the Titans has its supporters.

Entertainment Weekly has already flagged its list of ones to watch. They include Almost Famous, which has done well critically, if not at the box office.

MGM have hopes for Michael Winterbottom's mining drama, The Claim. Miramax will be marshalling support for All the Pretty Horses and Bounce. New Line is pushing David Mamet's Hollywood satire, State and Main, with William H Macy and Sarah Jessica Parker.

The Coen Brothers' chain gang comedy O Brother, Where Art Thou? and Kenneth Lonergan's film You Can Count On Me are both being touted as producing nomination-worthy performances.

Among the others to have received a mention are Tom Hanks's yet-to-be-released Cast Away and Steven Soderbergh's film Traffic, which was based on the British television mini-series of the same name.

Finding Forrester has Sean Connery also being tipped as a contender for his role as a reclusive author in Gus Van Sant's coming-of-age story about a black teenager in the south Bronx.

And Britain's other hopes? Universal are trusting that Stephen Daldry, director of Billy Elliot, is this year's Sam Mendes, - the British theatre director who wins the hearts of the Academy members. The film has been heavily marketed here and would hope at least to be in the running. High Fidelity, based on Nick Hornby's book but set in the US rather than in London, has also been mentioned.

One things is clear. If there is any dispute about the rightful winners, at least it will not be the secretary of state for Florida who will decide on how the votes should be recounted.

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 23
fields.trailText: November 23: Vodafone has poached the head of Coca-Cola Germany to be its first global brand director.
fields.body:
Vodafone has poached the head of Coca-Cola Germany to be its first global brand director. David Haines, managing director of Coca-Cola GmbH, takes up the newly created position on January 1.

Ford is expected to hand the £50m global ad account for Land Rover to Young & Rubicam. The switch is also expected to see Ogilvy & Mather restored as Ford's lead agency in Europe.

Cadbury Trebor Basset's UK marketing director, Mark Smith, is moving to a new post with Cadbury in Australia.

Channel 5 is to take on BSkyB with the launch of a rival television shopping service.

United News & Media is to shut its holiday web site uTravel.co.uk because of competition in the sector.

Elida Faberge and Laboratoires Garnier are believed to be planning a relaunch for their Organics and Fructis haircare brands. The decision follows the news that Procter & Gamble is relaunching its Pantene brand.

Swizzle.co.uk, the Procter & Gamble-backed portal aimed at teenage girls, has withdrawn its chatroom and bulletin board facilities after a dispute with joint-venture partner Excite@home.

The Royal Mail is launching an ad campaign featuring Carol Smillie and Ground Force presenter Charlie Dimmock.

Insurance company AXA has hired the former Land Rover brand director Andy Hurst to take over the newly created role of director of brand development.

Coca-Cola has hired Mother to create the first local advertising for its Dr Pepper brand. The move is part of Coca-Cola's new "think local" strategy.

The Independent Television Commission has given the go-ahead to Channels 4 and 5, Flextech, GMTV and Sky to pool their sales arrangements.

fields.headline: Former Loaded editor faces axe as Switch2 cuts back
fields.trailText: 10am: Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell is among staff facing the axe at the Switch2 internet service. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Loaded's former editor and publisher and the founder of soccer title 90 Minutes are among staff facing the axe at the Switch2 music, sport and movies internet service.

Former Loaded editor Tim Southwell and publisher Adrian Pettett were lured from IPC earlier this year by the media portal.

The service, which was launched by parent company Edison Interactive to huge fanfare, is struggling to stay alive according to insiders.

Other recruits among the 100 or so staff included 90 Minutes founder Paul Hawksbee, Dave Morley, who produced Channel 5's Night Fever and former MTV head of production Simon Pizey.

Staff at Switch2 were not available for comment.

A spokesman for Edison Interactive said: "All our staff are undergoing a period of consultation as to where they will be located within the company. The number of staff we're going to lose won't become clear until the end of the week."

Of the five consumer lifestyle channels on the portal, only the music site - Done and Dusted - will be maintained. The company says it wants to develop the music channel, which it says has prospects for growth.

The remaining channels, covering sport, games, film and comedy, are expected to close.

Edison Interactive said that the cutbacks were a result of a bid to reform "the company's strategic business".

The company wants to split its business into two parts. It has acknowledged that its broadband strategy was not a success in the consumer marketplace, claiming that "penetration of ADSL into the consumer market is slow".

Switch2, which counts Sky-owned interactive service Open among its shareholders, was launched with a flourish of publicity earlier in the year, targeting 15 to 24-year-olds.

fields.headline: Freeserve back in merger talks
fields.trailText: 9.30am: ISP Freeserve is back in talks with a potential European buyer, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve has confirmed it is back in talks with a company that could see the ISP finally find a European buyer.

The internet service provider, which is 80% owned by Dixons, said it was in talks "which may or may not lead to an offer being made for the company in shares".

Reports suggest that the interested party is French rival Wannado, which is owned by France Telecom, although Freeserve refused to confirm this. The company said it was still talking to other potential partners.

In a statement, Freeserve said that any offer made for the company would be at a realistic price.

Freeserve saw its shares plunge in June by 20% after the collapse of merger talks with German rival T-Online that could have led to a £6bn deal for the internet service provider.

An over-inflated price tag was blamed for the collapse of the June negotiations.

"On the basis of yesterday's share prices it is unlikely that any such offer would be at a substantial premium to Freeserve's share price," the company said.

A further statement is to be made in due course, although it is thought the proposed all-share deal is still weeks away.

Should the deal with Wanadoo come off, a Freeserve tie-up with NTL is inevitable, given France Telecom's large shareholding in the cable company.

Freeserve's shares shot up 9.3p during morning trading to reach 155.3p. It is thought an offer might be placed for the company at around 175p.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Principles not profit | Wind is no solution | Measuring worth | Keeping bad company
fields.body:
Principles not profit

Your report on the financial crisis facing Oxfam (Trouble in store, November 15) shows that, despite the difficulties facing high street retailers such as Marks & Spencer, Oxfam shops have held their own during the past three highly competitive years, even while the amount of their takings going to aid projects has been cut in half.

The costs responsible for this drop are not to be found in the pittance paid to shop managers, but in the elaborate administrative structure, outside consultants and resulting American-style retailing strategies and fancy (but badly designed) shop fittings.

Unfortunately, this latest retailing review, like the all-too-frequent preceding ones, seems to be heading once more in the wrong direction. It is suggested that the connection with Oxfam's overseas projects be made vaguer and that a kind of internal market be imposed, even though such a device has proved so divisive and wrong-headed in the NHS. In addition, recycling activities are to be halted and unsold stock sold to jobbers who will ship it overseas (where it may undermine local clothing industries).

Oxfam is a niche market. It cannot aspire to be an ordinary business without jeopardising its raison d' étre. It would do better by stressing its founding principles of cooperation - rather than competition - long-term development and environmental concern.

Dorothy Stein

Oxfam volunteer, London

 Your article may have alarmed some Oxfam supporters, and understandably so. Sales of donated goods have held up remarkably well and are actually increasing, thanks to our supporters. The issue we face, in common with all charity retailers, is rising costs.

We plan to streamline our shops' supply chain, provide more cost-effective support and pilot new ideas such as e-commerce. But the most important part of making our shops more profitable is giving shop staff and volunteers a bigger say in how they're run. Far from facing job losses, they are the focus of our investment for the future.


Sarah Shekleton
Oxfam Trading

Wind is no solution

John Vidal regularly seems to write with almost religious fervour about wind turbines and to believe that we, the public, couldn't possibly not want them (Eco soundings, November 15).

In mid-Wales we have the highest concentration of wind farms in the UK and they are hated. Snowdonia National Park is slowly getting ringed by these developments, despite huge popular opposition, and now they're apparently starting on Pembrokeshire National Park too.

Here in Wales we know that wind farms are a "fiddling while Rome burns" response to global warming because of the pitiful amount of intermittent power they produce. If the government was serious, it would not bother to subsidise wind power but would subsidise solar panels and insulation for everyone.

Before Vidal criticises the Council for National Parks again, he should realise that most of us are very relieved that there are at least some parts of the open countryside which will hopefully withstand this pointless industrialisation.

Sue Dalton, Ian Thomas and Ken Chorlton

Borth, Ceredigion

Measuring worth

You raise the question of whether confidence in the voluntary sector is being undermined by there being too many charities (Too many cooks?, November 8).

Your article seemed to be trying to stretch a little data too far with its equation of more charities with less efficiency. The research quoted from Manchester Business School is at best a partial account: the 1997 data used show that charities only spent 8% of their total income on fundraising and publicity, with 9% on administration.

The so-called measure of "charity efficiency" proposed, and the league tables that might be derived from it, are not valid ways to measure the work of charities.

There is clearly more that charities can do to further publicise the value that they bring and the collaboration in which they engage. It was therefore disappointing that the article made little mention of the increasing trend towards joint working between charities, nor that this is an area about which organisations are most keen to receive support and advice.

Stuart Etherington

chief executive, National Council for Voluntary Organisations

Keeping bad company

How disappointing that you saw fit to publish such a patronising, complacent and inaccurate article on the Kids Company centre (Big noises call for quiet, November 15).

You portray the local residents who objected to planning consent as nimby whingers. Had your reporter troubled to consult the people directly affected by this centre's activities, he would have found that this run-down estate already hosts a disproportionate number of special needs facilities - the majority of which have been integrated without difficulty into the community.

The article focuses on the deprived children catered for by the centre. Those same children jeer and threaten my children, my neighbours' children and elderly residents as they walk past. Cars are regularly vandalised and older children have been assaulted. Last week, a boy outside the club was brandishing a gun. My nine and 12-year-old daughters wisely did not stop to inquire whether it was a replica or the real thing.

Can I suggest your reporter and concerned residents of leafy suburbs invite Kids Company to set up in their neighbourhood before so willingly encouraging the residents of Walworth to welcome the centre in theirs.

Maggie Alexande

 Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited

In mid-Wales we have the highest concentration of wind farms in the UK and they are hated. Snowdonia National Park is slowly getting ringed by these developments, despite huge popular opposition, and now they're apparently starting on Pembrokeshire National Park too. webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Staring into the abyss

fields.headline: Staring into the abyss
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: How far have we progressed since a Lords committee of expert scientists in April 1998 documented a great threat to public health: the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria?
fields.body:
A formal government response to Lord Phillips's 16-volume report on BSE and how mad cow disease spread to humans is still awaited. Meanwhile, how far have we progressed since a Lords committee of expert scientists in April 1998 documented a much greater threat to public health: the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria? A parallel study by the standing medical advisory committee concluded: "We are looking into the abyss."

The problem is easily put: misuse of antibiotics in intensive farming and over-prescribing by doctors is leading the world back to pre-penicillin days. Huge advances achieved by antibiotics in the last 60 years against a host of diseases and infections are now threatened by revitalised multi-drug resistant organisms.

Certainly more headway has been made than was achieved by the Swann committee, which called in 1969 for an over-arching expert committee to monitor the use of human and animal medicines. The committee never materialised. A sub-committee of the veterinary products committee was established, but when it asked in 1981 for funds to monitor the problem, not only was it refused by Tory ministers but the committee was abolished.

Acutely aware of this history, the Lords committee is due to review progress. There is movement: an inter-departmental steering group; new guidance to doctors and patients on the danger of misusing antibiotics; new bans on six antibiotic animal growth promoters. A seventh, just banned in the US, is being investigated. Growth promoter bans are EU and US driven. The UK was the only European member to oppose a 1996 ban, but all six bans in 1999 were supported by Labour.

But much more needs doing. One-off campaigns achieve little, at best a momentary dip, when the Lords report spoke of up to 50% over-prescribing. Only a sustained campaign will turn this round. The promised expert committee is still not in place, 30 months after the last proposal and 31 years after Swann. The call for more antibiotics research has not been taken up by Wellcome or Medical Research Council grants. And the monitoring of animal antibiotics falls far short: 1999 figures not due until next year, no distinction between species.

It has been left to the Soil Association to show that, despite growth promoter bans, vets continue to prescribe antibiotics in ever greater tonnage. Following Swann, tetracycline was banned as a growth promoter in 1969, when 19.5 tons was being used. A Soil Association report in 1998 calculated 350 tons were being prescribed for animal sickness 30 years later. Far from receding, the gaping abyss now looks even more threatening.

webTitle: What the  report from the World Commission on Dams will mean

fields.headline: Lies, dam lies
fields.standfirst: Phil Williams  and  Patrick McCully  look at what the recent report from the World Commission on Dams will mean for future projects
fields.trailText: Phil Williams and Patrick McCully look at what the recent report from the World Commission on Dams will mean for future projects
fields.body:
In 1997, when the World Commission on Dams was initiated, anti-dam activists were divided over the wisdom of cooperating with the World Bank. From the 60s on, the bank was the main force that financed and legitimised the big dam building boom that has transformed the world's rivers.

Activists participating in the "consultation" processes of the bank felt they were ignored or misrepresented. Others had seen progressive policies adopted on paper, then routinely ignored by bank staff. The World Commission must be used, they agreed, as a "truth commission", to produce a report that would indict the record and rationale of dams.

Dam promoters, guilty of 40 years of ecologic and social destruction, were to be held accountable. Reparations for the millions of dispossessed people and restoration of river ecosystems were to be advocated. Most importantly, the report must not become yet another endorsement of the "benefits" of dams, leaving unchallenged the keystone of the dam builders' ideology - that dams are needed for "economic development" that benefits the poor.

Last week in London a gathering of the world's great and good marked the release of the commission's final report. Leading anti-dam activists joined Nelson Mandela, James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, and representatives of the dam building industry. As they had expected, the report documented the huge social costs of large dams, with up to 80m people dispossessed and countless millions more impoverished. It acknowledged the shoddy economics and violations of human rights that attended dam construction. It advocated more rigorous standards for planning future projects, including the need for prior informed consent of affected peoples. So shouldn't activists feel vindicated?

The answer is no. The commission, evading its main task of adjudicating the "development effectiveness" of dams, emphasises that it is poor planning of past dams that has caused unnecessary harm. This contradicts critics' charges that it is the dams themselves, no matter how well planned, that inevitably create unmitigated social and ecologic impacts. Critics also charge that dams are the very antithesis of development for the poor because they enable the expropriation of the resources of a river valley, placing the livelihood of people who depend on rivers at the disposal of those who have the power to exploit them. Did the commission prove these critics wrong?

Not at all. The World Commission on Dams was no "truth commission", but more of a "peace process". The text of the final report is the product of a settlement negotiated among human rights activists, water policy experts and dam builders; not a scientific inquiry. Those activists who have facilitated the commission's process are pleased with the outcome. They believe much of the evidence will support their future campaigns, and they argue the commission's recommendations for transparent planning process and "prior informed consent", if enacted, would virtually preclude future dam projects.

Others will be less satisfied. They see failure to challenge the rationale for dam building to be a major setback, and the failure of the commission clearly to advocate reparations for affected people to be a disap pointment. Environmentalists too will disagree with the commission's view of the impact of dams on river ecosystems - that, with better planning, new dams can be built that will mitigate their adverse impacts or even enhance the river environment.

The pressure for consensus blinded the commission to what could have been its most important and original contribution: to address the global cumulative impacts of dams. Except for global warming, there is no more drastic human alteration of the physical and ecologic landscape in the last 40 years than the damming, regulation and diversion of the world's rivers. To say that dams affect 60% of the world's rivers greatly understates their affect on the transformation of river valleys, estuaries, coastlines and coastal seas in temperate and tropical zones.

The decline and destruction of species dependent on floodplains, wetlands, and natural river flows is not just an environmental tragedy but affects the food supply and livelihood of millions. Cities, river valleys and whole countries are now economically linked, held hostage for their water supply and flood protection to the operation of big dams upstream, dams that are silting up, ageing and growing more dangerous every year; dams we now acknowledge were poorly planned, in ignorance or disdain for their true long-term costs. The real question in the big dams debate is similar to that posed by nuclear power plants: not how to improve their planning, but how to get rid of them.

Over the last three years, while activists have been lobbying the commission, dam building has continued. Plans for new projects like Ilusu in Turkey, Wloslawek on the Vistula, resurrected projects like Arun in Nepal, or Bakun in the rainforest of Sarawak have moved ahead. Construction of Itoitz in Spain, Boguchany in Siberia and the Three Gorges in China has continued. Most poignant of all, last month the Indian Supreme Court approved completion of the World Bank-initiated Sardar Sarovar dam. It was the argument of presumed development benefits, not the vigorous prior informed dissent of 500,000 citizens of the Narmada valley, that the court found most persuasive.

 Dr Philip Williams, a consulting engineer in San Francisco, is founder and former president of the International Rivers Network. He resigned because of disagreements over the organisation's support of the WCD process

Guidelines give protesters hope

The World Commission on Dams recommends that dams should only be built if developers can gain the "demonstrable public acceptance" of affected communities at each of the key stages of the decision-making process. This requirement has huge implications for the global dam industry, which has in the past largely ignored the protests of those it would deprive of their lands and livelihoods.

If affected people agree that projects can go ahead, the commission recommends that developers should negotiate binding agreements, enabling communities to hold developers accountable to their promises of resettlement and compensation. Community participation in negotiations should be enabled through "timely access to information and legal and other necessary support".

Booker Prize-winning Indian author Arundhati Roy, a high-profile opponent of the dams on India's Narmada River, says that the controversial Sardar Sarovar and Maheshwar projects could never be built if their promoters had to gain the acceptance of the hundreds of thousands of people who would be displaced by the projects' reservoirs and canals. "There is no land available to resettle these people, the great majority are bitterly opposed to the projects, so it is inconceivable they would ever freely agree to give up their homes," says Roy.

It is also difficult to believe that the nearly two million people being evicted to make way for China's gargantuan Three Gorges dam would ever freely agree to the project. While it is just as unlikely that the Chinese government would give these people the chance to be heard, the WCD report could hinder China's efforts to raise hard currency from foreign export credit agencies and Wall Street banks for a project which is so blatantly in breach of what is the only set of international standards on dam building.

The Ilisu Dam, on the Tigris River in Turkey, under consideration for export credits from the British government, also clearly fails the test of community consent and information disclosure. The Kurdish areas affected by the project have been devastated by armed conflict and remain under emergency rule.

The UK and other European export credit agencies proposing to fund Ilisu would also fall foul of the commission's recommendation that there be no foreign funding for dams if countries downstream have not been properly consulted. Syria and Iraq, downstream on the Tigris, are both strongly opposed to Ilisu fearing it will increase Turkey's ability to cut off their water supply.

And the Bujugali Falls dam, on the Nile in Uganda, which the World Bank is currently evaluating for funding, would break the recommendation that "risks must be identified, articulated and addressed". The power purchase agreement for Bujugali, which allocates the financial risks of the project between the developer - US multinational AES - and the Ugandan government, is a state secret.

 Patrick McCully works for International Rivers Network and is author of Silenced Rivers (Zed Books)

webTitle: Grand piano takes pride of place in Amazon village church

fields.headline: New sound of the forest
fields.standfirst: Grand piano takes pride of place in Amazon village church
fields.trailText: Grand piano takes pride of place in Amazon village church
fields.body:
The rainforests of Guyana have been the setting of many fantastic events, which now must include the recent delivery of a grand piano to an Amazonian community of Wai Wai Indians, one of the most remote peoples on earth.

It all began when explorer Colonel John Blashford-Snell was asked by a village elder if he could get a piano for their church. Having been converted by the American Unevangelised Field Missions in the 40s and 50s, the Wai Wai in Guyana are now devout Christians who neither smoke nor drink. They have a Bible translation in their language but are otherwise left to fend for themselves without a priest. The only musical instrument they have for their services is a guitar.

Last month, an 800lb piano, provided by a London hotel group, reached Georgetown, the capital of Guyana. With the help of Blashford Snell and a 72-year-old former Royal Engineer, a sled was constructed outside the premises of a local hardwood supplier. This was to go with the piano to Gunn's Strip, the most remote airstrip in Guyana, close to the Brazilian border and the vast jungles.

The rest of the trip was alternately preposterous and amazing. Men, women and children met the plane with only a small wheelbarrow and a bicycle to carry the tools, pumps, pipes, food, petrol, medicines and school books which had been donated. The crate was strapped to the sled and pulled with ropes across five miles of sandy savannah, down forest tracks, through ravines and creeks to the Wai Wai's old village.

However, the village has now moved because of recent floods. The choice was to either spend a week hacking through dense jungle or to use a large canoe made from a hollowed-out tree. This would be short but perilous. Rapids would have to be negotiated against the current and the piano then dragged uphill to the new village.

The river option was chosen and with supreme confidence an alarming number of Wai Wai piled into the canoe with the piano and proceeded upstream and then through a side creek to the closest access to the village site. It was a struggle.

When they finally came out of the cool forest they met the cauldron of heat at the newly-cleared site of the partly-built village. Some fires of felled trees were still smouldering and acrid smoke filled the air.

When the crate was opened the Wai Wai looked on in some awe. The piano was assembled and tuned by an ex-army GP from Peterborough, and the first tune, "God Save the Queen", was played, followed by hymns.

Then the Wai Wai who wanted to do an impromptu concert. The spectacle of a grand piano being played intuitively by Amazonian indians in resonance with the pristine green mansions of their forest home touched everyone and at least one man shed tears. It was a new sound in the village, one to join the repertoire of everyday early morning choruses of troupes of Howler monkeys, dogs, chicks, a tame trum peter bird, a toucan and a parrot.

But many forest voices were not there. The forests are becoming more and more silent. What is happening now in Amazonia is a sort of twilight of the tribes. This Wai Wai group came originally from Brazil and the area where they are was traditionally occupied by others.

The Taruma and Atorad peoples, for example, are not even listed among the tribes of Guyana, and their unique cultures, language and knowledge are unrecorded and therefore unknown. Although these lost tribes still exist, they are effectively invisible and on the point of extinction. Their cultures, language and knowledge are disappearing even faster than the habitats themselves.

Unless they and others are given help, recognition and perhaps are paid to be guardians of the forest and to provide the security for it and its resources, they will surely die out. The grim reality is that no one is taking seriously their knowledge and potential contribution to the world.

A global amnesia is settling among liberated cultures, captivated by the economics of modern consumerism which may be sowing the seeds of its own destruction. The Wai Wai now represent a people at a watershed of change with potential access to global communications, including television and the mores of the global consumer society. But can their forest homes sustain such expectations? And what if they fail and abandon their forest to destruction?

 Dr Conrad Gorinsky is a chemist and ethno botanist

webTitle: Swiss firm wins Design Museum award

fields.headline: Green textiles
fields.standfirst: Swiss firm wins Design Museum award
fields.trailText: Swiss firm wins Design Museum award
fields.body:
An obscure Swiss textile firm, which turned round its ailing business by going green and inventing a biodegradable and compostable upholstery fabric, has won the Design Museum's £40,000 prize for sustainability.

Rohner Textil AG was a traditional mill, struggling to compete against low-cost producers in developing countries, when its managing director, Albin Kälin, decided to make environmental and social responsibility his selling point. The revolutionary fabric, Climatex Lifecycle, is made of a mix of wool from "free range, humanely sheared" New Zealand sheep and ramie, a moisture conducting fibre used by the Egyptians 4,000 years ago and now organically grown in the Philippines.

The company has literally "greened" its old mill, in Balgach, by planting a grass roof to alleviate the steamy temperatures inside. Alternative health practitioners have been brought in to advise on ergonomics and stress management. In addition, the company runs an educational programme and has set up a profit sharing arrangement with its 30-strong workforce.

It was this holistic approach that gave Rohner the edge in a high profile shortlist for the Design Sense award, which included the likes of architects Foster & Partner's energy efficient design for the Reichstag, the German parliament, and BMW's recyclable C1 motorcycle.

Entries were evaluated in terms of their environmental, commercial, social and aesthetic impact on current and future generations. The judges of the award for sustainable design, sponsored by metal producer Corus, said Rohner was a commercially successful example of how the notoriously dirty global textile industry could clean up its act. webTitle: NHS finance chief Colin Reeves  to quit

fields.headline: Out for the count
fields.standfirst: NHS finance chief Colin Reeves  to quit
fields.trailText: NHS finance chief Colin Reeves to quit
fields.body:
The hunt is on for a new finance chief for the NHS. Official confirmation is due tomorrow that Colin Reeves, the quietly authoritative and respected director of finance, is off to the private sector in a move that will leave a big hole in the senior management team at a critical period for the government's NHS reforms.

Reeves, who has been in the post for more than six years, is to head the review board of the Accountancy Foundation, a regulatory body. Meanwhile, his deputy, Bill McCarthy, will also leave to take up an unspecified operational job within the NHS.

The official steer is that the moves reflect a feeling that with the NHS plan published, the big finance management challenges now lie outside the Department of Health. Yet, with £19bn being invested in the health service over the next four years, the lack of any obvious successor to Reeves will cause comment.

McCarthy, who was chief number-cruncher to Alan Milburn, health secretary, during the drafting of the NHS plan, would clearly have been in the frame had he not opted for a change.

There appears to be no whiff of scandal, or falling out, accompanying Reeves's resignation. Indeed, it is suggested that Milburn asked him in vain to stay. Reeves wavered, but eventually decided to go to what will, in its own field, be a higher profile, as well as better paid, job.

News of his departure follows a wider management reorganisation at the top of the NHS, instituted by new chief executive Nigel Crisp. He will shortly appoint a new head of primary care to replace the recently departed Mike Farrar.

Reeves's successor will retain responsibility for NHS and social care financial matters, but will no longer have responsibility for performance management areas such as waiting lists. That role passes to Neil McKay, recently appointed chief operating officer.

Reeves, an experienced NHS accountant, moved to the top NHS finance job in the mid-90s alongside then chief executive Alan Langlands, with whom he had worked at the former North West Thames regional health authority. As a measure of his success, Reeves has managed to deliver "unqualified" NHS annual accounts - meaning passed by the auditor - in each of the past five years, an achievement far from guaranteed in the early 90s.

Reeves has also been popular among his peers - again, not always the case with his predecessors - and well known for his commitment to supporting colleagues on the front line of NHS financial management.

Last December, when the Healthcare Financial Management Association (HFMA), which represents NHS accountants, was publicly rebuked by Langlands for publishing a survey on health authority deficits, Reeves, who was not directly involved, was discreetly supportive.

"Colin was very sympathetic to what we had done," says an HFMA figure. "He never denied the figures were right, and I think he appreciated that the figures had been aired outside his office. I do not doubt he had been telling ministers the same thing from inside his office."

Several names are being mooted as potential successors to Reeves, including John Bacon, director of finance and acting chief executive at the NHS London region (where Crisp was his boss), and John Flook, director of finance at County Durham health authority and a member of the NHS modernisation task force.

webTitle: OK! close to deal for Express

fields.headline: OK! close to deal for Express
fields.trailText: 9am: The Express Newspapers are set to be snapped up by the owner of OK! magazine in a £125m deal.
fields.body:
The Express Newspapers are set to be snapped up by the owner of OK! magazine in a £125m deal.

Richard Desmond has come from nowhere to beat the billionaire Hinduja brothers to the head of the queue for the titles, according to reports in the Financial Times.

A deal has yet to be signed and sealed, but it is believed that Northern and Shell will also inherit a stake in the lucrative Westferry printing plant, which is joint-owned with Daily Telegraph owner Hollinger International.

Both sides were said to be meeting last night to rush through a deal which would add the Express, the Star to Desmond's array of titles which include Asian Babes and Exotic Stories.

The £125m deal hinges on a number of performance targets for the newspapers.

Before Northern & Shell's dramatic entry into the race, it was thought the Hindujas or the Daily Mail would win control of the papers.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Business as usual | That sinking feeling | Get the message? | Low budget
fields.body:
Business as usual

The conference hall in the Hague in which 160 countries are trying to come to a deal on climate change is below sea level. Symbolically on Saturday, in the biggest demonstration Friends of the Earth has ever organised, 6,000 volunteers from 40 countries built a 500 metre-long sand bag barrier round the conference hall. The Dutch environment minister, Jan Pronk, who is also president of the conference, came out and placed the last of the 50,000 bags. That night the demonstrators celebrated their feat in a "flood survival tent". By Sunday, the good mood had evaporated and, while delegates, press and officials were inside the vast atrium of the Netherlands ministry of environment at Pronk's official welcome party, it was back to normal outside with riot police dispersing a crowd of demonstrators. And on Monday, to make sure it really was business as usual, the sand bag barrier had been removed to make way for the traffic.

That sinking feeling

Inside the hangar in the conference hall, the major row is about "sinks". These are claims that if you plant trees or crops that take carbon out of the atmosphere it can be claimed as a credit to be counted against your emissions from burning fossil fuels. The US gets the flak for this loophole, but the Australians are the most shameless exponents, claiming anything that grows more than 15cm high can be counted as a sink. The largest cafe in use in the climate conference sports not flowers on the table but buckets of grass, they are labelled "Australian sinks".

Get the message?

The www.climatevoice.org website started an ambitious plan on August 22 to send messages to world leaders demanding they use the Hague summit to tackle climate change. They had an ambitious target of 10m in three months. On Monday, 93 heads of state, from Afghanistan to Zimbabwe, had received a total of 11m messages.

Low budget

The dominate players at the Hague are the US and EU. The people who will get wiped out first in Africa and low-lying islands hardly have a voice. It's all to do with economics. The US have 150 delegates at the luxury Bel Air Hotel. Mozambique have three delegates - they are sharing a dormitory in the Hague youth hostel with a group of Japanese students on vacation.

webTitle: Profile:  Alec Jenner, the man who helped to create Valium

fields.headline: Keeping an open mind
fields.standfirst: Alec Jenner, the man who helped to create Valium
fields.trailText: Profile: Alec Jenner, the man who helped to create Valium
fields.body:
It is 41 years since Alec Jenner was sitting in a Sheffield hospital canteen, reading in the Daily Mirror how a circus trainer was using a drug to sedate his tigers. "Hey, this could work on the people of Sheffield," he joked to his colleagues.

But the ambitious young psychiatrist saw in the story more than material for a wisecrack; he'd spotted an opportunity to further his career. He wrote to Swiss pharmaceutical company Hoffmann La Roche, suggesting the drug could relieve anxiety in humans and offering to carry out trials on patients. The company agreed and, after Jenner and his colleagues' research yielded positive results, Roche developed Valium.

The drug was launched on to the global market in 1963. Over the next 40 years, Valium and similar tranquillisers called benzodiazepines became legendary for their immediate relief of anxiety and depression for millions across the world.

Jenner, now 72 and retired, should therefore perhaps be glowing with pride in his farmhouse near Sheffield, after playing his part in the creation of the drug, known affectionately as "mother's little helper". But, over the past 20 years, he has witnessed Roche and other benzodiazepine manufacturers feeling the wrath of thousands of users, complaining of addiction and brain damage they claim has been caused by long-term use of the drugs.

In 1986, 17,000 people brought a group action against benzodiazepine makers Wyeth, Roche and Upjohn. Although the action collapsed in 1994, when the legal aid board stopped paying legal fees that had already reached £35m, the sense of injustice felt by the victims is as strong as ever. At a "beat the benzos" conference earlier this month, calls were renewed for compensation for benzodiazepine victims and a full inquiry into how the drugs were prescribed, despite their having been listed as drugs of "dependence" by the World Health Organisation and the British Medical Journal as early as the 60s.

In fact, it took until 1988 - two years after the group action launch - for the committee of safety of medicines to recognise benzodiazepine dependence and to introduce guidelines specifying that the drugs should not be prescribed for more than four weeks.

Jenner admits that when he carried out his early trials, he did not even consider the possibility of dependency problems - for which he is left feeling "extremely naïve". He says: "When I was researching the drug, we just thought of the advances this new drug could make. In the late 50s, the main treatment for anxiety was the barbiturate drugs, which were a lot more dangerous. When I was an ambitious doctor, I did not even think of Valium's addictive potential - although I now wish I had."

Jenner admits that research on long-term effects of medication is not a cosy fit with the profit-making plans of pharmaceutical companies. "Long-term trials are very expensive and difficult to arrange," he says. "You cannot take this out of the equation in assessing what happened with benzodiazepines.

"And I would have been surprised if Roche had asked me to do long-term trials of Valium. The company would have been anxious to get it on the market. This is where you can be critical of the drug companies - but it is the system in which they work."

After his early pioneering trials, Jenner did little further work for Roche. But, in 1990, he received a letter from the company's solicitors asking him to give his scientific opinion on the files of dozens of the group action Valium users complaining of addiction and memory loss, epileptic fits, vision problems, mood swings and extensive cognitive deficits. His assessment was that, generically, the users' problems were as likely to be due to "addictive personalities" and "neurotic" or "pre-morbid" diagnoses as Valium addiction and damage.

Roche used Jenner's analysis in its defence. A company spokesman says its benzodiazepines have, since launch, been fully researched and kept under constant review. "They have come to play an essential role in modern clinical practice, not only in the treatment of sleep and anxiety disorders but in a wide variety of psychiatric and medical uses." The litigation had been "misguided and bound to fail".

Jenner says now: "A lot of files I examined were those of people who have what I call 'problems of living' and who are searching for explanations of why they have such problems. I have sympathy for the people involved, some of whom may have a case. But the issue for me was to demonstrate scientifically whether their complaints were because of the effects of Valium. This was not the case. And, in legal cases, the benefit of the doubt is always with the accused.

"Having said this, much of the research is contradictory and we are not certain of very much in psychiatry. Allegations of damage could turn out to be true - in the same way as we did not originally think of the possibilities of addiction but now recognise this to be so."

Jenner agreed to talk to the Guardian because he believes in open discussion about psychiatry and its drugs. His philosophy was demonstrated by him becoming founding editor in 1986 of Asylum - A Magazine for Democratic Psychiatry, which questions traditional psychiatric practice and continues the debate about benzodiazepines - particularly raising concerns about the high levels of the drugs given to patients in secure psychiatric units.

And despite Jenner's view that the drug companies have no case to answer, he still recognises some validity in calls for a public inquiry. "Such an inquiry might find something I have missed," he says. "It might satisfy people who think that something has been hidden in the whole story about benzodiazepines."

 Asylum is published quarterly by Handsell Publishing (01452-380319)

Patsy Kensit stars in ITV's Christmas panto. P16

EMI faces EC hurdles in BMG merger. P79

webTitle: Five-year plan for cerebral palsy charity

fields.headline: Five-year plan for cerebral palsy charity
fields.standfirst: As shop profits plummet, Scope takes stock and refocuses attention on four priority areas
fields.trailText: As shop profits plummet, Scope takes stock and refocuses attention on four priority areas
fields.body:
Scope, the cerebral palsy charity, is the latest voluntary organisation to announce cuts after a collapse of income from its high street shops. The charity aims to reduce its spending next year by almost £4m.

Simultaneously, though, Scope is refocusing and sharpening its agenda. For the first time, it will have clear and quantified five-year goals for expansion of services in priority areas of work.

The result is something of a paradox. "The next two or three months are going to be pretty painful," admits Richard Brewster, the charity's chief executive. On the other hand, he says, because of the new agenda "the sense of release of energy is palpable".

The sharp downturn in the fortunes of most charity shops has been ascribed variously to higher costs, greater competition and the arrival of budget clothing chains such as Matalan. As Society reported last week, Oxfam is restructuring after its shop profits halved in two years.

Scope's shop profits, measured before taking account of central overheads, have plummeted from £6.8m in 1997-98 to £2.6m last year. The charity as a whole recorded deficits of £2.7m in 1998-99 and £800,000 last year - a figure cushioned by substantial legacy income.

Brewster reflects ruefully that the downturn came just as the charity was embarking on a fundamental review of what it was - and was not - doing to help people with cerebral palsy (CP). "The number of things we can do goes nowhere near meeting the needs," he says, "and therefore the thing that Scope finds most difficult is saying no."

But say no it will. Future work is to focus on four priority areas: support for children newly diagnosed with CP; education support for children and young people with CP; support for disabled people to obtain and retain work; and support for disabled adults in daily living. Within each of the four, further priority will go to those facing the greatest inequality, whether by severity of impairment, poverty or race.

To release funds for this work, while additionally adjusting for the slump in shop profits, Brewster says Scope will have to "cut into some of the real flesh". About £1m is to come out of overheads through reorganisation; the existing structure of 13 generic community or "partnership" teams will be wound up; four of the charity's "schools for parents" may close; and grant-giving to individuals will cease.

Set against this, new developments will include creation of new teams, initially five, to build relations with health and social services. The aim is for Scope, within five years, to be in touch with all children with CP, compared to just half at present.

Net job losses are likely to amount to 65-70, or 80 if the schools for parents do not survive. Ten of the charity's 314 charity shops have already closed and 10 more are expected to follow. But sales are rising again and Brewster says morale among shop staff is on a "huge high".

In the sense of the proverbial ill wind, would Scope have refocused its work in the same way but for the nosedive in shop income? "We would have had the new goals," says Brewster, "but whether they would have been so sharp is an interesting question."

webTitle: Mersey tunnels become a unique heritage site

fields.headline: Carved with pride
fields.standfirst: Everyone's heard of the Mersey tunnels. Or have they? Deep beneath the city, a long-forgotten labyrinth is being opened up to create a unique heritage site - and jobs.  Carol Davis  reports
fields.trailText: Everyone's heard of the Mersey tunnels. Or have they? Deep beneath the city, a long-forgotten labyrinth is being opened up to create a unique heritage site - and jobs. Carol Davis reports
fields.body:
It has been called the first job creation scheme. Now, it is about to spawn a second one. With £750,000 public funding, work will next month begin on reopening a labyrinth of tunnels under Liverpool, created by a local philanthropist to provide work for men returning from the Napoleonic wars. Once derided, but long forgotten, the tunnels are poised to become a unique visitor attraction for the city.

The extraordinary maze of tunnels runs through the sandstone of Edge Hill, once a village just outside what is now Liverpool's city centre. Nobody knows how extensive they are - though they include a dining hall and, reputedly, complete houses - and nobody quite understands why tobacco millionaire Joseph Williamson spent his entire fortune on digging the network.

Local historians know only that Williamson had one tunnel built so that he and his wife could stay dry while walking to church; that he entertained radical friends to a subterranean banquet; and that he spent the last days of his life in an underground suite of rooms.

But former seaman and labourer Gabriel Muies, driving force behind the Joseph Williamson Society and the one-man impetus for the project which will open them up, has his own answer. "This was the world's first job creation scheme," he says. "The pyramids were built by slaves, but Williamson paid the men who were coming back from the Napoleonic wars to create these tunnels, and he gave them back their dignity."

Today, the best route into the labyrinth is through the derelict lord mayor's stables, a Georgian complex of stabling and housing which is to become a visitor centre for the tunnels. In one corner of the complex, a graceful brick arch leads into a massive cavern. Old butter churns and wooden wheels lie around - paraphernalia of a long-forgotten world which will eventually become an on-site museum.

In the gloom at the back of the cavern, further arches lead to tunnels into the hill. Visitors can scramble through a hole to see a huge chamber above, tunnels running off to the left and towards the underground banqueting hall, and masons' chisel marks everywhere on the hand-hewn walls. Yet this narrow space is the apex of a massive tunnel, largely filled with some 12 metres (about 40 feet) of domestic ash and landfill from decades when the city used the tunnels as a dump.

Muies points out that Williamson, over the 20 years or so he paid men to build the elaborate tunnels, was also keeping alive their masonry, joinery and bricklaying skills. One half-finished tunnel marks the point where men employed by the great railway engineer Robert Stephenson tunnelled into a gang of Williamson's diggers. Stephenson promptly employed them.

Muies's own involvement with the tunnels goes back over half a century, when he used to fill a bag with scavenged coals so that he and his grandmother could have a fire at the weekend at their Toxteth home. "I'd go into the railway tunnels, and when the trains rattled through pieces of coal would fall off," he recalls. "But when the railwaymen spotted us, they would shout: 'Get out, or the Mad Mole of Edge Hill will get you!' The shouting echoed down the tunnels, and I used to pick up my bag and run like hell."

Like most people in Liverpool, Muies believed that the story of the Mad Mole's tunnels was a myth. He only re-encountered the tale many years later, as a parent governor concerned about possible structural defects at his son's school. The school turned out to be next door to the remains of Williamson's mansion.

Muies recounted the tales and was ribbed. When the parent governors adjourned to the pub, one roared, "Get a drink for the Mad Mole, him and his tunnels!" But one of the older regulars overheard, and commented that he had played in the tunnels as a child. Muies bought him a drink and got into conversation, the man remembering the one entrance that had not been filled in. Next time Muies visited the pub, the man had with him a a friend who remembered that there was another entrance through the lord mayor's stables.

For 15 years, Muies has been battling against red tape to gain entrance to the tunnels and preserve them. City council officers were quick to deny their existence: like other local landowners, they have had difficulty with the idea that the land may be unstable. Indeed, one Victorian newspaper called the tunnels "a gigantic nuisance" - and that has been the line taken by those in authority for over a century.

As Muies has pieced together the story through books, maps and diagrams gathering dust in the city's archives, a fascinating picture has emerged. When men returning from the Napoleonic wars begged Williamson for work, he paid them to clean up his fields, then to build a wall around his estate. When those projects were finished, and the men were desperate for more pay, he told them to dig a tunnel into the hill on which his mansion was built.

"Joseph Williamson arrived in Liverpool penniless as an 11-year old, and he died penniless - all he had was his mansion," says Muies. "This man was no madman: he was Liverpool's greatest benefactor."

Once he had rediscovered the tunnels, Muies pleaded with the council to develop them. Instead, the authority sold the lord mayor's stables and surrounding land, with permission to demolish the buildings. Muies went straight to the developer,Seymour Properties, and explained the story. "I told them that this is a little gem," he says. "They agreed it is a unique piece of Liverpool's history."

A deal was struck: Seymour gave 90% of the site to the Joseph Williamson Society, together with a £200,000 donation, covering the costs by developing the remaining part, which was built on in the 30s. Muies then used the initial donation to secure a total £750,000 funding from the Granby Toxteth partnership, the Parks partnership and the European "objective 1" programme for Merseyside, designed to create jobs in deprived areas.

He also plans to apply for further objective 1 funding over the next five years. His argument is simple: "I'm unemployed, I fit your criteria, and I'm creating jobs not only for myself but for other local people too."

Work is scheduled to start on the site within the next few weeks, with the first phase due to open to the public by next Easter. The scheme will eventually include the tunnels (with disabled access), a restaurant and marquee; children's entertainment, including a maypole and live theatre; and a range of heritage businesses, from horse-drawn taxicabs to traditional crafts. The signs are that local interest is strong: a heritage weekend in 1998, supported by the Guardian, drew 2,500 people.

Muies is fast turning into the stuff of local legend himself. When he drinks in The Empress, his local in Toxteth and the old watering hole of Ringo Starr's parents, they call him "the king of Liverpool's underworld". When a rumour went round town that he was removing chains from the tunnels, and that there was some connection with Liverpool's slaving history, he snorted: "Chains? There were no chains. Those tunnels were dug by a load of hard-working scousers - and a load of hard-working scousers will dig them out again."

The Mole of Edge Hill

Carol Davis

Joseph Williamson, the Mole of Edge Hill, lived from 1769 to 1840. Starting work in a warehouse at the age of 11, his numerical skills meant he was offered a job in the office. He eventually married the boss's only daughter.

After having made his tobacco fortune, Williamson had no children to lavish it on or leave it to. He was touched by the plight of soldiers returning from the Napoleonic wars and became obsessed with the idea of giving them a respectable wage.

He did not encourage visitors to his subterranean kingdom. One of his few visitors described "vaulted passageways cut out of solid rock: archways thrown up by craftsmen's hands, beautiful in proportion, elegant in form, but supporting nothing".

Other accounts describe a labyrinth of as-yet uncharted tunnels, said to include complete houses and a banqueting hall 24 metres long (80ft) and 12 metres high (40ft).

The Joseph Williamson Society is a registered charity based at 18 Rose Brae, Mossley Hill, Liverpool. Membership costs £5 adult, £3 concessions. Small groups of members may visit the tunnels by appointment (contact Simon Wrigley on 0151-233 4085).

Those tunnels were dug by a load of hard-working scousers - and a load of hard-working scousers will dig them out again." The Mole of Edge Hill Carol Davis Joseph Williamson, the Mole of Edge Hill, lived from 1769 to 1840. Starting work in a warehouse at the age of 11, his numerical skills meant he was offered a job in the office. He eventually married the boss's only daughter. After having made his tobacco fortune, Williamson had no children to lavish it on or leave it to. He was touched by the plight of soldiers returning from the Napoleonic wars and became obsessed with the idea of giving them a respectable wage. He did not encourage visitors to his subterranean kingdom. One of his few visitors described "vaulted passageways cut out of solid rock: archways thrown up by craftsmen's hands, beautiful in proportion, elegant in form, but supporting nothing". Other accounts describe a labyrinth of as-yet uncharted tunnels, said to include complete houses and a banqueting hall 24 metres long (80ft) and 12 metres high (40ft). The Joseph Williamson Society is a registered charity based at 18 Rose Brae, Mossley Hill, Liverpool. Membership costs £5 adult, £3 concessions. Small groups of members may visit the tunnels by appointment (contact Simon Wrigley on 0151-233 4085).

webTitle: Pioneering mental health care service celebrates anniversary

fields.headline: A vision that still works
fields.standfirst: Pioneering mental health care service celebrates anniversary
fields.trailText: Pioneering mental health care service celebrates anniversary
fields.body:
Care in the community for mentally ill people may seem like a modern idea, but in fact it goes back to the Victorian era and a hospital chaplain called Henry Hawkins. As early as the 1870s, he was proposing the creation of "half-way houses between the asylum and the world" and calling for support for discharged patients to enable them to resume, in his phrase, "life's ordinary associations".

Hawkins went on to found an organisation with an army of volunteers who arranged places in family homes for those convalescing after a spell in an asylum. It then offered them continuing practical assistance, including help finding a job.

Today, that organisation is holding a conference to mark its 121st anniversary. Maca, the Mental After Care Association, has grown into a thriving voluntary organisation with 800 paid members of staff who last year helped more than 30,000 people. Its clients range from former psychiatric in-patients with severe mental problems, and people with personality disorders, to those who need less intervention but rely on smaller projects like drop-in centres to prevent them relapsing.

Even though mental health care now is unrecognisable from the old asylum days, Maca holds on to its vision of helping people in the community achieve the basics like a roof over their head and gainful employment. Its chief executive, Gil Hitchon, insists that the challenge remains as great as when Hawkins first defined his mission at Colney Hatch asylum (later renamed Friern Barnet hospital) in north London). "The original goals remain relevant as we often still don't offer people those basic requirements for leading a fulfilling life," says Hitchon.

Hitchon believes Hawkins was on the right track with his emphasis on helping mentally ill people as individuals, not an amorphous group. The churchman noted early on that many convalescent patients left asylums only to return to "squalor and wretchedness", hampering their recovery. He was also anxious about the poor employment prospects they faced. In 1871, he wrote in the Journal of Mental Science (later the British Journal of Psychiatry) that, without work, patients would soon be back in the workhouse or, worse, finish "by an uncontrollable act of violence their miserable lives".

Eight years later, he wrote a second article on "after-care", expanding on his original ideas and proposing the formation of an association to help female ex-patients. The suggestion found ready support among philanthropists and psychiatrists who felt that the asylum system, set in train by the 1845 Lunacy Act, had laid the foundations for a segregated society.

In 1879, Hawkins called a meeting of like-minded people and the upshot was the formation of The After-Care Association for Poor and Friendless Female Convalescents on Leaving Asylums for the Insane. Care in the community had its first powerful and organised advocate.

Although the high profile figures in that early organisation were men, it was women volunteers - generally the well-heeled wives of psychiatrists, philanthropists and reformers - who were the linchpin from the outset. Hawkins was made the association's first secretary but, once he had ensured his ideas had taken hold, seemed happy to take a back seat. He saw it expand its remit to take in men, but in later years suffered ill health and died in 1904. So he never lived to see the huge growth of his organisation's work during the first world war, when it was called on to care for shell-shocked soldiers.

The second world war saw another burst of activity, as Maca helped relocate long-term mental hospital patients to residential care homes to make way for injured soldiers. The experiment was an immediate success and the organisation's annual report in 1943 noted: "We think that this method of caring for suitable chronic patients is worth further exploration and development."

And develop it they did, until, by the 80s, Maca was established as one of the most experienced providers of residential care for people with mental health needs. The 1990 NHS and Community Care Act prompted further diversification and the association has doubled its staff in the past four years.

"People underestimate the amount we do," says Hitchon. "We offer everything from advocacy services and assertive outreach with difficult to engage people, to support in people's homes, employment training and work schemes. We have moved into forensic services for people in contact with the criminal justice system - and then there's the helplines, the respite for carers, the supported housing."

Maca is content to be a service provider, not a campaigning organisation. But its "let's just get on with the job" approach means that some may have overlooked its pioneering work in the past, as well as its vital role today. As Hitchon sums it up: "As far as we're concerned, community care is the only model. And it has been from day one."

fields.headline: Labour unrest over NHS plan
fields.trailText: Labour MPs yesterday gave a clear warning of backbench unrest over a key plank of the NHS reform plan ministers want to put on the statute book before the general election
fields.body:
Labour MPs yesterday gave a clear warning of backbench unrest over a key plank of the NHS reform plan ministers want to put on the statute book before the general election.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, came under fire during question time in the Commons over his proposal to replace the community health councils with three new types of patient representation. They would involve scrutiny of NHS performance by local authorities, election of patient representatives to NHS trusts and creation of an advocacy and liaison service within the trusts.

David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health committee, said he wanted advocates to work within independent CHCs.

"My concern is that the proposal on patient advocates places them within trusts and they will not be seen to be independent in a way that pa tients need them to be completely independent," he said.

Barry Jones, Labour MP for Alyn and Deeside, said the CHCs did a good job representing patients."It might be possible that you would delay your approach to the CHCs until you have advanced your other reforms. Since it is working, perhaps we shouldn't seek to fix it too soon," he said.

Mr Milburn stuck to his guns, insisitng there would be more independence and "more patient power".

webTitle: Straw admits tens of thousands of rejected asylum seekers at large

fields.headline: Straw admits tens of thousands of rejected asylum seekers at large
fields.trailText: The government has lost track of tens of thousands of asylum seekers in Britain and knows that hundreds of rejected asylum seekers recently housed in its flagship detention centre are still here, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday
fields.body:
The government has lost track of tens of thousands of asylum seekers in Britain and knows that hundreds of rejected asylum seekers recently housed in its flagship detention centre are still here, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday.

Mr Straw conceded ministers had no knowledge of the whereabouts of many of the 72,000 backlog of asylum seekers. Their addresses had only been given at the time of application for asylum.

However, Mr Straw claimed the money being poured into the immigration directorate was reforming a system on its knees under the Conservatives. The processing of new asylum applicants had risen to 3,000 a week this month, he said, representing an increase of 1,200 on the weekly average of the first quarter of this year.

He described the figure as an "extraordinary improvement" as applications were currently being lodged at the rate of 6,300 a month. He assured MPs on the home affairs select committee there were penalties and incentives for applicants to keep in touch with the immigration directorate through its reporting centres.

But Humfrey Malins, a Tory member of the committee, said the speed with which decisions were taken was neither here nor there if no enforcement followed through the removal of failed applicants.

He argued that Mr Straw conceded in 1998 that 19,000 applicants had gone missing, and on current trends this would rise to 115,000 by 2002.

Ministers have repeatedly refused to give figures on the numbers of asylum seekers who have been refused permission to remain in the country but have not been removed because they cannot be traced.

But Mr Malins told the home secretary: "You and I know ... the chances of them being removed is so low as to make the system a mockery."

He pointed to figures showing that of the 763 processed appeals at the Oakington camp in Cambridgeshire, only 28 had been allowed and only 231 removed or left voluntarily. He said that if Oakington was not working the government had no chance of meeting its target of 30,000 enforced departures per year by 2001/02. The last full year figures showed 7,910 asylum seekers were removed from the UK.

But Mr Straw insisted that the government could achieve this significant increase through its £600m investment in the immigration service, including an increase in the number of detention places to 2,400. He said deportation was not easy as if someone came from a country where there was civil disturbance there was often no effective government with which to make arrangements for their return.

webTitle: Costly flu drug only for high risk patients

fields.headline: Costly flu drug only for high risk patients
fields.trailText: GPs yesterday warned they could be swamped by patients wanting the anti-flu drug Relenza despite NHS guidance yesterday restricting its use to up to 500,000 "at risk" patients including the over-65s, asthmatics and diabetics
fields.body:
GPs yesterday warned they could be swamped by patients wanting the anti-flu drug Relenza despite NHS guidance yesterday restricting its use to up to 500,000 "at risk" patients including the over-65s, asthmatics and diabetics.

The new advice issued by ministers followed a change of heart by the government body monitoring the cost-effectiveness of medicines, which estimates that each GP would have no more than 17 patients eligible for the drug each year.

The decision will add about £12m a year to the NHS drugs bill but health authorities hope that the relaxation of an effective ban on the drug for state funded patients will save money on other aspects of treating seriously ill flu patients.

The government insisted the guidance, which would allow pharmacists and nurses to supply the drug on the direction of doctors, would not mean a huge extra workload. Ordinary flu jabs remain the best protection for the population and Relenza should normally only be prescribed - even for at-risk patients - once flu cases had exceeded 50 per 100,000 people, as recorded by weekly return by doctors and the public health laboratory service. This is the minimum level for a flu "outbreak", but well below epidemic and pandemic levels.

The drug, administered by inhaler, costs £24 for a five day course, and its restricted use has been endorsed by the national institute for clinical excellence, which had at first refused to support the drug. It now accepts that the product may benefit some patients but insisted it had not been influenced by the government or manufacturers.

Patients with significant heart problems, chronic breathing problems and those with weakened immune systems would also qualify under the guidance. Most flu victims will have to make do with the traditional paracetamol and a couple of days in bed.

John Chisholm, chairman of the British Medical Association's GPs committee, said he thought allowing vulnerable people to receive Relenza was the right decision.

"We are fearful that, even with the drug only available to high risk individuals, that will place enormous extra demand on general practices during any epidemic."

Mike Pringle, chairman of the Royal College of General Practitioners, said Relenza had the potential to help high-risk patients, but warned: "As GPs are being stretched to their limit, the introduction of a new therapy that may involve hundreds of urgent consultations for each GP, many in the patient's home, is unacceptable without discussion and extra resources."

The health minister, John Denham, said extra government investment meant the NHS could afford the drug. Nice believed Relenza was only effective if administered within 48 hours of symptoms appearing and only reduced the impact of flu by a day. But its use for vulnerable patients would be an extra weapon in helping patients most likely to need NHS services.

Help the Aged said the decision would help keep some elderly people out of hospital and was confident that concerns over possible adverse reactions had been examined.

Up to now Relenza's use has been restricted mainly to private practice, where about 8,000 prescriptions have been issued. Sales worldwide are thought so far to total around £20m, mainly in the US. The advice only applies to England and Wales but is likely to be followed in Scotland too.

webTitle: BT unveils plans for dial-up game shows

fields.headline: BT revives plans for dial-up game shows
fields.trailText: 8.15am: British Telecom plans to enter the entertainment business by launching a series of dial-up comedy and game shows. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
British Telecom has resurrected plans to enter the entertainment business, claiming dial-up game shows and comedy will "set it apart" from its rivals.

A high-level former Hollywood executive has been hired to oversee the project with plans to launch the service by the middle of next year.

BT chiefs have told MediaGuardian.co.uk that they will broadcast their own game show and comedy programmes on the BTopenworld broadband service.

John Raczka, head of content at BTopenworld, said: "Broadband will be a very big business for BT. These original productions will add some unique flavouring that our competitors will not have."

Discussions are already taking place with US film studios and UK production companies about co-funding the 15-minute shows.

The radical initiative will see programmes broadcast down high-speed internet connections onto a customer's computer.

But ultimately the company plans to deliver the programmes to TV sets.

Chevy Chase fans will be pleased that BT intends to launch a Saturday Night Live-style sketch show, and the game show programmes may involve interactive elements.

"We want it to be unique, unlike what we see on TV. But it must not be expensive, so we will pool our resources alongside other production companies and telecoms operators," added Mr Raczka.

Revenues will be generated by syndicating the productions around the world, and by selling successful game show or comedy formats to TV networks.

BT sees its ambitious programme as the key to converting customers from slow-moving narrowband internet services onto multi-purpose broadband lines.

BT's production plans give an inkling of what is on the way when the government lets the group broadcast entertainment programmes down its lines from January 2001.

The previous Conservative administration had banned BT from moving into programming in order to encourage cable operators to build networks.

Mr Raczka said: "From a platform perspective, we plan to move broadband from PC to TV in the next 18 months. And as for broadcasting BBC and ITV over BT lines, it depends on who is bedfellows with whom. Everyone is giving it serious thought."

fields.headline: UK indie opens up shop in LA
fields.trailText: 8.15am: DF Television is setting up an office in Los Angeles after a £5m order from Channel 4 and the US for Scrapheap Challenge, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
UK indie RDF Television is setting up a Los Angeles production office on the back of a £5m order from Channel 4 and the US for factual entertainment format Scrapheap Challenge.

Stephen Lambert, RDF director of programmes, said the indie had decided to open an LA office after being commissioned to make 14 editions of the show - which is called Junkyard Wars in the US - for cable channel TLC.

RDF will be making the TLC programmes, along with 15 instalments of Scrapheap Challenge ordered by Channel 4 for 2001, in California.

Scrapheap Challenge executive producer Cathy Rogers, who also presents the Channel 4 version of the show with Robert Llewellyn, is to head RDF's LA operation.

The second series of the show has just finished an impressive early Sunday evening run on Channel 4, with ratings well over 3m.
