fields.headline: France launches publicity blitz to tackle BSE fears
fields.trailText: 8am: The French government has launched a publicity campaign to quell consumer panic over BSE. Claire Cozens reports.
fields.body:
The French government has launched a major publicity blitz in an effort to quell rising consumer panic over BSE.

Keen to avoid a repetition of the collapse seen in British farming after the BSE crisis, the French government has gone on the offensive to reassure consumers.

The government has taken out full-page ads in newspapers using the line, "Where you can eat beef without fear" alongside a photo of a healthy-looking cow.

The ad explains the measures taken by the government over the past decade to counter BSE and carries a free advice line number.

And French prime minister Lionel Jospin last week announced extra safety measures to reassure consumers.

The government banned the use of recycled cattle bones and entrails in cows' feed 10 years ago and has recently stepped up its measures against BSE.

The news that French cows had succumbed to so-called "mad cow disease" came as a major embarrassment to the French government, which banned British beef after the BSE crisis.

fields.headline: Oil firms cleared of profiteering
fields.standfirst: Special report: the fuel crisis
fields.trailText: Oil companies were cleared last night of charges of price fixing and abusing their position at petrol stations by the office of fair trading.
fields.body:
Oil companies were cleared last night of charges of price fixing and abusing their position at petrol stations by the office of fair trading.

An inquiry, demanded by independent retailers, concluded that anti-competitive behaviour was not the reason why diesel and petrol margins had been squeezed.

John Vickers, director general of the OFT, said: "The independent retailers have had to pay wholesale prices which have reflected the increased world oil prices while public pressure had held down prices at the pump.

"No evidence has been found of either price fixing agreements or abuse of a dominant position by the oil companies."

The Petrol Retailers Association, which represents independent fuel sellers, said it was "very disappointed" by the outcome but not surprised.

Ray Holloway, a PRA spokesman, said: "The prime minister interfered with retail prices in October when he told Esso not to put up its prices. That has affected the market."

BP, which controls 1,900 petrol stations under its own name or the National brand, was delighted with the outcome. A spokesman for the world's third-largest oil group said: "We are pleased that the allegations of anti-competitive behaviour have been refuted."

Shell, which has 1,100 stations, said it too was happy with the OFT result. "We were always confident we never engaged in any anti-competitive practices. The market is very tough and margins are very slim just because business is so competitive."

The OFT said it would continue to monitor the market and would not hesitate to take action if it found firms were deliberately damaging competition.

The price of petrol has been a political as well as a commercial issue. Most anger has been directed at government but oil companies feared they would be open to attack if the OFT ruled they had been profiteering.

fields.bodyText: Oil companies were cleared last night of charges of price fixing and abusing their position at petrol stations by the office of fair trading. An inquiry, demanded by independent retailers, concluded that anti-competitive behaviour was not the reason why diesel and petrol margins had been squeezed. John Vickers, director general of the OFT, said: "The independent retailers have had to pay wholesale prices which have reflected the increased world oil prices while public pressure had held down prices at the pump. "No evidence has been found of either price fixing agreements or abuse of a dominant position by the oil companies." The Petrol Retailers Association, which represents independent fuel sellers, said it was "very disappointed" by the outcome but not surprised. Ray Holloway, a PRA spokesman, said: "The prime minister interfered with retail prices in October when he told Esso not to put up its prices. That has affected the market." BP, which controls 1,900 petrol stations under its own name or the National brand, was delighted with the outcome. A spokesman for the world's third-largest oil group said: "We are pleased that the allegations of anti-competitive behaviour have been refuted." Shell, which has 1,100 stations, said it too was happy with the OFT result. "We were always confident we never engaged in any anti-competitive practices. The market is very tough and margins are very slim just because business is so competitive." The OFT said it would continue to monitor the market and would not hesitate to take action if it found firms were deliberately damaging competition. webTitle: Court gives Gore five more days

fields.headline: Court gives Gore five more days
fields.standfirst:
"The right of the people to cast their votes is the paramount concern overriding all others."
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The state of Florida must accept late ballots in the US presidential election until 5pm on November 26, Florida's Supreme Court has ruled.
fields.body:
The state of Florida must accept late ballots in the US presidential election until 5pm on November 26, Florida's Supreme Court has ruled. The 42-page opinion gives the Gore campaign just five days to overtake Bush's slender lead.

The unanimous ruling reversed two orders by trial courts and was hailed as a boost for Democrat candidate Al Gore, who had been pushing for the hand recounts to be included in the final election result. Three counties in Florida have been carrying out hand recounts since the election two weeks ago.

The court ruling means Florida Secretary of State Katherine Harris may not certify the result of the contested election between Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W. Bush until that time. A statement read by court spokesman Craig Waters did not specify whether - or under what guidelines - manual recounts might continue until the new deadline.

Bush holds a 930-vote lead in the official, but uncertified vote tallies from Election Day, with overseas absentee ballots included. Gore has slowly been eating into that lead in recent days as recounts have proceeded at his urging in three Democratic counties.

Gore was in Washington, Bush in Texas, as the court issued a ruling that could determine which one wins the White House.

In a brief statement read on the courthouse steps, Waters said the decision was based on the court's longstanding view that "the right of the people to cast their votes is the paramount concern overriding all others."

Waters did not directly address the issue of the recounts in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade counties. Nor did his brief statement say whether the court had ruled on a Democratic request for the issuance of uniform standards that might guide the local canvassing boards conducting the recounts.

The issue of what rules should be applied to such things as "dimpled ballots" - those with indentations but not punched through - was raised in oral arguments and also was addressed in the response brief to the court from Gore's lawyers.

Republican Bush's legal team said it was too late, that the issue should have been raised earlier.

Bush's lawyers suggested that the court should not even address the issue of a voter's intent when punching a ballot.

"This is an intensely fact-bound question, and there is no existing Florida law on this question. It would thus be particularly inappropriate to decide this question in this legal and evidentiary vacuum. At a minimum, if the court does proceed, we request an opportunity to be heard on this question," the Bush lawyers argued.

The Gore lawyers responded: "The issue is one of law appropriate for determination by this court... It does not present factual issues."

Jenny Backus, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Party, said of the Bush filing: "It's not only highly unusual. It has the appearance of being an attempt to delay action by this court."

The Bush brief said there was "an extremely tight timeframe for consideration of these issues," suggesting officials had already missed the last deadline for certifying the election in time to allow it to be contested properly.

Bush's lawyers said state law requires a 22-to-27 day period for candidates to contest certified results, meaning the state should have certified the vote by Monday of this week "at the very latest."

In case they lose in Florida, Republican lawyers were prepared to seek an emergency appeal directly to the US Supreme Court, bypassing lower federal courts where they have suffered setbacks.

Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, the Republican candidate's brother, said he expected a conclusion soon. "This is going to come to an end, and the rule of law will prevail, and we'll move on," he said. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta is considering George W. Bush's efforts to stop the recounts but set a timetable Tuesday that would allow some written arguments to be filed as late as Novomber 29 - with the counting proceeding in the meantime.

In another brief filed with the Florida Supreme Court yesterday, Broward County's canvassing board said it was waiting for the justices to rule on the question of what ballots could be counted - "and it is imperative that it be resolved immediately."

Before the day's briefs were filed, the justices already were faced with multiple choices in crafting a decision for history that would end the stalemate holding up the selection of the nation's 43rd president.

fields.headline: MEP quits 'intolerant' Tories
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague last night suffered another defection from the Conservative ranks over his hardline policies on Europe as MEP Bill Newton Dunn joined the Liberal Democrat ranks in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
William Hague last night suffered another defection from the Conservative ranks over his hardline policies on Europe as MEP Bill Newton Dunn joined the Liberal Democrat ranks in Strasbourg.

After 20 years as an MEP Mr Newton Dunn, vice chairman of the European parliament's foreign affairs and defence committee, yesterday denounced his old party's "hard swing to the right". The East Midlands MEP becomes the seventh MP or MEP to join the Lib Dems in the past four years. Mr Newton Dunn, aged 59, is a "one nation" moderate on economic policy as well as being pro-European. When asked about the defection last night one party official dismissively replied: "Who ?"

In a statement the MEP also attacked "an intolerant and dogmatic belief in tax cuts at any price. The Tories have failed to add that they could not deliver these tax cuts without corresponding cuts in health, education and transport". Such remarks are manna to the Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, but also to Labour's election team which is saying the same thing.

Mr Kennedy said: "As William Hague takes his party further and further to the right, on and off every passing bandwagon, the Liberal Democrats continue to offer a real home to people with moderate one nation values."

webTitle: US berated for wriggling out of treaty pledges

fields.headline: US berated for wriggling out of treaty pledges
fields.standfirst:
EU fury grows as Americans try to exploit loopholes

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The EU launched a scathing attack on the US yesterday for attempting to avoid its commitments on climate change and undermining the credibility of the Kyoto agreement made in 1997.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, environment correspondent in the Hague
fields.body:
The EU launched a scathing attack on the US yesterday for attempting to avoid its commitments on climate change and undermining the credibility of the Kyoto agreement made in 1997.

In an extraordinarily blunt statement, Dominque Voynet, the French environment minister, said: "We are seeking ways we can meet our commitments, not ways we can avoid them and create new escape routes. The US is trying to avoid domestic measures to curb emissions and create a series of loopholes, in effect unravelling the treaty.

"We are not prepared to be led down a road which would destroy the particularly hard work we have built up over three years," added Ms Voynet, who was speaking on behalf of the EU, since France currently holds the presidency.

Ms Voynet, known for her fiery nature, was referring to attempts by the US to claim that existing forests had soaked up so much carbon from the atmosphere since 1990 that it cancelled out about half of all the emissions Americans created from burning fossil fuels. Using natural vegetation to capture carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is known as creating "sinks".

As a concession, the Americans announced on Monday that they were prepared only to claim part of the total for existing forests. But overnight, EU scientists studied the proposal and claimed this sink was such a "massive loophole" that it rendered US promises made in Kyoto meaningless.

Kjell Larsson, the Swedish environment minister said: "The US is supposed to reduce its emissions by 7% on 1990 levels by 2010. The number crunchers have been working overnight on the US proposals and discover that it would allow an increase in US emissions of between 8% and 9%.

"That means, in effect, the US emissions would go up rather than down as they promised only three years ago. This is far beyond what is even possible to discuss."

Ms Voynet, wearing a badge with the slogan "Face up to climate change", added: "No compromise can be made, the proposals are simply not acceptable. We do not intend to redebate this item. We want to discuss ways in which we can meet our commitments, not ways in which we can avoid them."

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, in his set speech to the conference, supported the EU stand. "Our task this week is not to rewrite the Kyoto protocol but to reaffirm it," he said. "This Hague agreement must maintain the environmental integrity of the Kyoto agreement, especially the 5% cut in greenhouse gas emissions by the developed world.

"Minus five may be a small step - but it is a small step in the right direction and must not be reversed by an over-generous interpretation of the contribution from sinks.

"Developed countries must lead the way. We created the mess, the polluter must pay and individual developed countries must introduce their own policies to cut emissions."

Prodding a sandbag on the podium, Mr Prescott said: "This sandbag symbolises a lot to people in my country. Two weeks ago much of my country was under water. In the ancient Roman city of York hundreds of people worked through many nights to save it from the worst floods and storms since 1625.

"It was only the thousands and thousands of these sandbags which saved the city. This was a wake-up call. People know something is wrong. The people are looking for a successful Hague agreement."

He added: "Climate change is already upon us. But it can get much worse if we fail to act. Unless we join together in this agreement this week, we will be throwing away the opportunity of a lifetime."

The US was increasingly defensive last night. Frank Loy, the undersecretary for global affairs and head of the 150-strong American delegation, said: "These are not loopholes or 11th-hour gimmicks. Without them we and other nations will not be able to fulfil our Kyoto commitments."

He was referring to the fact that US emissions have soared since 1990 because of the booming economy. Rather than begin to reduce fossil fuel burning as the UK and Germany have done there has been a continued steep climb in North America. Unless the US takes action its emissions will increase by as much as 35% above 1990 levels by 2010.

What the US was proposing on Monday was a way of soaking up 8% of the total by using forests to capture carbon. What irritates the EU is that this proposal is only one of a number, including planting or buying forests in the developing countries, that the US is considering in order to avoid taking domestic action.

There were signs yesterday that the EU was prepared to reach an agreement with other developed countries which excluded the US if necessary.

Environment commissioner Margot Wallstrom said the EU was prepared to start the process of ratification of the treaty within weeks so that it would come into legal force by 2002. Ms Voynet said the EU wanted a deal but was "not prepared to cease taking action because of the unilateral requests of one country".1515

fields.headline: Angry Blair lambasts anti-EU 'nonsense'
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday blew his top over the growing stridency of "anti-European nonsense" in the media when he denounced "fundamentally dishonest" distortions of Britain's military commitment to the EU's new rapid reaction force.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in  Moscow  and Michael White  in London
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday blew his top over the growing stridency of "anti-European nonsense" in the media when he denounced "fundamentally dishonest" distortions of Britain's military commitment to the EU's new rapid reaction force.

Speaking at a press conference in Moscow after talks with President Vladimir Putin, the prime minister concentrated his first remarks not on his day of intensive talks in the Kremlin, but on the criticism of press coverage of Monday's European defence initiative.

"I'm used to the British media being impossible on the topic of Europe, but I hope the public will be given the facts," Mr Blair declared. "There is no concept of a European army," he said, repeating assurances given by ministers and officials in Brussels and London - but largely ignored by his tabloid enemies. Yesterday's Daily Mail asked: "Is Blair playing with Fire?" in a 12,000 troop commitment to future peacekeeping work which the paper warned would unravel Nato. The Sun declared: "EU're in the army now" while the Daily Telegraph claimed - wrongly, ministers insist - "US regards Euro army as threat to Nato role."

Briefed by his press spokesman, Alastair Campbell, at Britain's Moscow embassy yesterday, Mr Blair was incensed. Travelling prime ministers are used to having foreign trips subsumed by domestic conflicts and Mr Blair's outburst does not signal a switch towards outright war with the Tory tabloids, as some ministers urge.

Charles Kennedy also openly urged Mr Blair to "tell our story of Britain in Europe" last night. But it took the robust media criticism of the 60,000-strong European rapid reaction force (RRF), due to be formed by 2003, to goad Downing Street into attacking some of the newspapers he has courted since 1994.

Mr Campbell has faxed letters demanding a right of reply in the Sun and Daily Mail today, to allow Mr Blair to correct what officials are calling "lies" by newspapers and by William Hague's team. Both papers agreed in principle

Mr Hague was unabashed. Citing the support his stance has won from retired soldiers and politicians, including Labour's Lord Denis Healey, he went on television to taunt Mr Blair as an ex-CND supporter whose military U-turn showed that: "Labour is being reckless with defence."

Mr Hague even likened Mr Blair's tactics to his "stealth" taxes. "He always talks about scare-mongering and then what people are worried about turns out to be true," the Tory leader said before repeating what Labour regards as the key lie.

"Mr Blair is signing up to a European army, but he doesn't want to refer to it as a European army," he said, accusing the government of engaging in a purely political project which will undermine the 53-year Nato-US link. In reality no British troops will be involved in RRF actions without the explicit consent of the British government. A Tory government would withdraw from the RRF project, Mr Hague said.

No 10 distinguishes between the complex issues behind the single currency controversy and the relatively simple question of enhanced European military cooperation, the fruit of Europe's humiliating inability to act in Bosnia and Kosovo without US ground troops, airlift and intelligence capability.

Confident that Democrats and Republicans in Washington back the RRF, Mr Blair went on the offensive over what he sees as malicious media coverage at least three times during his 24- hour trip.

While nuclear arms cuts and controversial American plans for national missiles defence (NMD) had been expected to dominate the talks between Mr Blair and Mr Putin, both leaders said they had spent more time discussing European security issues and specifically the RRF.

While Mr Putin remains opposed to NMD, he sounded conciliatory on the European force which will only act when Nato or the US chose not to.

Mr Blair said that Mr Putin's impression was that the European scheme was aimed at "maintaining stability".

Mr Blair stressed that the European force would focus on "peacekeeping, peace enforcement and humanitarian" issues - complementing Nato, not undermining it.

Meanwhile the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, told the foreign affairs committee Nato would be more threatened if the US Congress felt the EU is not doing more to pull its weight in military matters.

Mr Blair said that since British troops are already engaged in United Nations, Nato, and Commonwealth missions, it is only sensible to work with the Europeans "in the limited circumstances we've set out". It would be "absolute and utter madness for our country" to stand aloof from the military cooperation being pursued by "the key strategic alliance on our doorstep".

"I won't let this type of anti-European nonsense distort the true national interest of our country," Mr Blair said. "Even by the standards of part of our anti-European media, some of the coverage in today's newspapers is fundamentally dishonest."

fields.headline: Small is beautiful
fields.standfirst:
Analysis

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Whatever decisions are made in the Hague this week - if any - the energy industry faces important choices. One of the most fundamental is about scale.
fields.body:
Whatever decisions are made in the Hague this week - if any - the energy industry faces important choices. One of the most fundamental is about scale.

In the 20th century, energy was big business - huge power stations and mega-dams using vast transmissions networks to distribute electricity to the masses. Economies of scale meant larger power stations created lower costs per unit of fuel burnt and hence increased revenue. But big projects created big environmental problems: radiation from Chernobyl in Ukraine, displacement of populations from the Narmada dam in central India, acid rain from coal-fired power stations in Europe. The most serious environmental problem so far is, of course, climate change and the capital invested in fossil fuel power stations is one of the factors that has prevented a much swifter response to the threat of climate change. The fossil fuel industries successfully lobbied against action to cut greenhouse gases.

Climate change is now recognised in all parts of the world as a genuine threat, with the possible exception of Austin, Texas. Evidence is mounting and, despite the desperate search for loopholes in the Kyoto protocol now under way in the Hague, the energy sector is beginning to look for low-carbon options. There has been an exodus of energy companies from the American anti-Kyoto lobbying group Global Climate Coalition. Boardrooms are starting to talk about clean fuels.

But the real corporate choice is going to be between big and small. There are "big" low-carbon options: hydroelectric dams, tidal barrages and nuclear power among them - means of generating electricity without major emissions of carbon into the atmosphere. But these require huge capital investment and in a liberalised, more competitive energy market, they are risky.

Global support for mega-dam projects took a blow last week with the first report of the world commission on dams. It recommended much stricter criteria for approving projects, including more local consultation and better assessments of environmental consequences. The first casualty could be the Ilisu dam in Turkey, which is dependent on export credit guarantees, not least from the UK, to go ahead. The Chinese are building the Three Gorges dam, but only a totalitarian regime could possibly impose such a project on its population in the modern age.

The most grandiose low-carbon option of all has also become visible in recent weeks. The Royal Academy of Engineers recommended the UK needed to build new nuclear power stations to meet climate obligations. The first application for a new nuclear power station in western Europe since the 1980s was made in Finland last week. Nuclear power received a great deal of public subsidy over decades to establish the industry, but now it is largely in the private sector, major investors have been impossible to find. Scientists are still no nearer solving the problem of waste disposal than when Windscale was first opened and the environmental risks involved would push the boundaries of public acceptability.

The expansion of hydro and nuclear power would, regardless of environmental effects, lock us into another straitjacket when the lesson we should learn is that diversity and flexibility are virtues in energy supply.

The future is smaller. This trend has already started with the introduction of the gas turbine, which generates less electricity than traditional thermal power stations. Generators powered by gas are still large but are more flexible because they can be sited nearer electricity customers; they can also be used to produce combined heat and power (CHP) for industrial sites, radically cutting fuel costs.

The most exciting technological advances in energy, as in communications, electronics and biology, are micro in scale.

Solar panels, wind turbines, fuel cells and domestic boilers which generate electricity in the home as well as heat, are all developing rapidly and do not require the sort of capital investment that old-style mega power stations did. Until the liberalisation of the energy sector only lone voices such as Amory Lovins in the United States or Walt Patterson in the UK would contemplate such a transformation. Now the big companies are getting in on the act.

BP and Shell are moving into the solar market. Offshore wind turbines are being built in northern Europe and promoted by major engineering companies such as AMEC. BG Group, part of the old British Gas, is developing new micro-CHP boilers which will produce electricity and heat in the home. ABB, a major power engineering company, has pledged to move its business into wind turbines and fuel cells. Nearly all the major motor manufacturers in the world are developing vehicles based on fuel cells which convert hydrogen into electric power, with an exhaust gas of water vapour. Last week, the chairman of BMW urged the UK government to promote the use of hydrogen as a fuel.

While they will produce less energy per installation, "micro-power" plants could improve overall efficiencies in the system as they do not require high voltage transmission lines to link supply to demand. This will make the technologies particularly valuable in the developing world, where the grids that do exist are extremely unreliable and most people still do not have access to electricity.

webTitle: If you can't stand the heat, better stay inside

fields.headline: If you can't stand the heat, better stay inside
fields.standfirst:
Weather: Forecasts to warn of high temperatures that can kill

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Weather forecasts should in future carry more explicit danger warnings about hot weather to prevent an increasing number of people dying of heat stroke and other related illnesses, the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) said yesterday.
fields.body:
Weather forecasts should in future carry more explicit danger warnings about hot weather to prevent an increasing number of people dying of heat stroke and other related illnesses, the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) said yesterday.

The level at which death rates begin to soar is 33C (93F) in cities like Rome but is less in places further north such as Toronto, according to scientists looking at increased mortality rates in European and American cities during heat waves in the last 10 years.

Researchers are studying death rates in major cities during heat waves to find the local trigger temperature for increased deaths so they can design a "heat-watch" warning system for weather forecasts.

They believe heat waves already cost "tens of thousands" of lives worldwide and this could double by 2020 as climate change takes hold.

Speaking at the climate talks at the Hague, Professor Godwin Obasi, the secretary-general of the WMO, said concern was triggered partly because in 15 large US cities there were, on average, 1,500 more deaths a year during heat waves than there were in 1990.

It was estimated that 400 to 500 more people were dying in Shanghai each year because of higher temperatures.

A warning system for hot weather and advice to put on telephone help lines was being formulated by the WMO and the World Heath Organisation to reduce the number of deaths.

Philadelphia, one of eight cities around the world that already has a warning system, believed it was saving 300 lives a year by timely alerts, according to Dr Laurence Kalkstein from the University of Delaware centre for climate research, who is developing the programme.

During a heat wave people were advised "to stay in air conditioning where possible, drink plenty of water and take a cool bath".

Dr Kalkstein said: "Behaviour patterns are important. In Arizona at noon when it is hot, people stay indoors but in London it might be seen as an opportunity to play tennis. It could be fatal above a certain temperature, but as yet we do not know what that [temperature] is for London."

He said that in New York, another temperate city, normal summer temperatures were 28C to 30C, but when the temperature suddenly reaches 40C "people die very rapidly".

People over 65 were most vulnerable but one study in Rome suggested that more women died. There was no scientific explanation for this although one theory was that in Rome women wore black clothes, which were far hotter, and carried on working in kitchens despite the heat.

It is not the direct sunlight that kills but the air temperature which causes the body to overheat and then induces heart attacks, strokes or respiratory failure.

In a report, Dr Kalkstein said: "It is not necessarily the hottest places on earth that exhibit the greatest numbers of heat related deaths and illnesses. In fact it is weather variability rather than heat intensity that is the most important factor in defining human sensitivity to heat.

"People living in highly variable summer climates are ill-adapted to extreme heat, mainly because it occurs irregularly."

fields.headline: Rights the UK won't give
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: This month in Rome there was a celebration to mark the 50th anniversary of the signing of the European Convention on Human Rights. In honour of the occasion, Protocol 12, prohibiting all forms of discrimination, was officially opened for signature. It was signed by 25 of the Council of Europe's member states - but the UK was not among them. It is puzzling that a government committed to the legal protection of human rights should hesitate to take this step.
fields.body:
This month in Rome there was a celebration to mark the 50th anniversary of the signing of the European Convention on Human Rights. In honour of the occasion, Protocol 12, prohibiting all forms of discrimination, was officially opened for signature. It was signed by 25 of the Council of Europe's member states - but the UK was not among them. It is puzzling that a government committed to the legal protection of human rights should hesitate to take this step.

The new protocol is an important addition to the rights and freedoms guaranteed by the convention now secured in our own Human Rights Act. In many ways the convention is an outdated instrument and the weak protection of discrimination is a serious flaw. Article 14 states that "the enjoyment of the rights and freedoms" set out in the convention (for example, respect for private life, family life, freedom of expression and religion), shall be secured without discrimination on any grounds including sex, race, religion, political opinion, property birth or other status. The snag is that article 14 does not guarantee a free-standing right to equal treatment without discrimination. It complements the other substantive convention provisions but has no independent existence.

The general principle of equality and non-discrimination is recognised as a fundamental human right. It is also very similar to the recently agreed discrimination provision in the charter of fundamental rights of the European Union.

Although the government states that it is, in principle, in favour of an independent anti-discrimination right, it is not prepared to sign the new protocol at present. The government claims that the right is "too general and open-ended". Yet protocol 12 is no more open-ended than the discrimination guarantee in the international covenant on civil and political rights, or in similar rights set out in the written constitutions of the US or other Commonwealth and European countries.

The government has also expressed concern that the protocol "does not follow the case law of the European court of human rights in allowing objective and reasonable justified distinctions". They have clearly grasped the wrong end of the stick. The pre-amble of the protocol accurately reflects the approach already adopted by the Strasbourg court. Indeed the explanatory report accompanying the protocol makes it clear that it was not considered necessary to include a restriction clause since not every difference of treatment amounts to discrimination: it would only be discriminatory if it "has no objective and reasonable justification". The protocol would not prevent a government from taking positive measures to reduce inequality.

Perhaps an underlying fear of the government is that an equality provision will draw the judges into examining social issues, perhaps with cash implications. Yet the judiciary already deal with highly sensitive and complex issues of social policy and frequently exercises restraint and the structure of the Human Rights Act ensures that the judges could not strike down any acts of parliament. Why then shouldn't it be possible to challenge a public authority if its actions discriminate without justification?

We have anti-discrimination legislation but it operates in clearly demarcated areas. The current domestic legislation is outdated, inadequate, inconsistent, and at times incomprehensible. Arbitrary exclusions such as age, sexual orientation and religion or belief (apart from Northern Ireland) are not protected at all. The operation of the legislation has led to anomalies: the Race Relations Act has been interpreted to include some religious groups such as Jews and Sikhs, but Muslims as a religious group are excluded. Where groups are not protected by domestic legislation, it will be more difficult, if not impossible, to obtain a remedy if they suffer discrimination: for example, if employment were refused without justification on the basis of age.

In order to meet our international and European legal obligations radical legislative reforms are needed. For too long our discrimination laws have developed in a piecemeal fashion. There should be a single equality act covering all the main grounds throughout the UK. A coherent regulatory framework would mean that domestic law would be well placed to meet the standards required by the new protocol.

The refusal to sign the protocol does not send a positive message to the new European democracies that are members of the Council of Europe. It is not too late for the government to reconsider its position .

 Stephanie Palmer is a law fellow at Girton, Cambridge.

webTitle: Newsnight blamed for rape trial collapse

fields.headline: Newsnight blamed for rape trial collapse
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday abandoned the trial of a Merseyside man accused of raping his stepdaughter and sexually abusing his daughter because he feared the jury could be prejudiced by a similar case shown on Monday's BBC Newsnight.
fields.body:
A judge yesterday abandoned the trial of a Merseyside man accused of raping his stepdaughter and sexually abusing his daughter because he feared the jury could be prejudiced by a similar case shown on Monday's BBC Newsnight.

The decision to discharge the jury on the second day of the trial will cost the taxpayer tens of thousands of pounds, the lord chancellor's department said last night.

David Clarke, Liverpool's most senior judge, abandoned the proceedings after seeing the programme in which a Merseyside woman claimed she had been sexually abused by her stepfather in the 1970s.

Judge Clarke, the recorder of Liverpool, told the jury there were too many similarities between the cases for the 54-year-old defendant to receive a fair trial and remanded him on bail to await re-trial next year.

The development could open the way for defence lawyers to use similar arguments to get the jury dismissed if media coverage of a case echoes their own.

The defendant had denied three charges of indecently assaulting his stepdaughter in the early 1970s beginning when she was seven and four offences of raping her when she was 15. He also denied two offences of indecently assaulting his 12-year-old daughter in the 1980s.

The BBC2 programme claimed a 71-year-old pensioner, named only as Stanley, regularly raped his three stepdaughters in Birkenhead, Merseyside, but was not on the Sex Offenders' Register.

When confronted by Newsnight he admitted that he started having sex with one of the children when she was 10. Another stepdaughter said she thought he was still capable of abusing children in the future.

The BBC said yesterday: "Newsnight decided to broadcast the film as it was a matter of huge public importance and public interest. Our film did not refer to any other case." Merseyside police said yesterday they had arrested two men in their 70s in connection with child sex abuse as a result of the broadcast and further investigations.

fields.headline: BT shells out £10m for wcities
fields.trailText: British Telecom, struggling to reduce its spiralling debts, has still found a spare £10m to buy a 17% stake in wcities, a location-based information service provider.
fields.body:
British Telecom, struggling to reduce its spiralling debts, has still found a spare £10m to buy a 17% stake in wcities, a location-based information service provider wcities.com.

The stake is part of a deal which will see BTopenworld, BT's mobile internet business, taking wcities' service which provides travellers with local information via their mobile phone.

The deal comes only weeks after BT announced plans for disposals and flotations to reduce its £20bn debt.

A BT spokesman said a stake in wcities because it would be a good investment in a business which could provide services for other parts of the group.

"We will not be getting involved in the management of the business," he said.

webTitle: Byers asks business to embrace e-commerce

fields.headline: Byers asks business to embrace e-commerce
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday warned against a new "digital divide" in Britain's new economy as Redstone Telecom set out ambitious plans to provide access to broadband internet services for thousands of small businesses.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday warned against a new "digital divide" in Britain's new economy as Redstone Telecom set out ambitious plans to provide access to broadband internet services for thousands of small businesses.

In a speech in Liverpool, Mr Byers said businesses in all parts of Britain needed to embrace e-commerce - worth £2bn in the UK last year - and ensure that old disparities between and within regions did not re-emerge in the digital era.

Pointing out that the number of business in the north-west of England with internet access had risen from 55% last year to 84% this year, Mr Byers said, however, that proportions trading online varied from 33% in Greater London to just 24% in the south-west.

Redstone's chief executive, Graham Cove, said, meanwhile, the firm is planning to steal a march on its bigger rivals in the struggle to provide broadband internet services for the UK's army of small businesses by offering them faster and more cheaply.

Mr Cove has laid plans to by pass the protracted dispute between BT and telecoms watchdog Oftel over "unbundling" the local loop - allowing competitors access to local exchanges - by July next year.

Redstone is to build its own roadside cabinets - one metre square steel boxes - outside BT's local exchanges and use them to house ADSL (asymmetrical digital subscriber line) equipment in an effort to capture 20% of Britain's 3m small and medium-sized firms.

Mr Cove said that BT had agreed to allow 600 external links to local exchanges from July but only 190 inside these exchanges and Redstone had applied for 425 sites, with hopes of winning most of these. "We don't get to know the answer until the end of February but our assumption is that we will get access to the vast majority of them," he said.

Redstone said this would cut the cost of connecting to an exchange to about £10,000 or, says Mr Cove, between a fifth and a third of the price for setting up inside exchanges.

Mr Cove, whose "conservative" target is to win 10,000 DSL subscribers by the end of 2003, believes this single-minded strategy will outsmart bigger rivals planning to offer a wider range of services to residential as well as commercial customers. But he failed to ignite investor confidence after raising the spectre of a further call for funding.

webTitle: Easier and uTravel close their doors

fields.headline: Easier and uTravel close their doors
fields.trailText: The dot.com gloom deepened yesterday with the closure of a leading travel website and the planned sell-off of a loss-making online property service.
fields.body:
The dot.com gloom deepened yesterday with the closure of a leading travel website and the planned sell-off of a loss-making online property service.

Holiday website uTravel became the latest internet failure when its owner, United News & Media, said it was being shut down in the light of competitive conditions in the online business-to-consumer travel market.

Property website Easier, which promised to "revolutionise the way homes are bought and sold", said it was to sell the company's ongoing business but keep its stock market listing as a shell company that can be sold to another start-up.

uTravel, part of United's new media division Xilerate, began business in 1999 and aimed to provide holidaymakers with information on trips and flights, and then direct them to their nearest travel agent to make a booking.

Xilerate said it believed that with the intense competition in the sector, which is dominated by players such as Thomas Cook's online arm and Lastminute.com, further investment in the business could not be expected to achieve the required return in the foreseeable future.

The announcement comes days after the closure of financial news site TheStreet.co.uk with the loss of 64 jobs. Another recent casualty was Wowgo, a site introduced by Unilever and aimed at teenage girls, which folded.

Easier said its board had decided that shareholder value would be best served by selling its main business, leaving the company as a cash shell, available as a route to market for another company through a reverse takeover. The board would also consider offers for the company, either before or after the planned sale of the business.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Stelios HajiIoannou, the founder of discount airline EasyJet, took another step into cyberspace yesterday with the launch of an online shopping comparison site.
fields.body:
Stelios HajiIoannou, the founder of discount airline EasyJet, took another step into cyberspace yesterday with the launch of an online shopping comparison site.

EasyValue will scour online retailers to find the best price for books, CDs, DVDs and videos, with more products to be added later. Many other companies already operate similar services in Britain, such as Kelkoo, Dealtime and Pricerunner. Mr HajiIoannou, who floated his budget airline for nearly £800m last week and still owns most of it, sells about 80% of the airline's seats on the internet.

 Settlement Chip-maker Intel and rival Broadcom yesterday said they had settled all claims against each other under trade-secret lawsuits. In a statement, the companies "expressed satisfaction with the terms of the settlement agreement, which are confidential". Intel filed suit against Broadcom in California last March. Broadcom filed a cross-complaint against Intel, the world's top chip maker, three months later.

 Positive result Shares in European information technology consultancy and services firm Anite Group raced ahead yesterday, boosted by a buoyant trading statement. The company said that first-half trading was ahead of expectations and that its consultancy and IT solutions divisions had made good showings. The firm's travel operations also saw continued growth, with demand for managed services. Anite Group's shares gained 7.5p to close the session at 176.5p.

webTitle: Rexonline vows to see off predators

fields.headline: Rexonline vows to see off predators
fields.trailText: Britain's first quoted online recruitment firm to make a profit yesterday promised to maintain its independence despite approaches from at least three big rivals.
fields.body:
Britain's first quoted online recruitment firm to make a profit yesterday promised to maintain its independence despite approaches from at least three big rivals.

Rexonline chief executive Simon Hersh said the company intended to expand as an independent player. He pointed out that the major shareholders were within the company.

But Dru Edmonstone, analyst at Durlacher, said if the company continued tobe successful and the dot.com market recovered it was "only a matter of time before somebody snaps Rex up".

The company posted a pre-tax profit of £70,000 for the six months to the end of October, compared to a loss of £144,000 for the same period in 1999. Turnover more than tripled to £923,000.

Mr Edmonstone forecast profits would rise to £3m by 2002.

Mr Hersh said that, while 65% of Rexonline's business was done with recruitment agencies, he hoped to see the majority of revenue coming direct from corporate clients in the future.

Past emphasis on IT jobs was also changing, with 30%-40% of advertised vacancies now in other areas, including accountancy, engineering and law.

In conjunction with partners, the company plans to introduce three niche recruitment sites in the new year, focusing on secretarial work, pharmaceutical jobs and management headhunting.

fields.headline: Straw's defence on crime toll
fields.standfirst: Research 'finds no link' with falling police numbers
fields.trailText: No direct link exists between the numbers of police in a constabulary and its ability to cut crime, Jack Straw said yesterday referring to figures prepared by Her Majesty's inspectorate of constabulary and the Home Office.
fields.body:
No direct link exists between the numbers of police in a constabulary and its ability to cut crime, Jack Straw said yesterday referring to figures prepared by Her Majesty's inspectorate of constabulary and the Home Office.

The home secretary intends to apply the figures in a reform of the police forces that is designed to improve leadership and instigate a searching inspection regime for the basic command units.

But the figures will also provide useful political cover for Mr Straw after he was forced to admit yesterday that total police numbers were still falling, despite announcements to recruit an 5,000 officers over 10 years.

"The suggestion has been that in those areas where police numbers have risen, there has been a reduction in crime and in those areas where police numbers have fallen, there is an increase in crime," said Mr Straw. "But there is no correlation whatsoever between the two, none whatsoever".

Ministers concede that if there is an election next spring, they will have to face the electorate with overall police numbers lower than at the time of the 1997 general election, potentially a serious embarrassment.

Yesterday Mr Straw released an analysis showing that in the 25 forces in which crime rose in 1999-2000, there was a 1.5% fall in officer numbers. In the 18 other forces where crime fell, there was only an average 1.6% drop in officers.

He also said that among the 25 forces which oversaw rises in crime, 68% had fewer officers. In the remaining 18 crime-cutting constabularies more than 80% had fewer officers. Mr Straw admitted police numbers had fallen by a further 213 between March and September, representing an overall fall of 2,900 since the general election. Despite earmarking extra funds solely for officer recruitment, Labour has acknowledged that police numbers will not reach the 1997 levels until 2002.

Mr Straw added that there was also no clear correlation between improved police budgets and crime levels. Some police forces, aware they were under a fiscal squeeze, had responded by deploying their officers more effectively, he said.

The Home Office had tried to reverse the tide by increasing the pay of Metropolitan police officers by £3,300 a year, but the increase had simply led to 200 home counties police applying for transfers to the Met's force.

The home secretary is deeply frustrated that overall recruitment was held back by the slow pay-out of extra funds allocated to home counties' forces. He wants police officers within 30 miles of London to be paid an extra £2,000. Yesterday Mr Straw branded the independent police negotiating board, responsible for allocating the extra cash to police forces, as byzantine.

The shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe said Mr Straw was "entirely to blame" for the fall in police numbers. "If it goes on at this rate, the police will find they cannot do things they should be doing because they don't have the manpower," she said.

fields.headline: A strange kind of freedom
fields.standfirst:
The home secretary wants more electronic tagging schemes to ease the strain on our prisons. But what is it like to be tagged? Jim Allen, who wore one for two months, describes life as a prisoner in his own home
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Real lives: The home secretary wants more electronic tagging schemes to ease the strain on our prisons. But what is it like to be tagged? Jim Allen, who wore one for two months, describes life as a prisoner in his own home.
fields.body:
I emerged from Blakenhurst prison blinking into an unseasonably warm, sunny spring morning, discharge grant and travel warrant in hand, a guinea pig in a big brother-style, information-age experiment. As instructed, I made it home to Manchester by 3pm. An hour and a half later, fortified by a steak and half a bottle of champagne, I answered the door to the two Securicor employees sent to fit my tag.

Home detention curfew (HDC), or electronic tagging, is the government's latest attempt to ease the pressure on the overburdened penal system. Having served 10 weeks of two concurrent nine month sentences for evasion of excise duty, I was considered an ideal candidate for the pilot scheme earlier this year.

Think of the earliest digital watch - a cheap-looking piece of kit, circular and about two centimetres thick. That is the tag. It is secured to your ankle by a black plastic strap with a wire running through its centre which, if broken, sends an alarm call to the monitoring centre. Coupled with this is a black box, connected to the electricity supply and the phone line. The first task of the Securicor fitters was to send me to the extremities of the house in order to adjust the range of movement. I was allowed, in a nutshell, no further than the front door.

They were affable enough chaps and did their job with a minimum of fuss. They gave me a brochure explaining my curfew hours and what to do if anything went wrong. They would visit again, in a month, for a routine check. For now I was flying solo, and relishing the thought of my first night in a decent bed in ages.

You wouldn't believe the stifling effect this seemingly innocuous gadget had on my life over the next two months. I had been under the impression that outside the curfew (6.45pm to 6.45am) the tag would make little difference. On the first day I realised how wrong I was. I received a barrage of phone calls that first morning, from friends anxious to find out how I was, whether I had been raped in the showers etc. During the second call, I was rudely interrupted by a bored and detached-sounding female voice insisting I hang up the receiver. Assuming it was a problem with the cable telephone company I ignored it, as I could still hear my brother talking.

However, the instruction persisted until it dawned on me that the voice was coming from the black box. But it was only 9am, and as far as I was concerned, the third hour of my time. I rang the monitoring centre to ask what the problem was. I was told that the box sends messages to them at regular intervals through the day, not simply during my curfew hours, so I would have to live with it for the next two months.

It might not sound that bad, but there are certain people (posh relatives, for instance) whom I would prefer not to know that I had been in prison. This problem occurred several times. I think I managed to convince people that it was just a problem with the cable, but not without a great deal of bluster and embarrassment on my part.

Before going to prison I was attending an Italian class at the adult education centre. I had continued my studies as best I could in prison and on release one of the first things I did was to visit the probation service and the college to get a variation on my tag hours for one night a week to resume my course.

Both were very helpful but I was disappointed to discover that the prison governor held the opinion that I would probably be committing crimes instead of attending my class - this despite the fact that before my imprisonment my most heinous crime had been speeding on the M6.

These weren't my only frustrations. I am not the world's biggest social butterfly and, in fact, hardly ever drink, but the presence of my tag meant I missed several parties, evenings out and concerts that I would have liked the option to attend. Socialising was restricted to daylight hours and when my friends saw me getting twitchy around six o'clock they would take great delight in threatening to tie me up and make me miss my curfew.

Over the first few days of tagging, various awkward incidents helped me appreciate my hours of liberty. For example, a pre-paid card meter, located on the outside wall of the house six feet or so from the front door, supplies my gas. I had charged up the card one day, but forgotten to put it into the meter before 6.45pm. It was a bitterly cold evening and the gas ran out. My wife was visiting a friend. My solution was to contort myself into a banana shape on the floor, tag in the doorway, and blindly fumble the card into the meter at arm's length. Pleased with my efforts I stood up - to be greeted by howls of laughter from the occupants of the house opposite, who had witnessed the whole farcical event. I beat a shame-faced retreat, vowing to be better organised.

So, for the remainder of my HDC I would get really annoyed if I overslept, or failed to do something productive during the day. So perhaps there was something positive to be gained from it.

Tagging is an awkward halfway house. Ask any sneak thief his favourite time of day and he will tell you the morning and afternoon school runs: the curfew hours don't curtail that kind of crime. More involvement from the probation service - and psychologists for the recidivists - would help. Under HDC, it seems that you are essentially left to your own devices once the tag has been fitted.

Now that the tag has been removed (one snap of a pair of shears) I have mixed feelings about the process. Of course it is preferable to imprisonment, but it is a strange kind of freedom. It is very difficult to shake off the feeling that someone is controlling your actions. At least inside you know where you stand.

webTitle: French beef ban rejected as Europe tests for BSE

fields.headline: French beef ban rejected as Europe tests for BSE
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Downing Street last night refused to countenance banning French beef as a rising tide of consumer hysteria in France helped to prompt its European partners into an EU-wide testing programme for BSE.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in  Brussels and  James Meikle
fields.body:
Downing Street last night refused to countenance banning French beef as a rising tide of consumer hysteria in France helped to prompt its European partners into an EU-wide testing programme for BSE.

A spokesman for Tony Blair said neither British food standards chiefs nor EU scientists considered a ban was necessary, but Italy, Spain, Austria, the Netherlands and Greece all began restricting imports either of live cattle or beef.

There were no plans for such action in Britain "for the simple reason that the scientific advice is not there to justify it".

But ministers and the food standards agency welcomed new measures, which included better labelling of the country of origin. The agency plans to seek new assurances from France on how it will implement controls to prevent beef banned in France from being exported.

Imports of processed beef are difficult to check but the only beef products made from animals over 30 months old that are allowed into Britain are from a handful of specialised herds in Britain or from 14 BSE-free countries.

The agency said yesterday: "There have been no substantiated cases of imported beef over 30 months old [from other countries] reaching UK consumers. It is illegal and the penalties are high. There is no reason to advise consumers against eating legally sold EU beef in the UK, although we are constantly checking the situation."

France accounts for about 5,650 tonnes of the 147,000 tonnes of beef imported into Britain each year, but has steadfastly refused to import British beef since the EU export ban on Britain was lifted in August last year.

The British government is, however, playing down the impact at home of EU-wide measures, which will also include bans on feeding mammalian meat and bone meal to cattle, a practice banned in Britain since 1996.

Britain is unique in already barring nearly all cattle over 30 months old from food, although it will undertake 17,000 random tests on older cattle killed in slaughterhouses and fallen stock over the next year. Smaller scale checks have in the past suggested 0.3% of such animals in Britain might have BSE, in addition to the 177,465 cases so far identified since 1986.

Other EU countries have barely 1,500 cases between them and even France has this year had only 99 cases compared with 1,141 in Britain. The official inquiry into BSE last month said it appeared Britain had exported the problem years ago through live cattle or infected animal feed.

The breakthrough on EU measures came yesterday at the end of a 16-hour meeting of farm ministers in Brussels at which France tried and failed to persuade other European countries to lift their own unilateral bans. Doubts about the safety of French meat surfaced after tests picked up dozens of new cases of BSE. Two French nationals have died after contracting the human form of the disease, vCJD. A third case is suspected.

In the ensuing panic domestic beef sales in France have plummeted by 40%. Paris is furious at the threat to its exports and persuaded other countries to agree to provide scientific evidence to justify their action. "France is not off the hook yet," said one EU diplomat who added that the entire testing scheme would not have been agreed without strong arm tactics from France, which is desperate to prop up its industry.

The Tories, meanwhile, seized on a report that Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has warned Mr Blair that BSE-tainted French beef may be able to enter the UK.

"There are now serious question marks about French beef and I think the government should introduce a ban immediately to protect British consumers," the shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, told the BBC.

"We can't allow the government's very well known reluctance to confront France on any issue to interfere with a proper response."

But the government declined to substantiate the report and the National Farmers' Union went out of its way to play down the dangers of eating French beef.

The new tests will see every beast in Europe considered to be "at risk" and over the age of 30 months tested for BSE from January 1 onwards. In July the testing programme may be extended to cover all animals over 30 months across the EU in a move which it is estimated would affect 7m cattle.

But the government declined to substantiate the report and the National Farmers' Union went out of its way to play down the dangers of eating French beef. The new tests will see every beast in Europe considered to be "at risk" and over the age of 30 months tested for BSE from January 1 onwards. In July the testing programme may be extended to cover all animals over 30 months across the EU in a move which it is estimated would affect 7m cattle.

webTitle: Leader: Only testing will show BSE's spread

fields.headline: Cattle grids
fields.standfirst:
Only testing will show BSE's spread

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Only testing will show BSE's spread.
fields.body:
It took European agriculture ministers 16 hours to decide early yesterday on what can only be called a minimum plan to test cattle for BSE. The delay was due to national pride - the Germans and Italians are still in denial about the presence of the disease in their countries - and the occupational imperative on such ministers is to put the short-run commercial interests of farmers before the wider public weal.

The EU-wide measure is nonetheless welcome. From January cattle which die unexpectedly or show signs of illness will be tested, with a view to extending testing to all cattle entering the food chain. The resulting data will paint a better picture of the spread of BSE. We certainly need one - all of us in Europe that is. It is clear the disease was exported from the UK but its passage through contaminated feed (probably) within and beyond France needs detailing. So far the human death toll is confined to the UK, France and the Irish Republic, but where are the guarantees variant CJD will not present itself in other countries? Free trade and travel are precious but some travellers are public-spirited types who donate blood. Health authorities in Belgium and Austria recently proscribed the blood of UK citizens - do they now extend that to French people? If ever there were a case for pan-European measures in food safety, public health and animal hygiene, BSE makes it impregnable.

Which is why yesterday's response by the Tory party is little short of deranged. French exports of beef to the UK are tiny and only bear worrying about if we are absolutely sure all modes of BSE transmission within the UK have been stopped off. We are not, by a long chalk. The Tories, by the way, are the party that brought us the disease in the first place and their economic coherence is shown by the way they want simultaneously to revive the farming industry (which depends on exports) and to ban foreign foodstuffs. Someone should tell William Hague he is not William Pitt.

The French do deserve criticism for failing to play by the EU rules on British beef yet, now, ask the EU to help enforce their domestic ban on feeding animals meal containing cattle remains. Rivalry between president and prime minister in Paris does not excuse their refusal to see that only the fullest intra-EU cooperation is going to get us anywhere near the beginning of the end of the BSE prion.

webTitle: Straw admits tens of thousands of rejected asylum seekers at large

fields.headline: Straw admits tens of thousands of rejected asylum seekers at large
fields.trailText: The government has lost track of tens of thousands of asylum seekers in Britain and knows that hundreds of rejected asylum seekers recently housed in its flagship detention centre are still here, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government has lost track of tens of thousands of asylum seekers in Britain and knows that hundreds of rejected asylum seekers recently housed in its flagship detention centre are still here, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday.

Mr Straw conceded ministers had no knowledge of the whereabouts of many of the 72,000 backlog of asylum seekers. Their addresses had only been given at the time of application for asylum.

However, Mr Straw claimed the money being poured into the immigration directorate was reforming a system on its knees under the Conservatives. The processing of new asylum applicants had risen to 3,000 a week this month, he said, representing an increase of 1,200 on the weekly average of the first quarter of this year.

He described the figure as an "extraordinary improvement" as applications were currently being lodged at the rate of 6,300 a month. He assured MPs on the home affairs select committee there were penalties and incentives for applicants to keep in touch with the immigration directorate through its reporting centres.

But Humfrey Malins, a Tory member of the committee, said the speed with which decisions were taken was neither here nor there if no enforcement followed through the removal of failed applicants.

He argued that Mr Straw conceded in 1998 that 19,000 applicants had gone missing, and on current trends this would rise to 115,000 by 2002.

Ministers have repeatedly refused to give figures on the numbers of asylum seekers who have been refused permission to remain in the country but have not been removed because they cannot be traced.

But Mr Malins told the home secretary: "You and I know ... the chances of them being removed is so low as to make the system a mockery."

He pointed to figures showing that of the 763 processed appeals at the Oakington camp in Cambridgeshire, only 28 had been allowed and only 231 removed or left voluntarily. He said that if Oakington was not working the government had no chance of meeting its target of 30,000 enforced departures per year by 2001/02. The last full year figures showed 7,910 asylum seekers were removed from the UK.

But Mr Straw insisted that the government could achieve this significant increase through its £600m investment in the immigration service, including an increase in the number of detention places to 2,400. He said deportation was not easy as if someone came from a country where there was civil disturbance there was often no effective government with which to make arrangements for their return.

fields.headline: Labour unrest over NHS plan
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the NHS
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour MPs yesterday gave a clear warning of backbench unrest over a key plank of the NHS reform plan ministers want to put on the statute book before the general election.
fields.body:
Labour MPs yesterday gave a clear warning of backbench unrest over a key plank of the NHS reform plan ministers want to put on the statute book before the general election.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, came under fire during question time in the Commons over his proposal to replace the community health councils with three new types of patient representation. They would involve scrutiny of NHS performance by local authorities, election of patient representatives to NHS trusts and creation of an advocacy and liaison service within the trusts.

David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health committee, said he wanted advocates to work within independent CHCs.

"My concern is that the proposal on patient advocates places them within trusts and they will not be seen to be independent in a way that pa tients need them to be completely independent," he said.

Barry Jones, Labour MP for Alyn and Deeside, said the CHCs did a good job representing patients."It might be possible that you would delay your approach to the CHCs until you have advanced your other reforms. Since it is working, perhaps we shouldn't seek to fix it too soon," he said.

Mr Milburn stuck to his guns, insisitng there would be more independence and "more patient power".

webTitle: Costly flu drug only for high risk NHS patients

fields.headline: Costly flu drug only for high risk NHS patients
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: GPs yesterday warned they could be swamped by patients wanting the anti-flu drug Relenza despite NHS guidance yesterday restricting its use to up to 500,000 "at risk" patients including the over-65s, asthmatics and diabetics.
fields.body:
GPs yesterday warned they could be swamped by patients wanting the anti-flu drug Relenza despite NHS guidance yesterday restricting its use to up to 500,000 "at risk" patients including the over-65s, asthmatics and diabetics.

The new advice issued by ministers followed a change of heart by the government body monitoring the cost-effectiveness of medicines, which estimates that each GP would have no more than 17 patients eligible for the drug each year.

The decision will add about £12m a year to the NHS drugs bill but health authorities hope that the relaxation of an effective ban on the drug for state funded patients will save money on other aspects of treating seriously ill flu patients.

The government insisted the guidance, which would allow pharmacists and nurses to supply the drug on the direction of doctors, would not mean a huge extra workload. Ordinary flu jabs remain the best protection for the population and Relenza should normally only be prescribed - even for at-risk patients - once flu cases had exceeded 50 per 100,000 people, as recorded by weekly return by doctors and the public health laboratory service. This is the minimum level for a flu "outbreak", but well below epidemic and pandemic levels.

The drug, administered by inhaler, costs £24 for a five day course, and its restricted use has been endorsed by the national institute for clinical excellence, which had at first refused to support the drug. It now accepts that the product may benefit some patients but insisted it had not been influenced by the government or manufacturers.

Patients with significant heart problems, chronic breathing problems and those with weakened immune systems would also qualify under the guidance. Most flu victims will have to make do with the traditional paracetamol and a couple of days in bed.

John Chisholm, chairman of the British Medical Association's GPs committee, said he thought allowing vulnerable people to receive Relenza was the right decision.

"We are fearful that, even with the drug only available to high risk individuals, that will place enormous extra demand on general practices during any epidemic."

Mike Pringle, chairman of the Royal College of General Practitioners, said Relenza had the potential to help high-risk patients, but warned: "As GPs are being stretched to their limit, the introduction of a new therapy that may involve hundreds of urgent consultations for each GP, many in the patient's home, is unacceptable without discussion and extra resources."

The health minister, John Denham, said extra government investment meant the NHS could afford the drug. Nice believed Relenza was only effective if administered within 48 hours of symptoms appearing and only reduced the impact of flu by a day. But its use for vulnerable patients would be an extra weapon in helping patients most likely to need NHS services.

Help the Aged said the decision would help keep some elderly people out of hospital and was confident that concerns over possible adverse reactions had been examined.

Up to now Relenza's use has been restricted mainly to private practice, where about 8,000 prescriptions have been issued. Sales worldwide are thought so far to total around £20m, mainly in the US. The advice only applies to England and Wales but is likely to be followed in Scotland too.
