fields.headline: Face it: the tube is a disgrace and PPP is a dead duck
fields.standfirst:
There is still time to fix the capital's transport system - but only just

Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: On Monday the "best and final" offers were made by the contractors bidding for their 30-year contracts: politically this is virtual privatisation with such long leases and the tube broken up into three separate regulated mega-monopolies.
fields.body:
Pelham 123 is belting down the Underground line. Is there a driver in the cab? Yes, it is the chancellor, jaw set rigid, eyes staring straight ahead, iron hand on the handle. Beside him trying not to cower are those co-drivers he has forced to ride with him -or else: John Prescott and transport minister Gus Macdonald signed their name in blood on this trip. Can anyone stop them before London Underground turns into a needless political calamity?

On Monday the "best and final" offers were made by the contractors bidding for their 30-year contracts: politically this is virtual privatisation with such long leases and the tube broken up into three separate regulated mega-monopolies. These are bigger contracts than anything before: the largest hospital PFI was only £180m compared with £2.5bn each here. The contracts are so phenomenally complex they fill 14 filing cabinets. Realistically only a few weeks remain for the public private partnership to be reconfigured. Is the prime minister awake? As for the 51 London Labour MPs, where are they? Privately, many are hoping someone else will get them off the hook. If this ends in political disaster, it will be Gordon Brown's own.

Robert Kiley, the man brought in to rescue London Transport, flew back to New York last night in grim mood. Finally, after an absurd display of government truculence, he has eventually been given the contract papers he needs to peruse over the next week. In New York he is meeting top bankers to draw up an alternative plan for financing the vast new investment needed. The question is, when he returns will the ministers and especially the chancellor, be ready to listen? Kiley is not playing politics here, he is not Ken Livingstone's creature. He is a train man who has rescued both the Boston and the New York subway systems. He knows more than anyone about running subways, more even than the clever chancellor and other ministers. Many London MPs are alarmed, but worry that any public intervention by them will only make the obstinate dig their heels in harder.

Kiley has surveyed the tube management and plant with horror. He has toured control rooms still held together with devices he's only seen in transport museums, and wonders where the millions poured down the tube over the years have gone. He has looked at the through-put of trains and asks why there are so few. He promises that within 18 months, even before renewing track and signalling, he can make the existing system work far better. Professor Tony Travers of the LSE says it can be done: on the Northern line only 19 trains an hour run yet they can run at one a minute (40 an hour in 1912). As for the London Underground managers, if they were eager to sign their own death warrants, then they just did it flamboyantly this week by announcing the closure of the tube on New Year's Eve, cancelling the London firework display when every British city and every capital city plans global celebrations.

These incompetents now negotiate the "best and final" offers for the unbreakable 30-year private contracts. Kiley has met the bidders and fears those conducting these deals are ill-equipped innocents. Take the bid for the Victoria, Bakerloo and Central lines: they only promise to renew the rails and signals for one of those lines by the very end of their first seven years. The companies will put their first energies into smartening up stations which yield quick profits with rent from new shops and property deals.

But passengers just want trains. What of contracts that remove the ATP safety system to install cheaper moving block systems that have failed elsewhere? The tube is vastly over-manned, mainly with bureaucrats, 20% of whom will have to go. But the contracts cherrypick all the useful engineers and maintenance workers, leaving the publicly owned part still weighed down with the expense and difficulty of shedding large numbers. Kiley fears the structure of the PPP itself is flawed. How can he run it when he cannot order private depots to send out his trains? In the event of a row with them some morning, taking them to arbitration several weeks later will not keep his trains running.

All this is fixable. There is still time - just. The national audit office will assess the calculations comparing the PPP's value for money with a public sector alternative. They say they will seek out any weaselly assumptions that so often compare the very best of private outcomes with the very worst of public results. The health and safety executive also has to approve the PPP: after the Railtrack experience, will they be more sceptical? Maybe one of these will apply the brakes and get everyone off the hook.

Astonishingly, neither the chancellor nor anyone from the Treasury has yet met Kiley. He has met no-one above transport minister level. On high the official line remains that PPP has to stay. Between gritted teeth, they point out that Kiley took on the job accepting the PPP. Yes, there could be a bit of modification - but it must be PPP. Backing down is hard after Dobson went to his death for it, Prescott laid his old Labour heart on the rails for it, Macdonald was appointed handcuffed to it and Labour MPs voted for it. No turning back is still the word. Why?

Ken Livingstone. Government hatred blinds them to all else. It also delivers them straight into his cunning hands. Kiley arrived at Livingstone's invitation and was taken under the mayor's wing, so instead of calling him into the highest offices for talks, they seethed and accused him of being "Livingstone's man". Or, more patronisingly, Livingstone's fall guy whom the old sorcerer will hang out to dry if anything goes wrong. London MPs are torn between their hatred of Livingstone and their wise fear of pushing PPP against the voters' will.

The politics of all this is clear. When London voted against PPP, rightly or wrongly Labour lost the argument. After Hatfield and the Railtrack meltdown, it was in ruins as a recent Mori poll shows. Even if PPP is the best technical solution, politically it is a dead duck. Carrying on as if nothing has changed is unthinkable madness. Those who wish the Labour party well - especially Labour ministers and MPs - cannot stand by and let it happen. If it goes ahead with Kiley still proclaiming the system badly flawed, then every accident or glitch will be the government's fault, with Livingstone smiling like a tiger. Kiley is bemused by tribal British politics but knows a lot of faces have to be saved: he can do that if they will let him. Livingstone promises to agree whatever system Kiley thinks will work best. Now if Kiley comes up with a modified scheme he thinks better, the question is whether the government can swallow a little pride. Politically all that matters for Labour is that Kiley, Livingstone, Prescott and Brown all end up agreeing and London has a transport system that is no longer the worst in Europe.

fields.headline: Writers condemn ETA targeting
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: An attempt by the separatist group ETA to murder two journalists covering Spain's Basque conflict is condemned today in an advertisement published in the Madrid daily El Pais and signed by more than 60 distinguished writers and editors.
fields.body:
An attempt by the separatist group ETA to murder two journalists covering Spain's Basque conflict is condemned today in an advertisement published in the Madrid daily El Pais and signed by more than 60 distinguished writers and editors.

The defence of journalists' freedom to work, which has attracted the support of such figures as the photographers Henri Cartier-Bresson and Sebastiao Salgado, the Colombian author Gabriel Garcia Marquez and the novelist Norman Mailer, follows a failed bomb attack in San Sebastian on November 10.

The device was placed on the doorstep of the home of a young couple, both journalists. but failed to detonate. The incident has brought to a head concerns about threats of violence made against journalists reporting on the Basque country.

The letter published in El Pais declares: "The attempted assassination on November 10 in San Sebastian of two journalists... by a bomb placed in their own home targeted against them and their 18-month-old baby - has deepened our concern about the conditions in which news reporting professionals are carrying out their work in the Basque country.

"We wish to express our support for the journalists who are subjected to threats by ETA, and declare that we shall remain watchful in defence of their lives and independence."

The defence of journalists' freedom to work, which has attracted the support of such figures as the photographers Henri Cartier-Bresson and Sebastiao Salgado, the Colombian author Gabriel Garcia Marquez and the novelist Norman Mailer, follows a failed bomb attack in San Sebastian on November 10. The device was placed on the doorstep of the home of a young couple, both journalists. but failed to detonate. The incident has brought to a head concerns about threats of violence made against journalists reporting on the Basque country. The letter published in El Pais declares: "The attempted assassination on November 10 in San Sebastian of two journalists... by a bomb placed in their own home targeted against them and their 18-month-old baby - has deepened our concern about the conditions in which news reporting professionals are carrying out their work in the Basque country. "We wish to express our support for the journalists who are subjected to threats by ETA, and declare that we shall remain watchful in defence of their lives and independence." fields.headline: Compensation offer for rail travellers
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Rail passengers should be allowed to produce "proof of travel" letters from employers to claim compensation for disrupted journeys over the past month, the rail passengers' council said yesterday.
fields.body:
Rail passengers should be allowed to produce "proof of travel" letters from employers to claim compensation for disrupted journeys over the past month, the rail passengers' council said yesterday.

As the 25 rail companies received compensation claims from angry passengers with monthly and annual season tickets, the council said rail firms would be mean if they did not give equal treatment to those with daily and weekly tickets.

Stewart Francis, the council's chairman, said that it was pressing train companies to allow "proof of travel" letters or even hotel bills as evidence because most passengers in this category would have thrown away their tickets.

His comments came as rail passengers with monthly and annual season tickets were offered full refunds of up to 26 days free travel by the Great North Eastern Railway. Virgin, which operates west coast mainline and cross country services, is offering up to 22 days free travel.

GNER said that season ticket holders travelling in the period up to four weeks following the Hatfield rail crash could claim a 100% refund. This will come in the form of rail travel vouchers or cash.

Virgin's compensation deal involves monthly, quarterly and annual season ticket holders, covering the period between October 15 to November 11. GNER said it was also offering enhanced levels of compensation for non-season ticket holders beyond the normal provision. For delays of four hours or more, passengers will receive a full refund on their return ticket.

Anthony Smith, the rail passenger council's national director, welcomed the announcement by GNER and Virgin but said they were unlikely to have to pay out much because they both sold relatively few season tickets.

Mr Smith added: "If they are saying season ticket holders get the money back, why shouldn't everybody be treated in the same way?"

webTitle: Leader: Blair should be wary of Putin

fields.headline: To Russia with love
fields.standfirst:
Blair should be wary of Putin's embrace

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Blair should be wary of Putin's embrace.
fields.body:
Tony Blair seems to have enjoyed his flying visit to Moscow. That's nice. Hobnobbing with Russia's enigmatic president must make a welcome change from floods, broken rails and fuel protesters. But exactly what was the prime minister doing in that bierkeller with Vladimir (call me Volodya) Putin? Not discussing women, presumably, despite Mr Putin's off-colour joke. Mr Blair has met the Russian leader no fewer than five times this year. He says he has a personal liking for the man, that there is good chemistry between them. Mr Putin coolly describes the PM as "very pleasant".

For Mr Blair, the first western leader to congratulate Boris Yeltsin's successor on his election victory last March (before he was actually elected, in fact), there is the Thatcher-Gorbachev good pals precedent to live up to. There is also the temptation to cut out the French and Germans, to bank credit in Washington as the man with the inside track, and to act the big player on the world stage. But Mr Blair should beware lest enthusiasm outrun judgment and personal instinct become a basis for policy.

While the concrete benefits to Britain of this burgeoning relationship are less than obvious, for Russia they are clear. Mr Putin badly needs continuing western loans. In this, Britain can help. He also desperately needs a means of escaping the cul-de-sac presented by American plans to build a national missile defence system. Russia cannot match NMD, militarily or technologically. Yet, like China, it views it as a dire threat to national security. In this regard, too, by acting as a mediator-cum-moderator, as he has offered to do, and as Russia's traditional "bridge" to Washington, Mr Blair may provide Mr Putin with a way out.

Mr Putin's Russia is pursuing other policies that are plainly incompatible with British interests. Its opposition to Nato as the leading European security alliance remains undimmed; it would far prefer an enhanced role for the Osce and a definitive end to Nato's eastward expansion. In this respect, Mr Blair's evident pleasure yesterday at persuading Mr Putin of the benefit of the EU's new rapid reaction force seems positively naive. Given that it has been Russia's historic aim to "decouple" the US and Europe, Mr Putin was hardly going to object to a project that could ultimately split Nato asunder. Another obvious Anglo-Russian conflict of interest centres on Iraq, where Russia is actively breaking UN sanctions, expanding its oil interests, and bolstering Saddam's regime.

Mr Blair should be doubly beware of Mr Putin's embrace given that, in the longer term, he is likely to be cruelly dumped. Star wars schemes apart, a conservative Bush administration in Washington, opposed to overseas interventions, uninterested in Serbia and the Balkans, and oblivious to human rights issues, could yet prove more congenial to the authoritarian Mr Putin than to Mr Blair and Labour. Similarly in Europe, and despite Mr Blair's efforts to lead the pack and drum up business, Russia's natural interlocutor and biggest trade and investment partner is Germany, followed by France, and is likely to remain so.

Most of all, Mr Blair's moody passions should be tempered by chilling recollection of how Mr Putin got where he is today: over the bodies of thousands of Chechen civilians. The man chewing beefsteak in the bierkeller is known elsewhere as the "butcher of Grozny". He has never accounted for last winter's atrocities. Nor has the killing stopped. Surely our starry-eyed prime minister must realise that this is a man with whom it can be very dangerous to do business.

fields.headline: Odd couple laugh at doubters
fields.standfirst:
Fifth get-together in 10 months cements bond between leaders
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The fun loving, beer swilling, male bonding, ex-KGB colonel is always good for a laugh. And Vladimir Putin just could not resist telling us all a gag yesterday before heading off for lunch with his favourite guest from the west, Tony Blair.
fields.body:
The fun loving, beer swilling, male bonding, ex-KGB colonel is always good for a laugh. And Vladimir Putin just could not resist telling us all a gag yesterday before heading off for lunch with his favourite guest from the west, Tony Blair.

"We have this joke in Russia," the president said while describing the previous evening's get-together in a bierkeller on Lenin Prospect. "When blokes get together on their own, they talk about women. When they get together with women, they talk shop, about their work."

Teeheehee. As the Kremlin and the Downing Street press corps fell about laughing, the prime minister looked mildly embarrassed, though Alastair Campbell was in creases.

Was Mr Putin really rather ribaldly suggesting that Mr Blair had flown all the way to Moscow to sit down in a mock German pub to have a chinwag about the other sex over a jug or two of lager? Surely not. In fact, the joke as well as the bierkeller summit were all part of the Kremlin spin doctors' careful campaign to humanise their president and sell the idea that Mr Putin and Mr Blair do get along famously.

The Downing Street entourage got the message just before they landed in Moscow on Monday evening. "We'll go for a beer. Dress casually." And so down to Lenin Prospect just south of the Kremlin.

But as Mr Blair was whisked back to London last night after what was a flying 15 hour visit with no clear agenda and no big issues at stake nor deals to be signed, the question exercising the minds of Moscow pundits was, what is it all for?

"Tony Blair arrived in Moscow. Why?" asked the daily, Izvestia. "There's no burning need for a Russia-Britain summit right now. Most likely he's arrived just because of the deepening friendship with Vladimir Putin - an extremely strange European couple." The newspaper Moskovskiye Novosti was also perplexed. "It's difficult to say what links the former head of the FSB [intelligence service] with the liberal ideologue of the third way."

They certainly seem to like each other. When Bill Clinton came here in June, Mr Putin was furious when the US leader criticised creeping press curbs and took part in a phone-in on opposition radio. It was only last month that Mr Putin went to France for the first time after months of frostiness because of French criticism of his conduct in the Chechnya war.

Even the key relationship between Moscow and Berlin remains lukewarm despite Mr Putin's fluent German and his sending his two daughters to the German school in Moscow.

All those other western leaders were watching the cuddly Blair-Putin relationship with a lot of surprise and not a little envy, Moskovskiye Novosti said.

It is easy to see why the newspaper should take this view. Yesterday was the fifth time in 10 months that Mr Putin and Mr Blair were having a tete-a-tete. A fortnight before Mr Putin was elected in March, the Blairs showed up in his home town of St Peters burg for a night at the opera. Once he was elected, Mr Putin made Downing Street his first foreign port of call.

Briefing Russian journalists on the visit this week, the Russian ambassador in London said that the personal chemistry between Mr Blair and Mr Putin was such that relations between Britain and Russia were now the best ever.

Mr Putin said of Mr Blair yesterday: "He's very well-informed and pleasant - I've come to the conclusion that our meetings tend to be very informal, frank, and friendly."

Mr Blair said of Mr Putin: "He is someone who wants to do the right thing by himself and the world - he is highly intelligent, very capable, knows what he wants for Russia and is prepared to listen." While Izvestia was wondering about "the strange couple" and why Mr Blair was seeing Mr Putin, the simplest answer seemed to be - they just like each other.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Relations between Britain and Saudi Arabia may be about to decline. Last Friday in Riyadh, expat engineer Christopher Rodway was killed and his wife Jane injured when his car exploded, seemingly after a terrorist mistook him for an American. Given that Mr Rodway worked at a Saudi military hospital, you can imagine how dearly Saudi defence minister Prince Sultan bin Abdul Aziz felt the loss, as a visit to the official Saudi government website proves.
fields.body:
Relations between Britain and Saudi Arabia may be about to decline. Last Friday in Riyadh, expat engineer Christopher Rodway was killed and his wife Jane injured when his car exploded, seemingly after a terrorist mistook him for an American. Given that Mr Rodway worked at a Saudi military hospital, you can imagine how dearly Saudi defence minister Prince Sultan bin Abdul Aziz felt the loss, as a visit to the official Saudi government website proves.

Questioned about investigations into the killing at a technological exhibition, where he had just heralded the imminent arrival of the free market in that feudal land, the prince is quoted as replying: "It is improper to ask about this as it is a very trivial matter." How delightful. No doubt fearless foreign office minister Peter Hain will wish to slap down the prince, also a deputy premier of his country, with the same magisterial scorn he recently aimed at the French for daring to send cancer drugs by plane to the dying children of Iraq.

 After giving him a few weeks grace to settle in, the Diary attempts to contact Patrick Diamond, successor to Oofy Wegg-Prosser (now a big noise on our website) as O'Mandy Mandelson's best little helper.

Yesterday my colleague Richard Adams tried several times to get Young Paddy to the phone to test his rapid rebuttal powers. No luck so far, but it's early days. Paddy, lad, run if you like but we needn't quote Joe Louis to a 17-year-old man of the world like yourself. Talk to us. It's the only way. If you don't believe us, ask Oofy.

 With the West Bromwich byelection tomorrow, New Labour dispatched Ross Kemp to the town yesterday - the actor and his partner Rebekah Wade, the News of the World editor, are regular guests at Chequers - and he attracted a decent crowd which included a well-dressed, elegant woman queuing patiently for an autograph. On close inspection, local Labour people were alarmed to note that this was in fact Vanessa Finneran, the Tory byelection press officer.

Labour minders suspected a stunt, but not a bit of it. Vanessa just wanted the former EastEnders hard man's signature. The event was filmed by the BBC, with Newsnight's Mark Mardell interviewing one local elector: "Excuse me madam, are you more likely to vote for Labour now that Ross Kemp has signed your knickers?" "Yes," she replied. "I am."

 Hats off to WH Smith for courageously returning soft porn back to its stores. Just so long as it's clear that this is not a cheap commercial decision but one of principle; and that stores do draw the line somewhere, many refusing to stock such dubious top shelf titles as Tribune, the Literary Review, the New Statesman and even the Jackal's Spectator.

fields.headline: So farewell soon, Lord Falconer
fields.standfirst:
The minister for the dome must be counting the days to the New Year

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: If you thought the festivities on the night of the millennium were impressive, they'll be nothing compared to the party that is planned for December 31 this year. On the stroke of midnight Lord Falconer will be jumping up and down shouting: "Hooray! I don't have to be minister for the Bloody Dome anymore!"
fields.body:
If you thought the festivities on the night of the millennium were impressive, they'll be nothing compared to the party that is planned for December 31 this year. On the stroke of midnight twice as much champagne will be consumed, more fireworks will light up the sky, and the cheering will be 10 times louder. And all these celebrations will be coming from one little office in Westminster where Lord Falconer is jumping up and down shouting: "Hooray! I don't have to be minister for the Bloody Dome anymore!"

However, Lord Falconer might need to be kept in his job because the problem of the dome is not going to go away. The national audit office has just announced a second inquiry, this time into its actual sale. The first buyers pulled out when they realised that the estate agents' blurb ("Unique spacious property with views over Thames. Security recently upgraded. Reduced for quick sale") did not tell the whole tale. This week's new bidder is planning a hi-tech e-commerce park inside the dome, although if past history is anything to go by, half the emails sent to Greenwich will probably decide: "Oh, I can't be bothered to go all the way out there."

So just because the Cabinet looks set to finally be shot of the place does not mean that it will disappear as a political issue. Because for anyone looking for a way to bash the government, there is a mind-numbing inevitably that their first stop will always be the Millennium Dome.

So Tony is sitting at home having dinner with the family and he says: "No Euan, you can't have Playstation two for Christmas - it's too expensive."

"Well maybe you could have afforded it if you hadn't spent so much money on the dome!"

Then Cherie sips the wine and says: "Yuck, maybe you could have bought a decent bottle of plonk if you hadn't spent so much money on the dome!"

And the man selling dusters knocks on the door and Tony says: "No thank you," and the man says: "Yeah, you won't buy a duster, but you don't mind spending all that money on the dome do you?" It must be starting to drive him a little bit mad.

Most people who are in contact with the PM must read the Guardian, so let's agree now to take this wind-up to the next stage as from today. If you are meeting with Mr Blair this week, when you talk to him try only using the word "dome". So if you're a civil servant outlining a new set of figures, just say : "Dome dome dome dome." And the PM will turn to Alastair Campbell and say: "What's he saying?" And then Campbell should say: "Dome d-dome dome domey dome-dome."

All governments have cock-ups, and the dome is of course nothing as compared to Black Wednesday or Neville Chamberlain saying "Let's give this Hitler chap the benefit of the doubt." In one sense the Millennium Dome has been a triumph. A British theme park should give us the chance to do the things we enjoy the most and the dome has been top of the list of subjects to moan about all year long.

All its problems stem from one crucial and overwhelming mistake - the projected number of visitors. The number of people who have been to the dome has been very disappointing and he didn't even bring a friend. In fact the target attendance figures were set under the last government and much as the Tories love to see the dome as a symbol of New Labour, it started out as the baby of the last Conservative deputy prime minister. That is not to say that this government should not have seen that the figures were crazy (and to their credit they have now admitted as much) but the idea that the dome would have been better run by a John Major government that couldn't even organise a traffic cone hot-line is just a little bit rich.

But for a project that was intended to entertain us, the entertainment has been non-stop. Ever since he took up the job, Lord Falconer has been under pressure to resign, but that was of course the whole point of his appointment in the first place. The card in the job centre said: "Fall guy wanted to take flak and get roasted on Newsnight. Temporary appointment only." They could of course still sack him but they'd only have to replace him with someone else and Frank Dobson wasn't that keen, for some reason.

This has been the best idea to come out of the whole debacle - appointing a special junior minister to act as public whipping post for unpopular government policies. So Lord Falconer had better not get too drunk on New Year's eve, because the next morning he'll be getting a very important phone call. "Hi Charlie," the prime minister will say, "I've got a great new job for you. How do you fancy being minister for Very High Petrol Prices?"

The number of people who have been to the dome has been very disappointing and he didn't even bring a friend. In fact the target attendance figures were set under the last government and much as the Tories love to see the dome as a symbol of New Labour, it started out as the baby of the last Conservative deputy prime minister. That is not to say that this government should not have seen that the figures were crazy (and to their credit they have now admitted as much) but the idea that the dome would have been better run by a John Major government that couldn't even organise a traffic cone hot-line is just a little bit rich. But for a project that was intended to entertain us, the entertainment has been non-stop. Ever since he took up the job, Lord Falconer has been under pressure to resign, but that was of course the whole point of his appointment in the first place. The card in the job centre said: "Fall guy wanted to take flak and get roasted on Newsnight. Temporary appointment only." They could of course still sack him but they'd only have to replace him with someone else and Frank Dobson wasn't that keen, for some reason. This has been the best idea to come out of the whole debacle - appointing a special junior minister to act as public whipping post for unpopular government policies. So Lord Falconer had better not get too drunk on New Year's eve, because the next morning he'll be getting a very important phone call. "Hi Charlie," the prime minister will say, "I've got a great new job for you. How do you fancy being minister for Very High Petrol Prices?" comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Dot.com doubts over dome's new role

fields.headline: Dot.com doubts over dome's new role
fields.standfirst:
Buyer sees huge demand for a hi-tech business park but IT companies point to difficulties over image, location and incentives

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Buyer sees huge demand for a hi-tech business park but IT companies point to difficulties over image, location and incentives.
fields.body:
Legacy, the company that is buying the Millennium Dome, has not yet got a single company to guarantee that it will take space in its hi-tech business park - and will not be able to sign up anybody until it has finalised its £125m deal with the government, a spokesman admitted last night.

The company, run by Robert Bourne, a Labour donor who is a friend of Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and of the public relations and advertising consultant Charles Saatchi, is the preferred bidder for the dome, at a price that has already been reduced by £25m since its original bid. It is expected to take over the dome in February.

A company spokesman said that market research had shown there was a huge demand for businesses to move into the dome, but this was not stood up by IT companies contacted by the Guardian.

There appeared to be no sign of the optimism expressed by Lord Falconer, the cabinet office minister and shareholder in the dome, that it was going to be a booming attraction.

Some leading internet firms also warned the government to keep its hands off the dome if the troubled project is to have any chance of succeeding as a dot.com business park.

The bidder is relying on the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the attraction, taking up to five months to decommission the dome. It initially will occupy buildings on the site, not the dome itself, until there is demand to build office space. It is vague about the phasing of development, but a spokesman promised that the dome will not be left dark and unused.

It is also assuming that few of the 14,000 people who could work there will arrive by car. There is minimal parking space at the moment.

The firm is strongly against taking any money from the government, saying that the flexibility of its hi-tech accommodation would not require any subsidy from Whitehall.

Many internet firms expressed scepticism that firms would be interested in relocating there, saying the dome had "one hell of an image problem".

City investors added that following the dot.com crash in March few internet companies could afford to move to the dome unless there was substantial investment in infrastructure, and incentives such as cut price leases for start-up companies.

"One of the biggest problems with the new scheme is over coming the dome's image of having been a complete fiasco," said Rhonda Alexander-Abt, co-founder of The Chemistry, a European networking hub for the start-up sector.

"There is potential to build a hi-tech hotbed there but there are a lot of difficulties."

She said the government should not get involved. "Stepping back and letting the private sector run with it and treat it as a real capitalist endeavour is vital. They didn't do that before and too many other interests were being served.

"Robert Bourne is a smart man and I would imagine what he would be asking for is some government concessions to institute a real hi-tech centre so you can get the best broad-band capability of any centre that is being built.

"If they are trying to attract start-up companies to this centre they can't expect them to pay exorbitant real estate prices. But they must do it quietly so that it is perceived they are finally handing it over to the public sector."

Mark Rattley of Virage, a company that converts video for use on the web, said: "Success depends on how the government facilitates the transfer to a technology park and overcomes the dome's poor image. It was recently voted as the most depressing building in London, even more depressing than the floods and the fuel crisis.

"What I found depressing was that I was at the dome on Monday giving a live demonstration to 200 media companies at a technology conference and there was no internet connection so we could not even demonstrate our products live.

"The key is the project's infrastructure, costs, and whether you can attract people to that location given that it takes an hour and a half to cross between west and east London on the rail network."

Sir Peter Hall, professor of planning at University College London, told the BBC's Today programme the project was beset with difficulties: "The dome is not exactly at the fashionable end of town and is going to be let to a great number of small tenants on very short leases so they can always pull out.

"It has exhibition space but there's Excel across the water competing. And finally, we are at the end of a very long property boom in London. Last time Canary Wharf was almost blown away and this time we don't know what's going to happen."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report on the NSPCC's survey of child abuse, page 10, November 20, we wrongly suggested that most sex acts against children under 16 were perpetrated by members of their family. In fact relatively small numbers of the young people in the survey had experienced sexual abuse by family members: 1% suffered sexual abuse by a parent or carer and 3% by another relative. One in 10 (mostly girls) had experienced penetrative sex, oral sex or attempts at these against their will by people known to them but unrelated.
fields.body:
In our report on the NSPCC's survey of child abuse, page 10, November 20, we wrongly suggested that most sex acts against children under 16 were perpetrated by members of their family. In fact relatively small numbers of the young people in the survey had experienced sexual abuse by family members: 1% suffered sexual abuse by a parent or carer and 3% by another relative. One in 10 (mostly girls) had experienced penetrative sex, oral sex or attempts at these against their will by people known to them but unrelated.

In a report from Ho Chi Minh City, page 18, November 20, we said, "...Mr Clinton made his setpiece appearance far from the city centre, at the new freight terminal as the guest of the US shipping company APL: American President Lines." In fact, American President Lines is no longer a US shipping company. It was taken over by Neptune Orient Lines of Singapore in 1997. Now known simply as APL, it is the container shipping arm of NOL, and is run from Singapore by a Dane, Flemming Jacobs.

Contrary to what we said in a caption on page 10 yesterday, the man between Vladimir Putin and Tony Blair, was not the British ambassador to Russia, Sir Roderic Lyne. He was the Foreign and Commonwealth Office's chief Russian language interpreter (KA Bishop). Incidentally, Roderic is spelt without a final k.

In a column (The age of dissent), page 7, G2, November 20, we suggested that reaching the age of 60 was sufficient qualification for a free television licence. It is not. You have to be 75.

Not quite a homophone, from a report, page 25, November 20, "BT, which is expected to formerly announce Brightstar as early as next month..."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday.

webTitle: A chilly Thanksgiving for Bush and Gore

fields.headline: Talking turkey
fields.standfirst:
At Thanksgiving, American families will no doubt echo the presidential wrangles with feuds of their own

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: At Thanksgiving, American families will no doubt echo the presidential wrangles with feuds of their own.
fields.body:
Tomorrow is Thanksgiving in America, a day for families to gather together, carve the turkey, savour the cranberry sauce - and fight.

For this annual feast, older than the republic itself, occupies much the same space in American national life as Christmas does in ours. It's the one time in the year when all work stops, when far-flung relatives hop on trains and planes so they can reunite, sit down and eat - and remember why they all chose to live so far away from each other in the first place.

The routine is familiar enough. The day begins with joy and hugs, but as the afternoon slides into a hazy, overfed evening, the cracks soon appear. Tense barbs are traded between sisters; long-ago resentments revived by brothers. Before too long, doors are slamming, mothers are sobbing and everyone is looking forward to catching the first flight home.

Or at least that's the stereotype, recycled in a hundred home-for-the-holidays movies. With that in mind, spare a thought for Jeb Bush, governor of Florida. His task this year was clear and simple: to deliver the sunshine state for his brother, George W. If he failed, W had joked it would be a "chilly Thanksgiving" around the Bush dinner table.

Since it's not clear if Jeb did the business for his bro or not, expect the atmosphere chez Bush to be pretty strained. The Bush clan will gather tomorrow uncertain if it is celebrating a victory or mourning a defeat, all thanks to the theatre of the absurd currently being played out on Jeb's hometurf. On election night, as the TV networks first claimed Florida for Gore, Jeb reportedly went over to W, hugged him and, with tears in his eyes, blubbed: "I'm really sorry, brother." Expect Dubya to get snippy if Jeb tries that again tomorrow.

The Gore household is bound to be equally tense. Tipper was never too keen on a presidential campaign in the first place, let alone one that went more than a fortnight into extra time. And there may well be sharp exchanges between Al, brother-in-law Frank and daughter, Karenna - both of whom were among the geniuses running the Gore campaign, turning what should have been a victory stroll for the vice president into a photo-finish.

But enough of the lead players, gnawing anxiously at their turkey tomorrow. What of the American people itself; what does their Thanksgiving hold in store?

At first glance, they seem set only to honour the late-afternoon part of the tradition - by getting fractious and bitter with each other. A visit to the Palm Beach County recount centre last week offered a foretaste of the rancour to come. Bush supporters took delight in winding up their opponents, handing out placards that perfectly replicated the Democrats' Gore-Lieberman banners - except now they said Sore-Loserman. The Florida T-shirt and badge industry has been in overdrive, with slogans ranging from the crude ("Hand Count, Hand Job") to the celestial ("God has the last true vote"). Clad in shorts, sneakers and stetsons the Bushies stage a daily stand-off with the Goreites, both shouting in each other's faces, not listening to a word. Last week the only moment of peace came when a protester brought out his acoustic guitar and, 1960s style, urged everyone to "Pray for our nation/That God will heal our land."

Healing does seem to be what's required just now, when polls show the country divided even over whether it's divided. A CBS survey found 46% reckoning the current indecision was hurting the country, with 54% disagreeing. The punditocracy, however, is as one that whoever finally emerges from this thicket of law and partisan bickering, Gore or Bush, will be a hugely tainted figure.

Democrats may be just about able to accept a President W. If all recounted ballots are included and Bush is still the clear winner, Gore would be forced by the logic of his own argument - that the manual counts should be decisive - to accept the result and concede defeat. But nothing in the Bushies' rhetoric allows for a similar climbdown. They have trashed the manual counting process as inherently unfair and corrupt; they have traduced the reputation of most of the officials doing the counting. The Republicans have nowhere to go, no way of bowing out gracefully.

Instead, there would be a fierce legitimacy war for the next four years - as Republicans flatly refused to accept a Gore presidency. The Republican whip in the House has already talked of a move to reject Florida's 25 votes in the electoral college, should they eventually be certified for Gore. Even the usually moderate 1996 Republican nominee, Bob Dole, has suggested a boycott of the January 20 inauguration if their boy, George the Younger, is not on the podium. That would be serious business: inauguration is traditionally the time when America casts a constitutional spell, magically transforming what was once a mere party candidate into the head of state, head of government and leader of the nation. If Republicans boycott the event, the magic won't work.

Add to that a Senate which could be split 50-50 between the two parties and a wafer-thin Republican majority in the House, and you have all the elements of the traditional Thanksgiving formula: a family divided.

For all that, America could also remember the original idea behind tomorrow's festival - and give thanks. Despite everything, there is much to be grateful for. Take the zoo in Palm Beach County. Once you've got past the megaphones and banners, and inside the windowless, reinforced bunker (built for emergency coordination during a natural disaster) you find a picture of civic solemnity so impressive it's almost moving. In hushed silence more akin to an operating theatre, county employees and volunteers sit in groups of four (two counters and two observers from each party) inspecting every single ballot paper. They move cautiously, even reverently, awed by the task that fate has handed them: weighing the votes that could decide the presidency.

Or take a close look at that Florida Supreme Court hearing on Monday. A diverse bench - including two women and two African-Americans - sat in full view of the television cameras, practising open and intelligent justice. Whatever their decision, that session was an advertisement for the US system of constitutional law.

Or ponder the fact that America still does not know the name of its next leader, yet there are no riots on the streets, no tanks, and only 12% tell pollsters the current situation deserves to be labelled a "crisis". Indeed, America's numerical split in votes cast is belied by a deep national contentment about everything else: the indices of optimism and economic confidence have never been higher. "No one's freaking out," says one Gore aide, "people feel just fine."

So Americans gather tomorrow just like any other family: ready for rows and fights over the dinner table, but with equally good reason to mark the day as they were meant to - by giving cautious thanks.

fields.headline: Mods and mockers
fields.standfirst:
Mrs Thatcher was ousted a decade ago, but her influence on my Tory party is still very much in evidence

Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Everyone remembers where they were and what they were doing on November 22. I was at my desk in Conservative Central Office when a note was passed round informing us of the political assassination of the leader of the free world. Such an event seemed unimaginable and the trauma has left a deep and enduring scar.
fields.body:
Everyone remembers where they were and what they were doing on November 22. I was at my desk in Conservative Central Office when a note was passed round informing us of the political assassination of the leader of the free world. Such an event seemed unimaginable and the trauma has left a deep and enduring scar.

The resignation of Margaret Thatcher, on the day of the anniversary of President Kennedy's assassination, took place a decade ago. Despite the passing of time, no one can deny that her legacy continues to shape British politics.

It is a truism that Mrs Thatcher is Tony Blair's chief influence. He has acknowledged it himself in the way that he seeks to lead his party. It is also true, in the week that his government forced through air traffic privatisation, that many of his policies follow her agenda.

The Tory party's relationship with its former mistress remains as complex and subtle as the ebb and flow of tides. In some sort of complicated psychosexual way, the Conservatives still hanker after the smack of firm leadership. A recent survey showed that her photograph still causes greater palpitations than some cruder efforts to stimulate the male MP. And if it was not for the memory of Mrs Thatcher, how else could Ann Widdecombe now be taken seriously as a leader-in-waiting if not because she seems, because of her sex, to be the simplest substitute to help recreate the golden years?

Leaving such whimsies aside, elements of the Tory party are still engaged in a fierce struggle to gain control of the Thatcherite soul. The resignation of Michael Portillo and Francis Maude from the No Turning Back group is the most obvious recent public outbreak of hostilities. Political aficionados will know that the NTB group is a dining club set up in the early 1980s to protect the Thatcher legacy. It draws its name explicitly from her famous "the lady's not for turning" speech.

Over the past few years, it has become a Jacobin rump, toasting the Queen in the Other Place. That Michael Portillo, for so many years the anointed successor to Mrs Thatcher, should choose to leave it now is an event of some significance for the future direction of the Conservative party.

Mr Portillo's public explanation is suitably anodyne. He has resigned because private remarks at an NTB dinner were made public. The real reason is because the split in the Conservative party is no longer left against right, but right against right.

Broadly speaking, it is a dispute between mods and rockers, between those who wish to move the Conservative party forward and those who want to carry on listening to Elvis, a battle to be fought on the beaches of Blackpool and Bournemouth conferences over the next few years.

Much still unites these factions. They are all free-marketeers. They are all Eurosceptics. They are, in one sense, Thatcherites who wish to roll back the frontiers of the state. They have chosen, instead, to found their differences on social policy. Messrs Portillo, Norris and Maude all wish to see a kinder, gentler conservatism. The NTBers see this as a soft and wishy-washy selling-out.

Both, in their own ways, are wrong. Thatcherism was never about society - she said as much herself, though her quotation was taken out of context. Thatcherism was first and foremost about economics and strong government. Her political battles were fought over privatisation and the trade unions. Her interest in social policy was at best minimal. Her home secretaries - Willie Whitelaw and Douglas Hurd - were liberals, and she never whipped a vote on capital punishment.

As far as morality went, she represented solid middle England values - the need to keep up appearances, not rock the boat and to spurn hand-outs from the state. But she was not prurient about people's private lives and tried as far as possible not to judge.

S o the NTBers are wrong to see a kindlier, gentler Portillo as some sort of betrayal of a Thatcherite legacy. Mr Portillo is ploughing a furrow that he deems to be central to the current political zeitgeist, just as Mrs Thatcher did. It happens that under Mrs Thatcher, Britain became a more diverse, free and liberal country and Mr Portillo realises that the Tory party must now reflect this.

All the same, Mrs Thatcher has let it be known that she considers Mr Portillo to be "confused". And this is where Mr Portillo is wrong. The reason that Mrs Thatcher remains such an enduring force in our political mythology is that she had about her an air of absolute clarity, conviction and resoluteness. She was not afraid to be unpopular provided she was effective. The new right of the Tory party has done enough navel gazing. With an election around the corner, it is time to return to conviction politics on issues of real substance.

Like Kennedy, the Thatcher legacy is one of myth and romance. Each side takes from it what it wants. But what remains true is that her dominance continues, if only in a different form.

comment@theguardian.com
fields.bodyText: Everyone remembers where they were and what they were doing on November 22. I was at my desk in Conservative Central Office when a note was passed round informing us of the political assassination of the leader of the free world. Such an event seemed unimaginable and the trauma has left a deep and enduring scar. The resignation of Margaret Thatcher, on the day of the anniversary of President Kennedy's assassination, took place a decade ago. Despite the passing of time, no one can deny that her legacy continues to shape British politics. It is a truism that Mrs Thatcher is Tony Blair's chief influence. He has acknowledged it himself in the way that he seeks to lead his party. It is also true, in the week that his government forced through air traffic privatisation, that many of his policies follow her agenda. The Tory party's relationship with its former mistress remains as complex and subtle as the ebb and flow of tides. In some sort of complicated psychosexual way, the Conservatives still hanker after the smack of firm leadership. A recent survey showed that her photograph still causes greater palpitations than some cruder efforts to stimulate the male MP. And if it was not for the memory of Mrs Thatcher, how else could Ann Widdecombe now be taken seriously as a leader-in-waiting if not because she seems, because of her sex, to be the simplest substitute to help recreate the golden years? Leaving such whimsies aside, elements of the Tory party are still engaged in a fierce struggle to gain control of the Thatcherite soul. The resignation of Michael Portillo and Francis Maude from the No Turning Back group is the most obvious recent public outbreak of hostilities. Political aficionados will know that the NTB group is a dining club set up in the early 1980s to protect the Thatcher legacy. It draws its name explicitly from her famous "the lady's not for turning" speech. Over the past few years, it has become a Jacobin rump, toasting the Queen in the Other Place. That Michael Portillo, for so many years the anointed successor to Mrs Thatcher, should choose to leave it now is an event of some significance for the future direction of the Conservative party. Mr Portillo's public explanation is suitably anodyne. He has resigned because private remarks at an NTB dinner were made public. The real reason is because the split in the Conservative party is no longer left against right, but right against right. Broadly speaking, it is a dispute between mods and rockers, between those who wish to move the Conservative party forward and those who want to carry on listening to Elvis, a battle to be fought on the beaches of Blackpool and Bournemouth conferences over the next few years. Much still unites these factions. They are all free-marketeers. They are all Eurosceptics. They are, in one sense, Thatcherites who wish to roll back the frontiers of the state. They have chosen, instead, to found their differences on social policy. Messrs Portillo, Norris and Maude all wish to see a kinder, gentler conservatism. The NTBers see this as a soft and wishy-washy selling-out. Both, in their own ways, are wrong. Thatcherism was never about society - she said as much herself, though her quotation was taken out of context. Thatcherism was first and foremost about economics and strong government. Her political battles were fought over privatisation and the trade unions. Her interest in social policy was at best minimal. Her home secretaries - Willie Whitelaw and Douglas Hurd - were liberals, and she never whipped a vote on capital punishment. As far as morality went, she represented solid middle England values - the need to keep up appearances, not rock the boat and to spurn hand-outs from the state. But she was not prurient about people's private lives and tried as far as possible not to judge. S o the NTBers are wrong to see a kindlier, gentler Portillo as some sort of betrayal of a Thatcherite legacy. Mr Portillo is ploughing a furrow that he deems to be central to the current political zeitgeist, just as Mrs Thatcher did. It happens that under Mrs Thatcher, Britain became a more diverse, free and liberal country and Mr Portillo realises that the Tory party must now reflect this. All the same, Mrs Thatcher has let it be known that she considers Mr Portillo to be "confused". And this is where Mr Portillo is wrong. The reason that Mrs Thatcher remains such an enduring force in our political mythology is that she had about her an air of absolute clarity, conviction and resoluteness. She was not afraid to be unpopular provided she was effective. The new right of the Tory party has done enough navel gazing. With an election around the corner, it is time to return to conviction politics on issues of real substance. Like Kennedy, the Thatcher legacy is one of myth and romance. Each side takes from it what it wants. But what remains true is that her dominance continues, if only in a different form. Ed Vaizey is a Conservative. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Bank bid rumours put to rest

fields.headline: Bank bid rumours put to rest
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces.
fields.body:
Now we know for sure: Lloyds TSB is not interested in Abbey National . Well, that was the conclusion City traders were arriving at as details of a private briefing seeped into the market yesterday.

On Monday, group finance director Kent Atkinson and some of the other suits from Lloyds popped in to the Broadgate offices of its joint broker ABN Amro for an after hours meeting with its sales force.

While no one was suggesting any price sensitive information had been divulged, those present are said to have left with the distinct impression that Lloyds is not interested in gate-crashing the current talks between Abbey and Bank of Scotland .

The broad thrust of Mr Atkinson's pitch seems to have been roughly as follows: while Lloyds continues to look for deals in the UK, they will not be of the group-transforming variety because of its market position. He made clear that Lloyds was well aware of the regulatory problems of having a 20% to 25% market share in any one banking product.

Dealers took the hint. If Lloyds were to take over Abbey, for example, it would have a 25% market share in mortgages, something that would not sit easily with the regulators. Most expect Lloyds to look towards Europe and a deal in the financial services arena. And sure enough, Mr Atkinson talked to the ABN sales force about financial services distribution in Europe.

Lloyds shares ended the day 19p higher at 722p, on relief it would not be starting a bidding war. Abbey National rose 30p to £10.90 and Bank of Scotland added 1p to 700p.

In the wider market, leading shares endured an erratic session. After Monday's decline the market rallied at opening only to fall into negative territory as jitters set in ahead of the start on Wall Street. News of a record US trade deficit and more problems at telecoms equipment maker Lucent had traders fretting about another sell-off.

But much to everyone surprise Wall Street held its nerve (well it did not move lower) and this allowed London to recoup the morning losses in the last hour. At the close the main FTSE 100 index was ahead 37.1 points at 6,382.1.

However, the mood was far from positive with institutions seeking safety from technology-led volatility by indiscriminately piling into old economy favourites regardless of their fundamentals. For example, BAT moved up 28p to 536p despite news that a US district court judge had taken the first step in certifying a potential multi-million dollar class action lawsuit against tobacco companies.

And then there was Marks & Spencer, a company which is continuing to buy back its shares. It rose 7.25p to 196p. Even Railtrack got in on the act and closed up 45p at 947p.

Scottish & Southern Energy was 25p higher at 635p, Tesco advanced 9.5p to 286p and Sainsbury gained 11.25p to 431.25p despite speculation that today's interim results would be weaker than expected.

The flip side of this rotation was more weakness in technology and telecoms shares. Baltimore lost 12p to 395p and Dimension Data dropped 14p to 540p. The FTSE Techmark 100 finished 19.44 points lower at 3,040.65.

Elsewhere, the FTSE Mid 250 closed 22.9 points weaker at 6,641.2, with biotechnology stocks in particular coming under fire. Cambridge Antibody Technology lost 342.5p to £33 and Oxford Glycosciences eased 125p to £15.

On the upside, Severn Trent added 9p to 800.5p on talk that a foreign predator has been looking at the utility.

In the small cap world, the main talking point was corner shop group Alldays. It shares rose 3.5p, or 20%, to close at 21p on wild speculation that Sainsbury will table a 30p-a-share bid with today's figures.

Computer games group Eidos shed 2p to 207p despite chatter that a 300p-a-share bid is on the way.

fields.headline: At this price? Zetters Group
fields.trailText: Score draws are fast becoming a thing of the past for Zetters Group, the pools company on its way to becoming an online betting and gaming business.
fields.body:
Score draws are fast becoming a thing of the past for Zetters Group, the pools company on its way to becoming an online betting and gaming business.

The job of picking winners has moved into the boardroom where the new management team is looking for new products to offer over the internet.

The reverse takeover of IFX at the beginning of the year gave Zetters an online trading system in need of new financial offerings to tempt punters. The bingo business has been sold and the new team do not hold out much of a long-term future for the pools business.

Chief executive Graham Wellesley said the board decided it would not make sense to try to halt the decline of the pools operation by spending a lot on marketing.

He did not rule out a trade sale of the pools business, which is still profitable, but added that he was not looking for a buyer for the business. But he expected other sport-linked services to be developed and marketed under the Zetters name.

The first new service using the IFX online platform, contracts for difference trading - or spread betting for shares - is due to start on December 1. Others, including conventional spread betting, are due to follow and the company is considering acquiring an online casino.

The Zetters board is planning to acquire companies with appropriate products for the IFX system. But they have ruled out using Zetters shares to fund such deals.

The group would rather raise money from shareholders for acquisitions than issue shares or borrow. It also has £14.5m in cash.

The interim results, published yesterday, had the air of an away defeat. It lost £1.02m before tax during the half year, compared with a £1.47m profit for the comparable period last year.

Zetters shares have tumbled since the euphoria of the IFX deal in January. Down 2p to 153p yesterday, they still look a risky bet.

webTitle: Ups and downs of Iron Lady's favourites

fields.headline: Ups and downs of Iron Lady's favourites
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Throughout her years at No 10, Mrs Thatcher had a substantial fan club of businessmen. But some were specially close to the Iron Lady, a small band of industrialists who were regularly referred to as "Mrs Thatcher's favourite businessmen".
fields.body:
Throughout her years at No 10, Mrs Thatcher had a substantial fan club of businessmen. But some were specially close to the Iron Lady, a small band of industrialists who were regularly referred to as "Mrs Thatcher's favourite businessmen".

Lord Sterling, then and now chairman of P&O, was a central figure in one of the Thatcher era's great union struggles when he used strike-breaking ferry crews to break a blockade of the Channel ports.

Lord Sterling's hand is still firmly on the tiller at P&O, despite criticism for staying on beyond the company's normal retirement age. Last month the company split into shipping and cruise line companies, with Lord Sterling in the top job at both. He recently advised Tony Blair on how to prevent a repeat of the recent fuel crisis.

Lord Hanson, with Lord White, built Hanson Trust into a transatlantic conglomerate, only to split it into four when conglomerates went out of fashion. He retired in 1997 and is now best known as a strident anti-euro campaigner, but still has an eye for a deal. Yesterday, with Lucas White, the son of his late partner, and cancer specialist David Skeggs, he invested £200,000 in Mediwatch, an AIM-listed company developing a prostate cancer test.

Mrs Thatcher was proud of British Airways after John King - later Lord King - transformed it from a nationalised loss-maker into a business he dubbed the world's favourite airline. Three years after Mrs Thatcher was forced out of office Lord King was ejected from the top job at BA following the "dirty tricks" scandal. He remains BA president emeritus and interests include directorships at the Daily Telegraph, Spectator, headhunter Norman Broadbent and engineer Short Brothers.

David Young - later Lord Young of Graffham - came to prominence as chairman of the manpower services commission. "Others bring me problems", said Mrs Thatcher, "David brings me solutions." By 1990 he had moved back into business as chairman of Cable & Wireless, a Thatcher privatisation with which Lord Young had been closely connected at the DTI. Five years on, a boardroom rift claimed his scalp. In 1996 he set up Young Associates with two partners to back hi-tech start-ups.

webTitle: 10 years after Thatcher: Philip Fletcher on water privatisation

fields.headline: No bare-knuckle fight, just watchdogs wagging their tails
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: The Thatcherite revolution of privatising state-owned utilities has been an unqualified success, says Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator.
fields.body:
The Thatcherite revolution of privatising state-owned utilities has been an unqualified success, says Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator.

He told a London conference last week that £50bn would have been invested by 2005 in improving drinking water and protecting the environment; leakage rates had been cut by a third and this year for the first time customers are enjoying the benefits of efficiency gains in the form of an average 12% cut in bills.

"There was nothing to suggest from the industry's pre-privatisation performance that public sector ownership would have delivered these benefits," he said. "Equally, we have no proof that private monopolies - left alone - would have delivered them either."

Tomorrow, Callum McCarthy, the energy market watchdog, will be similarly ecstatic about deregulation and privatisation. Nearly 6m gas and well over 5m electricity customers (29% of 20m and 20% of 25m respectively) who have switched suppliers have seen their bills cut by £1bn a year since Ofgem, the body he heads, began introducing competition more than three years ago.

A further £1bn off bills has come from price controls on electricity distribution companies.

Margaret Thatcher's "bare-knuckled fight" with industry never emerged; instead, regulators took a tough stand with the privatised companies.

"We spend more time focusing on our relations with the regulator than going out there and beating the world," says Brian Duckworth, managing director of Severn Trent.

What has happened is a fundamental shift in the focus of the privatised companies' activities from promoting the interests of shareholders and the companies themselves to ensuring competition and guaranteeing consumers fair - that is lower - prices.

In the early days of privatisation the Thatcherites' main concern was to create an army of "Sids", spreading the benefits of a shareholding democracy rather than promoting consumers, and reducing the utilities' demands on the public purse. The "public interest" was already served under this model in their view but regulators were appointed to act as what Peter Vass, director of Bath University's centre for the study of the regulated industries, calls "surrogates for competition". They did so in the form of price controls. Profits and shareholder returns flourished.

All that has changed. BT, which still retained a 93% market share in 1993, is now under siege even though it retains 80% of all domestic phone calls. The duopoly in power generation - National Power and Powergen - has been eroded through competition and the seven producers, many foreign-owned, have seen their margins squashed by price controls.

Water companies, squeezed by the regulators and shunned by the market, have toyed with the idea of returning ownership to customers; recently Glas Cymru proposed to make Welsh Water a debt-financed company answerable to its "members" rather than shareholders.

When a partner at law firm Denton Hall remarked that regulators had far more power than ministers ever had, few paid attention. His name? Tom Winsor. His new job? Rail regulator.

webTitle: 10 years after Thatcher: privatisation has become common currency

fields.headline: A whole world sold on sell-offs
fields.standfirst:
Ten years after the fall of its great exponent, privatisation has become the common currency of political parties

Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText: Ten years after the fall of its great exponent, privatisation has become the common currency of political parties.
fields.body:
Love her or loathe her, Margaret Thatcher changed the industrial landscape of Britain. It is 10 years to the day since she was ousted in a palace coup. But the main legacy of her time in Downing Street lives on, not just in Britain but across the world.

The shorthand version of the Thatcher years, as retold in the Iron Lady's memoirs, and on the after-dinner circuit - where she earns an estimated £1.5m a year - is that Britain was changed from the land of Red Robbo and wildcat strikes to the land of "Sid" and the share-owning democracy. In one stroke, the dead hand of the state was removed from the economy, unleashing a new spirit of enterprise and derring do.

But memoirs, like memory, can play tricks. By the time the usually steely-eyed Lady Thatcher made her tearful departure in November 1990, one in four of the population owned shares and more than 40 former state-owned businesses had been privatised, a process which affected more than 600,000 workers in former nationalised industries.

Privatisation was, however, no overnight revolution; rather it was a slow-burn process that only really began in Mrs Thatcher's second term. In fact Jim Callahan sold a chunk of BP in the 1970s to to keep the International Monetary Fund happy. What is more, the record of some companies that were denationalised looks different today from the late 80s, when tycoons like Lord King at British Airways were members of the prime minister's inner court.

Mad dash for shares

The truth is that privatisation hardly featured at all between 1979 and 1983, when Mrs Thatcher was preoccupied by three struggles - the fight against inflation, the fight against the unions and the fight against the Argentines. Even during the second term, from 1983 to 1987 - easily the most radical of the four successive Conservative terms in office - there was no real conception of how a scheme to make money for the Treasury could be used as a weapon to win votes.

It was only after the mad dash for shares in British Telecom in 1984 that the penny dropped in Downing Street. Privatisation was not just about ownership and industrial organisation, it was also about politics. As such, the BT sell off was followed by the privatisation of British Gas in 1986 and of Rolls-Royce, British Airways and the British Airports Authority in 1987.

Apart from the unions and the Labour party, everybody seemed happy. The government had extra cash to spend on tax cuts, voters had shares which were going up in value and those running the companies had freedom to act and much fat ter pay packets. But how much has really changed? To be sure, many of those working in the old nationalised industries have lost their jobs as the newly cost-conscious companies responded to shareholder demands to boost productivity and profits. But BT is still seen as flabby and staid, BA is struggling to compete in the global airlines business, and Railtrack - a company sold off long after Mrs Thatcher was ousted - is dogged by controversy about whether privatisation is to blame for the state of the nation's railways. The tough regulation to prevent the privatised utilities exploiting their natural monopolies has made some of them hanker after giving up their PLC status.

In her memoirs, the former prime minister evocatively described the sale of state assets as essential to "eroding the corro sive and corrupting effects of socialism". Yet five years after she left office, a star was created out of a 30-stone pink and black pig named Cedric, who was to come to symbolise corporate excess with its snout buried in the "trough of privatisation". Ironically, though, the level of pay being protested about then - a 75% rise for chief executive Cedric Brown, to £475,000 and potential performance-related bonus of £594,000 - would now barely cause even a raised eyebrow.

Unsurprisingly, Lady Thatcher and her teams of politicial and financial advisers prefer not to dwell on the boardroom self-enrichment that followed privatisation, arguing instead that there were beneficial effects for the wider economy.

Tony Carlisle, a City public relations adviser involved in 90% of the privatisations, acknowledges: "One of the key accusations of privatisations is that it works for the bosses and the shareholders, but ... pity about the poor consumer."

But he argues that privatisation actually served the consumer well. Through deregulation and increased competition, there is more choice about which company gas, electricity and telephone services can be bought.

Without privatisation, companies such as Vodafone and Energis might never have been created. A senior corporate finance executive closely involved in the privatisation says: "You may argue about the pricing, the public policy and the structure of the deals but if it had not been done you would not have the competition we now see across all industries".

The more cynical take the view that privatisation demonstrated that being British was not best. One highly regarded City analyst says: "In general, companies with British in their names haven't done very well. Being British quickly became too parochial."

Words such as "globalisation" have quickly eclipsed "privatisation" in the City's lexicon of catchphrases. The big, national monopolies that were privatised increasingly drew their customers outside national boundaries.

"British" is now eradicated from British Steel, after merging with Hoogovens of Holland to form Corus; from British Gas, now three separate companies, only one of which refers to itself as BG. British Petroleum has long been BP and now BP Amoco after its multi-billion dollar takeover of the US company.

Another frequent criticism is that the companies were sold off too cheaply. Another City analyst warns this can be a too simple conclusion drawn from the way in which many of the share sales were overscribed. Not all the share sales were successful. BP, for instance, hit the market in the midst of a stock market crash, leaving many banks licking their wounds.

Tell Sid

Yet, an analysis of the companies which were privatised during the Thatcher years shows that the privatisation portfolio, constructed for the Guardian by investment bank ING Barings, outperformed the benchmark FTSE 100 for most of the period. An indication that investors were sold the companies too cheaply, or a reflection of sound management which outpaced the rest of the industry?

To one City analyst it is almost irrelevant whether the privatisation portfolio outperformed the market. "The 'Tell Sid' campaign sticks in people's minds. It made people more aware that the equity market could be a form of saving for the future just as it became the state could no longer provide for old age," the analyst said.

Tony Alt, a corporate financier at investment Rothschild who was involved in many of the major privatisations, regards the most important legacy as creating "a platform for privatisations around the globe".

More than £400bn of assets have now been privatised in countries as diverse as the Czech republic and New Zealand, and a word which gained currency during Lady Thatcher's government is now internationally recognised.

But the real political impact of privatisation has not been in Prague or Wellington but in London. In 1983 when he first became an MP, Tony Blair fought on a Labour manifesto committed to an extension of state ownership. The strength of Mrs Thatcher's enduring legacy is that Labour has not only turned its back on nationalisation, but now has privatisation plans of its own.
