fields.bodyText: Love her or loathe her, Margaret Thatcher changed the industrial landscape of Britain. It is 10 years to the day since she was ousted in a palace coup. But the main legacy of her time in Downing Street lives on, not just in Britain but across the world. The shorthand version of the Thatcher years, as retold in the Iron Lady's memoirs, and on the after-dinner circuit - where she earns an estimated £1.5m a year - is that Britain was changed from the land of Red Robbo and wildcat strikes to the land of "Sid" and the share-owning democracy. In one stroke, the dead hand of the state was removed from the economy, unleashing a new spirit of enterprise and derring do. But memoirs, like memory, can play tricks. By the time the usually steely-eyed Lady Thatcher made her tearful departure in November 1990, one in four of the population owned shares and more than 40 former state-owned businesses had been privatised, a process which affected more than 600,000 workers in former nationalised industries. Privatisation was, however, no overnight revolution; rather it was a slow-burn process that only really began in Mrs Thatcher's second term. In fact Jim Callahan sold a chunk of BP in the 1970s to to keep the International Monetary Fund happy. What is more, the record of some companies that were denationalised looks different today from the late 80s, when tycoons like Lord King at British Airways were members of the prime minister's inner court. Mad dash for shares The truth is that privatisation hardly featured at all between 1979 and 1983, when Mrs Thatcher was preoccupied by three struggles - the fight against inflation, the fight against the unions and the fight against the Argentines. Even during the second term, from 1983 to 1987 - easily the most radical of the four successive Conservative terms in office - there was no real conception of how a scheme to make money for the Treasury could be used as a weapon to win votes. It was only after the mad dash for shares in British Telecom in 1984 that the penny dropped in Downing Street. Privatisation was not just about ownership and industrial organisation, it was also about politics. As such, the BT sell off was followed by the privatisation of British Gas in 1986 and of Rolls-Royce, British Airways and the British Airports Authority in 1987. Apart from the unions and the Labour party, everybody seemed happy. The government had extra cash to spend on tax cuts, voters had shares which were going up in value and those running the companies had freedom to act and much fat ter pay packets. But how much has really changed? To be sure, many of those working in the old nationalised industries have lost their jobs as the newly cost-conscious companies responded to shareholder demands to boost productivity and profits. But BT is still seen as flabby and staid, BA is struggling to compete in the global airlines business, and Railtrack - a company sold off long after Mrs Thatcher was ousted - is dogged by controversy about whether privatisation is to blame for the state of the nation's railways. The tough regulation to prevent the privatised utilities exploiting their natural monopolies has made some of them hanker after giving up their PLC status. In her memoirs, the former prime minister evocatively described the sale of state assets as essential to "eroding the corro sive and corrupting effects of socialism". Yet five years after she left office, a star was created out of a 30-stone pink and black pig named Cedric, who was to come to symbolise corporate excess with its snout buried in the "trough of privatisation". Ironically, though, the level of pay being protested about then - a 75% rise for chief executive Cedric Brown, to £475,000 and potential performance-related bonus of £594,000 - would now barely cause even a raised eyebrow. Unsurprisingly, Lady Thatcher and her teams of politicial and financial advisers prefer not to dwell on the boardroom self-enrichment that followed privatisation, arguing instead that there were beneficial effects for the wider economy. Tony Carlisle, a City public relations adviser involved in 90% of the privatisations, acknowledges: "One of the key accusations of privatisations is that it works for the bosses and the shareholders, but ... pity about the poor consumer." But he argues that privatisation actually served the consumer well. Through deregulation and increased competition, there is more choice about which company gas, electricity and telephone services can be bought. Without privatisation, companies such as Vodafone and Energis might never have been created. A senior corporate finance executive closely involved in the privatisation says: "You may argue about the pricing, the public policy and the structure of the deals but if it had not been done you would not have the competition we now see across all industries". The more cynical take the view that privatisation demonstrated that being British was not best. One highly regarded City analyst says: "In general, companies with British in their names haven't done very well. Being British quickly became too parochial." Words such as "globalisation" have quickly eclipsed "privatisation" in the City's lexicon of catchphrases. The big, national monopolies that were privatised increasingly drew their customers outside national boundaries. "British" is now eradicated from British Steel, after merging with Hoogovens of Holland to form Corus; from British Gas, now three separate companies, only one of which refers to itself as BG. British Petroleum has long been BP and now BP Amoco after its multi-billion dollar takeover of the US company. Another frequent criticism is that the companies were sold off too cheaply. Another City analyst warns this can be a too simple conclusion drawn from the way in which many of the share sales were overscribed. Not all the share sales were successful. BP, for instance, hit the market in the midst of a stock market crash, leaving many banks licking their wounds. fields.headline: Sugar counts £5m cost
fields.standfirst: Mobile phone relaunch delay means Amstrad misses Christmas market
fields.trailText: Mobile phone relaunch delay means Amstrad misses Christmas market.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar's electronics company Amstrad yesterday revealed that its attempt to take on the world's biggest mobile phone makers has stalled, due to difficulties in developing a new lightweight handset.

The firm was planning to re-enter the mobile phones market next month, following a three-year absence in which it has concentrated on computer accessories, satellite equipment and television set-top boxes.

However, a hold-up in negotiations with network operators has pushed back the launch of its phones to the first quarter of next year, missing the crucial Christmas period.

The news sent Amstrad's shares tumbling 20.5p to 133p, cutting the value of Sir Alan's 29% stake by £5m to £30m.

Finance director Martin Bland admitted that the company's initial timetable had been "a misjudgment, with the benefit of hindsight". He said: "You've got to take a view on these things initially, but life throws up a few surprises along the way."

Mr Bland insisted the setback was "a timing issue, as opposed to a setback in absolute terms".

However, analysts said it would leave a glaring gap in the company's earnings. House broker Howard Brooks of Beeson Gregory slashed his profit forecast for the year to June 2001 from £7.5m to £3.1m and reduced his estimate for the year to 2002 from £11.5m to £9.5m.

Mr Brooks described the timing of the delay as an "absolute worst case scenario". He said: "Missing the Christmas quarter is a big hit - it's a crucal period for consumer electronics."

Once the talisman of Britain's electronics industry, Amstrad has faced difficulties in recent years. A planned merger with the handheld computers firm Psion failed in 1996 and a year later, Sir Alan spun off computer maker Viglen, leaving Amstrad focused on consumer electronics.

The company has been supplying set-top boxes to satellite broadcaster BSkyB but demand is expected to slow in the months ahead, as the rate of new subscribers settles down. Mobile phones were expected to arrive just in time to fill the earnings gap.

Amstrad is producing its handsets in China, and hopes to snatch a significant slice of the mobile market by undercutting established players such as Nokia and Ericsson.

Mr Bland said: "The key attraction to network operators will be the low cost of the phones. The plans are in place, and working samples are ready - it's just that the whole process of getting something to the final production stage takes time."

Amstrad's shares have been under pressure in recent months because the industry has been unconvinced of the attractions of another venture - the firm's "emailers". These are telephones which can send emails, and Sir Alan predicted that that the company would sell more than 1m at the time of launch in March.

Amstrad yesterday insisted its emailers were on track - the company said that by the end of November, it expected to have sold 100,000 units to retailers.

Mr Bland said: "The emailers weren't initially understood correctly by people but we're now getting the message across."

The company said it planned an advertising blitz for the emailer both on television and in the press, "to stimulate sales" in the run-up to the all important Christmas period.

It also plans a new voice services function for the machine, to allow users to contact service providers directly. Amstrad said it would receive income from every call made.

webTitle: EMI takes £43m hit for failed merger

fields.headline: EMI takes £43m hit for failed merger
fields.standfirst: Advisers overseeing talks with Warner were 'stunningly effective'
fields.trailText: Advisers overseeing talks with Warner were 'stunningly effective'.
fields.body:
EMI's failed attempt to merge its music business with America's Warner Music cost the company £42.9m in advisers' fees, with law firm Freshfields snapping up the lion's share.

That pushed the group into the red during the first half, with a pre-tax loss of £9.7m.

EMI abandoned the deal last month when it became clear that the European commission was preparing to block it. The firm is discussing a tie-up with German rival Bertelsmann. EMI chairman Eric Nicoli yesterday said talks were proving "very friendly and constructive".

He insisted he had no regrets about the costs: "If we had succeeded, the fees would have been fantastic value for money. Because we didn't, they clearly weren't.

"Our advisers were stunningly effective and efficient. It wasn't their fault that the deal didn't happen."

Thousands of lawyers, bankers, lobbyists and stockbrokers worked on the Warner transaction, which involved providing more than 1m documents to the competition authorities in Europe and the US.

At one point, regulators asked for details of every transaction between EMI and retailers over the past four years, and each individual e-mail sent from the company's head office.

Mr Nicoli said "rigorous and cautious" were the keywords in negotiations with Bertelsmann. Analysts say a deal would give EMI greater firepower in developing online music ventures, and yield up to £200m annual savings in administration.

Excluding exceptional items, EMI's operating profits fell 6.9% to £111m, as earnings from new-media activities slipped from £23.9m to £6.1m. Mr Nicoli said profits from e-commerce ventures were notoriously "lumpy". A year ago, the company benefited from selling its stake in musicmaker.com, an online CD compilation service.

Profits from retail sales of recorded music rose 6.4%, with Robbie Williams' Sing When You're Winning providing EMI's biggest hit of the year. Director Ken Berry said he was also pleased with Radiohead's Kid A: "Radiohead's album was fabulous, it was a work of art. It's doing very well in the US, considering it's not the most radio-friendly track in the world."

webTitle: Ben & Jerry turn icy about Unilever

fields.headline: Ben & Jerry turn icy about Unilever
fields.trailText: Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, the two friends behind Ben & Jerry's ice-cream, are threatening to leave the company seven months after its controversial takeover by Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group.
fields.body:
Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, the two friends behind Ben & Jerry's ice-cream, are threatening to leave the company seven months after its controversial takeover by Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group.

The pair, who were kept on as senior advisers after they sold in April, are furious at Unilever's decision to choose one of its longstanding managers to head the business they founded in 1978.

In a tersely worded statement released after Yves Couette was confirmed as the new chief executive, the company founders indicated the decision had gone against their wishes.

"As owner, Unilever of course has the legal right to manage Ben & Jerry's in the way it sees fit. We have not decided whether or not to remain with the company."

Although the statement did not name their preferred candidate, he is understood to be Pierre Ferrari, a member of the Ben & Jerry's board with a professed commitment to social responsibility.

Steve Milton, a Unilever spokesman in New York, said that Mr Couette, who has been with Unilever for 24 years, had been chosen because of his experience in running a company. "Once Yves gets there, they will realise he is a very cool guy."

In their statement the founders said that while Mr Couette "seems like a very nice man, we strongly supported a different candidate".

After receiving about $49m for their stake in the company in April, the two are understood to have received no further incentive to stay with the company. Mr Cohen, who was more in favour of the merger than his partner, agreed to stay on as a board member to ensure that the Ben & Jerry's "social mission" continued.

Unilever is keen to keep the two men, not least for their iconic value. Antony Burgmans, Unilever vice chairman, is understood to have written to Mr Cohen last week to underline the company's commitment to maintaining his social values.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: BMW gives Rolls lowdown
fields.body:
BMW gives Rolls lowdown

BMW said yesterday it was ready to submit a planning application to build the world's most "exclusive" motor plant underground near Goodwood racecourse, west Sussex.

The £60m plan to build a new generation of Rolls-Royce cars will create 350 jobs. BMW, which has acquired rights to the Rolls-Royce name, said the site will be extensively landscaped and screened. Output should average 1,000 cars a year after 2003.

BA to boost India service

British Airways aims to increase its flights to India from the current 19 a week to meet rising demand. "This country represents a tremendous market for our business," said Dale Moss, worldwide sales director.

Mr Moss said BA would be open to taking equity in a consortium set up by Ispat International chairman Lakshmi Mittal and financial house Kotak Mahindra to bid for a 26% stake in Air India.

Coffee bar boom brewing

Coffee Republic's results yesterday showed Britain's caffeine addiction increasing. The chain, which has 75 coffee bars in the UK, said turnover was up 100% in the last half-year at £9.7m, and it had trimmed losses by 15%.

Chief executive Bobby Hashemi said the UK market for coffee bars was forecast to triple. Pre-tax losses fell to £1.3m from £1.5m.

Oftel directory inquiry

Telecoms regulator Oftel will consult consumers to find out whether there is a demand for competition in directory inquiry services.

Three choices have been signalled: retention of the traditional 192 for directory services with the addition of numbers in the form 118xx for individual service providers; replacing 192 with 11800 number, other operators receiving a 118xx number; and removing 192 in favour of individual 118xx numbers for all.

Hyundai tries to sell LG plant

Hyundai, the Korean conglomerate, is in renewed talks to sell its mothballed semiconductor plant in Newport, south Wales, under an £800m plan to save the group from bankruptcy.

The firm, which sold a similar mothballed plant in Dunfermline to Motorola, acquired the Newport factory when it took over LG Semicon three years ago.

fields.headline: Computer glitches
fields.trailText: It has been a sour start to the millennium for Sir Alan Sugar, the East End tailor's son who was once credited with bringing home computers to the masses.
fields.body:
It has been a sour start to the millennium for Sir Alan Sugar, the East End tailor's son who was once credited with bringing home computers to the masses.

All of the public companies he chairs - Amstrad, Viglen and Tottenham Hotspur - have fallen out of favour in the City. His shares in the three were worth £180m at the beginning of 2000 but are now valued at £100m.

The most serious problem has been Amstrad which, leaving aside yesterday's profits warning, has failed to convince the electronics industry of the virtues of its "emailer", online telephone. Shares in the company have fallen 45%.

More worrying for Sir Alan's wallet has been computer manufacturer Viglen, where he owns a 72% stake. The company is trying to reposition itself as a provider of high-margin IT equipment for schools and universities, but the transformation has failed to excite investors. Its market value has shrunk from £137m to £60m.Viglen attracted unwelcome publicity when unwittingly caught up in a share-tipping scandal at the Mirror.

There has been little respite for Sir Alan at White Hart Lane, where Tottenham fans have been baying for the blood of manager George Graham. Sunday Sport millionaire David Sullivan has snapped up a small stake and is tipped to be seeking a new challenge.

About the only bright spot in the year for Sir Alan, who began his career selling car aerials, was a trip to Buckingham Palace in June to receive a knighthood from the Queen.

webTitle: Grid unfazed as it cools Energis sale

fields.headline: Grid unfazed as it cools Energis sale
fields.trailText: The downturn in stock market confidence in technology companies has forced the National Grid to put the sale of further shares in its telecoms spin-off Energis on to the back burner, it admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
The downturn in stock market confidence in technology companies has forced the National Grid to put the sale of further shares in its telecoms spin-off Energis on to the back burner, it admitted yesterday.

But chief executive David Jones said the company did not need to raise cash immediately to fund its US acquisitions. He said its takeover of US east coast utility Niagara Mohawk was already underwritten and was not dependent on offloading the 34.6% stake in Energis, which is worth nearly £3bn.

Mr Jones said the company was still looking for an exit from Energis but this was less likely to come as early as it had looked 12 months ago. "We are under no pressure to act quickly," he added, pointing out there were tax advantages to delaying any sale till next year. But he admitted the company planned further purchases of electricity companies in America within the next 12 months which would require it to raise more money.

National Grid's gearing reached 115% by September, the halfway stage of the financial year stage, leaving interest cover at 4.7 times.

New businesses in the US were performing more strongly than expected with return on investment up from 8.3% to 9.3% by the half-year stage. The group was fast approaching its goal of 10.5% originally pencilled in for 2003 to 2004.

Success in the US and a more stable regulatory environment in Britain for its core electricity transmission business has encouraged National Grid to set a target of raising its dividend 5% each year from 2001 for a further five years.

Yesterday it announced a 6.05p-per-share interim dividend on the back of profits on ordinary activities before tax of £310.5m, up from £248.2m last time. Group turnover from continuing operations rose from £741.7m to £1.8bn. National Grid, which admitted spending £100m more than it expected on establishing its Intelig telecoms joint venture in Brazil, says it could also make two new telecoms acquisitions within 12 months.

Shares ended the day up 8p at 646p.

"We are under no pressure to act quickly," he added, pointing out there were tax advantages to delaying any sale till next year. But he admitted the company planned further purchases of electricity companies in America within the next 12 months which would require it to raise more money. National Grid's gearing reached 115% by September, the halfway stage of the financial year stage, leaving interest cover at 4.7 times. New businesses in the US were performing more strongly than expected with return on investment up from 8.3% to 9.3% by the half-year stage. The group was fast approaching its goal of 10.5% originally pencilled in for 2003 to 2004. Success in the US and a more stable regulatory environment in Britain for its core electricity transmission business has encouraged National Grid to set a target of raising its dividend 5% each year from 2001 for a further five years. Yesterday it announced a 6.05p-per-share interim dividend on the back of profits on ordinary activities before tax of £310.5m, up from £248.2m last time. Group turnover from continuing operations rose from £741.7m to £1.8bn. National Grid, which admitted spending £100m more than it expected on establishing its Intelig telecoms joint venture in Brazil, says it could also make two new telecoms acquisitions within 12 months. Shares ended the day up 8p at 646p.

fields.headline: Co-pilot role for Airtours chief
fields.standfirst: Crossland pledges to turn round losses
fields.trailText: David Crossland, guiding light for 30 years at the UK's second largest tour operator Airtours, agreed yesterday to take a back seat role after a grim year that saw annual profits slump by 23%.
fields.body:
David Crossland, guiding light for 30 years at the UK's second largest tour operator Airtours, agreed yesterday to take a back seat role after a grim year that saw annual profits slump by 23%.

Crossland will remain chairman but has handed over day-to-day operations as chief executive to his former managing director Tim Byrne with immediate effect.

The City remained sceptical that Crossland was relinquishing real power in the company and questioned management's ability to produce a speedy turnaround of its loss-making business in Germany.

Airtours shares, which have already lost 42% of their value this year, fell a further 14p to 223p. Takeover talk has always been diminished by Crossland owning 10% of the shares and Carnival Corp owning 25%.

Profits before tax and exceptional items came in at £101.3m, down from £131.5m. But analysts said the latest figures were flattered by one-off gains.

Airtours was hard hit by a number of problems, particularly continuing losses at Frosch Touristic in Germany which was bought earlier this year. Frosch suffered heavy competition combined with high overheads, and management there has been replaced.

Mr Byrne said: "Anything that could have been done wrong was being done wrong." A new German chief executive has been appointed but his name was not given yesterday "for contractual reasons".

There were difficulties also at its North American Leisure Group where a £16.1m profit was turned into a £16.1m deficit over the 12 months to September 30. Airtours blamed a very bad millennium period for much of the losses saying the high price of holidays over that period encouraged many to stay at home. A range of changes had been put in place to cut costs with 150 of the 600 jobs being axed and a new boss being put in place.

Mr Byrne admitted that costs had been too high across the group but he said this was being put right by a massive restructuring, which involved closing down a range of operations in Belgium, France and Holland.

In Britain 600 jobs are to be lost at Woking in Surrey and others could go in Huddersfield in Yorkshire as Airtours relocates all its backroom operations to Rochdale in Lancashire.

Mr Crossland said: "I am confident that the strategic plans and actions initiated during the last 12 months, together with the strong forward booking growth, means Airtours is well placed to resume its profitable growth."

Group bookings for this winter are up by 5% and summer 2001 by 4% year on year. In Britain the rises are 13% and 8% respectively.

Analysts remained cautious. Julian Easthope at UBS Warburg said: "These results were in line with expectations, but the jury is still out on whether Airtours can turn around its German operations."

The company's shares have been in trouble since the summer after a plunge in third quarter profits followed by a profit warning in September.

webTitle: Intec plans to take over one of its US suppliers

fields.headline: Intec plans to take over one of its US suppliers
fields.trailText: British-based phone billing and settlement software provider, Intec, yesterday unveiled plans to raise £180m in order to buy one of its US suppliers, Computer Generation.
fields.body:
British-based phone billing and settlement software provider, Intec, yesterday unveiled plans to raise £180m in order to buy one of its US suppliers, Computer Generation.

Despite the market's recent frosty attitude towards the telecom sector, Intec plans to raise cash for the acquisition through an open offer of 30m new shares.

Chief executive Kevin Adams said: "It will double our revenue and triple our profits; it is a consolidation of complimentary services and a huge global expansion - all for around 20% of our market capitalisation."

The offer has been underwritten by Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. New shares will be priced at 600p - a 17% discount on the 722.5p at which shares were suspended this month when Intec announced it was in acquisition talks.

Subject to shareholder approval next month, Intec will pay $245m (£172.3m) for CompGen, which extracts and collates raw data from different telecom networks.

Intec announced full year pre-tax profits of £3.8m on revenues of £20.3m. In 1999 the company made £556,000 on revenue of £8.4m. Mr Adams said Intec now held 35% of the global market share of interconnecting billing solutions.

fields.headline: Holiday firm stuck in the mud
fields.standfirst: Notebook: results ground former high flier
fields.trailText: It seemed fitting that an Airtours-chartered jet yesterday found itself stuck in the mud at Manchester airport. If ever a formerly high-flying tour operator had found itself grounded it was the firm that David Crossland has piloted for 30 years and brought to the stock market in a blaze of hope back in 1987.
fields.body:
It seemed fitting that an Airtours-chartered jet yesterday found itself stuck in the mud at Manchester airport. If ever a formerly high-flying tour operator had found itself grounded it was the firm that David Crossland has piloted for 30 years and brought to the stock market in a blaze of hope back in 1987.

The financial figures for the 12 months to September released yesterday were as clear as Manchester mud. But peeping out were indications that Airtours had not filled itself with glory.

Group profit before tax, e-commerce, non-recurring items and goodwill amortisation had fallen to £101.3m from £131.5m. But easier to understand was a fall in the diluted earnings per share before exceptional items amounting to 10.69p - or about half of the figure for the previous year. Bloomberg estimated real profits were down 70%.

Germany is highlighted as the major problem area but there are dismal performances dotted around the group, which has forced Airtours to cut back operations from north America to Britain and around continental Europe.

Restructuring is under way but those at the top seem immune from the pain that is being inflicted on those at the bottom who are losing their jobs.

Mr Crossland is said to be handing over the day to day controls but few believe this is much more than a cosmetic affair. He is remaining executive chairman, has 10% of the shares and a lifelong involvement with the company - suggesting he will be unable to simply sit back and contemplate strategy.

And the new chief executive Tim Byrne can hardly been termed new blood given he presided over much of the current turmoil as managing director and finance director before that.

If it was not for the dominant shareholder structure with US group Carnival, fund manager Schroder and Mr Crossland holding 48% between them this would be a prime target for takeover.

Airtours did not deny that it had been in talks with various parties but weekend speculation of a £4 per share offer on its way is surely wishful thinking for a company worth almost half this amount last night.

Even ABN Amro, a long-time supporter of the company, yesterday turned cool on Airtours, leaving a pick-up in winter bookings at Airtours as the only good news.

Oh, but there were some winners yes terday. Airtours raised the dividend 9% to 7.2p - giving Mr Crossland a nice little windfall of some £3.5m.

A celebration

Scottish & Newcastle's genial boss Brian Stewart can finally raise a glass of single malt tonight to the sale of Center Parcs - a business which the company has been battling to offload for months.

The disposal puts an end to an 11-year struggle in which S&N has valiantly tried, but ultimately failed, to persuade Britons that a giant plastic bubble can make Suffolk as balmy as Cyprus.

Now he can concentrate on his strategy to focus purely on brewing and pubs - and hopefully put a bit of fizz back into the shares. They have slumped from 932p less than three years ago to 501p last night and the company has been turfed out of the FTSE 100 in the slide. But in an industry undergoing rapid change, S&N's position looks questionable.

In the years ahead, S&N's biggest competitor is likely to be Interbrew - assuming the Belgian group's purchase of the brewing arms of Whitbread and Bass are given the go-ahead.

Interbrew will push S&N into an unaccustomed second position in the beer market and in terms of the all-important big-volume brands which Mr Stewart has poured so much energy into building, the Edinburgh-based firm is lagging behind. Its Foster's, John Smith's and McEwan's portfolio is second rate compared to Interbrew's Carling, Stella Artois and Tennants.

In an attempt to shore up its position, S&N snapped up the French producer of Kronenbourg earlier this year. However, at £1.7bn, most analysts feel the asking price was too high - it valued the business at 12 times earnings, which is heady for the low-growth beer sector. Elsewhere, S&N's portfolio of 2,600 pubs contains many of the tower-block tavern-type boozers which have wilted in recent years. The firm has few of the trendy high street bar chains which are dominating the sector and although S&N has made it clear it wants to sell the weaker end of its estate, it has been slow off the mark. Whitbread and Bass are already looking for pub buyers and with an estimated 12% of Britain's licensed houses on the market, prices will be as flat as a pint of London bitter.

Mr Stewart has a long-term ambition to move into the US market. But having finally closed the door on the traumas of Dutch holiday camps, he must first turn his full attention back to beer.

And he needs to work hard - the company is developing an unfortunate habit of missing City forecasts and first needs to quench investors' thirst for success at home.

fields.headline: Taxing time for Inland Revenue
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Why both collectors and taxpayers are groaning under weight of chancellor's zeal for reform
fields.trailText: The Inland Revenue is buckling under the weight of tax and benefit reforms devised by chancellor Gordon Brown over the last 3 years as part of the Treasury's drive to influence the economy and redistribute wealth.
fields.body:
The Inland Revenue is buckling under the weight of tax and benefit reforms devised by chancellor Gordon Brown over the last 3 years as part of the Treasury's drive to influence the economy and redistribute wealth.

Monitoring and implementing most of the new rules is a job that has increasingly been given to the Revenue and, while the government's main tax collecting agency claims it is improving the way it works, taxpayers' groups and tax advisers are almost unanimous in voicing concern about the organisation's ability to cope.

Hundreds of staff due to switch from processing tax returns to investigating tax avoidance continue to wrestle with computer systems that have struggled to match expectations. Only last month the government sanctioned the Revenue closing 1m unresolved tax records to give staff a chance to tackle 5.2m records - almost 20% of the British workforce - that could not be found anywhere on the computer system.

Changes in employee share schemes, property taxes and pension benefits for the elderly announced in the recent pre-budget statement will, say critics, worsen a situation that already has staff reeling at the organisation's headquarters in Somerset House on the Thames. The working families tax credit, soon to be superceded by the integrated child credit, the 10p tax rate that started in April and changes to capital gains tax that few people understand are some of the "reforms" already clogging up the Revenue's systems.

Revenue chairman Nick Montagu is also wrestling with big picture changes. First the Revenue was told to leave tax processing to computers and slim down and concentrate on monitoring and investigating taxpayers. Then it was told to take work from the Benefits Agency, scale up and become Gordon Brown's main weapon as he attempts to re-engineer the economy.

Staff costs have been rising instead of falling, with overall salaries topping £1bn for the first time last year. John Whiting, a senior tax adviser at accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, said he questions whether the agency has the manpower to deal with all the changes. "It is coping with difficulty. There are plenty of signs of stress and strain."

John Battersby, of accountants KPMG, argues that Mr Brown's changes are also having an impact on taxpayers. He points out that the guide produced by the Revenue to help taxpayers fill out their self-assessment tax return has leapt from eight pages last year to 28 pages for the 2000-2001 tax year.

"The Revenue has spread out some of the explanations to make them easier to understand and that accounts for a few extra pages. But well over 1,000 pages of tax legislation have been added to the statute book by this government. It shows how much more complicated it will be for the 9m people who calculate their own tax to get it right."Pensioners are struggling to fill in their tax returns, following a raft of changes to the way benefits are calculated, the Low Incomes Tax Reform Group said yesterday. A huge centralisation of tax district offices has also led to a cut in the number of services available to pensioners, including home visits, the group said.

One body representing tax advisers, the Chartered Institute of Taxation, has gone so far as to say that tax rules are now so complicated that "a culture of non-compliance will become more commonplace".

A Revenue spokesman said: "We don't accept that the Revenue cannot cope with the pace of change. We have put in place a lot of support for businesses and individuals to meet their responsibilities."

The complexities of the tax system have undoubtedly been felt inside the agency. In the last year the Revenue has been forced to abandon the exact calculation of 6.2m PAYE records for the 1998-1999 tax year. As a result, millions of taxpayers have possibly paid too much tax, while others have paid too little. Most of them will never know if they did or not. The only comfort offered by Revenue officials is that they think the sums involved are small.

Much of the problem centres on the dif ficulties two computer systems have talking to each other. Marrying computer records with paper records sent in by employers has also been blamed.

In the past two years the government has pushed through a merger with the Contributions Agency, which handles the collection of national insurance. The agency was saddled with a system called Nirs2, designed and run by the consultancy firm Andersen Consulting. MPs on the public accounts committee, the main parliamentary watchdog, said in the summer that the system had never worked properly and believed it would still not be fully functional until April 2001, despite denials from Andersen and the Revenue.

The Revenue's PAYE computer run by US firm EDS has also had its problems. Earlier this year it wrongly sent out letters to thousands of taxpayers, telling them they paid too little or too much tax. By the Revenue's own admission it still locks out users for one hour in every 100.

The organisation's ability to track down fraud is also under question. As part of a switch in direction ordered by the last government, the Revenue is supposed to leave the processing of tax returns to computers and switch to monitoring, checking and investigating, much like America's much feared Internal Revenue Service.

But according to the last available figures for the year ending March 1999, the Revenue successfully pursued only 32 cases of fraud through to conviction.

The previous year the Revenue's fraud investigations team - the special compliance office - could claim a tally of guilty verdicts almost double at 62. Embarrassment at the collapse in number of successful prosecutions is matched by the fact that a third of the 32 guilty verdicts in 1999 were for internal fraud and imposed on Inland Revenue employees. A year before convictions for internal fraud were a fifth of the total.

The Revenue said an improvement would show through in this year's figures - due out this month - and said the figures for internal fraud were slightly exaggerated by the inclusion of "external accomplices". According to taxpayer groups and accountants the situation is likely to worsen across all departments unless the chancellor reigns in his reforming zeal.

fields.headline: Lauda quits his own airline
fields.standfirst: Founder resigns after auditors' criticism
fields.trailText: Niki Lauda, the formula one world champion driver turned entrepreneur, last night quit the airline he founded after an external audit criticised the way the company handled foreign currency transactions.
fields.body:
Niki Lauda, the formula one world champion driver turned entrepreneur, last night quit the airline he founded after an external audit criticised the way the company handled foreign currency transactions.

His departure is expected to clear the way for Lauda Air to be taken over by Austrian Airlines, which already holds a 36% stake.

In a statement released by the company announcing his resignation as chairman of Lauda Air, Mr Lauda said that the criticisism related to an area outside his area of executive responsibility.

"I will not go into whether this criticism is justified, how it is to be evaluated , or whether any blame can be attached to me personally," he said.

"However, as I have always maintained that I would resign my function if so much as a semblence of a reason should arise to criticise me as an individual, I herewith announce my resignation."

According to Mr Lauda's statement the report from KPMG "found no evidence whatsoever of any personal enrichment on my part, nor did it find any indication that any damages had been caused to Lauda Air."

However it did criticise "the internal control system for foreign currency transactions." According to Mr Lauda that did not come under his area of direct responsibility, which covered flight operations, public relations and strategic partnerships."

His departure comes at a difficult time for the airline, which has been losing money as a result of escalating fuel prices and the strength of the dollar. Latterly Mr Lauda, who was seen as determined to keep his airline independent, had been at loggerheads with Austrian Airlines over a sale-and-leaseback deal with Boeing. Austrian Airlines opposed the deal.

According to Mr Lauda that did not come under his area of direct responsibility, which covered flight operations, public relations and strategic partnerships." His departure comes at a difficult time for the airline, which has been losing money as a result of escalating fuel prices and the strength of the dollar. Latterly Mr Lauda, who was seen as determined to keep his airline independent, had been at loggerheads with Austrian Airlines over a sale-and-leaseback deal with Boeing. Austrian Airlines opposed the deal.

fields.headline: Stock exchange warned against delusion
fields.trailText: City share dealers and policy makers could be operating under a delusion if they believe London remains the best place to do business, according to a group of stock exchange users.
fields.body:
City share dealers and policy makers could be operating under a delusion if they believe London remains the best place to do business, according to a group of stock exchange users.

Despite its success in fighting off the £1bn takeover bid from Sweden's OM the London Stock Exchange cannot rest on its laurels, the practitioner group warned yesterday.

"Change is inevitable and the status quo is not an option," the group warned. "Although we are all very careful to deny complacency, there is an implicit assumption among UK policy makers and many market users that London is still the best place to do business - best in terms of cost, best in terms of spreads, best in terms of regulatory touch. This may be a delusion."

The report, published by Apcims, which represents private client stockbrokers and investment managers, urges the exchange to adopt a six-point plan. It says a poll of around a third of the exchange's shareholders would prefer an alliance to a merger.

The most favoured options are a link with Nasdaq and a tripartite alliance with the US exchange and Euronext, the merged Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels market.

Among the proposals it wants the LSE to adopt are an improved marketing strategy, lower costs, fundamental changes to the trading platform and an active role in the debate over the restructuring of share dealing in Europe.

The report concludes: "Market and political pressures are now both pushing for solutions that will drive down costs, lower barriers to entry and facilitate cross-border equity trading in Europe. [The LSE] cannot afford to miss this opportunity. If it does, someone else will eat its lunch."

A spokesman for the LSE described the report as a "helpful contribution".

fields.headline: Late booking: S&N finally offloads Center Parcs
fields.trailText: Scottish & Newcastle finally checked out of the holiday industry yesterday by selling its troublesome Center Parcs business to the French firm Pierre & Vacances for a maximum of £670m.
fields.body:
Scottish & Newcastle finally checked out of the holiday industry yesterday by selling its troublesome Center Parcs business to the French firm Pierre & Vacances for a maximum of £670m.

The deal followed six months of negotiations, prolonged by a fire at a resort in the Netherlands.

However, analysts said the price was at the bottom end of expectations. Many hoped for £700m.

The final amount will depend on the cash and capital injected into the business before completion, and could be as low as £640m. S&N shares fell 19.25p to 497.5p. The group's chief executive, Brian Stewart, said: "I'm comfortable with the price, and I'm comfortable with the business we're selling."

Center Parcs' 13 resorts offer year-round holidays because they are partly covered by domes. Three of the resorts are in Britain, the rest in France, Germany Belgium and the Netherlands.

Profits from Center Parcs, which peaked at £85m in 1995, were £58m last year.

S&N recently sold its Pontins holidays operation to leisure tycoon Trevor Hemmings to concentrate on beer and pubs.

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.standfirst: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Arthur Smith
fields.body:
About six months after Diana died I was asked to go on a radio show to discuss the view that we should all stop talking about her. I said to the producer, "Do you not see the absurd paradox at the heart of your programme? You are asking me to talk about why I shouldn't be talking about what I am talking about. I'll do it for £75."

I have now received an invitation to contribute to "an anthology of poems to mark what would have been Princess Diana's 40th birthday on June 1, 2000". This enterprise is entirely appropriate because, in the week following her death, the banks of the River Crap Poem burst spectacularly and flooded the land with sickly doggerel. No doubt the editor of this volume, Dennis Evans FRSA, will sift out the real turkeys (this metaphor is out of control) but it's likely that much dross will remain since some of the poets are "prominent people from all walks of life and the professions". I mean, who wants to read a poem by Anthea Turner's accountant? I refer you to a verse by Gazza in an anthology of football poetry a couple of years ago:

"Now Mel and Len both work for me/

Both working day and night/

One's an accountant, one's a lawyer/

Making sure that I'm alright."

I don't mean to sneer at rubbish poetry - I've served up some myself. I find it rather wonderful that, when in extremis, people express themselves in rhyme. They don't do contemporary dance or a painting. It may be a poem that finally pins down the meaning of that strange, sentimental, violent first week of September 1997, which in my mind is associated with another event that sent the country potty - the Falklands War. Perhaps my poem will yoke the two together, or perhaps I'll do something in a lighter vein, recalling my father's description of the funeral: "Then Ben Elton sang that song about Marilyn Monroe". Or maybe something in Gazza's style:

"She was the finest of all ladies/

What a shame about that Mercedes."

More likely when I've finished my crap poem I shall throw it away, thereby saving Dennis Evans FRSA 10 wasted minutes. The poor man has a dismal winter ahead of him.

fields.headline: Main changes at a glance
fields.trailText: Tax and benefit
fields.body:
Tax and benefit

The 10p tax rate (involves altering tax code of every taxpayer)

The national minimum wage (monitored by Revenue department)

Working families tax credit takes over from family credit, while married persons allowance becomes child tax credit (soon to be part of an integrated child credit scheme)

Capital gains tax taper relief (first it ran for 10 years and then five years, further changes announced in this month's pre-budget report

Car tax tied to engine size of vehicles

Employee share schemes revised several times

Advanced corporation tax abolished, scraps dividend tax credit for pension funds

IR35 rules preventing consultants from avoiding tax by paying themselves in dividends

Peps and Tessas disappear, replaced by Isas

Abolition of mortgage interest relief (Miras)

Strategy

Merger with Contributions Agency (runs national insurance scheme)

Cost of 10-year computer contract with EDS soars from £1bn to £2bn

Nirs2 national insurance computer still not working properly according to MPs.

Thousands of staff switched from processing tax returns to investigating avoidance

Centralising of tax offices

Move to telephone-based services for taxpayers

Increasing use of electronic tax returns

fields.headline: Heard the one about the drugs bust?
fields.standfirst: Tommy Cooper started out entertaining the troops in a double act in postwar Palestine. But when  Garry Lyons, his sidekick's son, came to write a play about those days, he found there was more to the great comic than his genial stage persona
fields.trailText: Tommy Cooper started out entertaining the troops in a double act in postwar Palestine. But when Garry Lyons, his sidekick's son, came to write a play about those days, he found there was more to the great comic than his genial stage persona.
fields.body:
My father tells an intriguing story. Early in 1947, when as "Frankie Lyons" he was a young comedian entertaining the troops throughout the Middle East, he was travelling north through the Sinai Desert in the back of a props truck when the vehicle came off the road and overturned.

He sustained injuries to his legs and face and was sent to hospital in Jerusalem to recuperate. While he was there he wrote to my grandmother back in Norbiton to tell her what had happened and he received in reply a letter full of worry.

She had read reports in British newspapers that illegal drugs had been found on a Combined Services Entertainment props truck that had overturned on a road in Palestine. The reports said that a CSE sergeant had been arrested, along with others. My dad was a sergeant, and my poor grandmother must have put two and two together and made five. In fact, the truck with drugs on board had come to grief some way north of where my father had his accident, overturning on a road between Jerusalem and Gaza.

But it was little wonder my grandmother was having kittens. The drugs operation was no tinpot smuggling caper reminiscent of an Ealing comedy. It was an attempt to shift a large consignment of narcotics.

On March 7, 1947 The Times printed a dispatch from Jerusalem filed the previous day. It said: "A large quantity of opium and hashish has been discovered by military police among stage equipment in a lorry used by a Combined Services Entertainment company that has been touring Palestine for the last two months. The players left Jerusalem for Gaza in an omnibus followed by the lorry carrying the 'props'. Later the lorry parted company with the bus and took a minor road, where it overturned. When the military police arrived on the scene they found 195 pieces of opium and 941 slabs of hashish, the total value of which is £40,000. A British driver and a British sergeant have been arrested here, and two arrests have been made in Egypt."

Half a ton of drugs was allegedly seized, worth millions of pounds at today's street prices. There was a high incidence of drug trafficking among British military personnel in the region during this period, but even so, the military police must have seen this as a major coup.

Meanwhile, my dad recovered from his injuries and spent several weeks touring with a show in Palestine. It was only when he returned to the CSE headquarters in Cairo that he heard rumours that the arrested sergeant was a fellow comic and ex-Horse Guard called Thomas Cooper - Cooper the Trooper.

The young Cooper was not universally popular in Cairo, remarkable as that may seem to us now. He was certainly all too familiar to my father. Only a few months before, the two of them had been detailed to work together as a double act by the local CSE management, who were trying to put together a new variety show. Before that, both men had independently made names for themselves as comics in Cairo and on military bases all the way from Tobruk to Tel Aviv. They worked on the same bill in For Your Approval, an occasional cabaret performed at the Cairo YMCA. But, after a brief honeymoon period, the double act became one of the British Army's least fine hours and was terminated by the management before it ever reached the stage.

This isn't so surprising. The marvellously original comic that Cooper was to become had already begun to develop his highly individual style - the bungled magic tricks and the outrageously corny one-liners - and was bound to find it hard working alongside a more traditional, less confident entertainer.

But, like many geniuses, Cooper had a gigantic ego to match his talent. Other Cairo artists from the time confirm my father's impression of the 24-year-old Cooper as a driven obsessive, desperate to find fame and unable to switch off his act even when away from the stage. He was jealous and selfish, prone to violent rages and not averse to running off with a show's earnings without paying the rest of the cast.

This all came as a shock to me when I started research for my play Frankie and Tommy, a dramatic account of the mismatched double-act that has just received its London premiere. I knew there had been some bad feeling between the pair, but I was unaware that the relationship had been quite so acrimonious. The picture of Cooper that emerged from interviews I did during my research was at great variance to the image of the genial, bumbling clown and devoted family man the British public adored.

I have no doubt that age and success mellowed Cooper, and that he could be warm-hearted and charming as well as hilarious. But, for some, he remained a monster to work with throughout his career. He could be mean as well as generous, had a history of alcohol abuse and suffered a great deal of emotional turmoil in his private life.

Even now, 16 years after his death on live television, Cooper devotees refuse to accept that there was pain or anger lurking beneath the fez. (The famous story of Cooper getting the idea of the fez when he snatched one from the head of a Egyptian waiter is an example of showbiz mythologising - the fez was the traditional headgear of the conjurer-clown in English music hall.) I find this reluctance to peek behind the curtain of Cooper's humour strange, particularly when we have scrutinised other comics of his generation, such as Tony Hancock, Benny Hill and Sid James. I recall a woman walking out when Frankie and Tommy was performed at the Edinburgh festival, muttering "Sacrilege!".

She is not the only fan I have come across who regards Cooper as an entertainment saint or deity, whose image should not be desecrated or abused. But, as a playwright, I'm fascinated by what motivates a compulsive comic like Cooper. It doesn't destroy the legend to understand that his humour stemmed from deep-seated social inadequacy. On the contrary, I believe it enriches it.

Social inadequacy is one thing. Drug-running is quite another. Was Cooper the sergeant arrested on the Gaza road? There is no evidence that this was anything other than malicious gossip. In any case, the driver concerned does not appear to have been charged.

However, according to a number of sources, the show Cooper fronted at the time was called Juke Box. On August 27, 1947 The Times reported that a lieutenant, described as the manager of the Juke Box road show, had been acquitted in Jerusalem of a charge of conspiring to smuggle the drugs that were seized.

Of course, this far from implicates Cooper. The fact that he may have been in the same show is purely circumstantial, but it is an interesting point nonetheless. The full truth may lurk in military police records in the Public Records Office, in Colonial Office papers that will stay shut for another 22 years.

 Frankie and Tommy is at the Lyric Studio, Hammersmith, London W6, until December 9. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

webTitle: Arts: Violinist Gidon Kremer talks to Charlotte Higgins

fields.headline: 'Perfect isn't good enough'
fields.standfirst: Thirty years ago Gidon Kremer was rated as one of the world's outstanding violinists. Then he really started making waves. He talks to  Charlotte Higgins
fields.trailText: Thirty years ago Gidon Kremer was rated as one of the world's outstanding violinists. Then he really started making waves. He talks to Charlotte Higgins.
fields.body:
Gidon Kremer has pale but piercing eyes. Or rather, his eyes, gazing out from behind neat, wire-framed specs, do not so much pierce as seem to pin you against the wall. The Latvian violinist is very intense, and does not laugh very much. He is also tired. He got up at three in the morning to catch a plane to London from his home in Paris for a two-hour rehearsal. In an hour or so he will take another plane to Milan.

"I am thinking about my young daughter who is seven, and who plays the piano," he says. "I don't know if I want her to lead such a hard life as I do. I wouldn't wish a day like this on anyone." But this hard life has a good side, for us at least. Without Kremer, many music-lovers might never have heard of two great 20th-century composers - Alfred Schnittke and Astor Piazzolla.

Born in 1947 in Riga, Kremer grew up in Latvia before moving to Moscow to study under the violinist David Oistrakh. He was the child of violinists, both of whom had their careers blown to the winds by the second world war. His Jewish father survived the Holocaust by hiding in a Riga cellar for two years, and the young Kremer was groomed to fulfil his father's frustrated ambitions. That was not his only burden. "Growing up in a totalitarian regime, I also had to endure the pressure of the state ideology. It was hard, trying to be a free artist."

Nevertheless, Kremer flourished musically, winning numerous prizes. The most important was the 1970 Tchaikovsky competition, where conductor Herbert von Karajan was moved to call him "the greatest violinist in the world". For the next 10 years, until he finally left the Soviet Union, Kremer struggled against the regime, risking his career promoting the music of seriously out-of-favour composers - Schnittke and Arvo Part among them.

"If you wanted to perform music that you loved and believed in but was not written in a socialist-realist style, you got into trouble," he says. "Schnittke's music was not forbidden but there were very few artists willing to risk their careers to present it. It took some efforts." Schnittke's fourth and last violin concerto, written in 1984, was dedicated to Kremer. The composer and violinist's initials, translated into musical notation, formed a framework for much of the work.

One of Kremer's other great enthusiasms, the work of the Argentine Astor Piazzolla, has led to his recording six CDs of the composer's music over the past four years. Piazzolla, who studied composition in Paris under Nadia Boulanger, and returned to Buenos Aires to breathe new life into the tango, died in 1992 little known outside South America. Now he is intensely fashionable; performances of his heady, complex tangos proliferate.

Though Kremer does not shy away from the traditional repertoire - he was in London to rehearse the Sibelius concerto - his sense of adventure is at the heart of his identity as a performer. He is an explorer on the borders of the known musical world. "For me it would be too boring to play music by only dead composers or to present music as if it were in a waxworks museum," he says. "I don't want music to be a matter of comfort but of expansion of the spirit."

Kremer's interpretations of Piazzolla have been criticised for being too coolly postmodern and tame, for not reeking strongly enough of the sweat and smoke and sex of the world of tango. Maybe so, but Kremer will never give his audience an easy ride. He can produce sounds as soft and creamy as fresh butter, then jolt you with crash landings and emergency stops. His violin does not merely sing; it strains and rasps and rattles and groans. "One of my favourite conductors, Nikolaus Harnoncourt, says, 'Don't strive for perfection, because perfection is in conflict with beauty.' I would say that my role is to deliver something of beauty. Not ordinary stuff. Not something that is merely perfect."

Does he agree that he plays at the very limits of his physical ability? "Being on the edge, being on the border, being extreme - this is correct," he replies. "I know so many colleagues who deliver great performances on the scale of technique. But very often behind it there is an empty message, or no message at all."

Just as Kremer's playing occasionally strains, so too do his words. You feel that his mind is roaming free and that language - or at least English - cannot quite contain it. But then Kremer, who has lost his childhood fluency in Latvian but speaks Russian, English, German and French, believes that music is also a language, and one that can express emotion in its rawest form.

This is crucial when it comes to selecting repertoire. It attracted him to Schnittke and Part, and more recently to the Georgian composer Giya Kancheli. He talks about music with a "human heart". "This is what drew me to Piazzolla," he says. "He has the same sense of beauty and nostalgia that Schubert had." It is typical of the connections that Kremer makes that he should talk of a 19th-century Austrian and a 20th-century Argentine as if they were contemporaries, even friends. "I am attached to music that speaks to you and does not just manipulate your sophistication. The point is not only to say something unheard of before but to say it in a language of emotion. Music can be a mirror of ourselves. It offers us the opportunity for reflection.

"Occasionally the audience is not aware of the precious things that are presented to them," he says sadly.

In 1997 Kremer set up the Kremerata Baltica, an ensemble of young musicians drawn from the Baltic states of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. This move is not merely musical or personal. "To defend their national identities and to do something good for the music of those countries - this is certainly political," he says. There is a poetic justice to it - after all those years of being identified as a Soviet or Russian violinist, Kremer is staking out a territory of his own.

He works with Kremerata Baltica for about five months of the year. "They are still fresh, still far away from the routine of many orchestras that are really only to do with money-making." One of their recordings, of works by the Latvian Peteris Vasks, contains a note by the composer about his 1991 piece Balsis. He writes of "the Soviet empire's dying excesses and the peaceful resistance of the Baltic peoples".

This does not mean, however, that Kremer regards Latvia as the place where he belongs. Championing the music and musicians of the Baltic states (he has recently recorded a disc of contemporary Baltic music called From My Home) does not provide "an ID of myself. It is part of my past, and I pay tribute to it, just as I pay tribute to other parts of my past. A big part of my life is to do with Russian culture."

So where is home? "I have lost the sense of home. It is very dispersed, it is very vague. It is here," he says, tapping his head. "It is more the idea of a creative process in which I feel at home. It is an internal landscape. Inside this home I know all my shelves better than I do the ones in Paris. When I return to Paris, I find that my books are not where I thought they were. The shelves of my mind are a little more ordered."

fields.bodyText: Gidon Kremer has pale but piercing eyes. Or rather, his eyes, gazing out from behind neat, wire-framed specs, do not so much pierce as seem to pin you against the wall. The Latvian violinist is very intense, and does not laugh very much. He is also tired. He got up at three in the morning to catch a plane to London from his home in Paris for a two-hour rehearsal. In an hour or so he will take another plane to Milan. "I am thinking about my young daughter who is seven, and who plays the piano," he says. "I don't know if I want her to lead such a hard life as I do. I wouldn't wish a day like this on anyone." But this hard life has a good side, for us at least. Without Kremer, many music-lovers might never have heard of two great 20th-century composers - Alfred Schnittke and Astor Piazzolla. Born in 1947 in Riga, Kremer grew up in Latvia before moving to Moscow to study under the violinist David Oistrakh. He was the child of violinists, both of whom had their careers blown to the winds by the second world war. His Jewish father survived the Holocaust by hiding in a Riga cellar for two years, and the young Kremer was groomed to fulfil his father's frustrated ambitions. That was not his only burden. "Growing up in a totalitarian regime, I also had to endure the pressure of the state ideology. It was hard, trying to be a free artist." Nevertheless, Kremer flourished musically, winning numerous prizes. The most important was the 1970 Tchaikovsky competition, where conductor Herbert von Karajan was moved to call him "the greatest violinist in the world". For the next 10 years, until he finally left the Soviet Union, Kremer struggled against the regime, risking his career promoting the music of seriously out-of-favour composers - Schnittke and Arvo Part among them. "If you wanted to perform music that you loved and believed in but was not written in a socialist-realist style, you got into trouble," he says. "Schnittke's music was not forbidden but there were very few artists willing to risk their careers to present it. It took some efforts." Schnittke's fourth and last violin concerto, written in 1984, was dedicated to Kremer. The composer and violinist's initials, translated into musical notation, formed a framework for much of the work. One of Kremer's other great enthusiasms, the work of the Argentine Astor Piazzolla, has led to his recording six CDs of the composer's music over the past four years. Piazzolla, who studied composition in Paris under Nadia Boulanger, and returned to Buenos Aires to breathe new life into the tango, died in 1992 little known outside South America. Now he is intensely fashionable; performances of his heady, complex tangos proliferate. Though Kremer does not shy away from the traditional repertoire - he was in London to rehearse the Sibelius concerto - his sense of adventure is at the heart of his identity as a performer. He is an explorer on the borders of the known musical world. "For me it would be too boring to play music by only dead composers or to present music as if it were in a waxworks museum," he says. "I don't want music to be a matter of comfort but of expansion of the spirit." Kremer's interpretations of Piazzolla have been criticised for being too coolly postmodern and tame, for not reeking strongly enough of the sweat and smoke and sex of the world of tango. Maybe so, but Kremer will never give his audience an easy ride. He can produce sounds as soft and creamy as fresh butter, then jolt you with crash landings and emergency stops. His violin does not merely sing; it strains and rasps and rattles and groans. "One of my favourite conductors, Nikolaus Harnoncourt, says, 'Don't strive for perfection, because perfection is in conflict with beauty.' I would say that my role is to deliver something of beauty. Not ordinary stuff. Not something that is merely perfect." Does he agree that he plays at the very limits of his physical ability? "Being on the edge, being on the border, being extreme - this is correct," he replies. "I know so many colleagues who deliver great performances on the scale of technique. But very often behind it there is an empty message, or no message at all." Just as Kremer's playing occasionally strains, so too do his words. You feel that his mind is roaming free and that language - or at least English - cannot quite contain it. But then Kremer, who has lost his childhood fluency in Latvian but speaks Russian, English, German and French, believes that music is also a language, and one that can express emotion in its rawest form. This is crucial when it comes to selecting repertoire. It attracted him to Schnittke and Part, and more recently to the Georgian composer Giya Kancheli. He talks about music with a "human heart". "This is what drew me to Piazzolla," he says. "He has the same sense of beauty and nostalgia that Schubert had." It is typical of the connections that Kremer makes that he should talk of a 19th-century Austrian and a 20th-century Argentine as if they were contemporaries, even friends. "I am attached to music that speaks to you and does not just manipulate your sophistication. The point is not only to say something unheard of before but to say it in a language of emotion. Music can be a mirror of ourselves. It offers us the opportunity for reflection. "Occasionally the audience is not aware of the precious things that are presented to them," he says sadly. In 1997 Kremer set up the Kremerata Baltica, an ensemble of young musicians drawn from the Baltic states of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. This move is not merely musical or personal. "To defend their national identities and to do something good for the music of those countries - this is certainly political," he says. There is a poetic justice to it - after all those years of being identified as a Soviet or Russian violinist, Kremer is staking out a territory of his own. He works with Kremerata Baltica for about five months of the year. "They are still fresh, still far away from the routine of many orchestras that are really only to do with money-making." One of their recordings, of works by the Latvian Peteris Vasks, contains a note by the composer about his 1991 piece Balsis. He writes of "the Soviet empire's dying excesses and the peaceful resistance of the Baltic peoples". This does not mean, however, that Kremer regards Latvia as the place where he belongs. webTitle: Arts: Jonathan Romney on The Sunday Format

fields.headline: The art of chip-wrapping
fields.standfirst: Sunday supplements
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney on The Sunday Format
fields.body:
I think we all recognise the agonies expressed by playwright Mark Ravenhill in the Guardian last Saturday when he complained of not being able to keep up with a surfeit of art and culture. His solution was a year's moratorium on reviews, listings and media tittle-tattle.

Perhaps Mr Ravenhill and other weary consumers could use a makeover from a personal entertainment counsellor. One client reports that she was delighted with her counsellor's bold, decisive gestures, such as throwing out her classical record collection and getting her on a diet of magazines ("Being 35 doesn't mean you have to read books"). "No longer," reports the satisfied customer, "am I embarrassed by having missed the latest trendy drama or hip comedy show." Read more about this therapy in the best-selling Entertain Yourself Young.

It could happen - although for now this is purely an invention of the Radio 4 comedy programme the Sunday Format. Although the show has been around for a while (originally a one-off in 1996, it's currently in its second series), I've managed to miss it until now - too busy out doing culture, don't you know. The Sunday Format is a Sunday paper for the air, complete with pull-out sections and supplements devoted to particular areas of cultural consumption: Literality, Visuality, Gastronimity, Cruciality, and Inside, "Our new insider's guide to what goes on on the inside of anything that's in." Plus the occasional special cut-out-and-keep guide, "which you can cut out and keep but should throw away on Thursday."

The Sunday Format is acute on the fact that the Sundays' obsession with being up-to-the-minute keeps them just a column inch away from chip-paper obsolescence. The in-built outdatedness even extends to some of the humour, notably the repeated "new black" gags: affabilité is the new insouciance, constipation is the new diarrhoea. This inexhaustible in-joke seems hopelessly stale, although real newspapers continue to use it, so maybe it's not that off-beam after all.

There's nothing new about radio and TV comedy masquerading as zeitgeist-obsessed reportage. But one innovation is the way the show works the very question of format. Its primary subject is papers' obsession with their own shape as papers, as if a stack of newsprint were terribly novel. As an excited reader puts it in a bogus vox pop, "It's like a website you can hold in your hand!"

The programme is particularly good on the print media's claim to global comprehensiveness, which in this case becomes breathless randomness. The state of the world is filtered through a dizzy succession of fatuous lists, spurious trends, features based on arbitrary juxtapositions of words - not that bizarre since newspaper people and comedy writers use much the same thought processes to generate ideas.

The show really shouldn't be transferred to TV because it so brilliantly evokes in sound the visual feeling of blitzing distractedly through a Sunday paper. Items are continually interrupted by voices directing us to imaginary photos, or break off mid-sentence, even mid-word, to return to earlier items. The relentless pace is accompanied by innocuously trendy background music, all very Sunday supp: Philip Glass, Moby, Italian beer-ad themes. Best of all, its cast (including Rebecca Front, Alexander Armstrong, Emma Kennedy and Chris Langham) gets the voices right. The Sunday Format columnists are not so much characters as embodiments of journalistic styles, from the smooth, self-satisfied domestic goddess through the patrician opera critic with his "pregnant serendipity", to the petulant, hurt tones of the young literary profiler meeting her Irvine Welsh-like idol.

The show's main observation - again, not that original, but always worth a reminder - is that in our media-channelled zeitgeist, The Way We Live Today has been superseded by the way we think we live today, and by the way we read about the way we think we live today. And the programme pinpoints another, unspoken function of the Sunday papers: while they offer themselves as a comprehensive digest of the previous and the coming weeks, we read them not so much to absorb information as to forget it. We diligently wade through them just so that we will never again have to think about the latest controversial novel or the hot new movie. This function as an aid to forgetting should offer some comfort to Mark Ravenhill and all of us culturally beleaguered masses.

 The Sunday Format is on Radio 4 on Tuesday at 6.30pm.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Chirac may face court questions
fields.body:
Chirac may face court questions

A French lawyer has asked a judge to allow him to call President Jacques Chirac as a witness in an investigation of fraud and favouritism in a printing company while Mr Chirac was mayor of Paris.

He wants to question Mr Chirac about the Sempap company, which was set up in 1986 and was responsible for the city hall's printing requirements.
AP, Paris

Farmers fight seizure ruling

Zimbabwe's Commercial Farmers' Union is to appeal against a court order allowing squatters to stay on white-owned farms.

On Monday a high court judge ruled that war veterans and supporters of President Robert Mugabe could remain on the farms pending a supreme court decision on the legality of the land seizure programme.
Reuters, Harare

Ancient tomb found in dunes

A team of Czech archaeologists has discovered a 4,300-year-old nobleman's tomb in sand dunes south-west of Cairo. The tomb, built for a judge, dates from the reign of Pepi, said Bratislav Vachala who is leading the excavations.
AP, Abu Sir

fields.headline: More than 20,000 missing in Bosnia
fields.trailText: The International Committee of the Red Cross marked the fifth anniversary of the Dayton peace agreement yesterday by updating its figures on the number of people still missing after the Bosnian war.
fields.body:
The International Committee of the Red Cross marked the fifth anniversary of the Dayton peace agreement yesterday by updating its figures on the number of people still missing after the Bosnian war.

It put the total at 20,484, made up of 16,979 Muslims, 2,537 Serbs, 719 Croats and 249 others. "Most of these persons are presumed dead," said the head of the ICRC mission to Bosnia, Balthasar Staehelin. But families often refuse to accept this unless a body is found, he added.

Because of the slow pace of finding their remains, it might take decades to solve the issue, he added. The true number of dead - by far the largest in any conflict in Europe since the second world war - could be higher since, in some cases, entire families are missing and there are no close relatives left to submit a tracing request.

Efforts to make the former warring sides exchange data about the circumstances in which people of the rival ethnic groups might have disappeared have so far been unsuccessful because such exchanges might reveal incriminating war crimes information.

The ICRC's new data were the most sombre contribution to a generally downbeat commemoration of the Dayton agreement, which ended the war.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees pointed out that only 9% to 10% of refugees who fled areas where another ethnic group was in the majority had returned home.

International organisations had hoped the rate of "minority returns" would increase as time passed, but only 80,000 people out of the roughly 800,000 internally displaced have risked defying the ethnic cleansers.

Under Dayton, Bosnia was divided into a Bosnian Serb entity and a federation shared by Muslims and Croats. The federation is also, in effect, divided ethnically.

Many refugees who went back have suffered arson attacks on their homes. Only in cities like Sarajevo and Banja Luka, where refugees are less conspicuous, have some been able to return unharmed.
