webTitle: Bush team woos woman at heart of legal row

fields.headline: Bush team woos woman at heart of legal row
fields.standfirst:
Expertise in Latin American affairs makes Harris ideal as adviser

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Expertise in Latin American affairs makes Harris ideal as adviser.
fields.body:
Katherine Harris, the woman at the fulcrum of the legal dispute that could decide the presidency, is being sounded out for a role in a putative Bush transition team, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Florida secretary of state has become an icon of Democrat demonology for refusing to accept recounted votes received after last week's deadline.

She is being asked to consider taking on the task of adviser on Latin American affairs if George W Bush becomes president-elect, working with the team that would prepare for his administration.

"I don't think she is looking for a job in the government," said William Perry, an adviser at different times to both the governor of Texas and his father, the former president.

"In fact, she's told me she is not looking for such a job. But someone in her position could have influence on our Latin American policy and I hope to hell she has."

Mr Perry, a senior associate at a conservative thinktank, had hoped to discuss the matter with Ms Harris in Washington last week, a date overtaken by the turmoil over the Florida election. Now he might do so instead at the inauguration on Friday week of Vincente Fox as Mexico's new president.

Ms Harris, 43, a friend of George W Bush and his brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, has made acting as an envoy for trade one of the main functions of her office. She has led commerce missions to Mexico and lobbied Congress last year to place the Free Trade of the Americas secretariat offices in Miami.

Ben McKay, Ms Harris's chief of staff, confirmed that overtures had been made but said that the multi-millionaire from one of Florida's leading families had also spoken to Democrats about Latin-American affairs.

"Whoever wins, she will sit down with them," said Mr McKay. "She represents Florida's interests and she's going to say 'Here's Florida's interests.'"

Bob Hopkins, a Bush campaign national spokesman, said: "At this stage of the game it's really premature to be talking about transition." But Gary Springer, secretary general of the Gulf of Mexico States Accord, said: "That's what our state [Florida] does best, is Latin America."

Mr McKay denied that Ms Harris, who was co-chairman of George W Bush's election committee in Florida, was influenced by the Republican party in her decisions about the manual recounts in three counties in south Florida. But she has been using the same Republican media relations firm employed for a time on New York city mayor Rudy Giuliani's aborted United States senate campaign.

Ms Harris's boss, Jeb Bush, who says he is feeling the strain in the post-election period, received 27,000 emails in the week after voting day. The material, released under Florida's freedom of information "sunshine law," shows Mr Bush's response to messages saying that 19,000 votes were disqualified in Palm Beach county, south Florida.

The governor, who says that he has removed himself from the post-election process, sent an email to his director of communications saying: "This is a concerted effort to divide and destroy our state."

With the state apparently still in one piece yesterday, the seven members of the Florida supreme court were still considering their ruling on whether the late recounts should stand.

An unofficial deadline was fast approaching - tomorrow's Thanksgiving holiday when the US comes to a halt. Craig Waters, the court's public information officer, said he would let it be known if and when it became clear that the judges would be unable to reach a decision before then.

webTitle: Changing sides in a land of terror

fields.headline: Changing sides in a land of terror
fields.standfirst: Former rebels join the army in Rwanda, a country still at war with itself six years after the genocide which killed 800,000
fields.trailText: Former rebels join the army in Rwanda, a country still at war with itself six years after the genocide which killed 800,000.
fields.body:
Truckloads of young soldiers pass through villages on the road to the border, smiling and waving as they head for Congo. They look too light-hearted to be going into a war which has fractured the largest country in Africa and divided the continent. Over the last two years, nine countries have been sucked into fighting.

By the roadside, women in long dresses, and ragged barefoot children laugh and wave back as though what lies before these young men is something far more normal than terror and death.

But six years after the genocide which killed 800,000 in three months, terror and death are still the backdrop to life in Rwanda. Over the border in the Democratic Republic of Congo, about 15,000 Rwandan troops who were involved in the genocide of the Tutsi minority are fighting to return and finish their work.

All wars have surreal aspects, but none more than this one. Among the soldiers in every convoy are a number going back to a war they know, because they were fighting on the other side until recently.

Under a tree in the military barracks in Ruhengeri sit a dozen men and boys in tattered clothes, many barefoot. A few speak poor French, a legacy of time in the army of the former regime, trained, supplied and supported by France, even through the genocide. They are returnees from the fighting in Congo. Some have been captured, but most have given up and are now asking to be brought into the new national army.

The story of Festi, 28, shows the tangled allegiances of these men's insecure lives. A former sergeant, he deserted the Interahamwe militia a few months after the genocide, giving himself up with his weapon to the new authorities, and was sent home to his village in the north-west, bordering Congo.

But he found that his family had been kidnapped by the Interahamwe and taken off into the guerrilla camps of Congo in retribution for his desertion. He followed them and changed sides again, rejoining Interahamwe units based in the dense forest of Walikale. Like several other prisoners, he was part of the Dream Battalion of Interahamwe, whose function is to infiltrate north-west Rwanda and mobilise villagers against the government.

"We came to tell people not to forget us, to remind them that we would be coming back to claim our rights, to tell them Tutsis are bad people, don't trust them."

But it was his own Hutu people from his former village who last month went to tell the authorities that Festi was back and was urging people not to send their children to school and to destroy village crops in protest at the government. He was arrested on the third day.

Now he will have a few weeks in a "solidarity camp" with other returnees from Congo, then he hopes to go into the government army "to be safe from the Interahamwe".

In the last year, 40,000 people have come back to this area from Interahamwe units. Some were captured inside Congo, or as they tried to infiltrate Rwanda to prepare peasants for another genocide. But many more returned of their own choice.

Jacques, 25, came back to his village, ambushed his mother as she was working in the fields, gave her his gun and asked her to take him to the government soldiers.

Sixteen-year-old Anastas was kidnapped by the Interahamwe from a school on the border when he was 13. He began to look for Rwandan units in Congo after he heard persistent stories from Dream Battalion soldiers who crossed and recrossed the border that those who gave themselves up were well treated.

He is bright eyed and cheerful, in marked contrast to the confused and defeated men around him. His parents have been to the barracks to see him and he is soon going back to school.

These have enabled the rebels to maintain training with rifles and machine guns in what he called the " Ecole Militaire Supérieure " in Walikale.

The forest camp is also home to two former ministers, priests, both Catholic and Protestant, and university people, he said.

fields.headline: Congolese battle for resources
fields.trailText: Rival rebel groups fighting to overthrow Laurent Kabila, the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, have been pitted against each other in the past few days.
fields.body:
Rival rebel groups fighting to overthrow Laurent Kabila, the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, have been pitted against each other in the past few days.

This has underlined both the ethnic conflicts left over from the Rwandan genocide, and the scramble for resources between Congolese. In a fight over access to minerals, forces of the Congolese Rally for Democracy (RCD) tried to take Banalia, north of Kisangani, but were repulsed by the Congolese Liberation Movement (MLC), which controls north-western Congo, MLC leader Jean-Pierre Bemba said.

Divisions within a third rebel group, led by Professor Wamba dia Wamba and linked to the RCD, brought armed clashes several times this month in Bunia. Dozens were killed.

Meanwhile, fighting has intensified in southern Congo, where the Rwandan army and the RCD made gains at the southern end of Lake Tanganyika, forcing thousands of Congolese soldiers to flee to Zambia.

In a separate incident north of the RCD stronghold of Goma, Rwandan Interahamwe militiamen, allied with Mr Kabila, attacked a village and killed five civilians. Agencies

webTitle: The chad debate - are dimples Gore's best hope?

fields.headline: The chad debate - are dimples Gore's best hope?
fields.standfirst:
Evidence of voter intention is being hotly disputed

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Evidence of voter intention is being hotly disputed.
fields.body:
While the Florida supreme court wrestled with the problems of hand recounts and deadlines yesterday, a hotly contested “ground war” in the three disputed counties focused on the arcane but potentially crucial issue of “dimpled” or “pregnant” chad.

The manual vote counts in Miami-Dade, Palm Beach and Broward counties are producing far fewer gains for Al Gore than the Democrats had expected. But several thousand ballots have been set aside as “questionable” because the voter did not fully punch through the ballot paper, leaving an indentation rather than a hole alongside the name of a candidate.

The small, perforated, rectangular plug, or chad, remains attached but protruding and is described as pregnant or, increasingly, as merely dimpled.

Democrats believe that if the voter’s intention is to be measured, these indentations should be counted as votes, and they believe that the majority of them would be votes for the vice-president. As the manual recounts proceed, that might be the only way Mr Gore will overtake George W Bush’s official lead of 930 votes.

It is also possible that Mr Bush could lengthen his lead, especially after the Florida attorney general, Bob Butterworth, decided that several hundred absentee ballots from military personnel overseas could be counted even if they bore no postmark showing they had been sent before election day. Those votes were expected to favour the Texas governor.

The fate of the dimpled chad is the cause of heated struggle at each counting centre, where the local electoral committees, or canvassing boards, are being lobbied hard by both sides. The state supreme court has also been asked to provide guidelines for what counts as a valid vote, but it might leave those decisions to the counties.

As of yesterday, Miami-Dade was counting dimpled chads as votes, Broward was not, and Palm Beach was somewhere in between, counting some dimples but not all. Chad hanging by one, two or three corners, “hanging” “swinging” or “tri-” respectively, would be counted in all three counties. The fate of chads connected by four corners was unclear.

In Palm Beach county, the recount had brought Mr Gore a net gain of only three votes by yesterday afternoon, but Dennis Newman, a Democratic lawyer, said that several hundred dimpled ballots had been put to one side. Mr Newman said 276 of them indicated a vote for Mr Gore and 73 were votes for Governor Bush.

Charles Burton, the chairman of the county’s three-member canvassing board, said that dimpled chad would be considered in the light of the whole ballot. If the voter showed a “tendency to dimple” - denting the ballot to indicate his or her preferences rather than punching right through it with the pointed stylus provided - then a dimpled chad would be counted as a vote.

In Broward, Mr Gore had made a net gain of 117 votes from the manual recount, with 554 out of 609 precincts counted. Two thousand disputed ballots have been set aside. In Miami-Dade, Mr Gore had clawed back 46 votes, dimpled ballots included, with about a tenth of precincts counted.

webTitle: Turkey leads a scramble by EU hopefuls to bolster new force

fields.headline: Turkey leads a scramble by EU hopefuls to bolster new force
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Turkey offered up to 6,000 men, ships and planes to take part in the EU's new rapid reaction force yesterday as aspiring members from across the continent scrambled to do their bit for the union's fledgling military might.
fields.body:
Turkey offered up to 6,000 men, ships and planes to take part in the EU's new rapid reaction force yesterday as aspiring members from across the continent scrambled to do their bit for the union's fledgling military might.

On the second day of a landmark defence ministers' meeting in Brussels, the meaty offer from Turkey - reflecting its heavyweight position in Nato - topped a list of more modest pledges from 12 other countries queueing up to join the EU.

The Czech Republic, a former member of the Warsaw Pact and now also a member of the transatlantic alliance, offered chemical warfare specialists, commandos and transport helicopters.

Slovakia said it could provide 450 men. Similar offers came from Poland, Romania, Bulgaria and Malta, though few specifics were announced. Iceland and Norway, in Nato but not the EU, also made offers.

"These contributions were substantial." said Alain Richard, defence minister of France, which holds the EU rotating presidency.

On Monday the EU launched what many in Brussels - and national capitals - see as the union's most ambitious project since the single currency: building a 60,000-strong force that would operate in crises in which Nato chooses not to get involved.

Defence ministers pledged a poll of about 100,000 troops, 400 combat aircraft and 100 ships for use in peacekeeping, evacuation and humanitarian operations.

But it was the Turkish offer, including a mechanised infantry brigade, armour, air defence forces, eight ships and two squadrons of F-16 fighters, that stole yesterday's show.

Diplomats described Ankara's position as "very positive," despite unresolved questions about how the EU force will work with Nato.

Turkey, ever sensitive about its relations with the EU, has been blocking EU access to Nato documents.

"The Turks are being very stubborn," said one alliance diplomat. "They are very worried that the EU might use this stuff in their region without their seal of approval."

Nato insists it is broadly pleased with the EU's defence initiative, despite warnings from Eurosceptic Britons about the danger of undermining the alliance.

France, always ambivalent about relying on US power, has been sounding distinctly conciliatory in recent days, though it is far from clear whether new institutional arrangements can be agreed in time for next month's EU summit in Nice.

Speaking in Berlin yesterday, the Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson, stressed that EU plans, if properly funded and organised, will strengthen Nato's overall capabilities and see Europe shoulder more responsibility for peacekeeping and crisis-management missions.

According to the EU timetable, by 2003 the rapid reaction force will be capable of deploying within 60 days and remaining on the ground for up to a year.

"That's quite an ambitious target," Lord Robertson said. "I hope they make it, but it will mean substantial investment will have to be made during that time, and I'll be there to remind them of their commitment."

Speaking during a visit to Moscow, Tony Blair complained about the press coverage of EU plans.

"I am used to the British media being impossible on the subject of Europe but I hope very much the public will at last be given the facts," the prime minister said. "I will not let this type of anti-European nonsense disturb the true national interests of our country."

webTitle: Ocalan in death-row appeal to Europe

fields.headline: Ocalan in death-row appeal to Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Kurds
fields.trailText: Turkey's death sentence against the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan was challenged in the European Court of Human Rights yesterday. It is a case which could have profound repercussions for Ankara's ever sensitive relations with the EU.
fields.body:
Turkey's death sentence against the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan was challenged in the European Court of Human Rights yesterday. It is a case which could have profound repercussions for Ankara's ever sensitive relations with the EU.

As thousands of supporters and opponents gathered outside the court in Strasbourg amidst heavy security, seven judges were asked to rule on whether the complaint was admissable.

At the same time Turkey's foreign minister accused the EU of acting like "colonial governors" in dealings with his country.

Ocalan's appeal is on the grounds that he was denied a fair trial because Turkey violated the European Convention on Human Rights, under which the court was established. Although the court is entirely distinct from the European Union, observance of the convention is mandatory for all members of the EU, which Turkey has long aspired to join.

The court has the power to overturn rulings from national courts that it deems in violation of the European Convention on Human Rights. It has frequently ruled against Turkey on human rights issues, and though a member of the Council of Europe and supposed to abide by the court's rulings, it has ignored them.

Ocalan, founder of the outlawed Kurdish Workers Party or PKK, was kidnapped by special agents in Kenya in 1998 and flown to Turkey for a trial at which he was condemned to hang for hundreds of killings in the PKK's 16-year war against Turkey and its army.

The Turkish authorities have not carried out a death sentence since 1984. While Ankara has agreed not to execute Ocalan while the case is in progress, it rejects his appeal to the human rights court as a ploy. Government lawyers said the case was neither merited nor admissible.

If the complaint is allowed to proceed, the Strasbourg court is likely to take several months to reach a decision, and either party can then appeal to a higher chamber. A ruling on admissibility is expected within a week or two.

Ocalan's legal team includes a British QC, Sir Sydney Kentridge, who acted for Nelson Mandela. Also involved is Gareth Peirce, known for her involvement in cases where miscarriage of justice is alleged.

Some 60 to 70 relatives of Turkish soldiers killed in the war against the PKK rebels sat in the galleries at Strasbourg along with similar numbers of Ocalan supporters.

From his cell in a island jail in the Sea of Marmara south of Istanbul, the PKK leader has ordered his party to abandon its armed struggle and seek cultural rights and autonomy by peaceful and democratic means. Violence has dropped sharply as a result, but the Strasbourg hearing has revived tensions in Turkey and beyond.

Ankara was also upset when Brussels last week laid down the economic and political changes Ankara must make before it can start membership talks under a so-called accession partnership agreement. Turkey was incensed that the document said Ankara's short-term aims should include "strong support" for UN efforts to resolve the division of Cyprus.

Greece is demanding that a reference to "the solution of Aegean territorial disputes" be inserted in these aims. Its EU partners disagree, but the standoff led EU foreign ministers to put off a decision on the Turkey agreement on Monday.

As one diplomat put it, the ministers were unable to maintain "the exquisite balance between keeping an appetite for reform in Ankara and a sense of comfort in Athens".

Yesterday, Ismail Cem, the Turkish foreign minister, said angrily: "One of the fundamental elements of the architecture of European culture is respect. The EU and some of our friends act like colonial governors, and show disrespect because they want to change certain situations in Turkey."

Turkey got the status of an EU membership candidate only a year ago at the Helsinki summit.

webTitle: Latest robot toy unveiled in Tokyo

fields.headline: RoboKop
fields.standfirst: World's first techno-striker set to score with Japanese fans
fields.trailText: World's first techno-striker set to score with Japanese fans.
fields.body:
Japan's legions of robot lovers were given a new object of desire yesterday when Sony unveiled a techno-baby that can move, groove and play football.

The Sony Dream Robot, or SDR-3X, is a 50cm-tall humanoid that packs a wicked shot and celebrates a goal by going down on its silver knees and throwing its arms up in the air in triumph.

With 24 joints, the anthropomorphic machine is also a smooth mover when it comes to Japan's latest dance craze - the para para, which is a cross between Saturday Night Fever disco style and line dancing.

The robot resembles an astronaut wearing a helmet, gloves and backpack. It has a camera for eyes, microphones for ears, speaker for a mouth and sensors in its torso and feet to maintain balance.

Voice-recognition technology enables it to respond to about 20 verbal instructions and reply with a vocabulary of about two dozen words.

"Hello everybody, my hobby is soccer," the mechanical critter said in an introduction in Tokyo.

SDR-3X is the latest brainchild of Sony's Digital Creatures Laboratory, which produced last year's surprise hit: Aibo, the cyber-puppy. Sony has sold more than 45,000 Aibos and last week unveiled an updated model of the robot-mutt that will go on sale at £1,000 a head.

Sony has yet to decide on a price for SDR-3X, which shares much of the same technology as Aibo, but a prototype is said to have cost as much as a car.

Toshi Doi, president of the Digital Creatures Laboratory, said robots had considerable commercial potential because they would soon be able to help with housework.

"In about five years' time, most entertainment robots are going to be humanoid types," Mr Doi said. "And there will be less distinction between entertainment robots and those carrying out useful tasks."

Japan has surged ahead in developing humanoids and mechanical animals for entertainment and welfare.

Last week, Honda unveiled the world's most advanced anthropomorphic robot, Asimo, which is capable of extremely smooth movement as well as face identity and voice recognition.

Matsushita is developing a line of techno-pets that will provide company and give medical advice to elderly people living alone.

NEC is working on a sophisticated egg-shaped messenger robot that will roll around the home passing on email messages.

But SDR-3X comes closest to a sporting robot.

Next year, Japan will host the first international robot games, where SDR-3X will be looking to put its victory celebrations into practice.

Matsushita is developing a line of techno-pets that will provide company and give medical advice to elderly people living alone. NEC is working on a sophisticated egg-shaped messenger robot that will roll around the home passing on email messages. But SDR-3X comes closest to a sporting robot. Next year, Japan will host the first international robot games, where SDR-3X will be looking to put its victory celebrations into practice.

webTitle: Peru will vote in caretaker president

fields.headline: Peru will vote in caretaker president
fields.trailText: The Peruvian congress was expected last night to confirm the opposition speaker Valentin Paniagua as the country's interim president, filling the vacuum left by the abrupt departure of President Alberto Fujimori.
fields.body:
The Peruvian congress was expected last night to confirm the opposition speaker Valentin Paniagua as the country's interim president, filling the vacuum left by the abrupt departure of President Alberto Fujimori.

Mr Fujimori, fleeing a corruption scandal, ended his 10-year rule on Monday with a letter of resignation to Lima from Tokyo, where he is staying.

A caretaker president will be appointed to oversee the transition to a new government and ensure that elections in April are free and fair.

Congress voted yesterday to accept the resignation of the first vice-president, Francisco Tudela, removing him from the line of succession.

The second vice-president, Ricardo Marquez, who would have been in line under the constitution, resigned several hours after Mr Fujimori.

Mr Tudela said he would have accepted the interim presidency but denied planning to run for president in 2001. His departure left the way clear for Mr Paniagua to be declared president once the congress decides how to deal with Mr Fujimori's resignation. Congress must decide whether to accept his resignation or sack him for "moral unfitness".

Mr Paniagua, 63, was voted in as speaker on November 16 as the first member of the opposition to hold that post for more than eight years. A veteran lawmaker and former minister in two previous administrations of President Fernando Belaunde, he is seen as a safe pair of hands to steer the country through a difficult electoral period.

However, he has virtually no political base of his own - his Popular Action party has only three seats in a 120-seat house - and his power depends on maintaining support from a fragmented congress.

The swing vote is in the hands of a group of independents, including defectors from government benches who were suspected of links to Mr Fujimori's disgraced spy chief Vladimir Montesinos. Mr Fujimori called elections after footage showed Mr Montesinos apparently bribing an opposition congressman.

fields.headline: Red Cross says fighters edging into all-out war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A day of bombs and gunfire rocked the fortress-like Jewish outposts of the Gaza Strip yesterday, as Palestinian militants stepped up their attacks to drive out the settlers.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Gaza and  Peter Capella in Geneva
fields.body:
A day of bombs and gunfire rocked the fortress-like Jewish outposts of the Gaza Strip yesterday, as Palestinian militants stepped up their attacks to drive out the settlers.

The morning after Israeli gunboats and attack helicopters pounded Gaza City in retaliation for the bombing of a school bus of Jewish settlers, the deadly cycle of vengeance resumed.

The Red Cross warned from its Geneva headquarters that the conflict had reached a crossroads and appealed to Israel and the Palestinians to stop targeting civilians and taking reprisals against them.

Angelo Gnaedinger, the senior Red Cross delegate for the Middle East, said: "We are, both in political and humanitarian terms, at a crossing."

The use of "extreme and heavy weaponry" such as attack helicopters was, he warned, bringing events "to the brink of outright warfare".

As the people of Gaza City picked their way through rubble and glass to take stock of the damage of the night before, armed militants unleashed their wrath against the isolated groups of Jewish settlers.

"It's the Arab way, you see," said one Palestinian commuter, craning to hear the car radio of a nearby taxi. "If they kill one of us, we have to kill 10 of them."

By noon, two Palestinian men had been shot dead near the Jewish settlement of Gush Katif: one had been trying to detonate a bomb at an important road junction; the second, a policeman, opened fire at Israeli troops at Kfar Darom, the Jewish settlement where Monday's bus bombing took place.

Hours later, as Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, was visiting an army base in the Gaza area an Israeli man, aged 18, was shot in the head by Palestinians who opened up on a settler convoy. Another Israeli was wounded last night in two explosions in the same area.

Yesterday's attacks may not dent the resolve of the 6,500 Jewish settlers determined to stay in Gaza despite the bitter resentment of more than 1m Arabs in this in this sandy Palestinian territory. The settlers who control Gaza's scarce water resources and best land enjoy the fruits of a lucrative agriculture industry - but for Israel, their presence is becoming an increasingly costly proposition.

Although Gaza was the focus of yesterday's violence, in the West Bank there was no let-up in the bloodshed that has killed nearly 250 people in the last eight weeks. A Palestinian teenager was killed, shot in the chest by Israeli soldiers at Tulkarm. Another Palestinian was killed in Jenin.

The potential for further bloodshed loomed even larger after some leading Palestinian figures proclaimed the peace process "clinically dead". In Ramallah, the Palestinian Authority announced that in areas where it has jurisdiction its 40,000 policemen were now under orders to protect protesters from Israeli fire.

There have been dozens of instances where Palestinian police have fired on Israeli soldiers or ambushed them, but yesterday's directive added a dangerous new element.

"We are in the same trench with our people on one front against the Israelis," Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, general secretary of the authority, declared. "Our policemen will now use their guns in self-defence in areas under our full sovereignty. They have the right to respond."

For Gazans, who spent a terrifying night in total darkness, waiting for the clatter of the helicopters to fade, daylight brought the realisation that Israel's punishment could have been even more deadly. Only one man was killed, and among the 60 hurt, most suffered relatively minor injuries.

At the wretched jumble of cement houses that makes up the densely packed Jabaliya refugee camp, missiles had punched a hole in every one of the barracks of the training school for Yasser Arafat's elite Force 17 guard.

In the refugee housing, a missile in the adjacent alley shattered the corrugated roof of Sohail Fahmi el-Hassani's home, and sent shards of asbestos hurtling into the living room. Three of his nine children were cut when the roof caved in. "What were they aiming at? There are no military positions in this area," said the unemployed plasterer, his frightened seven-year-old son clinging to his legs.

The damage was relatively limited among his neighbours, but the fury was intense.

"We want to tell Mr Barak and Mr Clinton: "Why kill my children, and my brother, and all the other children, why?" said Abla Khatib, a school teacher.

fields.headline: Egypt pulls its ambassador out
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Egypt recalled its ambassador from Tel Aviv yesterday as a protest at Israel's shelling of Gaza.
fields.body:
Egypt recalled its ambassador from Tel Aviv yesterday as a protest at Israel's shelling of Gaza.

The foreign minister, Amr Moussa, said the move was a result of "Israel's aggression against the Palestinian people, and its intentional excessive use of force".

Foreign ministry sources said no decision had been taken on how long the ambassador, Mohammed Bassyouni would be kept in Cairo.

The same sources maintained that the recall was only a first step, "as Egypt now is conducting a comprehensive review of the whole situation in light of Israel's violent policy and the escalation in the use of force."

In 1979 Egypt became the first Arab country to sign a peace treaty with Israel, bringing accusations from neighbours that Cairo had put self-interest before regional solidarity. The past two months of violence between Israelis and Palestinians has again exposed Egypt to such criticism.

"It is becoming more and more embarrassing for Egypt to maintain full diplomatic relations with Israel," Hussein Amin, a former Egyptian ambassador to Algeria, conceded yesterday.

President Hosni Mubarak had resisted pressure by hardline Arab states - such as Syria and Iraq - to sever ties with Israel since the new Palestinian uprising started more than seven weeks ago.

Shortly before hosting an Arab summit on October 21, Mr Mubarak said he was opposed to breaking relations because communications with Israel should be kept open.

When Cairo cut ties in 1982 to protest at Israel's invasion of Lebanon, he said, dialogue with Israeli officials was difficult. The Egyptian ambassador at that time stayed in Cairo for eight months.

Yesterday, Israel's foreign minister, Shlomo Bin-Ami, said it was not considering any retaliatory recall of its ambassador in Cairo.

Jordan, the only other Arab state to have signed a peace treaty with Israel, is maintaining relations with Tel Aviv, saying its contacts are aimed at benefiting the Palestinian side in eventual peace talks.

But Jordan has signalled its displeasure by refraining from sending its newly appointed ambassador to Israel.

On Sunday, an Israeli diplomat in Amman was shot and slightly wounded.

Leaders at the Arab summit in Cairo last month threatened to intensify measures gradually against Israel if the violence continued.

Oman, Morocco, Tunisia and Qatar - among the few Arab countries who responded to US pressure to establish ties with Israel to encourage the Israeli public to support peace - had already decided to close low-level representation offices in Tel Aviv, and Israel's similar offices in their countries.

Mauritania is now the only Arab country maintaining normal diplomatic ties.

Mustafa Kamel el-Sayed, a political science professor at Cairo University, said in an interview yesterday that Egypt's decision was unlikely to alter Israel's policy towards the Palestinians.

"This decision will mainly satisfy Egyptian and Arab public opinion which has been calling for such a step," he said.

Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, said on a visit to Gaza: "I am not, of course, happy about the fact that Egypt has decided to recall the ambassador and I express my hope that it will be for a short time."

Egypt, he went on, "has a role in the peace process, a positive role, and I do not think that the recall of the ambassador ... contributes to continuation of this positive role".

But Professor Sayed argued that in reality Israel would not feel too bothered by the actions of the Egyptian leaders "because of the strong support it is getting from the United States and Europe".

In the longer term, however, Prof Sayed predicted, "Israel is not just jeopardising its prospects of reaching peace with Palestinians, but with the whole Arab world".

"After we all saw live on television Israeli missiles raining houses of innocent Palestinian civilians, we can only expect an escalation of violence by angry people all over the Arab world, regardless of the stands of their governments and their appeals for calm."

webTitle: Gore should give up if court rules for Bush, says Democrat

fields.headline: Gore should give up if court rules for Bush, says Democrat
fields.standfirst:
Gore allies say ruling should end contest

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Gore allies say ruling should end contest.
fields.body:
Al Gore's allies yesterday signalled that the US vice-president would come under immediate pressure to abandon the White House contest as early as today if the Florida supreme court rules in favour of George W Bush on the two-week-old disputed election.

As all sides in the battle for victory in Florida tensely awaited the court's crucial ruling yesterday, a senior Gore ally said on US television that a judgment in favour of Mr Bush could mark the end of the road for Mr Gore in his efforts to take the 25 Florida electoral college votes that hold the key to the White House.

Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a Democrat, said that he had spoken to Mr Gore after Monday's court process in Tallahassee. He said Mr Gore had told him that the process had been fair and that he was "optimistic that the court's going to make a judgment that both sides are going to be able to trust".

If the verdict goes against Mr Gore, Mr Kerrey said he would join fellow Democrats such as Senator John Breaux of Louisiana and former Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia in pressing the vice-president to end further legal challenges to the November 7 election.

Asked if a ruling against the Gore campaign in the supreme court should be the end of the challenges, Mr Kerrey said: "I don't disagree with that at all."

The issue now, he added, was whether allies of Mr Bush would do the same for their man if the court rules in favour of Mr Gore. "He [Bush] has painted himself into a corner by saying that what's going on is election fraud, stealing the election, irresponsible statements about the military votes."

Mr Kerrey, a decorated Vietnam war veteran, accused the Bush campaign of "making reckless and wrong charges" about Mr Gore's fitness to be America's commander-in-chief after Bush aides at the weekend accused Democratic lawyers of trying to exclude overseas military votes from the recount process.

There were few clues yesterday about the timing or the content of the seven-member court's vital ruling. With both sides in the Florida argument on tenterhooks as the judges reviewed the law, a court spokesman in Tallahassee said: "There's no timetable at the present time.

"Our staff has been working full time," Craig Waters said. "I left here late last night and there were many lights on in the lawyers' offices. The work has been going on continuously. We are putting in an extraordinary effort in this particular case."

While the judges weighed up whether to instruct officials to await the results of hand recounts in three south Florida counties, officials in the counties spent another day counting the ballot papers.

Mr Gore had picked up 166 net votes in the three recounts by midday yesterday, not enough to threaten Mr Bush's statewide lead of 930 votes.

In Broward county, with 554 of 609 precincts recounted, Mr Gore had gained a net 117 votes. In Palm Beach county, with 104 of 531 precincts counted, Mr Gore had a net gain of just three. In the third and largest county, Miami-Dade, Mr Gore's net gain was 46 votes after officials completed counting 67 of the 614 local precincts.

In Broward county, the only Republican on the three-person election supervisory board said she was resigning from her post. "I feel like I'm incarcerated, with lunch and dinner brought into me and six attorneys sitting across from me the entire day," Jane Carroll complained.

Florida governor Jeb Bush named Judge Robert Rosenberg to replace Ms Carroll.

fields.headline: Passnotes
fields.standfirst: No: 1766 Eleanor of Aquitaine
fields.trailText: No: 1766 Eleanor of Aquitaine
fields.body:
Age, for £1,000: That's easy. Everyone in Fulham knows she was born in 1122.

Appearance: Extraordinarily beautiful, but you will have to take my word for it as 12th-century paparazzi were remarkably inept and no authenticated pictures survive.

Status: £1m quiz question.

Sorry? Don't play dumb. I know what you were doing on Monday evening.

I thought she was an old queen. But who was she married to?

Give me a clue. Was it Henry I, Henry II, Louis VII, or Charles the Weird?

Henry II? Good try (good enough to win a million, in fact), but it's a trick question. She was actually married to Henry II of England and Louis VII of France, though not at the same time.

How did she manage that? Eleanor was quite a woman. She married the king of France and went on the second crusade with him in 1147. But an affair with her uncle, Raymond of Poitiers, put paid to that union and she got hitched to Henry II instead.

Complicated. Wait till you hear this. She bore Henry eight children, but in 1173 plotted with three of her sons to overthrow her husband, whose infidelity she resented. The revolt failed and Henry locked her up for 15 years.

Relate couldn't help? Sadly not. Henry died in 1189, Eleanor was released and spent much of the next decade governing the country as her lionhearted son, Richard, went crusading.

What a gel. One in a million. She rode across the Pyrenees in her 70s and was still defending Aquitaine against the forces of her grandson, Arthur of Brittany, at 80.

Is that your final answer ? No, she died at 82 and is entombed at the monastery of Fontevrault in Anjou (pictured).

Not to be confused with: Camilla of Aquascutum.

Do say: "Exit pursued by a tabloid reporter."

Don't say: "Wasn't One Foot in the Grave marvellous."

webTitle: Where were you on the day Thatcher quit?

fields.headline: Where were you on the day she quit?
fields.standfirst:
Ten years ago today, Margaret Thatcher resigned. She had been prime minister for 11 extraordinary years, and whether you adored her or detested her, it was electrifying - one of those few moments in life that you are unlikely to forget. This is how some of us remember it

Special report: the Thatcher era
fields.trailText:
Ten years ago today,
Margaret Thatcher
resigned. She had
been prime minister
for 11 extraordinary
years, and whether
you adored her or
detested her, it was
electrifying - one of
those few moments in
life that you are
unlikely to forget. Read
is how some of us
remember it.
fields.body:
Linda Jenkins, 50, Retired secretary from Didsbury
I was in a pub in Didsbury called the Barley Corn when the news came through on the television. Everyone shouted "Hurrah!" and I stood up and said, "How dare you! She's the best thing that ever happened to this country."

She'd been hounded on the question of Europe for months. People were tired of her handbagging the pro-Europeans, but I said, hit them harder. I felt very sad, like we were losing a national figure whose importance we wouldn't fully appreciate until she had gone. Britain was going to the dogs before she came along. Thatcher and Gorbachev freed a lot of the world and he got a bad deal in the end, too.

I'm afraid I never forgave Heseltine for the way he treated her. You realised, that week, how terribly vulnerable she was; that she was, in some sense, an ordinary woman, a mother who had needed to run the family home sternly.

Ken Loach, 64, Film director
I was in a car going back to a flat we've got in Chiswick. I remember it must have been how people felt at the end of the war - street parties and people singing songs to a piano in the street. I knew the malign influence would carry on, but there was a wonderful feeling of caps in the air.

Posy Simmonds, 55, Illustrator from London
I had been out to lunch that afternoon and was slightly merry as it had been a long one. I did feel guilty though, as I should have been in the studio working that afternoon, which I set about doing in the evening. It wasn't until I was sitting at my desk feeling guilty and merry that I heard the news on the radio. My sentiments were of both surprise and rejoicing - which led to me upsetting the paint water on my desk.

Andrew De Rosa, 39, Manchester city council worker
I was driving along the Embankment in London, coming out of Chelsea. I was the general manager of the Dominion theatre at that time, and was on my way to work. There was a newsflash on the radio and I rang a friend who promptly burst into tears. This was someone who had been on the platform with the lady. We didn't get much done in the office that week. Work stopped. Everyone was shocked. I thought she gave one of the best performances of her career, that week. They had a televised censor motion in the House of Commons and we were glued to it in the office. Thatcher was... serene.

Norman Tebbit , 69, Ex-Conservative party chairman
I knew she was going because I'd been with her late the previous night helping her to write her great resignation speech. In the morning I was at the House of Commons being badgered by colleagues to stand in the election to succeed her. I had two thoughts in mind - three actually: I'd decided to leave front-line politics; by standing I might have let Heseltine in; and the third thought was I'd said quite firmly to a number of people, "Who in their right mind would want to lead the sort of people that had just overthrown Margaret Thatcher?" I think I said it in more colourful terms - not suitable for a family newspaper.

Alan Pearson, 33, Labourer from Hull
I remember seeing her crying, and gloating over it. I thought she was making a bloody mess of the country, although she was better than William Hague, who's useless.

It wasn't much of a surprise, because I'd thought she was going be pushed out four years before. It was long overdue, because she was all for the rich, and didn't give much for the poor. I had a rich boss then, drove a Rolls-Royce, and I remember he was very arrogant about my opinion of her. He said she was doing good for the country, but she was only doing good for the likes of him.

Patrick Marber 37, Actor and playwright
I was in bed, asleep, in my then girlfriend's flat. She came rushing in and exclaimed, "Thatcher's gone! She's fucking gone!" I'm fairly sure she proceeded to dance a merry little jig at the end of the bed. Regarding Mrs Thatcher's demise: I felt joy. And then some pity. And then more joy.

Lemn Sissay, 33, Poet
I was working at a community publishing house in Manchester at the time. I was glad she'd gone, but when she came on the news she suddenly looked like an old lady. There was an initial feeling of pleasure that she was going, and of course she had to go, but then it hit my humanitarian self and I felt sorry for her. Everything that had made her what she was had been taken from her. She was like a grandmother looking back at her children who'd grown up and hated her for what she'd done.

Tracey Emin, 26, Artist
I was walking through Elephant and Castle and I looked up at the buses, and people were banging on the windows and going: "Yeah!" And I noticed people were jumping up and down in the street. It was the first sign of the resignation, and people looked so happy. I felt absolute jubilation.

Peter Tatchell, 48, Gay rights campaigner
I was at home making a cup of tea when I turned on the radio and heard the news. For a moment I stood frozen, stunned with disbelief. Then I threw the tea down the sink and poured myself a triple scotch in celebration. After all the years of arrogant leadership, attacks on civil liberties and the crushing of the labour movement, it was a glorious moment when she got her comeuppance.

On a personal level I did feel sorry for Mrs Thatcher when she left Downing Street in tears. There's no doubt the way she was treated by her own ministers and MPs was an act of staggering betrayal. She brought them the most successful Tory government of the century and they stabbed her in the back. But politically I could not feel even a whisper of sympathy. Her suffering was nothing compared to the misery her government inflicted on millions of people.

Mo Shaw, 32, Registrar from Manchester
I was an actor back then, and touring with a company called Dodgy Clutch. We were doing a production of An Elephant Called Slowly in Hexham. We were in the hotel bar, watching the telly, when the news broke. I thought, "Oh, brilliant." I was the only one taking much of an interest; no one else was bothered.

Carol Thatcher, 47, Daughter and writer
I did actually know that my mother was planning to resign the night before. After 10 years you always wonder how it's going to end - and I don't think anyone foresaw it would end like that - but once you're in it you're in it, and there's not much you can do about it. I remember saying to Mum: "Welcome to the freelance club." I think that it was not until she walked out for the last time that it became real. I was at my home in Fulham when it was announced, and I remember being very practical about it. I had organised for a bunch of people to come for supper and they started to phone and ask if they should come, and I said yes of course you must come.

Lauren Booth, 32, Journalist
I know exactly where I was, and the very second I was told. I was in Australia in a pub, and one of the guys came in and said, "Oh, have you heard, Margaret Thatcher has been kicked out?" And my boyfriend, now husband, just looked at me and said, "No way!" We just went berserk. We bought the whole place drinks and were up until 2am; they thought we were mad. It was as if we had won the World Cup. Our only sadness was that we weren't there to witness the tears.

When she left it felt like the wicked witch of the West had been got rid of, because it had felt like she was absolutely indestructible. I had sat up for three successive elections and almost given up hope.

Margaret Bairstow, Pensioner from Preston
I was sitting at home watching the television and I was shocked by the way she had been treated. My husband was gloating, and still is, but all I could think of was what a great time of change we were entering, and how uncertain the future was. I thought she was treated very unfairly. She didn't deserve to be pushed out like that after the service she'd given to the country.

Katie Hickman, Author
I was travelling around Mexico with a circus, doing the research for what became my book Travels with a Circus. I tried to tune in to the BBC World Service to hear what Mrs T was going to do, but the reception was too bad, so I listened to Mexican radio, in company with members of the circus - and was very amused by their completely amazed reaction to the news that the person who was to take over from Mrs T, John Major, was the son of a circus performer - they couldn't talk about anything else.

Ian McEwan, 52, Novelist
I was being interviewed by a foreign - maybe Danish - television company in a hotel near the Tower of London. Her picture came up on a television monitor and I stopped the interview and turned up the volume. I felt a certain grim satisfaction, but the film crew were unimpressed by the news and a little dismissive. They provided a useful perspective. It wasn't the end of an era.

Dr AC Grayling, 52, Academic and writer
I was at home, glued avidly to the television, and when she announced that she was going I went delirious with joy and literally danced about the room. Subsequent footage of her biting her lip and wiping away tears as she was chauffered from 10 Downing Street did nothing to soften me: I saw in those tears a contemptibly self-regarding and very pale reflection of the anxiety, difficulty, and often real suffering of the millions who lost jobs, opportunities, local libraries, the protection of a caring society, their homes when mortgages went through the roof, or their chance of a home when council houses were sold off - and much besides. In short, I thought only of the cost of her "no such thing as society" war on human lives in the name of market economics, and rejoiced mightily that the lecturing, hectoring, callous succuba had been forced to go at last. A very good riddance!

Charlie Whelan, 46, Journalist
I was in my office at the Engineering Union and a friend of mine rang me from the Press Association, and I thought "Great!" Then I thought, "Oh no. It means we're going to have more of the Tories."

Oona King, 33, Labour MP
I remember exactly what I was doing, exactly. I was tapping into a VDU screen in Vauxhall, because I was working as a VDU operator, and the tea trolley woman came round at 9.30am and said, "Margaret Thatcher has resigned." Everyone said, "Really, oh, goodness," and went back to tapping, but I said to my boss, "I have to go to Downing Street." She wouldn't let me leave until my lunchbreak, so I took my lunch at 9.30am. I ran from Vauxhall to Downing Street just to see it happening. It was the next morning, I think, when she actually left. I made a poster - the only poster I have ever made, and I still have it at home - and it said: "I am 23 years old and I have waited exactly half my life for today. Goodbye Maggie." I was so happy that that woman was not going to be prime minister any more.

Barrie Rutter, 53, Theatre producer
I had the drinks laid out in preparation. And then the news came through and I couldn't drink them, because I had to go and pick the kids up from school. I was frustrated until the evening. I wanted to see the old cow go, massively. As soon as I woke up the next morning with a hangover, though, my regret was that a lot of what she had put in place would remain and come back to haunt us - which it has with Railtrack, because she led the privatisation initiative. A lot of her minions are still in place.

I didn't feel sympathy for her when she came out of Downing Street. Like a lot of other people, I screamed at the television, "Suffer, baby, suffer." I have respect for her, in certain ways - who hasn't? - but she has nothing in her that represents human charm.

Joyce Quarry, 50, Publisher from east London
It was my 40th birthday present, that was! I can't remember exactly where I was. I had some wonderful 40th birthday presents, but that was the best. I just remember feeling extremely happy. I think it meant a return to human values. I felt the Iron Maiden title suited her very well, because I thought she had very little emotion and very little compassion, and I hoped that we would see a return to values.

Anthony Wilson, 50, Founder of Factory Records
My prime memory was of cheering Peter York on the Late Show. It made the Late Show worthwhile. He called her a Maoist. I remember he did a wonderful thing with his hands, he said, "Whenever she saw an organisation," and then he stretched out his arms as if to indicate the building they were in, "she pulled it down." Another thing I wonder is how many lefties - and I'm a lefty - look back now with misty eyes on the enterprise allowance scheme, that great nurturer of the young.

Jack Jones, 87, Pensioners leader
I was very pleased of course. It was clear she was out of favour, and I wasn't all that enamoured of the Tory party. From the point of view of pensioners and Britain in general, she was an absolute disaster. But I didn't think of it as a new start, because all the traditions she had and all the people around her were still in place. Thatcher's end didn't mean the end of Thatcherism - we're still suffering from it now.

Harriet Harman, 50, Labour MP
Firstly I felt delighted that someone who'd done so much damage had come unstuck. Then hard on the heels of that came the realisation that it might save the Tories from damage. I was in the House of Commons when I heard, walking from one end of the committee corridor to the other, and I bumped into a crowd of Tory MPs. They were outside the office where the vote was being counted. They were all jubilating, and I joined them momentarily until I realised that a change in the Conservative leadership might cost us the next election.

Faith Brown, 53, Comic
I was at the BBC and was doing a sketch at the time as Mrs Thatcher. It was funny because I had delivered this line, "I may have my faults, but being wrong isn't one of them." How ironic. My heart sank when I heard the news, because I did a lot of work as Thatcher. Thank God I have other people that I can do. Though I still do her quite a lot in America. She's still very popular there. I was a great admirer of Thatcher, and I think she had a bit of a raw deal, to be honest. She was great when she first started, but then I think she started to believe her own publicity. By the end she was starting to resemble her own parody.

Steve Bell, 49, Cartoonist
I was sitting at my desk at home doing something or other, and somebody from the Grauniad rang up and said, "Did you know, she's gone, she's resigned," and I said, "Oh wonderful." Later on they asked me to do a drawing about it. I remember because it was one of the first big political drawings I did for the Guardian. It was of her being carried on a pole by Heseltine, Hurd and Major, in the guise of crocodiles. I didn't worry about life getting less colourful. I was so glad to hear that she had gone, the old cow. I had been drawing her for 10 years, longer than that, and you can only go on saying the same thing about someone for so long.

I was bemused by John Major, I remember that. I didn't know anything about him. But I had drawn him at a party conference a few weeks before and the thing I noticed was the amazing prehensile upper lip.

Lord Tim Bell, 59, Former Thatcher adviser
I was at a dinner party in Hampstead with Mark Thatcher and Nick Lloyd [the editor of the Express] when I heard. It was the night before the official announcement and I left the party and went straight to Downing Street. I couldn't tell anyone why as it was still a secret. I felt devastated. It was the end of an era. None of us had wanted her to resign and it was devastating to realise she had made that decision. I don't know how to explain what was going through my mind. It was a terrible end to a fantastic period of government, and it left you wondering what was going to happen next. The next day in the office, there was a great deal of gloom and sadness and anger at how stupid the Conservative party was to have done this.

Glenda Jackson, 64, Labour MP
To the second, to the minute. I remember it was thrilling. I'm living the joy of it even as I'm speaking to you. I had to be on parliament green, for some charity thing. I came up on the tube and the London Evening Standard was on the street and the front page was SHE'S GONE in huge capitals, and a photo of herself. So I opened the paper and was reading it as I walked along the platform, chortling all the way. Coming towards me were a group of grannnies down from the north on a day trip, I assume. One of them looked at my Standard and said, "Is it true, is it true?" and I said, "Yes, it must be," and she said, "She's gone, she's gone," and they all start cheering. At which point the Queen Mother drives past and they turn from cheering at Margaret having gone to cheering and waving at the Queen Mother. Just heaven. Glorious. It was was worth the 11 years just to have that. Well maybe not.

Jake Fior, 36, Bookshop owner from London
I was working in Camden, selling books from home. I can't remember very much, apart from relief that the woman had finally gone. She didn't go without a bit of a fight, did she? There was a kind of a rearguard action from the Tory grandees which actually got rid of her as I remember. I was very pleased. She'd single-handedly kind of destroyed most of the elements that I admired in this country, and I was very glad to see the back of her. I think hers was the most corrupt government actually, because she had such a majority for such a long time, they'd really become very blase.

Peter Hitchens, 49, Writer
I was in my flat in Moscow, where I was a correspondent for the Express. I can't remember if I heard the news on the World Service or in a phonecall from the desk. I was very surprised but I was much more worried about what was happening in the Soviet Union at the time and had been immersed in Russian politics for about 18 months. British politics seemed rather trivial in comparison. It certainly wasn't a Kennedy-esque moment and I don't remember feeling particularly sad.

Jeremy Brill, 40, London music shop owner
I was working in Peckham, because I was a teacher there at the time, and someone came and told me over the fence. What did I do at that moment? I think I whooped with some great excitement! I think there was much whooping. Whooping combined with disbelief really. I just thought "God, it's about time. Why's it taken so long?"

 Interviews by Esther Addley, Laura Barton, Emma Brockes, Simon Hattenstone, Angelique Chrisafis and Annalena McAfee

Glenda Jackson, 64, Labour MP To the second, to the minute. I remember it was thrilling. I'm living the joy of it even as I'm speaking to you. I had to be on parliament green, for some charity thing. I came up on the tube and the London Evening Standard was on the street and the front page was SHE'S GONE in huge capitals, and a photo of herself. So I opened the paper and was reading it as I walked along the platform, chortling all the way. Coming towards me were a group of grannnies down from the north on a day trip, I assume. One of them looked at my Standard and said, "Is it true, is it true?" and I said, "Yes, it must be," and she said, "She's gone, she's gone," and they all start cheering. At which point the Queen Mother drives past and they turn from cheering at Margaret having gone to cheering and waving at the Queen Mother. Just heaven. Glorious. It was was worth the 11 years just to have that. Well maybe not. Jake Fior, 36, Bookshop owner from London I was working in Camden, selling books from home. I can't remember very much, apart from relief that the woman had finally gone. She didn't go without a bit of a fight, did she? There was a kind of a rearguard action from the Tory grandees which actually got rid of her as I remember. I was very pleased. She'd single-handedly kind of destroyed most of the elements that I admired in this country, and I was very glad to see the back of her. I think hers was the most corrupt government actually, because she had such a majority for such a long time, they'd really become very blase. Peter Hitchens, 49, Writer I was in my flat in Moscow, where I was a correspondent for the Express. I can't remember if I heard the news on the World Service or in a phonecall from the desk. I was very surprised but I was much more worried about what was happening in the Soviet Union at the time and had been immersed in Russian politics for about 18 months. British politics seemed rather trivial in comparison. It certainly wasn't a Kennedy-esque moment and I don't remember feeling particularly sad. Jeremy Brill, 40, London music shop owner I was working in Peckham, because I was a teacher there at the time, and someone came and told me over the fence. What did I do at that moment? I think I whooped with some great excitement! I think there was much whooping. Whooping combined with disbelief really. I just thought "God, it's about time. Why's it taken so long?"  Interviews by Esther Addley, Laura Barton, Emma Brockes, Simon Hattenstone, Angelique Chrisafis and Annalena McAfee

webTitle: Ministers may sacrifice bill to aid Trimble

fields.headline: Ministers may sacrifice bill to aid Trimble
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is preparing to offer a major concession to Ulster unionists by abandoning a parliamentary bill which would have allowed the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, to sit simultaneously in the British and Irish parliaments.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is preparing to offer a major concession to Ulster unionists by abandoning a parliamentary bill which would have allowed the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, to sit simultaneously in the British and Irish parliaments.

As London and Dublin intensify their efforts to save the peace process from collapse, Downing Street was on the verge last night of delivering the last rites to the bill which has been condemned by Tories and Unionists as "sinister".

The government's u-turn over the disqualification bill, which comes after peers voted down the measure on Monday night, will be warmly welcomed by Ulster Unionists who believe it was the product of a secret deal between Downing Street and Sinn Fein. The bill would have cleared the way for Mr Adams, the MP for West Belfast, to stand for election to the Irish parliament in Dublin.

Downing Street insisted last night that it was premature to say that the bill would be killed off. It is understood, however, that the bill will not make it onto the statute book before the end of the current session of parliament next month after the Lords defeat on Monday night.

Ministers will hope that jettisoning the bill, which has been so roundly condemned by the Ulster Unionists, will boost the position of the party's leader, David Trimble, who is fighting off a challenge from party hardliners.

The government is involved in frantic negotiations to broker a deal between the UUP and Sinn Fein over IRA disarmament to prevent Mr Trimble from walking out of Northern Ireland's power sharing executive in January.

Mr Blair will step up his efforts tomorrow when he holds a "mid-air summit" with his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern. The two leaders will discuss the peace process when Mr Ahern joins the prime minister on his plane to a Balkans summit in the Croatian capital Zagreb. The tentative plan will involve give and take on both sides. The two governments will step up the pressure on the IRA by insisting that republicans must live up to the commitment to negotiate with the international decommissioning body.

However, Dublin wants the British government to offer reassurances to republicans that it will implement the Patten report on policing. The Northern Ireland police bill passed its final stage in the Commons last night, to the dismay of nationalists who believe that it falls short of the Patten report.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
After years of witnessing the poor, undeserving paparazzi being hounded by camera-shy American celebrities, the boot has finally been snugly transferred to the other foot with the news that Barbara Streisand and husband James Brolin are being sued by freelance snapper Wendall Wall, after the photographer was arrested for allegedly stalking the couple earlier this year.

In a rather florid-sounding suit filed at LA Superior Court last week, Wall is claiming the entire ruckus was engineered "with evil motive and intent, and in callous, reckless and wanton disregard" of his civil rights. The original incident occurred on January 8th in Malibu, when Streisand and Brolin alerted the police to Wall having - according to their version of events - pursued them throughout the day.

The hapless shutterbug was immediately arrested, only to be released without charge after prosecutors concluded there was a "lack of evidence of a credible threat" to the couple's well-being. Next stop, perhaps predictably, said lawsuit, which cites the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department as "co-conspirators" in both the arrest and the subsequent hiking of bail from $150,000 to $1m. Streisand's legal team have yet to comment; Wall is now seeking a $25,000 civil penalty from each of the defendants, plus as-yet-unspecified punitive damages...

Elsewhere, busy times for country starlet LeeAnn Rimes, who slapped her record company, Curb, with a federal suit in Dallas last week claiming her contract with them - signed on her behalf by her parents when the singer was twelve - is technically invalid. "We're not saying that [the record company] was taking advantage of her," remarked Rimes's lawyer Tom Rhodus (perish the thought), "but she thinks she can do a lot better. LeeAnn simply wants to be her own person." And don't we all? At press time, the case looks to be heading for an out-of-court settlement...

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Thinking Allowed | Performance On 3
fields.body:
The persistent, and apparently burgeoning, problem of domestic violence comes under the microscope of Laurie Taylor in Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4). He talks to Professor Betsy Stanko of the Royal Holloway College in London, who has spent her career investigating such attacks and the best legal way to deal with them. One frustrating aspect of the professor's research has been that, though each year and across the social spectrum some 10 per cent of women are attacked by their partners, a significant proportion refuse to reveal it.

The remarkable versatility of the BBC Singers is displayed in Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3), a recording of their appearance at last month's Canterbury Festival. The concert draws on the polyphonic splendours of the 1490 Eton Choirbook, including Robert Hacomplaynt's Salve Regina, and also features two specially commissioned contemporary works, Gabriel Jackson's motet saluting St Cecilia and Bo Holten's In Nomine.

fields.headline: No pain, no gain
fields.standfirst: Coronation Street has been censured because of its violence. But for viewers who are used to the excesses of Gladiator, says  Charlie Brooker, the problem these days is that soaps just aren't brutal enough
fields.trailText: Coronation Street has been censured because of its violence. But for viewers who are used to the excesses of Gladiator, says Charlie Brooker, the problem these days is that soaps just aren't brutal enough.
fields.body:
Last week, Coronation Street was accused of sadism. Not because of that aggravating theme tune (the aural equivalent of having half-chewed, week-old Battenburg cake dribbled into your ear canal by a senile grandparent), but because of the bothersome antics of Weatherfield's number one bad guy, Jez Quigley - a seriously unpleasant cross between John "Cold Feet" Thomson and the head Blue Meanie from Yellow Submarine.

The majority of complaints were provoked by a scene in which Quigley attempted to smother Street wideboy Steve McDonald as he lay injured in hospital. Having been confronted with some genuine menace for once, as opposed to the Street's usual pantomime whimsy, a bunch of easily rattled simpletons phoned the ITC in protest. The regulator agreed that, yes, it was all a bit unpleasant wasn't it? Foul Mr Quigley had appeared to "enjoy" inflicting pain, and that simply wouldn't do.

Well, look, he was hurting Steve McDonald for God's sake - an oily, opportunistic skunk so astoundingly unsympathetic that an arthritic priest would can-can for joy at the news of his violent death.

The main thrust of the ITC's condemnation was that Quigley's lurid display of sadistic nastiness might have upset the show's younger viewers - presumably they'll go on to declare that in future, all fictional drug-dealing villains should be played by one of the Chuckle Brothers, in order to lessen any potential trauma.

Still, out of many millions of viewers, only four actually complained, while the rest gawped on in pleasure, drowsily spooning mouthfuls of congealing bolognese into their glistening chops while Quigley eventually sputtered his last, courtesy of a broken rib poking through his lung.

With any luck the success of this unusually bleak Street story line will encourage Granada to crank up the show's violence quota considerably, turning it into something akin to an Alan Bennett adaptation of Fight Club. Even the sponsorship stings could join in the fray: whose heart could fail to be lightened by a sequence in which one of those cheery Cadbury's chocolate proles unexpectedly plunges a shortbread screwdriver into a co-worker's forehead, then jigs with delight as the caramel brains ooze out to slap messily against the marshmallow cobblestones? Well?

If the Street fails to capitalise on its gore-spattered lead, the remaining soaps should seize the initiative and usher back in a golden age of needless violence. Remember Dynasty's machine-gun massacre? Brookside's Jordache stabbing? We deserve to see their like again.

EastEnders should try harder. For starters, they can forget about supposed arch-baddie Nick Cotton. The man simply isn't menacing; he's half as terrifying as an Argos catalogue. Whereas Jez Quigley looked as though he'd enjoy riding an onyx stallion through a field full of groaning, recently-impaled victims before galloping home to bathe in the blood of the fallen, Nick Cotton merely looks like he might, at a push, dispute the price of a dented tin of custard with a supermarket checkout girl while you wait behind him, won dering when he last washed his hair.

Here's what they should do: with a nod to the recent box-office success of Gladiator, they should dig up that drab little garden in the centre of Albert Square and replace it with an immense coliseum in which Walford residents settle their differences. Phil Mitchell is no Russell Crowe, but what a thrill it would be to watch him mercilessly pursuing Sonia around a sand-filled arena, frantically twirling a mace. They could take bets on the BBC website, and donate the proceeds to Children In Need: I'll have a tenner on Barry Evans (trident, net) versus Beppe (twin daggers, shield). And Roy could make an excellent thumbs-up / thumbs-down Caesar figure, although you'd have to shield your eyes if he turned round suddenly and his toga rode up.

Speaking of togas, our soaps could do with more naked flesh too. Sex-crazed Hollyoaks (aka S Club 7 Street) is currently the market leader - it's like watching a group of aroused, anatomically-correct Chapman Brothers dummies jostling in a tube carriage. It recently featured an entirely implausible naturist swimming club, and now both Brookside and EastEnders are to follow, showcasing special "nudity" subplots. Albert Square is set to be rocked by plans for a nude calendar shoot of Queen Vic regulars.

If you're reading this while eating, you'll be delighted to learn the April page features a blistering close-up of a full-frontal Ian Beale sprawling open-legged on a leather sofa. Not really. Still, thank your lucky stars Ethel's dead, or they might have crowned her Miss July. Then again, they still might.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: 8mm | The Last Seduction | Rope | The Boxer
fields.body:
8mm (Joel Schumacher, 1999) 11pm, Sky MovieMax

A low-life wallow from Schumacher, whose jolly-looking Flawless opens next week. This stars Nicolas Cage in world-weary private investigator mode, hired by a widow to find out whether the snuff movie found among her dead husband's possessions is the real thing. The trail through the gutter of LA's hardcore underworld is long and, frankly, sludgy, enlivened by Joaquin Phoenix as the sex-shop assistant who agrees to be the gumshoe's guide, and Peter Stormare's frantic porn-maker.

The Last Seduction (John Dahl, 1994) 10pm, FilmFour

Linda Fiorentino's femme fatale is far, far deadlier than the males in Dahl's dazzling, sexy thriller. On the run from husband Bill Pullman (she's ripped him off after his drugs deal - a small matter of $700,000), she fetches up in a hick town and finds a fall guy in Peter Berg, who for a short time thinks he's struck real lucky. The plot is a series of vicious convolutions, and with the late great JT Walsh involved, it's about as good as modern noir gets.

Rope (Alfred Hitchcock, 1948) 12.15am cine

A Hitchcock experiment in the 10-minute take - an overly self-conscious device, but it's only intermittently tedious. Based on the Leopold-Loeb case, the film stars John Dall and Farley Granger as two gay students who commit murder to demonstrate their superiority. When they serve party drinks from a trunk containing the body, professor James Stewart smells a rat.

The Boxer (Jim Sheridan, 1997) 3am, Sky Premier

This third teaming of Sheridan and Daniel Day-Lewis doesn't pack quite the mighty punch of In The Name Of The Father and the Oscar-winning My Left Foot, but it's a strong, earthy human drama nevertheless. Day-Lewis plays the boxer, a former IRA man picking up the gloves back in Belfast after serving 14 years in prison, trying to set up a non-sectarian club and getting involved with onetime girlfriend Emily Watson: a bleak, hard, ultimately affirmative tale.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What London stallholders are watching onTV
fields.trailText: What London stallholders are watching onTV
fields.body:
Niamh Cross: "I watch some television but my children usually tell me what to watch. They like the soaps and the drama series - it's all EastEnders with Steve and Mel and they turn the sound up very high. I don't like it. Last thing I watched? Michael Barrymore. I think he's smashing, a very talented man, and so good with children. I wish he'd have mine."

Mr R Wooten: "I like a lot of the afternoon programmes, the television keeps me company. I always have it on in the background, you know. I like the quiz shows - keeps the mind going. The Weakest Link? I can't stomach that woman. Anne Robinson - she's so unfair. I like the Hanna Gordon show... Paintbox Challenge - Watercolour Challenge. That's it. Lovely programme. Very good. Makes a change from all that shouting."

Mr Ali: (selling cheap cigarettes) "Er, I'm not sure. Don't use my real name. Do you want some of these? (Proffers packet of cigarettes). I like the cookery programmes, teaches me how to cook... I like... what do they say? Kitchen Goddess... long hair, pretty, looks good... yes! Nichola Lawson! [sic] She is very pretty and I try to learn about English food. I like her. Is she married?"

"David": (selling socks outside a supermarket) "What? TV? I watch a load of crap. I watch awful programmes because that's all that's on - I come back from the pub and it's all DIY or that awful woman's programme... what is it? My wife and her friends love it... Cold Feet, that's it. It's all about relationships, people watch too much about relationships these days. They talk about Men from Mars, Women from Venus and it's a load of balls."

Eric Simon: "I don't like TV presenters. Who? All of them. All the time, very false. Love themselves. Any names? No it really is all of them. Oh, the Big Brother people... they were a load of self-lovers, weren't they?"

 Sin Pattenden spoke to traders on the Holloway Road, North London.
