fields.headline: Oh what a tangled web
fields.trailText: Attachments | Hidden Love | Everyman
fields.body:
The buttons! The buttons! The buttons have to be finished by Thursday! That was the battle cry in the Attachments (BBC2) office as the situation began to look bleak(er) for the internet company where no one does any work. The technology may have advanced and they may swear like troopers but it seems those at seethru.co.uk have learned nothing from The House Of Eliot, where a similar obsession with buttons ended in tears ("Don't be silly, Tilly. You can't feed children on buttons!"), not to mention indigestion.

Of course, buttons are the least of their problems, with every relationship in the office sliding towards disintegration along with the company itself. Nasty Reece was exposed as, um, nasty after he posted webcam footage of him and Zoe the nik-nak queen doing it in the office on the internet. Despite having invited Flirty Fran the Frumpy Flatmate to live with him (instead of with Mike and Luce), Jake still continues to spend every waking hour "at the cinema". One suspects this is code for something since Jake is quite clearly as gay as a lord. That being the case, who knows what's involved in "an after-show discussion".

Brandon - who may have had his tongue cut out in episode five - continues to do wild things with computers and Sophie the lesbian lesbians on, drinking Red Bull and smoking fags (the cigarette kind). And then there are Mike, the dullest but best moisturised man in all of Christendom, and the appropriately-named Luce, whom they should have called Slack Alice and been done with it. So exciting are this lot, they make The House Of Eliot look like The Playboy Mansion.

In a tangentially related incident, Hidden Love (Channel 4) was all about women's relationships with their vibrators. You might not think that such a relationship needed an hour to explain - switch it on and slide it in! (or vice versa) - but that's where you'd be wrong. Ladies have complex connections to their little, and often not so little, battery operated friends, and Hidden Love did its best to explore them without getting all Channel 5. In the main, it succeeded, with a parade of wonderfully candid stories, but Hidden Love? Surely it's more a case of You-Can-Just-See-The-End-Where-The-Batteries-Go-In Love. And the buzzing would give it away too.

Everyman (BBC1) was an altogether more serious but no less watchable documentary. Entitled Carole's Children, it followed those who use contact centres in Leeds after the usually messy breakdown of their family. Carole, who grew up without a father, was determined other children shouldn't miss out on having both parents around even if the couple had split. A bit like bridges in Cold War movies where the Americans and the Russians swap spies, the contact centres act as neutral ground for one parent to bring children to see the other without them having to see their ex-partner.

Weaving Carole's own emotional story with that of the centre users, Everyman was a mature, engaging piece of television which didn't invite judgment or resort to emotional manipulation. With tales like Carole's, and that of the Hargraves family, it was eloquent and honest, and an invitation to further discussion of the difficulties of children from "broken homes".

The Hargraves were in a very difficult, but by no means unusual situation. A heavy-drinking father with a history of violence, Keith was only allowed to see two of his daughters, Juliette and Katherine, at the centre. Like his wife Audrey - but perhaps with less reason - he was eaten up with bitterness and anger and couldn't see why he shouldn't have unsupervised visits. He didn't think that him headbutting his other daughter, Joanne, giving her two black eyes during a fight with Audrey should make a difference since "it was a one-off incident". Not surprisingly, Joanne didn't want to see her father and her father didn't seem overly bothered not to see her.

Audrey, blinded by rage, harboured resentment that Juliette and Katherine wanted to see their father at all. All in all, it was not pleasant, but a situation which is sadly all too common. Had Audrey and Keith "stayed together for the sake of the children", it could have been much worse. While Juliette, especially, yearned for a normal, ideal family, she was too young to realise that, like the Tooth Fairy, there is no such thing. More than anything, Everyman made one lament that making a relationship work isn't an exact science.

fields.headline: Player power shakes Barbour bastion
fields.standfirst:
England team ready to defy coach's 11am deadline for ending strike

England's new strikers
fields.trailText: The final act in the protracted and painful transformation of English rugby union from the preserve of Barboured amateurs into a fully professional business controlled by agents and lawyers took place in a Surrey country club yesterday, when the entire England squad went on strike over a contract dispute and were ordered to pack their bags and go home.
fields.body:
The final act in the protracted and painful transformation of English rugby union from the preserve of Barboured amateurs into a fully professional business controlled by agents and lawyers took place in a Surrey country club yesterday, when the entire England squad went on strike over a contract dispute and were ordered to pack their bags and go home.

After their coach, Clive Woodward, heard that the squad had voted unanimously in a secret ballot to reject the latest pay offer from the Rugby Football Union, and would be withdrawing from Saturday's match against Argentina, he told all 22 players to leave the team's headquarters and to spend the night examining their consciences. Only if they returned for a training session at 11am today would they be considered for selection for the match at Twickenham, for which around 60,000 tickets have been sold. If they do not, he promises to put together a side from whatever resources are available to him.

At yesterday's press conference, Woodward said he felt "betrayed" by players with whom he has worked for the past three years and who, after capturing last season's Six Nations championship, beat Australia, the world champions, last Saturday. "The players had my full support," he said. "I don't think they were being greedy. But after seeing the offer, I can't believe they haven't accepted it."

He was particularly critical of "three or four strong characters" among the senior players. "They've made a huge mistake," he said. "A lot of the younger guys will be driving home now, panicking and wondering what the hell they've just done."

Most of the squad had already left the Pennyhill Park hotel, Bagshot, when an ad hoc committee consisting of three senior players - the present captain, Martin Johnson, and two of his predecessors, Lawrence Dallaglio and Matt Dawson - emerged into the courtyard. Accompanied by Alan Edwards, a PR man better known for advising the Rolling Stones and the Spice Girls, they put their side of the argument to reporters who had gathered expecting to hear nothing more exciting than Woodward's team selection for Saturday's match. Instead the journalists were witnessing the apparent meltdown of the one area in which rugby union, riven in recent years by the stresses imposed by the sudden influx of money from satellite television, had retained its unity.

At the heart of the dispute is a disagreement over the complicated formula determining the balance between fixed match fees and win bonuses stipulated by the four-year deal. Although neither side would be precise about figures, the RFU is offering a split under which the players would earn about £65,000 for winning all this season's eight matches, plus a top-up bonus, and about £25,000 for losing them all. The players, perhaps mindful of the painful experience of watching a Grand Slam win bonus go down the drain against Scotland in the final match of last season, want to raise the proportion represented by the guaranteed match fee.

This income comes on top of regular salaries from their clubs, which range from about £60,000 a year for the least experienced players to perhaps £120,000 for the most senior. Added to all this, for the international players, is a system of payments for intellectual property rights - in other words, for the use of their images as part of sponsorship and advertising deals. This, the RFU say, is expected to swell the players' pot by up to £2m over the four years of the deal.

Johnson read a prepared statement in which the players were highly critical of the way in which the negotiations, described as "frustrating and inconclusive", had been conducted by the "old-fashioned, patronising and arrogant" RFU, and in particular its chief executive, Francis Baron.

Principle

"The issue from the players' side is one of principle," Johnson said, "and their main drive is to bring the sport into the 21st century, and ensure that as performers they get something approaching a fair deal to bring them in line with other sports. Most rugby players earn a salary commensurate with many Premiership soccer players' weekly drawings, so there is no question of greed being a factor here. Our careers are very short and all we are asking is a fair share of the substantial income that these games generate. The players have made attempt after attempt to resolve the situation and we have been met by nothing other than prevarication, excuses and general delaying tactics. We will not be turning back."

The negotiations began in August, six months after the squad had put their collective financial affairs into the hands of CSS Stellar, a sports management company which also supervises the commer cial affairs of the England soccer team and which is largely controlled by former employees of Mark McCormack's International Management Group. On October 26, Baron left a meeting under the impression that he and his board had agreed a deal with CSS's Julian Hill and John Simpson.

Yesterday Hill and Simpson were at Pennyhill Park and said that although they had indeed recommended the RFU's offer to the squad, it was the players themselves who decided to turn it down and go back in search of improved terms. The agents also pointed out that although the required shift in the balance between fee and bonus payments would not affect the RFU's budget, the players were unhappy to be receiving a total sum equivalent to only 5% of the RFU's receipts from internationals, estimated at £2m a match.

The first serious rumblings of the dispute were evident to the team management early last week, a few days before the match against Australia. Johnson called Woodward to tell him that, at the next day's press conference and open training session, the squad would be staging a protest against the RFU's apparent unwillingness to resume negotiations by wearing their shirts and tops inside out, so that the sponsors' names could not be seen.

Woodward met the players the following morning and told them that if they refrained from "pratting about" in the build-up to the match, he would arrange a meeting between their representatives and the RFU management board. "I gave them my word on that, and they agreed to it," Woodward said. "I asked to put it out of their minds and concentrate on the match, which they did, with the results we all saw. My words to the players then were to get it sorted out one way or the other because I didn't want to go into another match under that sort of threat."

On Monday night the management board, led by the RFU's president, the former international forward Budge Rogers, met the three senior players and the men from CSS. "We spent four hours talking," Baron said yesterday, "during which we offered a number of improvements to the package. It would be an understatement to say that we were shocked when it was not only turned down but turned down with the immediate threat that they would not play for England on Saturday."

A seemingly petty incident might have concentrated the players' minds, or at least convinced them that the RFU did not have their best interests at heart. As part of the new contract package, the RFU announced its intention to reduce their allocation of free match tickets from three to two. Although the reduction was subsequently rescinded, this was was probably the factor that led Johnson to refer to the board's attitude as "feudal" yesterday.

"I have a terrible feeling that there's something going on here that I don't know about," Woodward said, hinting at dark forces behind the players' unprecedented resort to industrial action. He denied a suggestion that he was referring to the influence of the players' clubs, which believe that they should receive greater recompense for providing the personnel for the England side.

"I just hope that whoever plays on Saturday gets a standing ovation from the English public," the coach added, musing on his imminent selection problem.

Martin Johnson, asked if he would be returning for today's training session, answered in a single word: "No." But as he threw his bags into the boot of his top-of-the-range Audi, the last of the players to leave the team hotel, someone said they hoped he'd be back soon. "So do I, mate," he replied. "So do I."

fields.headline: Stellar performance that has made sports management a firm fixture
fields.trailText: It has the likes of singer Shirley Bassey and chat show host Michael Parkinson on its books, but sports management and marketing is the money-spinning game in which CSS Stellar is making its name.
fields.body:
It has the likes of singer Shirley Bassey and chat show host Michael Parkinson on its books, but sports management and marketing is the money-spinning game in which CSS Stellar is making its name.

Formed last year, it claims immodestly to be the "largest British-owned sports and entertainment management and marketing company".

Clients include the Football Association, England and Wales Cricket Board and the PGA European Tour. For the English football and rugby union teams it "oversees all commercial elements for the players, including sponsorship, endorsements and player appearances".

Motorsport is another significant part of CSS Stellar's business. The company's chief executive, Julian Jakobi, was Formula One star Ayrton Senna's manager at the time of his death at the San Marino grand prix in 1994.

With Mr Jakobi's help, Senna became the second highest paid sportsman in the world, behind basketball great Michael Jordan.

For the past 17 years the company bosses have been helping the Williams Formula One team attract more than £100m in sponsorship.

In May, the company announced it was forming CSS Stellar Golf Ltd. The subsidiary is headed by John Simpson who - like CSS chairman John Webber - is a former employee of the IGM empire. Its great coup was tempting Nick Faldo into the CSS fold.

CSS Stellar is not content simply to promote athletes. It wants to become part of the very fabric of sport.

Its broadcast subsidiary, CSS Television produces motorsport coverage for satellite television - while other arms of the company carry on representing rally and Formula One drivers.

An industry insider said: "Sport has become such a huge business that companies want to become involved in all aspects of it. Of course this can prove problematic.

"If a company is making programmes about a sport featuring someone they represent they leave themselves wide open to accusations of being biased. But of course companies like CSS Stellar do a fine job in making money for sportsmen like rugby players who traditionally haven't made much from thegame."

Away from the sports field, CSS Stellar's list of corporate clients features blue-chip companies such as Coca-Cola, AXA, Reuters, Orange, Mars and BSkyB.

The company - based in Great Portland Street, central London, but with offices in San Francisco, Porto and Hong Kong - is planning to float on the alternative investment market.

fields.headline: Trying times ahead
fields.trailText: Yesterday's action by England's rugby players is the latest in a series of incidents to propel the sport on to the front pages since it went professional in 1995.
fields.body:
Yesterday's action by England's rugby players is the latest in a series of incidents to propel the sport on to the front pages since it went professional in 1995.

Will Carling and his infamous line about Twickenham's "old farts", Lawrence Dallaglio's brush with the News of the World and England's temporary ejection from the Five Nations championship in 1999 have all tested the Rugby Football Union.

Most of the problems revolve around the Rob Andrew plan, an RFU-sponsored blueprint designed to improve the structure of the professional domestic game. But the bickering continues and even Andrew has cut his ties with the RFU. The most contentious areas are:

Finance
The clubs have threatened to break away from the union, accusing the RFU of withholding funds promised under the Andrew plan. The RFU, which recently announced an annual profit of £14.5m, says the handouts are conditional on a lasting peace deal.

Promotion/relegation
The top clubs are proposing a temporary "ringfencing" of the Zurich premiership, to allow the 12 club franchises proposed under the plan a chance to find their commercial feet. The second division clubs are opposed and the RFU is caught in the crossfire.

Demands on players
There had been talk of a players' strike earlier in the season because of the large number of matches international stars are required to play.

Television
The RFU is unhappy with the manner in which television revenue from the Six Nations pot is divided, believing that England, as the biggest box office draw, deserve a larger share. The accord is binding until 2007.

The score: rugby v football

Rugby Union Premiership player

Average salary £70,000

Club salary cap £1.8m for squad

Top earner Dallaglio: £120,000 a year

England appearance about £8,750

TV money (excluding Heineken Cup) £87.5m over five years with BSkyB

Average TV audience for live club game about 200,000

Average attendance less than 10,000


Football Premiership player

Average salary £350,000-£450,000

Top earner Alen Boksic: £63,000 a week. David Beckham: £4m from wages, sponsorship and endorsements

England appearance £10,000-£20,000

TV money about £1.5bn over three years

Average TV audience for live club game 2m

Average attendance 30,707

webTitle: Leaders: Cash before caps for rugby stars

fields.headline: England's new strikers
fields.standfirst:
It's cash before caps for rugby stars

Player power shakes Barbour bastion
fields.trailText: It's cash before caps for rugby stars.
fields.body:
Last Saturday English rugby was exultant, after a last-gasp victory over the mighty Australians, champions of the world. Today it is in crisis, with the England squad refusing to train unless its demands for better pay are met by the Rugby Football Union. If they don't train they will not be selected for Saturday's match against Argentina. The players' clubs may have colluded, and it is possible that the replacement players will refuse to turn out too. If you are going to the match at the weekend, it might be advisable to take some kit.

A decade ago, rugby was one of the last redoubts of amateurism (or, more often, "shamateurism", with players getting undeclared payments for playing but retaining their amateur status). It was a sociable sport, and the game's current administrators have little sympathy for the cash consciousness of today's players, who have been carried along on the tide of professionalism which has swept over the sport. Fran Cotton, the stalwart old prop forward who is now chairman of Club England, will have spoken for many yesterday when he castigated the players' greed. "Playing for your country should be regarded as the pinnacle of a player's career," said Cotton.

The England players are unhappy with a bonus-based pay deal worth an annual £70,000 per player, and compared with the money earned by, say, golfers, they have a point. As for international footballers, it would just about finance a quiet evening's cards. Rugby union players - fit, strong and dedicated, with not a beer belly in sight any more - are pros in every sense. Professional club rugby has struggled to bring in big crowds, but international rugby is booming globally and top players want a slice of the action. fields.bodyText: Last Saturday English rugby was exultant, after a last-gasp victory over the mighty Australians, champions of the world. Today it is in crisis, with the England squad refusing to train unless its demands for better pay are met by the Rugby Football Union. If they don't train they will not be selected for Saturday's match against Argentina. The players' clubs may have colluded, and it is possible that the replacement players will refuse to turn out too. fields.headline: Manager condemns 'betrayal'
fields.standfirst: Strike force: England squad kick out contract offer in row with rugby chiefs
fields.trailText: Strike force: England squad kick out contract offer in row with rugby chiefs.
fields.body:
England's rugby union players were accused by their manager, Clive Woodward, last night of betraying their country after the team went on strike in a pay dispute with the Rugby Football Union.

If the players fail to report for training in Surrey at 11am today, Woodward has confirmed he will seek to select a fresh squad for Saturday's international against Argentina at Twickenham, a scenario which would rank among the biggest embarrassments in English sporting history.

"If the players are not at training at 11am, they're not playing," confirmed Woodward last night as he arrived at a charity dinner in London in aid of the former England international Alastair Hignell, an event also attended by many of the players he sent home from the team hotel early yesterday.

Asked if he would use the occasion to persuade the players to change their mind, Woodward replied: "I don't want to speak to them. This is probably one of the saddest days in the history of English rugby."

webTitle: Rebel MP blames Blair for u-turn

fields.headline: Rebel MP blames Blair for u-turn
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The rebel MP, Dennis Canavan, yesterday blamed Tony Blair's sanctioning of "a cabal of control freaks" for his decision to resign his Westminster seat.
fields.body:
The rebel MP, Dennis Canavan, yesterday blamed Tony Blair's sanctioning of "a cabal of control freaks" for his decision to resign his Westminster seat.

Mr Canavan said he had broken off negotiations on rejoining the Labour party on learning that the prime minister had known of legal advice which said Labour's selection process for the Scottish parliament, which barred him, was fundamentally flawed.

Labour was mystified by the latest move by the Falkirk West MP and MSP. The Scotland Office minister, Brian Wilson, said: "Sadly Dennis has simply got his facts wrong. I can categorically state that there was no such legal advice. Indeed, the party was advised that its procedures were completely legal and proper."

Mr Canavan claimed the process was designed to keep radical candidates such as himself from Labour's list of candidates and had been cleared by Downing Street even though it "would not stand up in a court of law".

When Mr Canavan failed to be selected by Labour, he stood on an independent ticket, winning the largest majority in the Scottish parliament and effectively expelling himself from the party. After the death of Scotland's first ministerDonald Dewar, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, led negotiations with Mr Canavan to bring him back to the fold, thus avoiding an embarrassing byelection.

Mr Canavan, who announced earlier this month that he had reapplied to join Labour, yesterday said:"I had previously thought... that the people who were responsible for the selection system was a relatively small cabal of maybe less than a handful of control freaks. But this fresh evidence indicates there was involvement at the top too."

The MP said he had learned of the legal advice 10 days ago after discussions with senior party officials. A byelection is likely to take place in his constituency in January.

fields.headline: Mandelson likened to Militant left
fields.standfirst:
Former Blairite questions Northern Ireland secretary's commitment to Labour and draws links with 1980s infiltration

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Peter Kilfoyle, the former Blairite loyalist who resigned as a minister earlier this year, has stepped up his assault on New Labour by likening Peter Mandelson to the former Militant Tendency leader Derek Hatton.
fields.body:
Peter Kilfoyle, the former Blairite loyalist who resigned as a minister earlier this year, has stepped up his assault on New Labour by likening Peter Mandelson to the former Militant Tendency leader Derek Hatton.

The former defence minister has warned his party that it is in danger of slipping back to the 1980s when many people placed "too much trust in a sharp-suited personality trading in soundbites".

Mr Kilfoyle, who made his name fighting Militant in Liverpool, draws parallels between New Labour's apparent creation of a sect on the right of the party and Militant's infiltration of the left.

In a new book, in which he explains the reasons behind his ministerial resignation, Mr Kilfoyle warns Labour to remember the way in which Mr Hatton, the former Liverpool councillor, hid the true nature of his politics behind his slick media image.

"We should beware of personality politics," Mr Kilfoyle writes. "The lesson of Derek Hatton is not to place too much trust in a sharp-suited personality trading in soundbites. Remember that Hatton took in both Militant and the Labour party before he was rumbled. In fact a number of the Militant full-timers presented themselves in exactly the same fashion, hiding the true nature of their message under a visually media-friendly image."

Mr Kilfoyle is careful not to link Mr Mandelson by name to Mr Hatton. However, friends say that the Northern Ireland secretary is the only person he had in mind when writing his book, Left Behind: Lessons from Labour's Heartlands.

Mr Kilfoyle, who was one of the key party figures behind Tony Blair's campaign for the Labour leadership in 1994, has never forgiven Mr Mandelson for the secret role he played during the campaign.

Questioning Mr Mandelson's commitment to Labour, by branding him as an "ex-communist", Mr Kilfoyle writes that he had greater ambitions than simply winning the leadership for Mr Blair.

"It all added up to a strategy aimed at more than winning the leadership and, subsequently, the next election," Mr Kilfoyle says. "It increasingly appeared to be designed to change the party and the country in ways which many would never have agreed to if they had known what was to come. All this was packaged under the sobriquet 'New Labour', with its young, charismatically-sketched leader."

Mr Kilfoyle revives memories of his struggle with Militant when he likens the "control freakery" at the heart of New Labour with the central edicts issued by the Militant leadership, known as democratic centralism.

Appealing for more pluralism within the party, Mr Kilfoyle says that Labour should embrace a "coherent combination of ideas and principles". He writes: "That is not a threatening proposition to anyone who believes there is widespread sympathy with their ideas. It is only dangerous to those who wish to impose their views on others. Within Militant, that meant democratic centralism. Within New Labour, it is seen as control freakery."

Mr Kilfolye's provocative comparison between Mr Mandelson's tactics and Militant's behaviour will irritate the Northern Ireland secretary who was a loyal aide to Neil Kinnock during the battles against the hard left.

In his book Mr Kilfoyle lavishes praise on the former Labour leader for his famous attack on Militant at the 1985 party conference in which he spoke of the "grotesque spectacle of a Labour council - a Labour council - hiring taxis to scuttle round a city handing out redundancy notices to its own workers".

Mr Mandelson is likely to feel aggrieved at Mr Kilfoyle's assault because of his strong record in attacking both the politics and tactics of Militant in the 1980s. As a young councillor in Lambeth, south London, Mr Mandelson battled endlessly with the extreme left.

The harsh language of Mr Kilfoyle's book shows that there is little sign of a reconciliation in the near future with Downing Street, even though the Blairites made a gesture by despatching the cabinet office minister Lord Falconer, one of the prime minister's oldest friends, to the book launch on Monday night.

However, Mr Kilfoyle makes clear that he thinks New Labour has a limited shelf life. "Perhaps [the party will be] far less ready to buy a pig in a poke," he predicts in the final words of his book.

webTitle: Something amiss in the Amess menagerie

fields.headline: Something amiss in the Amess menagerie
fields.trailText: Mr David Amess, the Tory MP for Southend West, launched a 10-minute rule bill yesterday. It was designed to raise the minimum age at which a child could buy a pet. Mr Amess feels that too many youngsters are buying small furry animals and then not caring for them.
fields.body:
Mr David Amess, the Tory MP for Southend West, launched a 10-minute rule bill yesterday. It was designed to raise the minimum age at which a child could buy a pet. Mr Amess feels that too many youngsters are buying small furry animals and then not caring for them.

Listening to Mr Amess speak is like being trapped on a crowded train with an apparently amiable stranger. He starts talking and you think, well, I suppose I agree with most of that. Then you realise that his use of the English language is a little curious, even irritating. "I'm reliably informed that Christmas is still on December 25, unless that's something else that has been modernised!" he said with a misguided attempt at jocularity.

"There is a considerable attraction among the general public to purchase animals and particularly small animals. While there might be no attraction among the public in terms of their endearment to small MPs, there undoubtedly is a real attraction to the ownership of kittens, puppies and suchlike."

You're trying to pick the bones out of that when he gets slightly more personal. "The Amess household owns a great variety of pets," he says, and you realise to your horror that he is going to tell you about them all, possibly accompanied by photos.

"We have a black labrador, which is described as 'wayward', though I suppose it's not the only thing in the Amess household which can be described as wayward!" Ha, a joke, you think, and you manage to force your face into a courteous but very thin smile.

"Yes," he continues in a dreamy voice, "we have rabbits, hamsters, fish, canaries, finches, and the garden seems to be full of foxes. I can testify that encouraging children to look after all these animals is not always successful, and invariably it's up to mum and dad!"

Now the announcement you've been dreading: "We apologise for this stoppage, caused by Railtrack speed restrictions and flooding on the line. It looks as if we're in for quite a long delay here ..."

Mr Amess hardly notices. Indeed, the delay encourages him to become more expansive. "So many of these small furry animals are attractive to children: hamsters, gerbils, guinea pigs, rabbits ..." and you sense that he is not really speaking to you at all, but talking dreamily to him self. "Yes, teenagers are crazed by these turtles, ur, Teenage Mutant, um, Nurjna Turtles, or whatever it's called. And there's the revival of 101 Dalmatians, everyone's gone out to buy these dalmatians ... and I dare say that with all these dinosaur films on at the moment ..."

Labour MPs who had been wondering when they could politely feign sleep, or death, woke up at that. Surely even Amess didn't imagine that you could buy dinosaurs in a pet shop?

"It'll be iguanas that get purchased, and I suppose with all this publicity about sharks, people will keep baby sharks ..." I expected a guard to walk up and down the train offering complaints forms. "No," you'd cry, I don't mind being three hours late. Just get rid of this man!"

Nothing would stop him. "In Barnstaple, north Devon, two chinchillas were dumped on a doorstep after sparking a major row between a boy and girlfriend. The girlfriend had been promised 'something furry for Christmas'."

At this point, MPs had come through what athletes call "the wall". They had reached the other side. The sheer droning tedium had, in some weird way, become hilarious.

"In conclusion ..." he said, and Labour MPs, by now weak with laughter, shouted at him, "No, more! More!"

The bill will not become law.

webTitle: Soley faces second ballot for backbench chairman

fields.headline: Soley faces second ballot for backbench chairman
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Labour MPs last night delivered a barely veiled vote of no confidence in Clive Soley's performance as chairman of the backbench parliamentary Labour party. But they split their support between two rival claimants for his job - and forced a second ballot today.
fields.body:
Labour MPs last night delivered a barely veiled vote of no confidence in Clive Soley's performance as chairman of the backbench parliamentary Labour party. But they split their support between two rival claimants for his job - and forced a second ballot today.

Mr Soley, who had been accused of being more Tony Blair's shop steward to the rank and file than their voice in No 10, won 169 votes among the 369 MPs who voted, leaving the former minister, Tony Lloyd, well placed to build on his 121 votes and win tonight.

As expected, Andrew Mackinlay, the outspoken MP for Thurrock, came third and drops out. But his 77-vote share (two ballots papers were spoiled) was stronger than most MPs expected and narrowly denied Mr Soley his clear majority of 185 votes.

Mr Soley had written this week to 210 MPs most likely to back him saying "vote for me to avoid a second ballot'.' Political logic now dictates that most Mackinlay votes will go to the challenger. But that is never certain.

After the vote Mr Mackinlay said: "There would not have been an election but for my decision to stand. I have shown I have a significant constituency which should not be ignored. The need for a parliamentary caucus with its own leader, as I have proposed, is an issue which will not go away."

Last night's result emerged from a low key, abuse-free campaign. But there was disquiet that nearly 100 ministers had been allowed to help pick backbenchers' shop steward.

fields.headline: Russell Foreman
fields.standfirst: Widely travelled novelist and painter who almost became a citizen of nowhere
fields.trailText: Widely travelled novelist and painter who almost became a citizen of nowhere.
fields.body:
Russell Foreman, who has died aged 78 from a heart condition he had fought for 25 years, was an author, painter, art critic, traveller, teacher, philanthropist and bon vivant. But it was books that made his name.

His first, Long Pig (1959), was a historical novel set in the south Pacific; his friends, the authors Nevil Shute and Alec Waugh, wrote the dust-jacket copy. Two years later came Sandalwood Island, set in Fiji, and in 1976 he published The Ringway Virus, a prophetic medical thriller in which an influenza vaccine mutated and threatened to become a 20th-century plague.

Foreman nearly became a subject for a novel himself after a series of bureaucratic mishaps threatened to make him stateless. He was born in Melbourne, Australia, but while he was living in Fiji in the early postwar years the authorities persuaded him to register as a citizen of "the United Kingdom and colonies"; from then on he travelled on a British, rather than an Australian, passport.

The act of parliament granting Fiji independence in 1970 specified that those registered in the country as citizens of the United Kingdom and colonies automatically became citizens of Fiji, and their British passports were cancelled. Eight years later, when Foreman tried to renew his old passport, he discovered that he could no longer live in Italy - where he had by then settled - on Fijian documents.

Meanwhile, the Australian authorities said that, by registering as a citizen of the UK and colonies, he had lost both his Australian citizenship and his right to an Australian passport.

His literary agent at that time was Debbie Owen, the wife of the then foreign secretary, David (now Lord) Owen, and she appealed to her husband on Foreman's behalf - only to learn that Owen had no discretion in the matter, and that it would require another act of parlia ment to restore Foreman's British passport. With no country except Fiji prepared to grant him a passport or residence, Foreman did not know what to do until Canberra finally took pity on him and restored his Australian citizenship, an act of generosity that he never forgot.

Foreman's father came from an old Kent family and he had prospered in Victoria state, but he died early. After a spell in Kew, south-west London, with his mother, Foreman went to a Jesuit school, Xavier College, in Melbourne. After showing early artistic talent, he became a pupil, aged 10, of Max Meldrum, the Scottish-born trustee of the National Art Gallery of Australia and a controversial artist and teacher. Meldrum became a surrogate father to Foreman, and together they later wrote an acclaimed book on painting, The Science of Appearances (1950), in which they set out Meldrum's tonalist theories.

During the second world war, Foreman worked as an aeronautical engineer in Sydney. As travel restrictions were lifted, he went off to wander around the south Pacific, painting and gathering material for what became Long Pig.

En route to London, he met his future wife, Mary, during a stopover in Fiji; she was returning to Britain after working in Australia. They settled in Italy in 1962 and were married in 1973, Foreman's earlier marriage to a French woman having been dissolved. In Florence, he taught a writing course at an American girls' finishing school and set up the Russell Foreman School of Painting.

A dapper figure, always meticulously dressed and with exquisite, old-fashioned manners and an appreciation of good food and wine, Foreman grew closer to Australia the longer he lived abroad. He travelled the world but returned frequently to his native land, maintaining a close interest in Australian politics and doing what he could to foster reconciliation with the Aborigines. The tennis player Evonne Goolagong was one of his closest friends.

At the time of his death, at his home in Panzano, Florence, Foreman was working on a memoir of Max Meldrum, hoping it would provide useful source material for someone to write a full-scale biography. He is survived by his second wife, who plans to deposit her late husband's research material with the National Library of Australia in Canberra.

 Russell Foreman, author and artist, born December 15 1921; died October 2 2000

Meldrum became a surrogate father to Foreman, and together they later wrote an acclaimed book on painting, The Science of Appearances (1950), in which they set out Meldrum's tonalist theories. During the second world war, Foreman worked as an aeronautical engineer in Sydney. As travel restrictions were lifted, he went off to wander around the south Pacific, painting and gathering material for what became Long Pig. En route to London, he met his future wife, Mary, during a stopover in Fiji; she was returning to Britain after working in Australia. They settled in Italy in 1962 and were married in 1973, Foreman's earlier marriage to a French woman having been dissolved. In Florence, he taught a writing course at an American girls' finishing school and set up the Russell Foreman School of Painting. A dapper figure, always meticulously dressed and with exquisite, old-fashioned manners and an appreciation of good food and wine, Foreman grew closer to Australia the longer he lived abroad. He travelled the world but returned frequently to his native land, maintaining a close interest in Australian politics and doing what he could to foster reconciliation with the Aborigines. The tennis player Evonne Goolagong was one of his closest friends. At the time of his death, at his home in Panzano, Florence, Foreman was working on a memoir of Max Meldrum, hoping it would provide useful source material for someone to write a full-scale biography. He is survived by his second wife, who plans to deposit her late husband's research material with the National Library of Australia in Canberra.  Russell Foreman, author and artist, born December 15 1921; died October 2 2000

fields.headline: Alfred Lammer
fields.standfirst: Austrian-born photographer awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and bar
fields.trailText: Austrian-born photographer awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and bar.
fields.body:
The Austrian-born photographer Alfred Lammer, who has died aged 90, settled in prewar London, flew as a wartime Royal Air Force radar navigator and later established a reputation as a fine practitioner and teacher of his craft.

When he took the photographs for Thames and Hudson's book English Stained Glass (1960), his boyhood rock-climbing skills, head for heights and gift for improvisation were all exercised. He enjoyed the memory of leaning out into space high over the nave of Tewkesbury Abbey, secured only by a thin strap passed behind an equally thin and rusty piece of 14th-century iron in the window he was photographing. Meanwhile, John Baker, who wrote the text for the book, watched him, white-faced from below.

He was born Alfred Ritter von Lammer in Linz, Austria, the son of a retired railway official and a very enterprising businesswoman who worked in tourism and banking. He was a skilled and courageous rock-climber and skier in the mountains around Zell am See, near Salzburg. The von Trapp family were neighbours and friends, and Lammer took his driving test in Captain von Trapp's car.

After university in Munich and Innsbruck, where he observed Hitler's rise to power, he joined the paramilitary Heimatschutz, an Austrian anti-Nazi force of volunteers, in 1933, and was in active service with the Schutzcorps. From 1934 until the annexation of Austria by Germany in 1938, he worked in London for the Austrian Travel Bureau, on secondment from his mother's travel and banking business. When the latter collapsed, a result of Hitler's stranglehold on Austrian tourism, he was free to pursue photography; it was to be the career that really fired him. Marooned in London without a work permit, he decided to use what little money he had for a short course in photography at the Reimann school.

At the outbreak of war, officially classified as a "friendly enemy alien", he was restricted to travel within a five-mile radius of his lodgings. In Feb ruary 1940 he was commissioned in the RAF and joined the night-fighter 141 Squadron. Lammer was briefly an air gunner and then, with 255 Squadron in north Africa, a radar navigator. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and bar and was twice mentioned in dispatches. For the remainder of the war, by now a British subject, he was the chief instructor at the RAF's training unit for radar navigators.

After the war, he joined the London firm of photographers Studio Briggs before setting up as a freelance photographer in 1946. He began teaching in 1948 at Guildford School of Art, and a year later at the Central School of Arts and Crafts in London. In 1953 he photographed the passenger ships United States and America for United States Lines. His interior shots were all taken with magnesium flashbulbs to cope with the immense size of the public rooms (electronic flash was not then available), producing outstanding results. However, when he was asked to do a further shoot using dozens of models, he declined, saying he was not interested in photographing people.

In the mid-50s, he spent time helping and working for the Pestalozzi Children's Village, an international charity looking after orphans and refugees. It was a cause for which he cared passionately.

In 1957 he became the staff photographer at the Council of Industrial Design, employing inventive techniques to light and photograph difficult subjects such as items of silver and polished steel. He taught again at Guildford School of Art from 1964 until his retirement in 1976. He went on to teach photography part time for a further 10 years at the Royal College of Art, where he was made an honorary fellow. He was also decorated by Austria for his services to art and literature.

In later life, his passion was the photography of flowers. He developed a unique style, always photographing flowers in their natural surroundings, naturally lit, using a Leicaflex 35mm camera. He usually used a very shallow depth of focus in order to portray flowers in a way not accessible to the naked eye. He produced stunning colour prints of his flower photographs in a humble improvised darkroom at home. In 1987 the Post Office produced a series of stamps using his flower photographs.

Lammer's first marriage was to the violinist Kathleen Tierney, who died in 1956. In 1958 he married Countess Benedicta Wengersky, who survives him, together with their son and three daughters.

 Alfred Lammer, photographer, born November 28 1909; died October 4 2000

fields.headline: Louis Nèel
fields.standfirst: Nobel Prize-winning physicist whose discoveries about magnetism paved the way for hard disk drives and stealth aircraft
fields.trailText: Nobel Prize-winning physicist whose discoveries about magnetism paved the way for hard disk drives and stealth aircraft.
fields.body:
Louis Nèel, who has died aged 95, shared the 1970 Nobel Prize in physics for his discoveries concerning antiferromagnetism and ferrimagnetism, which helped shape modern theories of magnetism. His search for explanations into unusual aspects of magnetism in solids opened the way for many important applications, from microelectronics to the development of palaeomagnetic techniques to establish the age of fossils. Later, he played a leading role in making Grenoble the major international research centre that it is today, especially for studies in neutron diffraction spectroscopy.

In his drive to understand the basis of magnetism and electricity, Nèel followed an illustrious line of French experimentalists dedicated to studies of electromagnetic phenomena; they included André Ampère and Pierre Curie.

Nèel was born in Lyons and studied physics at Paris's École Normale Supérieure (1924-28). His first research work on magnetism was between 1928 and 1939 in Pierre Weiss's Strasbourg laboratory. In 1932 he obtained his DSc and was professor of physics at Strasbourg from 1937-45.

Conscripted in 1939, he worked on the defence of warships against magnetic mines and invented an effective new method, magnetic neutralisation. After the fall of France in 1940, he established the Laboratoire d'Électrostatique et de Physique du Métal at Grenoble, which in 1946 became one of the external laboratories of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS).

In 1956 Nèel created, as part of the French Atomic Energy Commission, the Centre d'Études Nucléaires de Grenoble, and was influential in the decision to set up a Franco-German project on neutron spectroscopy and in the installation of a high-flux reactor in Grenoble in 1967. From 1949-69 he was a member of the CNRS's board of directors; he was a scientific adviser to the French navy from 1952, and a French representative on the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation's scientific committee. From 1963-66 he was president of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics.

Ampère, an early scientist in the field, tried to explain magnetism with his hypothesis about elementary currents. In 1907, Weiss suggested that there must be a special kind of force that aligned the elementary magnets, although he could not identify it.

When Nèel began his research there were three recognised states of magnetism: dia-, para- and ferromagnetism. In the two former, the elementary magnets of the atoms behave independently of one another when subjected to a magnetic field. To these three types of mag netism, Nèel in 1932 added a fourth, anti-ferromagnetism.

Antiferromagnetism is a state that can give a material important properties. In antiferromagnetic materials, which include certain metals and alloys, the magnetism from magnetic atoms oriented in one direction is cancelled out by the set of magnetic atoms aligned in the reverse direction. From experiments, Nèel devised a model to show that crystals in the material he was using must be arranged with equally strong magnetic fields acting in opposite directions. He showed that this magnetic state would disappear at a specific temperature, now known as the Nèel point.

In 1948, he provided an explanation of some puzzling experimental observations, and a description of behaviour that could be exploited to make new synthetic ferrite magnetic materials. The explanation came from taking a different view of the strong magnetism found in ferrite materials, such as magnetite, by extending his earlier assumption to them about the arrangements of atoms within materials. This type of material is vital to advanced magnetic devices such as the read heads of computer hard disk drives.

Ferrite crystals are a major ingredient in snooper paint, which makes stealth aircraft absorb radar signals, making them undetectable by radar.

Earlier this year, the ultimate seal was put on Nèel's work when Americans produced the first images of the domain structures - tiny areas at an atomic level - of a ferrite material. The pictures revealed the alignment of tiny magnetic domains in antiferromagnetic fashion in lanthanum iron oxide; each domain was only a few hundred nanometres (billionths of a metre) in size.

Nèel extended our knowledge of many aspects of magnetism. The most important of these included the theory of Rayleigh's laws; magnetic properties of fine grains; magnetic viscosity; internal dispersion fields; superantiferromagnetism; and hysteresis.

His work was extensively recognised. He was a member of the French, Dutch, Soviet, German and American academies of science, and of the the Royal Society.

 Louis Eugène Félix Nèel, physicist, born November 22 1904; died November 17 2000

webTitle: Secrets and suspense for exhibition visitors

fields.headline: Answers on a postcard: secrets and suspense for exhibition visitors
fields.trailText: Fortune hunters and art enthusiasts will descend on the Royal College of Art today for an exhibition combining the suspense of a masked ball with the thrill of a lottery.
fields.body:
Fortune hunters and art enthusiasts will descend on the Royal College of Art today for an exhibition combining the suspense of a masked ball with the thrill of a lottery.

The exhibition, Secret, features hundreds of postcard-sized works by students and recent graduates of the RCA, established artists and celebrities including David Bowie, Nick Park and Terry Gilliam.

Each postcard is on sale for £35, the catch being that the buyer does not find out which, say, is the Hirst, and which the unknown, until after purchase; the back of the card reveals the artist's signature.

It is usually impossible to discern the famous creators from the obscure, but this year - the seventh in the series - some of the celebrities appear to have chosen to "celebrate" themselves. A watercolour of a penguin with a rubber-glove quiff looks suspiciously like the villain from Park's The Wrong Trousers, while the subject of another watercolour bears a striking resemblance to Shaun the Sheep. Bowie, whose website Bowieart.com sponsors the show, appears to have submitted a self-portrait.

There could be a few spoofs in the mix. Another of the postcards features a line drawing of a youthful Bowie with the (self mocking?) tag "Biggest Fan".

Visitors will search in vain for a giant cartoon foot crushing King Arthur's knights, but some postcards have a Pythonesque humour that suggests the hand of Gilliam, who has submitted four works.

Other contributors this year include Terry Frost, Peter Doig, Damien Hirst (the dot painting near the entrance?) Christo, Manolo Blahnik, and Brian Eno.

Some of those taking part this year might well join the throng of buyers, but everyone will be dealt with on a strict first come first served basis. Both Hirst and Bowie have expressed interest in some of the art.

The exhibition's sales raise money for RCA students; all who submit a card get £200 towards the cost of their degree show.

One of the featured artists, Billy Childish, said, however, he feared it was all a marketing gimmick. "It's good but it's a stopgap towards getting students proper grants. Creativity is not about making money. We should have confidence in creativity and allow it to develop without putting pressure on students.

"Art students need time to develop. I want money to go towards people who couldn't go to art college."

In past years, Eduardo Paolozzi, David Hockney, Chris Ofili and Tracey Emin have been among those submitting work. The show itself, said the curator, Emily Sargent, "liberates buyers", allowing them to buy purely for aesthetic pleasure without the pressure of conforming to established opinion.

RCA Secret 2000 opens from 10am to 6pm from today to Wednesday, at the RCA, Kensington, Gore, London SW7. Purchases from 8am Thursday, November 30.

fields.headline: Lockerbie prosecution leaves a 'gaping hole'
fields.standfirst:
Stalemate: case against accused Libyans adjourned at Camp Zeist after key witnesses crumble under cross-examination

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Stalemate: case against accused Libyans adjourned at Camp Zeist after key witnesses crumble under cross-examination.
fields.body:
After 73 days of evidence and more than 230 witnesses, the Lockerbie trial was adjourned yesterday amid warnings of a yawning chasm in the crown's case which augured little chance of conviction of any of the accused.

Since the indictment faced by Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah was read in the high security courthouse at Camp Zeist on May 6, the prosecution's case has travelled across continents and through territory more commonly associated with airport potboilers.

But although prosecution lawyers have done their best to construct an intricate trail between the Libyans accused and the biggest act of mass murder in British history, they have continually been let down.

Key witnesses have crumbled under cross examination; others have refused to make the links the prosecution so desperately needed them to do; some have offered testimony so bizarre that even the prosecution admits it is worthless. And there is the problem of the "gaping hole".

The Libyans face three charges: murder, conspiracy to murder and a breach of the Aviation Security Act. For these charges to succeed, according to Robert Black QC, the Edinburgh law professor who proposed the trial at a neutral venue, the prosecution must prove the bomb which blew up Pan Am flight 103 began its journey in Malta. Prosecution lawyers had barely sat down after completing their case before Professor Black was warning they had not succeeded in the fundamentals of their task.

"Unless I have missed something, and I do not think I have, there is a gaping hole at the centre of the crown's case," he said. "It is an absolutely crucial element in all the three charges that the suitcase containing the bomb started in Malta. The crown has to prove that the bomb was planted at Malta - and it has not. It has merely proved there is a theoretical possibility that it was."

The omission is hardly lost on defence lawyers. Lord Sutherland yesterday granted a request from Richard Keen QC, counsel for Fhimah, for a one week adjournment. On Tuesday Mr Keen will begin his "no case to answer" submission. If he is successful, half of the trial will come crashing down.

Repercussions

The chances of Mr Keen's success depend on the weight of evidence stacked against his client. The credibility of key prosecution witnesses may have been destroyed in cross examination, but such things are beyond the judge's consideration.

Although the route which brought them to Camp Zeist is complex, the charges faced by the Libyans rely on a few simple premises. Megrahi and Fhimah are alleged to have been members of the JSO, the Libyan intelligence service, who worked under cover in the offices of Libyan Arab Airlines at Malta's Luqa airport. On December 21 1988, the prosecution claims, the pair planted a bomb which was contained within a radio cassette recorder in a Samsonite suitcase and loaded it on an Air Malta plane at Frankfurt airport.

The crown says that suitcase was transferred on to Pan Am flight 103. A few hours later the jumbo blew up over Lockerbie, killing all 259 passengers and crew on board and 11 people on the ground. It is a neat scenario, but it is far from certain the judges will agree that the crown has proved it is accurate.

The trial of Megrahi, the co-accused, is destined to continue until his defence has been fully heard. William Taylor QC, counsel for Megrahi, yesterday asked for an adjournment to allow Syria to respond to a court request for the release of a se cret document which claims to offer an alternative explanation of the bombing.

Both Megrahi and Fhimah have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming Palestinian terrorist groups, including the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. If Fhimah's no case to answer plea is successful, his side of the story will never be heard. But, over the next weeks, it is expected that Mr Taylor will advance the scenario first accepted by those investigating the bombing.

In the first years of the investigation there was just one working theory. It was believed that the bomb was a revenge attack mounted by the PFLP-GC for the shooting down of an Iranian airbus in the Gulf by the USS Vincennes in July 1988. This theory was ditched around the time of the Gulf war, when America took on Iraq with the acquiescence of Syria and Iran.

For special defence to succeed, Mr Taylor, and perhaps Mr Keen, need not prove this scenario accurate. They need only place reasonable doubt over the veracity of the scenario advanced by the crown. Much of the crown's case relies on technical evidence which has gone unreported and unobserved as the trial grinds on in Holland. Yet there have been a few key witnesses - and they have not lived up to expectation.

The first of these was Anthony Gauci. This Maltese shop owner was crucial to linking Megrahi to the bomb. When investigators picked through the wreckage of flight 103 they found clothing stained with residue from a Semtex explosion; it was labelled "Malta Trading Company". The clothing was sold at Mr Gauci's shop. But, although Mr Gauci said Megrahi resembled a man whom he remembered buying similar clothing before the bombing, he stopped short of full identification.

Next came Edwin Bollier, a Swiss businessman whose Zurich-based company, Mebo, is alleged to have made the timer used in the bomb. For years before the trial, Mr Bollier waged an internet campaign denying the timer was supplied by his firm. Under questioning from the prosecution, however, he conceded that it could only have come from Mebo.

Protection

When Mr Bollier said he supplied such timers solely to Libya, the prosecution's case appeared to receive a boost. But that may have later been dented by the admission that he also supplied timers to the Stasi, the East German security force, who in turn backed Palestinian terrorist organisations.

As far as star witnesses are concerned, that left only Abdul Majid Giaka - a Libyan who worked alongside the accused at Luqa airport. Giaka was a double agent: working for the CIA at the same time as the JSO. He defected to the US on the witness protection programme and, as he emerged after 10 years, he told the court Fhimah had shown him explosives in his drawer; he claimed he had once handed Megrahi a report on how to place a bomb on a plane leaving Luqa airport. Finally, in his most crucial piece of evidence, he said he had watched Megrahi and Fhimah take a Samsonite suitcase, flown in from Libya, unaccompanied through customs.

But under cross-examination his cred-ibility was tarnished. "While in America, have you been able to dip into gems of American literature, such as their short-story writers like James Thurber?" asked Mr Keen. "Have you encountered someone called Mitty, first name Walter?"

Main players in bomb trial

Abdelbaset Al Megrahi
One of the accused. He is alleged to have worked undercover for the JSO, the Libyan intelligence agency, as head of security at Libyan Arab Airlines at Malta's Luqa airport. The prosecution says he used this position to plant the bomb on an Air Malta plane which fed on to flight 103 at Frankfurt. He has lodged a special defence of incrimination.

Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah
The co-accused. Like Megrahi, Fhimah is alleged to have been working undercover for the JSO when he worked as station manager at Libyan Arab Airlines.

Anthony Gauci
A Maltese shop owner whom the prosecution claims sold the clothing found in the case which housed the bomb.

Edwin Bollier
A Swiss businessman whose company, Mebo, made the timer which the prosecution say was used in the Lockerbie bomb.

Abdul Majid Giaka
The Libyan supergrass. He was a double agent - working for the JSO and the CIA - when he worked with the accused at Luqa airport. Claims to have been shown explosives in Fhimah's desk. Defence portrayed him as a fantasist who made up his testimony to secure a new life in the US.

Since the indictment faced by Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah was read in the high security courthouse at Camp Zeist on May 6, the prosecution's case has travelled across continents and through territory more commonly associated with airport potboilers. But although prosecution lawyers have done their best to construct an intricate trail between the Libyans accused and the biggest act of mass murder in British history, they have continually been let down. Key witnesses have crumbled under cross examination; others have refused to make the links the prosecution so desperately needed them to do; some have offered testimony so bizarre that even the prosecution admits it is worthless. And there is the problem of the "gaping hole". The Libyans face three charges: murder, conspiracy to murder and a breach of the Aviation Security Act. For these charges to succeed, according to Robert Black QC, the Edinburgh law professor who proposed the trial at a neutral venue, the prosecution must prove the bomb which blew up Pan Am flight 103 began its journey in Malta. Prosecution lawyers had barely sat down after completing their case before Professor Black was warning they had not succeeded in the fundamentals of their task. "Unless I have missed something, and I do not think I have, there is a gaping hole at the centre of the crown's case," he said. "It is an absolutely crucial element in all the three charges that the suitcase containing the bomb started in Malta. The crown has to prove that the bomb was planted at Malta - and it has not. It has merely proved there is a theoretical possibility that it was." The omission is hardly lost on defence lawyers. Lord Sutherland yesterday granted a request from Richard Keen QC, counsel for Fhimah, for a one week adjournment. On Tuesday Mr Keen will begin his "no case to answer" submission. If he is successful, half of the trial will come crashing down. Repercussions The chances of Mr Keen's success depend on the weight of evidence stacked against his client. The credibility of key prosecution witnesses may have been destroyed in cross examination, but such things are beyond the judge's consideration. Although the route which brought them to Camp Zeist is complex, the charges faced by the Libyans rely on a few simple premises. Megrahi and Fhimah are alleged to have been members of the JSO, the Libyan intelligence service, who worked under cover in the offices of Libyan Arab Airlines at Malta's Luqa airport. On December 21 1988, the prosecution claims, the pair planted a bomb which was contained within a radio cassette recorder in a Samsonite suitcase and loaded it on an Air Malta plane at Frankfurt airport. The crown says that suitcase was transferred on to Pan Am flight 103. A few hours later the jumbo blew up over Lockerbie, killing all 259 passengers and crew on board and 11 people on the ground. It is a neat scenario, but it is far from certain the judges will agree that the crown has proved it is accurate. The trial of Megrahi, the co-accused, is destined to continue until his defence has been fully heard. William Taylor QC, counsel for Megrahi, yesterday asked for an adjournment to allow Syria to respond to a court request for the release of a se cret document which claims to offer an alternative explanation of the bombing. Both Megrahi and Fhimah have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming Palestinian terrorist groups, including the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. If Fhimah's no case to answer plea is successful, his side of the story will never be heard. But, over the next weeks, it is expected that Mr Taylor will advance the scenario first accepted by those investigating the bombing. In the first years of the investigation there was just one working theory. It was believed that the bomb was a revenge attack mounted by the PFLP-GC for the shooting down of an Iranian airbus in the Gulf by the USS Vincennes in July 1988. This theory was ditched around the time of the Gulf war, when America took on Iraq with the acquiescence of Syria and Iran. For special defence to succeed, Mr Taylor, and perhaps Mr Keen, need not prove this scenario accurate. They need only place reasonable doubt over the veracity of the scenario advanced by the crown. Much of the crown's case relies on technical evidence which has gone unreported and unobserved as the trial grinds on in Holland. Yet there have been a few key witnesses - and they have not lived up to expectation. The first of these was Anthony Gauci. This Maltese shop owner was crucial to linking Megrahi to the bomb. When investigators picked through the wreckage of flight 103 they found clothing stained with residue from a Semtex explosion; it was labelled "Malta Trading Company". The clothing was sold at Mr Gauci's shop. But, although Mr Gauci said Megrahi resembled a man whom he remembered buying similar clothing before the bombing, he stopped short of full identification. Next came Edwin Bollier, a Swiss businessman whose Zurich-based company, Mebo, is alleged to have made the timer used in the bomb. For years before the trial, Mr Bollier waged an internet campaign denying the timer was supplied by his firm. Under questioning from the prosecution, however, he conceded that it could only have come from Mebo. Protection When Mr Bollier said he supplied such timers solely to Libya, the prosecution's case appeared to receive a boost. But that may have later been dented by the admission that he also supplied timers to the Stasi, the East German security force, who in turn backed Palestinian terrorist organisations. As far as star witnesses are concerned, that left only Abdul Majid Giaka - a Libyan who worked alongside the accused at Luqa airport. Giaka was a double agent: working for the CIA at the same time as the JSO. He defected to the US on the witness protection programme and, as he emerged after 10 years, he told the court Fhimah had shown him explosives in his drawer; he claimed he had once handed Megrahi a report on how to place a bomb on a plane leaving Luqa airport. Finally, in his most crucial piece of evidence, he said he had watched Megrahi and Fhimah take a Samsonite suitcase, flown in from Libya, unaccompanied through customs. But under cross-examination his cred-ibility was tarnished. "While in America, have you been able to dip into gems of American literature, such as their short-story writers like James Thurber?" asked Mr Keen. "Have you encountered someone called Mitty, first name Walter?" Main players in bomb trial Abdelbaset Al Megrahi One of the accused. He is alleged to have worked undercover for the JSO, the Libyan intelligence agency, as head of security at Libyan Arab Airlines at Malta's Luqa airport. The prosecution says he used this position to plant the bomb on an Air Malta plane which fed on to flight 103 at Frankfurt. He has lodged a special defence of incrimination. Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah The co-accused. Like Megrahi, Fhimah is alleged to have been working undercover for the JSO when he worked as station manager at Libyan Arab Airlines. Anthony Gauci A Maltese shop owner whom the prosecution claims sold the clothing found in the case which housed the bomb. Edwin Bollier A Swiss businessman whose company, Mebo, made the timer which the prosecution say was used in the Lockerbie bomb. Abdul Majid Giaka The Libyan supergrass. He was a double agent - working for the JSO and the CIA - when he worked with the accused at Luqa airport. Claims to have been shown explosives in Fhimah's desk. Defence portrayed him as a fantasist who made up his testimony to secure a new life in the US.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 90mph express nearly derailed
fields.body:
90mph express nearly derailed

Vandals almost derailed a 90mph express by placing a JCB tyre on the line at Poynton, Cheshire, on Monday night.

With the driver applying emergency brakes, the Euston-Manchester train rode over the tyre but it stuck underneath - disabling the locomotive and filling carriages with the smell of burnt rubber. David Ward

NHS call for post-op units

The lives of hundreds of people undergoing serious operations may be at risk because 40% of major hospitals have no high dependency unit, or half-way house between intensive care and surgical wards, a report suggested.

The inquiry received confidental evidence from surgeons on 1,500 of 20,000 deaths following surgery each year. James Meikle

Duke retires as award chairman

The Duke of Edinburgh is retiring as chairman of the award scheme bearing his name that helps young people improve themselves.

Philip, 79, said he was giving up because of his age, but would remain as patron. His replacement is Sir Tom Farmer, founder of the Kwik Fit chain.

Out of frying pan into fire

Three prisoners who escaped from Erlestoke prison in Wiltshire made a mistake when they stole a car to make their getaway.

Its owner chased them in a truck for two miles until they crashed and had to take to their heels. Police with dogs rounded them up, after which two were treated for chest injuries from the crash.

Top shelf makes comeback

Three years after clearing its top shelves, WH Smith is once again to sell so-called adult magazines.

A spokesman said: "Customer response to a Playboy trial we ran during the summer was so positive we decided to go into all high street stores and include a further nine titles."

Tests for Porton Down volunteers

In a Commons reply, the defence minister Lewis Moonie promised a new dialogue and honesty with servicemen who were among the 25,000 who volunteered for germ warfare tests at Porton Down and now report health problems.

He also said the MoD was taking advice on an independent medical survey.

Autumn rain record nears

England and Wales could be having the wettest autumn on record. To date rainfall is 63% above average for September, October and November, and a further 31mm (1.2in) would beat a record 455.8mm (17.9in) in 1852. More rain is predicted.

From sublime to ridiculous

Bibliophiles have until the end of the week to visit www.thebookseller.com and vote for oddest title this year. Top so far on 50% is High Performance Stiffened Structures, followed by Whose Bottom: A Lift the Flap Book (in fact a child's guessing game) on 27%, and Did Lewis Carroll Visit Llandudno? third on 11%.

Immigrants taken off lorries

Some 43 men, women and children from various countries were discovered hidden in three German lorries on the M20 and were taken to Dover for interview. Police said it did not appear to be deliberate smuggling.

Las Vegas slots put on hold

The delights of Las Vegas were put on hold yesterday when a flight to the US city got its wheels bogged in grass prior to take-off at Manchester. The 359 passengers returned to the terminal while the plane was freed; other flights were unaffected.

Queen decides against train

The Queen has cancelled a journey today from London to Cambridge by train, and will go by car instead. "The 45-minute journey is taking up to two hours. We did not want to risk disappointing anyone by having to cancel engagements," said Buckingham

fields.headline: Teaching 'should focus on innovation'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The concept of "innovation" should be put at the heart of education, the government's chief adviser on the curriculum will urge tonight.
fields.body:
The concept of "innovation" should be put at the heart of education, the government's chief adviser on the curriculum will urge tonight.

David Hargreaves, the new chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, will say that the knowledge economy requires students to acquire skills such as solving problems and working in teams.

Those "soft skills" were highly valued by employers, he will tell an event at the Institute of Education in London, organised by CreativeNet.co.uk and the Guardian.

Mr Hargreaves's active encouragement of innovation will be viewed suspiciously by education conservatives who believe teachers should concentrate on traditional methods. He says there are limitations in the conventional class room structures and supports.

"If teachers are not involved in innovative activity, they are not likely to understand how to create the conditions in which students learn how to be innovative," he will say.

Promoting innovation - which he defines as "the successful exploitation of a new idea" - would also attract graduates to teaching, he says. He is more approving than Chris Woodhead, the outgoing chief inspector of schools, about the government's belief in lifelong learning.

In the new economy "one cannot be educated between the ages of five and 20 for work for the rest of one's life", he will say. "Most people will have to return for formal education and training at regular intervals during adult life."

Mr Hargreaves will argue that design and technology is "moving from the periphery of the school curriculum to its heart".

fields.headline: Millionaire beats Meldrew amid claims of rigging
fields.trailText: Television's first quiz show millionaire and the demise of Victor Meldrew dragged in 5m more viewers than usual on Monday, as ITV took the moral high ground over the BBC's claims of game show rigging.
fields.body:
Television's first quiz show millionaire and the demise of Victor Meldrew dragged in 5m more viewers than usual on Monday, as ITV took the moral high ground over the BBC's claims of game show rigging.

According to unofficial figures released yesterday, 25m people watched either the last One Foot in the Grave on BBC1 or Judith Keppel's £1m win on ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

Reinvigorated by its first £1m winner, Chris Tarrant's game show scored an average 13.9m viewers. Almost 15m saw the moment when Ms Keppel, 58, hit the jackpot. The BBC sitcom averaged 10.7m viewers, peaking at 11.6m.

The BBC described the first quiz show millionaire as an "extraordinary coincidence". But Celador, which makes Millionaire for ITV, denied that the show was fixed, pointing out that it also makes a game show for the BBC, National Lottery Winning Lines.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, said the BBC should celebrate the success of both channels. He attacked the corporation's "childish behaviour", saying the accusations were an abuse of its position as a licence fee funded broadcaster.

"I think the BBC ought to celebrate the fact that four of five million more viewers came to British terrestrial television. That's a fantastic thing."

webTitle: PM to face public grilling on TV

fields.headline: PM to face public grilling on TV
fields.trailText: Almost two decades after Margaret Thatcher was floored on Nationwide by Diana Gould of Cheltenham, Tony Blair is to submit himself to the nation for a similarly risky exercise in popular democracy.
fields.body:
Almost two decades after Margaret Thatcher was floored on Nationwide by Diana Gould of Cheltenham, Tony Blair is to submit himself to the nation for a similarly risky exercise in popular democracy.

Eschewing the one-to-one grilling that politicians hate so much, Mr Blair will appear live on an hour long ITV show in which the public will be able to question him on any issue.

Ask The Prime Minister will be presented by Jonathan Dimbleby at 7pm on Tuesday, December 12. Some Tories were unhappy that William Hague, would not be given a similar opportunity, but the network insisted that Mr Blair would be appearing as leader of the nation rather than figurehead of the Labour party.

Questions will come from viewers by telephone and from a representative studio audience. A national phone line will be open for three weeks prior to the show to allow viewers to register their questions. "This programme will be tough, searching and an important democratic dialogue between the people and their prime minister," Dimbleby said.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, said there would be no set agenda, and Mr Blair would not see the questions in advance. Mr Blair would be given notice of the general topics to be covered.

ITV, which approached Mr Blair, has been negotiating for the past year. The network said Mr Blair had always been receptive, but had only recently agreed a date.

Steve Anderson, ITV's controller of news, said it was "the first time this century a prime minister has put his head above the parapet and taken questions from any one of 55m people."

The number to register questions is 0870 2425666, lines are open from today.
