fields.headline: Old Master returns after 220 years with Catherine the Great's treasures
fields.trailText: A magnificent painting by Poussin is back in Britain, 220 years after Catherine the Great provoked a huge political row by sweeping it away to Russia, along with an Old Masters collection that might have formed the basis of a British national gallery.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A magnificent painting by Poussin is back in Britain, 220 years after Catherine the Great provoked a huge political row by sweeping it away to Russia, along with an Old Masters collection that might have formed the basis of a British national gallery.

The painting is on loan to the Hermitage exhibition at Somerset House in London, opened yesterday by the Prince of Wales. Five rooms hold treasures from Catherine's personal collections held in the Hermitage in St Petersburg.

It is a deal that not only gives Britain a new visitor attraction, but the Russian museum an international shop window and desperately needed source of hard currency. Royalties from sales in the shop and one pound from each visitor admission go to the Hermitage, which has been granted the suite in the palatial Thames-side building rent free.

By return, the Hermitage will fill the rooms (which open to the public on Saturday) with changing displays of treasures from its gigantic collection - only 5% of its 3m objects is on display at any time.

The opening show has been set up to dazzle. It includes Catherine's silver thread wig, gold and gem snuff boxes, silver and porcelain, and a Chinese silver filigree mirror judged too plain and so studded with thumbnail sized diamonds on reaching Russia.

The elegant Georgian interiors by Sir William Chambers, who designed Somerset House as the first purpose-built civil service office block, have been transformed by the Russians. The door handles, chandeliers, floors, curtains and ceiling are copied from the Hermitage.

The Poussin, entitled Moses Striking the Rock, provoked furious debate in parliament in 1779 on the loss of such an important collection to the UK. There had already been questions about how the former prime minister, Sir Robert Walpole, had got so rich so fast, building himself a palace at Houghton Hall in Norfolk and filling it with art of imperial splendour. It had been suggested that the government buy the collection for a national art gallery.

When Catherine bought the cream of the collection she presented the Walpoles with a "consolation prize" portrait of herself - as a stocky woman with a determined chin, blazing with diamonds. The picture, still housed at Houghton Hall, appears in the exhibition.

webTitle: Three years for human rights activist

fields.headline: Three years for human rights activist who abused daughter
fields.trailText: Vincent McKenna, the controversial Belfast human rights activist whose campaign against punishment beatings nearly derailed the Good Friday peace agreement, was yesterday sentenced to three years in prison for sexual assaults on his daughter, Sorcha.
fields.body:
Vincent McKenna, the controversial Belfast human rights activist whose campaign against punishment beatings nearly derailed the Good Friday peace agreement, was yesterday sentenced to three years in prison for sexual assaults on his daughter, Sorcha.

McKenna, 37, was found guilty at Cavan circuit court, Monaghan, in the Irish republic 11 days ago of 31 charges of sexually and indecently assaulting Sorcha from the age of three in 1985. The abuse went on over eight years.

Sorcha, now 18, waived her right to anonymity after the conviction in order to name and shame her father who was director of the Northern Ireland human rights bureau.

In court yesterday she burst into tears when the sentence was announced and later complained about the leniency of the sentence.

"It does not reflect the crimes he committed against me. Three years is nothing in comparison to what he has done," she said.

"I don't think any sentence would have been enough for me but three years is the minimum, so it is ridiculous.

"I just hope other people won't be put off and will have the courage to look for justice."

Speaking last night on BBC Northern Ireland's Spotlight programme she said: "He would be campaigning for the rights of children ... when all along he had put me through hell. It sickened me that he was being so hypocritical and no-one could see that except me and my family."

Surrounded in the dock yesterday by eight police officers, McKenna listened to the sentence without emotion.

Judge Matt Deery said the abuse, which McKenna denied during the three-day trial, was of a "serious and explicit nature." He quoted from a victim impact report prepared by a psychologist which said his daughter suffered from serious post-traumatic distress and would serve a "life sentence" and require regular counselling.

"I commend Sorcha for pursuing the matter and speaking out. It required courage on her part," the judge said.

McKenna's barrister, Michael O'Higgins, was refused leave to lodge an appeal. Appealing for the most lenient sentence possible, he said his client had suffered "an enor mous amount of publicity and vitriol".

At the time of the assaults, McKenna was living with his wife and four children in Monaghan. After divorcing, he moved north to Belfast, studied politics at Queen's University and became an outspoken critic of the Good Friday agreement using socialist rhetoric. He allied himself to the human rights group, Families Against Intimidation and Terror, naming the alleged Omagh bombers. In May 1999 he set up the human rights bureau.

Always articulate and accessible to journalists, he was a vociferous spokesman against punishment beatings, often wielding a nail-studded pickaxe handle to dramatise their brutality.

He claimed that in his youth he was a member of the IRA's youth wing at the height of the H-block hunger strikes, but became disillusioned with what he called the organisation's "ethnic cleansing" of Protestants in Tyrone and Armagh. He served nine months in the IRA wing at Crumlin Road jail in 1984, after he was arrested by the RUC, granted bail and then went on the run in the republic until his extradition.

Sinn Fein called him a "Walter Mitty character as well as a willing political tool for anti-agreement unionists, rightwing Tories and possibly elements of British intelligence."

Last year, he appeared on a platform with the former head of the RUC, Sir John Hermon, and Charles Moore, the Daily Telegraph editor, calling for the changes proposed for the RUC in the Patten commission to be abandoned. Then he provoked calls for the resignation of the former Northern Ireland secretary, Mo Mowlam, when he challenged her to declare that punishment attacks were in fundamental breach of the ceasefire.

Yesterday Eileen Calder, the co-director of the province's rape crisis centre, said: "We are appalled at the leniency of this sentence when Sorcha only came forward to protect other children. It is almost as if the offences were treated as a misdemeanour and in the republic there is no sex offenders' register. In two years he will be out with no controls."

After divorcing, he moved north to Belfast, studied politics at Queen's University and became an outspoken critic of the Good Friday agreement using socialist rhetoric. He allied himself to the human rights group, Families Against Intimidation and Terror, naming the alleged Omagh bombers. In May 1999 he set up the human rights bureau. Always articulate and accessible to journalists, he was a vociferous spokesman against punishment beatings, often wielding a nail-studded pickaxe handle to dramatise their brutality. He claimed that in his youth he was a member of the IRA's youth wing at the height of the H-block hunger strikes, but became disillusioned with what he called the organisation's "ethnic cleansing" of Protestants in Tyrone and Armagh. He served nine months in the IRA wing at Crumlin Road jail in 1984, after he was arrested by the RUC, granted bail and then went on the run in the republic until his extradition. Sinn Fein called him a "Walter Mitty character as well as a willing political tool for anti-agreement unionists, rightwing Tories and possibly elements of British intelligence." Last year, he appeared on a platform with the former head of the RUC, Sir John Hermon, and Charles Moore, the Daily Telegraph editor, calling for the changes proposed for the RUC in the Patten commission to be abandoned. Then he provoked calls for the resignation of the former Northern Ireland secretary, Mo Mowlam, when he challenged her to declare that punishment attacks were in fundamental breach of the ceasefire. Yesterday Eileen Calder, the co-director of the province's rape crisis centre, said: "We are appalled at the leniency of this sentence when Sorcha only came forward to protect other children. It is almost as if the offences were treated as a misdemeanour and in the republic there is no sex offenders' register. In two years he will be out with no controls."

webTitle: Doctor 'let neglected child go back to aunt'

fields.headline: Doctor 'let neglected child go back to aunt'
fields.trailText: A cut and bruised girl was released by a London hospital's child protection officer back into her aunt's care seven months before she died, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A cut and bruised girl was released by a London hospital's child protection officer back into her aunt's care seven months before she died, a court heard yesterday.

Anna Climbie, eight, was said to have endured months tied up by her hands and feet in a binbag and left to sleep and eat in the bath, before dying in February of hypothermia and neglect. She had been sent from the Ivory Coast into her aunt's care so she might have a better life. A postmortem examination showed 128 injuries, including cigarette burns.

A jury at the Old Bailey was told the aunt, who moved Anna to Britain from France, admitted beating her.

Avril Cameron, a bible studies graduate, told the court the aunt, Marie Therese Kuoao, became "very annoyed" when she found out Ms Cameron had taken the child to hospital because she was covered in cuts and bruises. On a previous occasion Kuoao had said the cuts and blisters on her fingers were bug bites.

At Central Middlesex hospital the child was seen by Ruby Schwartz, a consultant paediatrician and the hospital's named child protection doctor, and released. The court had earlier heard Kuoao told the hospital the girl had inflicted the injuries on herself.

Kuoao, 44 and unemployed, and her boyfriend, Carl Manning, 28, a bus driver, of Tottenham, north London, deny murder. Kuoao also denies child cruelty and manslaughter. Manning admits child cruelty but the prosecution refuses to accept his plea of guilty to manslaughter.

Yesterday a relation of Kuoao's told of seeing the child. Grace Quansah, a teacher and former social worker, said: "She seemed very thin ... my son was four, and she was the same height and very frail."

On hearing from Kouao of the child's double incontinence and that she was beaten for it, Ms Quansah, through her mother, reported the child to social services, but never saw her again: "With hindsight, of course I feel absolutely terrible. I wish I could have done more."

The case continues.

fields.headline: Greed drove mother of child star, court told
fields.standfirst: Lawyer for manager says he enabled girl soprano to earn £10m in three years but was sacked by fax after quibbles over expenses for Jiffy bags
fields.trailText: Lawyer for manager says he enabled girl soprano to earn £10m in three years but was sacked by fax after quibbles over expenses for Jiffy bags.
fields.body:
The mother of child soprano Charlotte Church sacked her manager without warning because the mother's aim in life was "the pursuit and retention of money", a high court judge was told yesterday.

In one of the bitterest battles in the music industry for years, Jonathan Shalit, who discovered the unknown 11-year-old who within three years became an international star, is claiming £4m of her estimated £10m fortune.

Although Mr Shalit had turned Charlotte, now 14, into a star, her mother, Maria Church, quibbled over expenses claims for Jiffy bags and postage, and eventually sacked Mr Shalit so that she could cut out his 20% commission, claimed his counsel, Ian Mill QC.

In January solicitors acting for the girl, her mother and her adoptive father, James, faxed Mr Shalit a letter with the intent of terminating his contract, which was due to run to 2002.

"The driving force was Miss Church's mother Maria, who by her own admission is a fiery and driven individual," Mr Mill told the court.

"What seems to drive her particularly is the pursuit and retention of money.

"They [the singer and her manager] did have their dif ferences. But we suggest it was Maria Church who persuaded her family to have Mr Shalit removed on the basis no future manager would be appointed - thus stemming future costs.

"He has played an integral part in a remarkable success story and the idea that [the contract was terminated] because he has certain personal habits that Miss Church dislikes, or that he shouts on certain occasions, does not even begin to require analysis."

Mr Justice Evans-Lombe heard that Mr Shalit had "worked round the clock" to build the girl's career after discovering her in 1997. He invested time and money in recording demo tapes and in badgering uninterested record companies, and succeeded in winning her a five-album deal with Sony Records, an £800,000 deal for her autobiography, and an advertising contract with Ford.

As a consequence she is in high demand. Yesterday she attended court for only a while, leaving to make promotional appearances for her new album and to switch on the Christmas lights in Oxford Street in central London last night.

Hair pulled into a pony tail, she looked like any other slightly bored teenager as she fidgeted on the back row of the court room. But unlike most schoolgirls she has sung before the Queen, the Pope and Bill Clinton.

In the letter terminating Mr Shalit's contract the solicitor wrote: "Charlotte had no experience of commercial management, and her parents are and were similarly inexperienced. That you have achieved such one-sided contractual arrangements despite our misgivings is indicative of the extent to which you used your influence over them ... Charlotte wants no further dealings with you and has no further obligations to you."

The letter suggested the contract could be made void because it was made with a minor. But Mr Mill said the contract was binding even though it was with a minor, because the contract was valid if it could be shown to be in Charlotte's best interests. Mr Mill also said that, on Mr Shalit's advice, the Church family had been advised throughout the contract negotiations by a lawyer specialising in the music business. He claimed that Mr Shalit's commission fee of 20%, and his exclusive right to handle Miss Church's work, were standard in such situations.

The Church family's defence is believed to centre on claims that Mr Shalit treated Mrs Church disrespectfully and humiliated her, and was over strict and sometimes verbally abusive towards her daughter.

The termination letter continued: "You have been responsible for the breakdown of confidence between you and Charlotte and her parents ... In a meeting with you and Charlotte's parents they discussed these problems. Despite this, as a result of your continuing behaviour, this trust and confidence has never been restored."

Mr Mill said that, on the contrary, it had been Mr Shalit who raised complaints about Mrs Church's behaviour, and he maintained that her only concerns had been to do with money.

She had questioned an expenses bill of less that £5,000 for 22 months of work for Charlotte, challenging bills for mobile phone calls, postal charges, and even a parcel delivery charge of £9.99. "It was a quite extraordinary and disproportionate response to things like Jiffy bags and the amount he had spent on entertaining at The Ivy [a restaurant in the West End of London]," said Mr Mill.

"That response was indicative of the focus of the Church family on financial matters." Mr Mill said the family was trying to blame the dispute on the manager by raising "a whole series of allegations of untrue, petty and offensive nature, included with a view to embarrassing Mr Shalit."

The case continues.

fields.headline: Unwed parents twice as likely to separate
fields.trailText: Children of cohabiting couples are twice as likely as those born within marriage to see their parents split up, according to a study published today by the Institute for Social and Economic Research.
fields.body:
Children of cohabiting couples are twice as likely as those born within marriage to see their parents split up, according to a study published today by the Institute for Social and Economic Research.

It found 70% of children born within marriage will live until their 16th birthday with both natural parents, compared with 36% of children born to cohabiting couples.

The figures were based on an analysis of a government sample survey of 10,000 British households and the statisticians concluded that the birth of a child made it 60% less likely that a cohabiting couple would marry.

"The temporary nature of many cohabiting relationships means they should not be considered simply as marriage without the vows.

"They are a new and relatively unstable family structure which is leading to a dramatic increase in childbearing outside marriage and significant growth in the time children spend living in one parent families," said the au thors, John Ermisch and Marco Francesconi.

The study found 70% of first partnerships were cohabitations outside marriage. Typically they lasted two years before the couple either married or separated.

About 60% of first cohabitations became marriages and 35% dissolved within 10 years.

This pattern had contributed to postponement of the average age of marriage and motherhood. But more women were having children while cohabiting, rising from 2% in 1980 to 22% in 1997.

On average, children born to cohabiting couples spent 4.3 years of their childhood with just one parent, compared with 1.7 years for children born within marriages and 6.6 years for children born outside a live-in partnership of any kind.

Robert Whelan, of Family and Youth Concern, said: "Children need to have stable lives and be born within marriage."

The findings, based on the British Household Panel Survey, are published today in a book, Seven Years in the Lives of British Families.

webTitle: Letters: A winner in a million

fields.headline: A winner in a million
fields.trailText: As a contestant on Monday night's Who Wants To Be a Millionaire, I had the opportunity to speak with Judith Keppel after the programme was recorded (She's a TV millionaire, November 21). She was extremely warm and gracious, and expressed her concern that she was taking up all of the show, despite still being in shock about winning £1m.
fields.body:
As a contestant on Monday night's Who Wants To Be a Millionaire, I had the opportunity to speak with Judith Keppel after the programme was recorded (She's a TV millionaire, November 21). She was extremely warm and gracious, and expressed her concern that she was taking up all of the show, despite still being in shock about winning £1m.

It is extremely cheeky that anyone at the BBC should even hint that the show was dumbed down. For two years I called repeatedly to try and qualify for Millionaire, and have heard numerous qualification questions. I've only seen BBC's The Weakest Link a few times, but at least 20 questions that I've had as Millionaire qualification questions turned up.

I'm an American who has lived here for a few years, and it never ceases to amaze me how some British people feel the need to rubbish anything successful. Take pride in Judith and her accomplishment, and take pride in being the home of the most wonderful and suc cessful quiz show format the world has ever known.
Jeff Gross
Richmond, Surrey
jeff@inspiration-group.com

 Your leader (November 21) was a bit sniffy. I am not one to stick up for the "upper classes" but really, you cannot claim that they have been besieging this show. The rest of us have had a good chance, over a period of two years, and have frankly botched it. We have all either stumbled over fairly simple questions or have simply bottled out under the pressure.

The redoubtable Mrs Keppel set herself the target of getting on the show and persevered until she achieved her aim. She then demonstrated the benefits of: a good education, coolness under fire, a good friend, and the willingness to accept risk - possibly the very attributes which once made our nation great.
Peter Thornton
Longsleddale, Cumbria
peter@quicksnaps.co.uk

 Your leader misses an important point. The show's questions, with their emphasis on classical civilisation, international cuisine and "good" literature, generally discriminate in favour of the already culturally and educationally privileged, not to say widely travelled. Ms Keppel was particularly fortunate in that, of her 15 questions, none addressed popular contemporary culture, of either the soap opera or musical variety, the traditional Achilles heel of contestants of Ms Keppel's refined sensibilities.
Ronnie Landau
London

 Where is your sense of values heading? Your leader (leader, no less!) congratulating Mrs Keppel on her "well-earned" million-pound win gives pause for thought on what "well-earned" means to real people. Enough hype for this trashy feature of our selfish society, please.
David Harvie
Dumbarton
dave@kosmoid.demon.co.uk

 Does Rufus (Guardian Crossword, November 20) also set puzzles for ITV, or was it really just a coincidence that the £1m question broadcast on Monday night was "Which king was married to Eleanor of Aquitaine?" and that the answer to 17 down published on Monday morning, "English queen, one with real potential", was Eleanor?
Stefan Finka
Sheffield
stefan@finka.demon.co.uk

 Whatever happened to the ITV spin machine? With a name like Keppel, she could surely have found a forebear who knew Wilson and Betty and liked a good sand-dance instead of appearing as the Windsor pheasant-plucker's friend. They've robbed us of our People's Millionaire.
Ian Watson
Scarborough, North Yorks

webTitle: Letters: On the trail of a cocktail

fields.headline: On the trail of a cocktail
fields.trailText: You have done a service in highlighting the pioneering cocktail work of the Criterion and its bartender, Leo Engel (Shaking it up, Space, November 16). But the search for England's first "American bar" does not end there.
fields.body:
You have done a service in highlighting the pioneering cocktail work of the Criterion and its bartender, Leo Engel (Shaking it up, Space, November 16). But the search for England's first "American bar" does not end there.

In the introduction to the first cocktail recipe book ever published, The Bon-Vivant's Companion by Jerry Thomas (1862), we read the following: "We well remember seeing one day in London, in the rear of the Bank of England, a small drinking saloon that had been set up by a peripatetic American, at the door of which was placed a board covered with the unique titles of the American mixed drinks supposed to be prepared within that limited establishment."

The drinks in question included the Connecticut Eye-Opener, Alabama Fog-Cutter, Lightning Smash and Thunderbolt. They created a sensation. Find this bar, and you can say you've found the first cocktail bar in Europe.
William Grimes
Restaurant critic, New York Times

fields.headline: The day Maggie left
fields.trailText: "Thatcher's gone!" yelled my wife, who was listening to the radio (Letters, November 21). We both rushed to the TV, which chose that moment to give up the ghost.
fields.body:
"Thatcher's gone!" yelled my wife, who was listening to the radio (Letters, November 21). We both rushed to the TV, which chose that moment to give up the ghost. Within one hour we were installing a new set, just in time to witness the whole scene. We shall be toasting our 10-year-old telly today.
Rev David Meachem
Worcester
dm_missioncontrol@hotmail.com

 I was in a Wrexham poll tax court with 100 other non-payers when the clerk announced over the Tannoy that Thatcher had resigned. The cheer was so loud because we knew that it was the poll tax protest that saw her off.
M Davies
Welsh Socialist Alliance

 I was lodging on the top floor of a house owned by a High Court judge and his leisured aristocratic spouse. When the joyous news was announced I played Robert Wyatt's version of The Red Flag so loudly you could hear it all the way down to the servants' quarters.
Rob Chapman
Manchester

 Making Relenza available should at least cut waiting times to the 48 hours agreed with the British Medical Association. Doctors' waiting rooms full of sneezing and coughing flu victims should discourage most other patients from visiting at all.
Steve Downing
Liverpool
steved@liv.ac.uk

 Can we be told more about the "giant alsatian" encountered by John Vidal and the Greenpeace protestors during their visit to Britain's largest importer of genetically modified soya beans (Fowl play triumphs in dockside stunt, November 21)? How giant? What is the firm feeding it?
Bob Bird
Great Missenden, Bucks
bobbirdxxx@aol.com

 David Lewis of Chingford (Letters, November 21) refers to the "anachronistic distinction between fewer and less". I presume he would be happy to accept the alternative version of the words of Winston Churchill: "Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so less". We must deny his assertion and the quotation may serve to refute it.
Scott Hamilton
Cheadle, Cheshire

 Would Daniel Lewis prefer to be numbered among the fewer intelligent Guardian readers, or the less intelligent ones?
Murray Weton
Stevenage, Herts
murray@freesia.junglelink.co.uk

 More content, less grammar.
Ian Gunn
Oxford

webTitle: Letters: Excessive overtime? Get a life

fields.headline: Get a life
fields.trailText: However much official working hours are reduced (Excessive overtime causing havoc to families, November 21), there will still be those who choose to overwork, for no extra money, the presentees, often men with small children.
fields.body:
However much official working hours are reduced (Excessive overtime causing havoc to families, November 21), there will still be those who choose to overwork, for no extra money, the presentees, often men with small children.

Perhaps they are denied a role at home, are victims of a lousy childhood, maybe they are even jealous of the attention the children get from their partner. Excessive working hours need to be seen as the province of sad people, and not praised and encouraged. Rose Sutton
London

fields.headline: Chaotic train operators compound travellers' misery
fields.trailText: I am delighted to hear from George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies (Timetable despair, November 21), that 16 rail operators are now running near-normal train services. What about the other nine, on one of whose lines I am privileged to commute?
fields.body:
I am delighted to hear from George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies (Timetable despair, November 21), that 16 rail operators are now running near-normal train services. What about the other nine, on one of whose lines I am privileged to commute?

Since last Wednesday, we have had no trains at all between Middlesbrough, Hartlepool and Sunderland, ostensibly because of one landslip north of Hartlepool. When we asked the operator why this prevented the provision of trains at least to Hartlepool, we were told that passengers preferred to travel from Sunderland by bus to Middlesbrough [35 miles] rather than to change to and from a train en route. I have yet to meet any passenger who recognises any truth in this.

Commuters travel between Middlesbrough, Stockton and Hartlepool and - amid a welter of frequent buses and a good road network - increasing numbers have been choosing the train for this. So why does the rail management treat them so cavalierly, with not even a notice at any of the stations to say that the trains are not running, let alone to estimate just when the replacement buses might pass instead?

Connex lost its franchise because it cancelled too many trains without good reason. Is the Strategic Rail Authority keeping an eye out for similar infringements along the populous north-east coast, I wonder?
Peter Walker
Billingham, Tees-side

 I was one of those who believed that fuel should be taxed and that the public should be encouraged to use public transport. Recent experience changed my views.

Last week my wife wished to visit her mother in Manchester. When we arrived at Watford station we discovered that the train had been cancelled, and she had to wait for over an hour for the next train.

On the return journey my wife rang before leaving Manchester, but when I arrived at Watford station to collect her the train indicators were out of action and nobody knew when the Manchester train would arrive.

I can understand that trains are running slow due to rail repairs. But there is no excuse for the current chaos and the total lack of information. The train operators appear to care absolutely nothing about the public. I suspect they would like to take the government subsidy - taxpayers' money - and run no trains at all. The subsidy could then be distributed among directors and shareholders.
LJ Bental
Potters Bar, Herts

 Judging by the number of mobile phones being used on "trains from hell", the mobile communications industry must be making a fortune out of frustrated passengers. If they gave even 10% of these profits to Railtrack, the latter could afford to replace trains with chauffer-driven limos, thus freeing up the rail system for some emergency leaf-clearing.
Aine Duffy London

fields.headline: Hackneyed and hapless
fields.trailText: It is unfortunate that the Guardian readers' editor has undermined Peter Hetherington's fair and balanced article on Hackney (Hapless Hackney faces £40m meltdown, November 11) by printing a "correction" (November 20) that infers that the Liberal Democrats are innocent of creating the current crisis, having never been the majority party.
fields.body:
It is unfortunate that the Guardian readers' editor has undermined Peter Hetherington's fair and balanced article on Hackney (Hapless Hackney faces £40m meltdown, November 11) by printing a "correction" (November 20) that infers that the Liberal Democrats are innocent of creating the current crisis, having never been the majority party.

Hackney has been a hung council since 1996, however the voting record of the past four years shows clearly that the council was being run by an "anti-Labour" coalition of minority parties, of which the Liberal Democrats were the largest and leading component.

This coalition introduced the disastrous Transforming Hackney programme in 1997, that devolved financial management to departments without proper central controls, which led to the current crisis.

Although the Labour group made its opposition to such policies clear in the council chamber, a stance subsequently vindicated by various auditors and inspectorates, it was consistently out-voted by the Liberal Democrat-led alliance.

I suggest that in future you refer to the Liberal Democrat "maladministration" of Hackney.
Jules Pipe
Labour group leader,
London borough of Hackney

fields.headline: Adoption reform is long overdue
fields.standfirst: Adoption law in England and Wales has not kept up with changes in family relationships, writes Deborah Cullen of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering
fields.trailText: Adoption law in England and Wales has not kept up with changes in family relationships, writes Deborah Cullen of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering
fields.body:
Adoption law in England and Wales is out of date and not well-designed to meet the needs of the children who are now likely to be adopted, or their families. It is governed by the Adoption Act 1976, but much of this legislation in fact dates from 1958 - when adoption was chiefly concerned with the placement of babies born to single mothers.

Reforms enacted in 1975, and introduced piecemeal until 1988, acknowledged that some older, "hard-to-place" children were being adopted. Importantly, local authorities were given the power to pay adoption allowances in cases where children with special needs placed additional financial strains on their adoptive families.

Grounds for dispensing with parental agreement to adoption were expanded in an attempt to address the problem of children "languishing" in care. The concept of "freeing for adoption" was introduced, and was brought into force in 1984. This enabled the court to end the birth parents' rights over the child and to transfer these to the adoption agency.

The purpose of this was twofold. First, it aimed to stop the suffering of parents, who wished to relinquish infants for adoption, during delays before the adoption was finalised; and to avoid causing distress to the child and prospective adopters where parents withdrew from their agreement at the last moment. Second, where parents opposed adoption, a freeing application could be used to ask the court, in advance of a decision to place the child with adopters, whether it was appropriate to overrule the parents' opposition.

The legislation included only a very limited provision for revoking freeing orders if the child was not actually adopted. Unfortunately, a number of children - freed for adoption, but never adopted - now have as their legal parent only the local authority.

The 1975 reforms also attempted to reverse the increase in step-parent adoptions. But, despite an initial reduction, these have continued to represent more than half the adoption orders made. In the event, the specific requirement for the court to prefer a "joint custody" or "custodianship" order to adoption in such cases was removed by the Children Act 1989.

The Children Act was enacted following a thorough review of childcare law - called for by the House of Commons select committee on children in care in relation to concerns raised by the Cleveland inquiry, which occurred after Cleveland council took more than 100 children into care in 1987 on the grounds of suspected sexual abuse. But the opportunity to review adoption law was not taken at the same time, and an interdepartmental review of adoption law was only established as the Children Act was completing its passage through parliament. Despite a number of relatively minor amendments to the Adoption Act 1976, which are contained in the Children Act, adoption law has not kept up with children's legislation.

The Children Act requires a court to treat the welfare of any child under its consideration as the "paramount consideration". It sets out a useful checklist of factors to be considered in disputed applications, or those involving the local authority. It requires courts to act on the assumption that delay is likely to be harmful to the child's welfare. It explicitly requires local authorities to ascertain and take into consideration the views of children, their parents - including fathers who may not have "parental responsibility" - and other people important to the child. Under the Act, local authorities are required to have regard for the child's needs arising from his or her religious persuasion, racial origin and cultural and linguistic background, and to try and keep siblings together wherever possible.

All these, as well as a proper means of ensuring that children's views are always made known to the court, are matters that need to be incorporated in a new adoption bill. In addition, the following points need to be addressed.

 Cohabiting couples should be allowed to apply jointly for an adoption order. This would recognise the reality of the situation where a child is placed with two people living together, but not married to each other, who intend to share the parenting role. It would also increase the number of potential adopters.

 There needs to be change in the grounds for dispensing with parental agreement to adoption. This question was thoroughly addressed by the adoption law review. It is hard to better the recommendation, contained in the review's report to ministers, that a parent's consent to adoption should be dispensed with only if the court is satisfied that the advantages of adoption would be so significantly greater for the child than any alternative option as to justify overriding the wishes of the parents.

 "Freeing for adoption" should be replaced by a provision that enables the issue of parental consent to be addressed prior to the child's placement for adoption - without ending the child's relationship with his or her birth parents until new, adoptive, parents are able to take their place. Placement orders, as outlined in the March 1996 draft adoption bill, could provide an appropriate framework, with some amendments.

 Local authorities should be given a much stronger and clearer statutory obligation to provide post-adoption support for all those affected by the adoption, including greatly improved and more consistently applied adoption allowances.

 We need to see an adjustment in the definition of the legal status conferred by adoption. While it should remain the case that adoptive parents acquire full parental status from the date of the adoption, the legal fiction that the child was never the child of his or her birth parents should be removed.

 A new order should be introduced to confer guardianship on those caring permanently for a child, without severing all legal relationship with the birth parents. This would be useful in cases where the child is cared for by relatives and in instances where the child is to have a permanent home with current foster carers, but does not wish to lose his or her legal family relationships.

 A similar form of guardianship may be appropriate for some stepfamilies. In those cases where adoption is still thought to be appropriate, the law should be amended to enable the step-parent to be the sole applicant for an adoption order - so that the child's parent is not required to assume the artificial status of adoptive parent.

webTitle: Community groups should fight best value red tape with constructive ideas

fields.headline: Community groups should fight best value red tape with constructive ideas
fields.standfirst: Public sector ideas about best value policy implementation can be influenced by the voluntary sector, writes Margaret Harris
fields.trailText: Comment: Public sector ideas about best value policy implementation can be influenced by the voluntary sector, writes Margaret Harris
fields.body:
Managers of local voluntary agencies increasingly feel that they are engaged in an unending race to predict and react to changing public policies.

Best value is just one of the latest examples. Even before local authorities themselves have come to terms with demonstrating best value in their own performance, the shock waves are reaching the small voluntary agencies they fund. The "four Cs" (challenge, consult, compare, compete) may feel like a bundle of last straws on the back of a manager of a local advice bureau that is struggling with an overflowing waiting room of distressed clients and a shortage of volunteer advisers to help them.

But voluntary agencies need not be helpless victims of public policy change. Of course organisations need to be constantly aware of, and responsive to, their environments if they are to survive. And public policies are clearly an important part of the environment in which voluntary agencies work. On the other hand, organisations also have the capacity to influence their environments. Voluntary agencies can do much to shape the public policy agenda, even while responding to it.

In fact it is far more challenging to implement public policies than to formulate them. Once the think tanks and favoured gurus have moved on to their next big idea and the ministerial photo-opportunity launch has been reported, public sector officials are left with the puzzle of making it all happen at the local (and often these days, regional) level. At this stage they need active cooperation from the voluntary sector.

There has been a move towards local "compacts" which formally recognise the distinctive worth and contributions of the voluntary and governmental sectors. Nonetheless, it remains tempting for public sector employees who deal with local voluntary agencies to take an authoritarian stance, demanding detailed evidence of contract compliance or best value, for example. This approach mirrors the expectations placed on their own large departments, but can be overwhelming for a small community group.

Voluntary agencies may be reluctant to question these severe demands for fear of losing core funding and local good will. But they should not forget their own power to influence, as well as to be influenced.

Performing with best value, involving users, public-private regeneration initiatives, tackling social exclusion - all of these ideals require vision, enthusiasm and pragmatism if they are to be transformed from politicians' dreams into social benefits at the local and regional level.

Often the harsh approach of public sector officials masks a lack of alternative ideas. So voluntary agencies that use their practical experience of local service delivery and advocacy to propose effective ways to implement broad policy principles may find themselves more valued.

Voluntary organisations which approach their funders with confidence about their own community contribution and a quiver full of useful ideas can find that they are gradually accepted as truly equal "partners" in the policy implementation game.

 Margaret Harris is professor of voluntary sector organisation at Aston Business School. The book Voluntary Organisations and Social Policy, which she co-edited with Colin Rochester, has just been published by Palgrave (formerly Macmillan).

fields.headline: Lord's cracks down on appeals
fields.trailText: Cricket's much maligned men in white coats will get greater protection next summer, with a new law designed to curtail the growing intimidation of umpires.
fields.body:
Cricket's much maligned men in white coats will get greater protection next summer, with a new law designed to curtail the growing intimidation of umpires.

The England and Wales Cricket Board yesterday announced a law to cut down on aggressive appealing and premature celebrations. It reads: "In the event of an appeal, all members of the fielding team must maintain their fielding positions until a decision is given, unless legitimately in the act of fielding or backing up the ball which is not yet dead. For the purposes of this playing condition, a referral to the third umpire will constitute a decision."

The ECB is concerned that excessive appealing is spreading into county cricket from the more intense international game. The new law is also designed to discourage fielders, such as mid-on and mid-off, joining the wicketkeeper and bowler in their appeal.

But instead of welcoming the move, some umpires are concerned at the increasing level of responsibility being given to the third official. Ray Julian, who will retire after completing 30 years on the first-class umpires' list next season, said last night: "The job of the third umpire is now becoming one of the most difficult in the game. And he's paid less than the two officials who are standing.

"It is important that the human element in the game is maintained and that the men in the middle have a greater responsibility than just counting up to six."

Umpires are also concerned by reports that Channel 4 plans to give its own verdict on appeals next season. It is expected to unofficially uphold more appeals than the umpires, which is expected to put more pressure on the officials.

The ECB also moved to improve over rates next season. It is scrapping the old regulation whereby a team is fined for a slow over rate. That has had little effect on the players because the fine is usually picked up by the club or the sponsor. But from next season the ECB will introduce a points fine for teams failing to achieve the required over rates.

In its statement the ECB said: "The Board's Cricket Advisory Committee acknowledged that the current system of fines was not reducing the slow over rates in County Championship cricket. From the 2001 season a system of penalty points will instead be applied for slow over rates, on a match by match basis.

"The minimum over rate for all teams in every match throughout the season will be 16 overs per hour. If a team fails to attain this over rate, calculated over the duration of the match, it will be deducted championship points on the following basis: one over short of the match target, 0.25 points deduction; two overs short of the match target, 0.5 points deduction; three overs short of the match target, 0.75 points deduction etc."

No allowances will be made for wickets taken or drinks intervals when the over rate is calculated, but any suspension of play for an injury or other reason beyond the control of the players will be a deductible allowance.

webTitle: England lose Cork but not bottle

fields.headline: England lose Cork but not bottle
fields.standfirst: Hoggard and Tudor raring to stake claim for unexpected Test place
fields.trailText: Matthew Hoggard and Alex Tudor are raring to stake a claim for an unexpected Test place after the decision to send Dominic Cork home.
fields.body:
The back injury which had threatened Dominic Cork's tour finally proved too much. The Derbyshire bowler, a forlorn figure over the past few days, set out for England last night ready to begin the battle to be fit for the second leg of England's winter, in Sri Lanka at the end of January.

Five days ago he had a cortisone injection in his lower back in the hope that he could play in the three-day match here tomorrow and put himself in contention for the second Test in Faisalabad next week. There was also an MRI scan to help the diagnostics. Neither could save his tour.

With Matthew Hoggard raring for an opportunity and Alex Tudor also here, England will not be seeking a replacement unless, perhaps, something untoward happens to Craig White's hamstring in the next few days.

Cork's concern now is that the lower back pain, something new to him, is a symptom of something seriously wrong structurally. He said yesterday that he had bowled in the indoor school at Derby before joining the tour four weeks ago and suffered no discomfort. "It has been a gradual thing that has got worse," he said before packing his bags.

"It inhibited me in the first four-day match in Rawalpindi, where it may have looked as if I was not running in too well. I've never had anything like this before. It is a first for me and now I just want to see if anything structurally serious is wrong. We decided between us that to return home was the best course."

On his return he will be under the supervision of the England doctors and remaining in regular contact with the team physiotherapist Dean Conway. It will be a race against time. The side leaves for Sri Lanka in nine weeks' time and the selectors will want evidence of full fitness before that.

Although the inclusion of spinners here meant there was no place for him in the opening Test, he was still optimistic that a change of strategy by Pakistan might have meant more seamer-friendly pitches in Faisalabad and Karachi and that he might have had a part to play.

Criticism of the Lahore pitch has come from an unexpected source, the chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board. The Derbyshire bowler, a forlorn figure over the past few days, set out for England last night ready to begin the battle to be fit for the second leg of England's winter, in Sri Lanka at the end of January. webTitle: Is Waugh's team the best ever?

fields.headline: Is Waugh's team the best ever?
fields.standfirst:
Tomorrow the Australians set out to equal the Windies' 11 Test wins on the trot
Is Waugh's team the best ever?
fields.trailText: Tomorrow the Australians set out to equal the Windies' 11 Test wins on the trot. We compare the class of 1984 with the class of 2000.
fields.body:
Heartless, frowning, unbending ruthlessness is Steve Waugh's gift to Australian Test cricket. Twenty-one months ago Mark Taylor bequeathed to him the most powerful and attacking team in the world. Waugh retained the daredevil nuts and bolts but extinguished the mortal character flaws; the shakes that crept in when Australia were posed 120 or fewer to win, the careless habit of throwing away meaningless final Tests. Losing became a dirty word.

"This is only the beginning," Waugh announced last April after his side had nailed their 10th straight Test win. "We can play better than that. We're on the verge of something special." Tough-talking antipodean arrogance? Or a declaration of serious intent?

All will be revealed over the next two weeks. Tomorrow in Brisbane, Waugh's men will set out to equal the 11 wins in a row chalked up by Clive Lloyd's 1984 West Indians. A week later in Perth, they will be overwhelming favourites to shatter a record thought to be as unbreakable as Jim Laker's 19 wickets at Old Trafford or Courtney Walsh's 37 career ducks. And what a place to rewrite history: the Waca, bullring of bounce, paradise of pace, the happiest of Caribbean happy hunting grounds. The diatribe awaiting Jimmy Adams's dire tribe, should they lose, will haunt the Lillee-Marsh stand for years to come. The title of greatest team of the modern era will have been passed on.

Well, maybe. Waugh is not going to like this, but there is a compelling argument that his side lack the swagger and menace of Lloyd's laconic lords of '84.

Four times out of 11, Lloyd's side triumphed by an innings; Waugh's men have done so twice. West Indies' narrowest wins were by eight wickets and 172 runs; the 2000 Australians have scraped home by four wickets, six wickets (twice) and 62 runs.

Eight of West Indies' 11 wins came on foreign soil; Australia have been less unshakeable abroad. West Indies' batsmen averaged 42.17 per wicket; Australia's 41.59. Their bowlers 21.89 runs a scalp; Australia's 23.96. Pedantic considerations maybe, but decisive.

Yet there are uncanny parallels. Amid a shelf full of flashing blades, at the forefront of both teams is a stodgy, no-frills left-hander. Larry Gomes nudged 729 runs at 91 during the Windies' run, and Justin Langer - a new-millennium version of Gomes minus the afro - has been Australia's dominant runscorer.

Both sides possess precocious counter-punchers in Richie Richardson and Ricky Ponting, ageing masters in Lloyd and Waugh, and underperforming past masters in Viv Richards and Mark Waugh. They also boast the luxury of outstanding batsman-keepers in Jeff Dujon and Adam Gilchrist, and neither team contains a class all-rounder.

But in other areas West Indies reign supreme. For openers, Gordon Greenidge and Desmond Haynes form a more brazenly blockbusting duo than Michael Slater and Greg Blewett, who average only 34 for the first wicket. The Windies' mean machine has a distinct edge in quaking hostility. The explosive Brett Lee currently takes a wicket every 32.8 balls - a phenomenal strike-rate. But Malcolm Marshall, whose purplest patch coincided with the Windies' 1984 run, is at least Lee's equal.

On paper, Australia's ace card lies on the spin front. Yet the off-spinner Roger Harper played nine of West Indies' 11 Tests, accruing 24 wickets at a better average than Shane Warne has collected his. And he was a phenomenally acrobatic fielder to boot.

"I don't want to upset Steve Waugh too much," the former Australia left-hander Neil Harvey opined this year, "but I don't think his team is as good as Ian Chappell's 1972 side or Richie Benaud's 1958 side, let alone the 1948 side." Fans of Bradman's 1948 invincibles, Warwick Armstrong's 1920-21 Australians, Frank Worrell's 1963 West Indians and, at a pinch, the Illingworth Army, undefeated in 26 Tests through the late 60s and early 70s, could all challenge Waugh's side as the greatest ever.

What is unnerving, however, is they have won 10 successive Tests despite having glaring room for improvement. Slater still lacks a reliable opening partner - Matthew Hayden gets yet another chance tomorrow - and the speed dream team of Lee, Glenn McGrath and Jason Gillespie have yet to grace the field together; the latter withdrew yesterday with a hamstring strain. Just how far can they go?

Among the crowd tipping a whitewash of the Windies this summer are Kim Hughes ("our third team would beat them, the top XI will murder them") and Ashley Mallett ("Australia will win 5-0 unless they all play dead"). It is far from fantasy: the tourists have been blitzed in their opening two first-class matches and will field an attack green enough to make the survivors of the 1960-61 tied Test, who will be at the Gabba tomorrow, turn red.

If Hughes, Mallett and co are right, Australia will have won 15 on the trot come January. Add a quick fling in India and they could arrive on England's doorstep next summer chasing an unthinkable 19.

Steve Waugh was not kidding. Australia may be on the verge of something special.

webTitle: Dinning's early strike fires up Wolves

fields.headline: Dinning's early strike fires up Wolves
fields.trailText: Wolves 2 - 0 Grimsby
fields.body:
Wolves took full advantage of this meeting with their fellow rivals in distress to end a run of three consecutive league defeats which had left them on the cusp of the relegation zone.

The win, their first at home in the league since September, lifts them four places to 17th and above Grimsby, whose lack of resources does not augur well for their safety.

A sparse crowd by Molineux standards suggested that the fans' anger - which has seen off such honourable men as Graham Turner and Graham Taylor in the past and now threatens to do likewise to the club's benefactor and chairman Sir Jack Hayward - has turned to apathy. Either that or the weather did for them.

The cold wind and incessant rain suggested that Sir Jack, back in his Cayman Islands bolthole, is in the best place. The multimillionaire who has ploughed much of his fortune into the club headed back there after the disgraceful crowd scenes in the wake of Wolves' home defeat by Palace nine days earlier and promised he would not be back for "some time".

More of these high-octane starts, however, should have him scuttling back sooner rather than later. Five minutes had elapsed when George Ndah came within inches of giving them the lead with a curling left-foot shot which cannoned to safety off the angle of Danny Coyne's goal.

The Grimsby goalkeeper was not so fortunate a minute later, following an incisive Wolves move down the left. Carl Robinson began it with a defence-splitting pass which found Lee Naylor. The England Under-21 full-back took the ball to the by-line before pulling it back for the unmarked Tony Dinning to volley home with his right foot.

It was the midfielder's fourth goal in 11 games since arriving from Stockport and he should have increased that tally by half-time. Again it was a through ball from Robinson which unhinged the defence but this time Dinning, with only Coyne to beat, fired wide.

But with seconds of the half to go Ndah, who had been a constant menace, headed into the net following more fine work down the left by Naylor.

The Mariners who had barely troubled Wolves' keeper in the first period, displayed more ambition in the second. And their overdue enterprise almost paid dividends 10 minutes into the half when Paul Groves out-jumped a posse of defenders to head a corner against the crossbar.

Wolverhampton Wanderers (4-4-2): Oakes; Muscat, Butler, Pollet, Naylor; Bazeley, Dinning, Osborn, Robinson; Emblen, Ndah.

Grimsby Town (3-5-2): Coyne; Handyside, Groves, Fosterwold; McDermott, Donovan, Murray, Campbell, Smith; Neilsen, Livingstone.

Referee : R Harris (Oxford).

fields.headline: Leeds lure Ferdinand for record £18m
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand is on the verge of becoming the most expensive player the country has ever known, in a £18m deal taking him to Leeds from West Ham.
fields.body:
Rio Ferdinand, hailed as the future of English football, is on the verge of becoming the most expensive player the country has ever known, in a £18m deal taking him to Leeds from West Ham.

After months in fruitless pursuit of the 22-year-old England central defender, Leeds finally broke through the Hammers' barrier by raising their long-standing offer by £3m to a mouthwatering sum that will also make the Londoner the world's costliest defender.

West Ham accepted the improved bid and Ferdinand will discuss personal terms with the Elland Road club today. His Leeds debut is planned for Sunday's televised home game with Arsenal.

It is believed Bayern Munich's late intervention, with the German champions ready to offer £16m, prompted Leeds to improve their offer to one that simply could not be refused. West Ham have always been reluctant to sell their most prized asset to another Premiership club and believed they could prise even more from the likes of Barcelona and Roma.

Peter Ridsdale, Leeds's chairman, hinted at a breakthrough yesterday when he said he could meet West Ham's valuation, suggesting that the Hammers would concede the battle for a few million more. Before that, Ridsdale said, "the sticking point has never been the money involved but whether they wanted to sell".

The Leeds chairman also confirmed that he spoke to the West Ham chairman Terry Brown at Elland Road on Saturday evening after "Rio had a very good game against us" in the east London club's 1-0 win.

Since then Leeds have applied pressure on the Ham mers, Ridsdale saying on Monday that Ferdinand "might be worth only £5m to them in the near future" - a reminder of the grave uncertainties over the transfer system.

Such dramatic player devaluation, of course, is now being risked by Leeds.

Leeds, whose Champions League campaign - for which Ferdinand will not be cup-tied - signals their renaissance as a real financial and playing power in the land, will make him the highest-priced player in the English game, his fee eclipsing the £15m record held jointly by Alan Shearer and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

Ferdinand will also shatter the world record for a defender, the £13m paid by Roma for the Argentine Walter Samuel in June.

fields.bodyText: Rio Ferdinand, hailed as the future of English football, is on the verge of becoming the most expensive player the country has ever known, in a £18m deal taking him to Leeds from West Ham. After months in fruitless pursuit of the 22-year-old England central defender, Leeds finally broke through the Hammers' barrier by raising their long-standing offer by £3m to a mouthwatering sum that will also make the Londoner the world's costliest defender. West Ham accepted the improved bid and Ferdinand will discuss personal terms with the Elland Road club today. His Leeds debut is planned for Sunday's televised home game with Arsenal. It is believed Bayern Munich's late intervention, with the German champions ready to offer £16m, prompted Leeds to improve their offer to one that simply could not be refused. West Ham have always been reluctant to sell their most prized asset to another Premiership club and believed they could prise even more from the likes of Barcelona and Roma. Peter Ridsdale, Leeds's chairman, hinted at a breakthrough yesterday when he said he could meet West Ham's valuation, suggesting that the Hammers would concede the battle for a few million more. Before that, Ridsdale said, "the sticking point has never been the money involved but whether they wanted to sell". The Leeds chairman also confirmed that he spoke to the West Ham chairman Terry Brown at Elland Road on Saturday evening after "Rio had a very good game against us" in the east London club's 1-0 win. Since then Leeds have applied pressure on the Ham mers, Ridsdale saying on Monday that Ferdinand "might be worth only £5m to them in the near future" - a reminder of the grave uncertainties over the transfer system. Such dramatic player devaluation, of course, is now being risked by Leeds. Leeds, whose Champions League campaign - for which Ferdinand will not be cup-tied - signals their renaissance as a real financial and playing power in the land, will make him the highest-priced player in the English game, his fee eclipsing the £15m record held jointly by Alan Shearer and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. Ferdinand will also shatter the world record for a defender, the £13m paid by Roma for the Argentine Walter Samuel in June.  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: D'Jaffo checks Fulham's quick-fire start
fields.trailText: Sheffield Utd 1 - 1 Fulham
fields.body:
Laurent D'Jaffo last night prevented his fellow Frenchman and idol Jean Tigana from pulling Fulham eight points clear at the top of the First Division when he cancelled out Steve Finnan's fourth-minute goal with a bizarre strike four minutes later.

Fulham ran rings round United's defence in the first few minutes, barely allowing them a sniff of the ball, and it was no surprise when Steve Finnan put them ahead with a remarkable solo effort.

The defender, who scored on his Republic of Ireland debut last week, picked up the ball 40 yards from goal and embarked on a dazzling run that swept him past four bemused defenders. Finding himself in the penalty area, he calmly drew Simon Tracey before prodding home with his left foot from 12 yards.

Normally that might have seen Fulham slip into overdrive. Yet four minutes later a lapse in concentration allowed United to equalise. Michael Brown played the ball into the path of the French striker Laurent D'Jaffo and he reacted well to smack a shot against the angle of post and bar.

As he lay on the ground Fulham made a hash of mopping up the danger and, when the ball found its way back towards D'Jaffo, he leapt up and tapped it in.

That gave United renewed heart and Marcus Bent should have made more of Paul Devlin's right-wing cross. But, with the goal at his mercy, he headed straight into the arms of the waiting Mikhail Taylor.

Fulham, though, refused to be knocked out of their stride and on 24 minutes only the agility of Tracey denied Fabrice Fernandes. Lee Clark then tried a 25-yard drive that whistled into the keeper's arms and Finnan blazed over.

Jean Tigana brought on Luis Boa Morte for the ineffective Louis Saha on the hour and 10 minutes later United handed a first taste of League action to their Cameroon international Patrick Suffo. The striker had been forced to wait for his debut after a spitting incident in France when he was with Nantes. Having finally completed his eight-month ban, he was given a rousing reception by the home crowd.

Fulham (4-4-2): Taylor; Finnan, Melville, Coleman, Brevitt; Davis, Clark, Fernandes, Goldbaek; Hayles, Saha.

Referee: P Rejer (Tipton).

webTitle: Svensson flies in to join Sunderland

fields.headline: Svensson flies in to join Sunderland
fields.trailText: Sunderland are set to sign Swedish player of the year Anders Svensson for £2m.
fields.body:
Sunderland's manager Peter Reid will today discuss personal terms with the Sweden international Anders Svensson after agreeing a fee of £2m with his club Elfsborg Boras.

The 24-year-old attacking midfielder, who scored 10 goals for Elfsborg last season and was Sweden's player of the year, flew in yesterday hoping to join his international team-mate Stefan Schwarz at the Stadium of Light. "I have spoken to Peter Reid," he said. "He wanted me to come here to meet him, the players, and to take a look at the stadium."

Newcastle United have invited the Finland international Hannu Tihinen for a trial. The 24-year-old centre-half almost joined Blackburn from Viking Stavanger last month. The Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is still hoping to persuade his board to sanction a £2m move for Tenerife's Argentine defender Pablo Paz.

Stockport County have become the latest club to try to tap the potentially lucrative Chinese market with its advertising revenue by taking the 29-year-old midfielder Li Ming on trial, prompting a mass protest outside the Beijing radio station where he hosts a chat show. He has won 110 caps.

Erik Meijer has extended his loan at Preston for six weeks, though Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier can recall him at 24 hours' notice. "I want to play and now I'm into a rhythm thanks to the games I've had with Preston," the Dutch forward said.

Notts County have signed Danny Allsopp, the Manchester City forward, on a three-month loan with a view to a £350,000 transfer.

West Bromwich's captain Derek McInnes, a £450,000 buy from Toulouse last summer, will be out for up to nine months with a knee-ligament injury. "The difficulty is that you do not find a Derek McInnes around every corner," said the manager Gary Megson, who is looking for a replacement.

webTitle: Working lives: Matt Seaton on working from home

fields.headline: Should I stay or should I go?
fields.standfirst:
The results of the government's huge survey into Britain's work-life balance show that we would all rather work at home. Really? Matt Seaton tried it, hated it and here explains why it will never be the way forward.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The results of the government's huge survey into Britain's work-life balance show that we would all rather work at home. Really? Matt Seaton tried it, hated it and here explains why it will never be the way forward.
fields.body:
According to employment minister Margaret Hodge's shiny new survey, working from home is an idea whose time has come. Apparently, we are all queuing up not to get on the bus, but to carry our favourite coffee mug upstairs and cosy up with the laptop. We are fed up with the distractions, irritations and office-politics of the commuting life. And the overwhelming reason given by the 10,000 employees and employers questioned for the government by University of Warwick researchers was that they could be much, much more efficient if they worked at home.

I can see that there would be spin-off benefits for society generally from home-working: fewer commuting journeys, less stress, more flexible hours and so forth. And some handy savings for employers, too: reduced office space costs, lower heating and light bills, lower rates of absenteeism. But for anyone to argue that working from home is more efficient... Well, nice try, folks: you can fool the government and the researchers from Warwick, but you can't fool me.

The truth is that working from home is hell. It is not just inefficient; it's impossible. If you're very lucky, you might have a dedicated study in which you can barricade yourself against the depredations of household pets, the screaming tantrums of pre-schoolers, the marauding curiosity of post-schoolers and the general mayhem that is family life. For at least two people I know who work from home, the only way in which they could establish a sufficiently airtight and soundproof cordon sanitaire to keep their domestic menageries out of their working environment was to move into a shed in the garden.

I'm sorry, but where I come from, garden sheds are for middle-aged men to keep their potting compost and jazz mags in. They were never intended as hi-tech business units for teleworkers to blaze the trail of the new economy.

When I started working from home, I didn't have a study, so I set up a desk in the living room. This meant our young children were then exiled to the ground floor with their nanny. The only satisfactory aspect of this arrangement was that she was prevented from pacifying them with non-stop screenings of Pingu and the Teletubbies. Within weeks, however, my wife went freelance, too - working out of our bedroom on a folding table. As if having young children were not stressful enough, our marriage was put to the test by ferocious turf wars for telephone time, involving much hissing and angry gesticulation. Of course, we ordered a new phone number at once, but since we had recently swapped service providers, it proved impossible to get a line installed. An engineer finally kept a fourth appointment. Come to think of it, at least I hadn't given up any working time keeping the others - an efficiency saving after all!

The other awkward truth about home-working is that if, like me, you suffer from the slightest defect of motivation, you are placing yourself in the grip of mental agony. First, there are all those household chores you should really do before you start work - otherwise, you know that the dirty plates, the unhung laundry, the uncleaned loo will be whispering their silent reproaches all day. Then there's that fascinating radio programme you never used to catch when you went out to work: it only lasts half an hour, after all. And daytime TV? Let's not even go there.

Competition for phone and desk use meant I found myself migrating around the house with my laptop - even, on one occasion, perching on the loo because it provided temporary sanctuary from the domestic chaos raging outside. Contrary to popular assumptions, laptops are not actually intended for use on your lap; a few minutes of that results in aching shoulders and tingling fingers. It soon became obvious total nervous breakdown would shortly follow.

I remember researching and writing one article for a Sunday newspaper about the phenomenon of "presenteeism": the practice of spending long hours in the office, even unproductive hours, in order to appear "committed". To be sure, Britain does have a severe problem with its workplace culture of long hours - as the government's survey also highlights - but all I could think of at the time was, chance would be a fine thing!

Eventually, I found a cheap office-share with some other self-employees. My life - and my productivity - improved a hundred-fold. I could cycle to work, stop at a Starbucks, arrive with a latte at a quiet, empty office and do an uninterrupted day's work. I got so much more done I could even find time to go swimming or stop at the shops on my way home. After the madness of home-working, it was bliss.

What I discovered, even though I was then still working a four-day week and looking after my children for the extra day, was that a distinct break - a mental firewall, as much as the physical distance - between work and home was, for me at least, crucial for psychological health. When I was at work, I could really focus on the task I had set myself: I could achieve it, or something near enough, and then leave for the day, my mind at rest. By the same token, once I was at home, I was really present: instead of worrying about my work and scheming to snatch a few extra minutes at the computer or sneak in one more phone call, I could devote myself and my attention fully to my children and the domestic routine.

I realised also that, correspondingly, there is something profoundly depressing about working at home. It's as if you haven't got a proper job, as if you are some sad Walter Mitty-type fantastist, pathetically impersonating someone with a professional career, or like the eponymous hero of John Lanchester's last novel, Mr Phillips, who cannot accept his own obsolescence after being made redundant. Most of us gain self-esteem from our identity as a working person, but there is little benefit if that work takes place in social isolation.

It may be a "guy thing", this need for compartmentalisation: home here, work there. But I suspect not. The interesting small print of this week's survey was that men are far more enthusiastic than women about home-working: 40% of men, as against 29% of women, expressed a desire to work away from the office. Perhaps the women know something the men don't. All I know is that after a hectic family weekend, a week in the office feels like R and R.

fields.headline: Nationwide rate cut creates challenge
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nationwide building society yesterday cut its standard mortgage rate by 0.2% in a move that will reduce the average borrower's bill by £120 a year and puts pressure on other lenders to trim their borrowing costs.
fields.body:
Nationwide building society yesterday cut its standard mortgage rate by 0.2% in a move that will reduce the average borrower's bill by £120 a year and puts pressure on other lenders to trim their borrowing costs.

The announcement represents the latest manoeuvre in the cut-throat battle for home loan customers and underlines Nationwide's belief that interest rates have peaked and the next base rate movement is likely to be down.

From December 1, Nationwide's standard variable mortgage rate will drop from 7.29% to 7.09% - 0.65% below the standard rate of many of its competitors. But there was also disappointment for the society's 8m-strong army of savers with the news that savings rates will be reduced.

Home owners hoping their mortgage company will im mediately match the Nationwide's cut are likely to be disappointed - Halifax and Abbey National, the two biggest lenders, last night gave no indication that they planned to cut rates ahead of any base rate move.

New figures show that remortgaging has reached record levels as growing numbers of people become aware of the money they can save by switching to another lender's deal. Last month, for the first time, remortgages made up a third of all new mortgage lending, the Council of Mortgage Lenders said.

Nationwide and the other traditional lenders are having to fight hard to hold on to their borrowers, many of whom are being lured to more attractive deals by new entrants, some of them internet-based.

This month saw the arrival in the UK of Australia's biggest financial services company, Commonwealth Bank of Aus tralia, which is offering a range of flexible mortgages through an internet and telephone venture called NewWorld.

In the summer HSBC cut its standard variable mortgage rate by almost one percentage point, and the Halifax's new phone bank, Intelligent Finance, launched with a competitive rate.

Nationwide said someone with a £60,000 interest-only mortgage would see monthly bills cut by £10 a month (from £364.50 to £354.50). For a borrower with a £100,000 loan the saving would be £16.66 a month.

The Bank of England has kept interest rates on hold since February and there is a growing expectation among commentators that the next interest rate movement is more likely to be down than up, said Nationwide.

Rivals said the Nationwide move showed the mortgage price war was taking its toll.

fields.headline: Masekela shakes those rusty-dusties
fields.standfirst:
Hugh Masekela
Ronnie Scott's, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Hugh Masekela
Ronnie Scott's, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
It's a good 30 years since Hugh Masekela played in the Carnegie Hall and sold 4m copies of his hit track Grazing in the Grass, but there was no indication as he kicked off a two-week residency at Ronnie Scott's that this elder statesman of African jazz was anywhere near the end of the road. He has just released a CD of his greatest hits, and judging by his latest performance it'll be the first in a long series.

Still a notable trumpeter and flugelhorn player, these days his voice is his most persuasive instrument. He emerged in barbershop harmony with his guitarist, John Selolwane, summoning the audience into action. "Put your hands together, people," he sang. "We're so happy to be with you!" Bass player Lucas Seyatso and drummer Dumisane Hlela set up a roomy vibe, preparing the way for an evening full of joyful noise.

In another half-sung monologue, Masekela paid tribute to his late mother who died while he was in exile from South Africa. "When I said to my parents and relatives I was going to become a musician," he growled by way of introduction, "they all looked at me very weird. They were social workers, health inspectors, teachers, doctors. They said, 'What are you going to do during the day?' And my mum said to them, 'Give the boy a chance.' If it wasn't for her, we probably wouldn't be here."

And with that, he launched into a track telling of his musical liberation, conjuring shades of Gil Scott-Heron with its gritty drive and lazy definition, and ending in a memorable "Huuh!"

The band relied on simple grooves, building in bright South African colours and gruff funk by means of percussion, guitar and horn episodes and alliterative vocals. In one mesmerising track dedicated to "all those people who lose their lives working in cheap labour", they reinforced the message with contrasts between ear-shattering percussion and soft chord patches on keyboards. Masekela described the dark trek of diamond miners to the metropolis and followed up with a plaintive warble on horn in tribute to the eloquent lives of his subjects.

Late on, the set caught alight with an anthem to Nelson Mandela, for which Masekela had everyone on their feet. "At the ripe young age of 82, we want to wish him a great long life because he's a beacon of humanity," he beamed.

I'm not usually one for getting out of my seat and shaking my rusty-dusties, but at Masekela's bidding, I got up and shook.

 Ends Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.
