In one mesmerising track dedicated to "all those people who lose their lives working in cheap labour", they reinforced the message with contrasts between ear-shattering percussion and soft chord patches on keyboards. Masekela described the dark trek of diamond miners to the metropolis and followed up with a plaintive warble on horn in tribute to the eloquent lives of his subjects. Late on, the set caught alight with an anthem to Nelson Mandela, for which Masekela had everyone on their feet. "At the ripe young age of 82, we want to wish him a great long life because he's a beacon of humanity," he beamed. I'm not usually one for getting out of my seat and shaking my rusty-dusties, but at Masekela's bidding, I got up and shook.  Ends Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: Bridges and Harmonies
fields.standfirst:
Bridewell, London
**
fields.trailText:
Bridewell, London
**
fields.body:
After the horrors of Mademoiselle Colombe, the London Stage Company redeems itself a little with the premiere of Oren Lavie's elegiac stories about love beginning and love ending. The interest here is that while this is not a good play it shows enough signs of promise to suggest that Lavie might one day write one. You only wish that both he and the London Stage Company would curb their enthusiasm for the whimsical. "You start undressing, I'll join you in a minute," jokes artist Peter on meeting his new lodger, the beautiful, tearful, would-be comedienne Alice.

Alice rejects Peter's persistent advances but gradually lust turns to love and tears turn into rain beating against the panel of a window behind which two people kiss for the first time.

Meanwhile, on another part of the stage, Jane leaves songwriter Alex, making the parting easier by letting him believe that she has another lover. Alex refuses to compel Jane to stay by letting her know that he is dying.

Sounds like high-class Mills and Boon? It certainly is. This is the kind of evening that makes middle-aged men go misty-eyed and the hard-boiled like myself wish that the characters would get a life. Lavie's creations exist in a rarefied world where it is only the intensity of their feelings that matters, where they can dress up as clowns and weep all day, wander around soulfully to a little easy-listening music or sing duets at the piano. They exist only as tortured souls in love. They are artists who have turned their suffering into an art. You could never imagine them doing anything ordinary, such as going to Tesco or sitting on the loo.

By taking such an impossibly romantic stance (even a passing prostitute turns out to be beautiful, with cut-glass vowels and grade eight piano), Lavie reduces his characters from people to poseurs, from sympathetic heroes and heroines to stereotypes. So we have the kooky but unhappy girl with a past, the woman who needs to find herself before she can give herself in love, the dying artist, and the painter who needs to look behind the image to find love.

It is pleasant enough poppycock, given a slick, stylish production that puts us in no doubt that this is all supposed to be very moving and meaningful. If Lavie would stop being the self-conscious artist and both lighten up and toughen up, he might write a good play. Certainly there is enough grip of form and enough good lines in between the candyfloss to signal that he can do it. But please: not about artists, not about love and definitely not about artists in love.

 Until December 9. Box office: 020-7936 3456.

fields.headline: Moscow Radio SO
fields.standfirst:
Moscow Radio SO
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Moscow Radio SO
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating:****
fields.body:
Tchaikovsky's symphonies have always claimed a place in the hearts of most listeners. Yet there's still a tendency to think of Tchaikovsky as a picturesque tone-painter rather than a composer capable of sustaining a rigorous musical argument. He wrote some of the most heart-rending tunes in the repertoire, but has rarely been accorded the status of the greatest 19th century symphonists.

Vladimir Fedoseyev and the Moscow Radio Symphony Orchestra's performance of Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony was a magnificent riposte to this sentimentalised view of the composer. There was no lack of expressive detail in their playing, but they generated an ineluctable symphonic momentum.

Fedoseyev made each movement part of a logical progression, from the lamenting darkness of the slow introduction to the finale's intense light. The fleeting repose of the first movement's only major-key theme was heightened by Fedoseyev's broad tempo. This was a vision of unattainable resolution in the midst of the music's minor-key murk. The slow movement provided a perfect counterbalance. The radiant nostalgia of the famous horn melody was twice shattered by the brute, brassy force of the symphony's looming motto theme. In Fedoseyev's interpretation, the joyously transformed version of the motto in the introduction to the finale was only a provisional victory. The climactic thunder of the symphony's denouement was clinched through the last movement's whirling dynamism.

Even if Fedoseyev risked orchestral clarity in his pursuit of tempestuous energy - many passages were in danger of becoming cadenzas for the orchestra's noisily charismatic timpanist - he presented a Tchaikovsky of structure before sentiment.

After the luminous fantasy of Rimsky-Korsakov's May Night Overture, Freddy Kempf was the soloist in Rachmaninov's Third Piano Concerto. In another magisterial performance, Kempf brought a combination of enthusiastic impetuosity and experienced insight to the work's celebrated challenges. At 23, Kempf has already become a familiar figure in Russia, thanks to his legendary performances at the 1998 Tchaikovsky competition. And he has developed a symbiotic bond with Fedoseyev and the Moscow orchestra. Responding to the ebb and flow of each other's phrasing, Kempf and Fedoseyev created waves of melodic intensity which led inexorably to the overpowering final moments.

fields.headline: Au Coeur du Mensonge
fields.standfirst:
Edinburgh Filmhouse
*
fields.trailText:
Edinburgh Filmhouse
*
fields.body:
Claude Chabrol is a byword for French movie artistry, producing such films as L'Enfer, Madame Bovary and La Cérémonie in the last decade alone, but Au Coeur du Mensonge (The Colour of Lies) is lugubrious and leaden.

The premise is intriguing enough - a 10-year-old girl is found strangled in the woods outside her village, prompting a police investigation which exposes more than the murderer - but the execution is not. Returning to familiar territory, Chabrol concentrates on exposing bourgeois hypocrisies, the vice and violence lurking beneath the lacquered surface of life. In the provincial town, where everyone meets in the ironically named Bar des Amis, no one is completely honest with their friends, let alone with themselves. We are repeatedly reminded that everyone wears masks and covers their tracks, particularly those involved with the creative process. With the character of failed artist René, the artifice of painting is examined; while the faux philosophical musings of self-obsessed celebrity Desmot (a bog-standard Antoine de Caunes) expose the moral vacuum at the heart of the media.

For all its ambition, there is also a vacuum at the heart of this film. Beyond the first tense moments before and after the murder, it is simply not dramatic - the story plods on with all the energy and insistence of a sedated elephant.

None of the town's residents are supposed to be endearing, with the pathetic, irritating René emotionally as well as physically damaged after a bomb blast that sabotaged his career. He is possibly the last person to see the girl alive, yet while the town's moral panic swirls around him it is hard to engage with him emotionally, or with his wife, Vivianne. Only the policewoman - new to town and unfamiliar with the unspoken laws of the place - is interesting or, indeed, interestingly played. As Inspector Lesage, Valéria Bruni-Tedeschi is charismatic but woefully under-used.

Au Coeur du Mensonge is a pedestrian affair with only the stark scenery of Britanny providing any respite from what could pass for a sub-standard TV movie.

fields.headline: Ed Harcourt
fields.standfirst:
Ed Harcourt
Night and Day, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Ed Harcourt
Night and Day, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Spending a lot of time alone isn't always healthy. Left to stew in their own idiosyncratic juices, most singer-songwriters end up self-pitying and self-indulgent. Ed Harcourt, however, is different.

For a start, the 23-year-old plays electric piano, not acoustic guitar. And, while he retreated to a dilapidated house in a forest to write many of his dark songs, his biography reveals that he was nearly expelled from school for building a five-foot penis out of snow. It's safe to say he's serious but not taking himself too seriously. Last night he was joined by four supremely adept musicians playing everything from double-bass to trumpet. If his debut mini-album, Maplewood, is a homely peek into his world, here his songs were transformed into truly magical creations.

On certain levels, it's simple. Driving electric piano, pure plug-in joy, is juxtaposed with double-bass and that mercurial trumpet, while Harcourt unravels masterful melodies. The gospel-inflected Apple of My Eye could be U2, if they hadn't stopped writing good songs. Hangin' with the Wrong Crowd and Shanghai, meanwhile, are rich slabs of West Coast rock. Clearly, Harcourt could make a lot of money writing hits for other people. He's more interested, however, in playing his own songs such as I've Become Misguided, a banjo-led Cajun number via Badly Drawn Boy, and the warm, doleful complexity of the Flaming Lips-esque She Fell into My Arms.

Harcourt crams more ideas into one song (and he has already written more than 300) than most bands can muster for a full album. God Protect Your Soul starts out doomy spy-thriller and turns prettily psychedelic, before dropping a chorus where the keyboards seem to drain backwards out of the song. It's difficult to believe your ears. Moreover, it's a great chorus. These are clever songs, but even when the band impersonate a malfunctioning machine (clonking keys and panicked trumpet) the intention is obviously to create something beautiful and emotionally direct.

Part Jeff Buckley, part Mark Lanegan, Harcourt slips between a crushing baritone, a testifying zeal and a nicotine-scarred whisper, as he tells of the "bad things" he's seen. Harcourt may have grown up near Brighton but he's got those quasi-Biblical Nick Cave blues. He is canny enough, however, to realise that this lonesome lingua franca treads a fine line between universal truth and self-parody. Elsewhere, his lyrics are at vividly original, and subtly funny.

 Ed Harcourt plays the Social, Nottingham (0115 950 5078), tonight, then tours.

fields.headline: Edinburgh's erotic fabric show
fields.standfirst:
Alison Watt
National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh
Rating ****
fields.trailText:
Alison Watt
National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh
Rating ****
fields.body:
Alison Watt's exhibitions always do what they say on the tin. Her last major show in Scotland, Fold, at the Fruitmarket Gallery in 1997, was a series of diptychs contrasting the female nude "with all its folds and creases" and paintings of fabric. This show is called Shift, and now, in something of a fundamental shift in her way of working, Watt has ditched the body, preferring the sensual and suggestive delights of fabric alone.

Don't for one moment think that she has left the corporeal behind, though. For these are cheeky, impudent paintings. Faces swell out of the fabric panels; ghoulish eyes and noses peek from a seemingly innocent pale canvas. The way the fabric falls, you see a hooded figure or peer into suddenly obscene orifices, never quite sure if you have imagined it all.

First impressions are of intensity and elegance, especially in the first room, containing only white and cream paintings. Austere to begin with, these works grow on you. Their physicality reveals itself slowly, quietly. Spectral or sexual in the main, they are about the stories pieces of fabric might hold, the secrets they may have witnessed. Their use in concealment or undressing, the fact that to cover up can be more powerfully erotic than revealing all: this is what fascinates Watt. Swathes of cloth hang heavy, a droop or crumple of fabric begs questions, and sometimes there is an almost stifling human presence, especially in Rivière, a big deep intimate fold of fabric.

Less successful are the works that incorporate colour, not least because they are more like portraits of cloth rather than the fantastical, playful images in lighter tones. Suspend is the strongest of these, all flimsy loveliness, a gorgeous study in Virgin Mary blue, whereas Tournon, a painting of some vintage green and yellow fabric, feels like the life has been drained out of it. And it is life that Watt's best work captures - the way a discarded robe might tell a story, or crumpled sheets mean anything but sleep has taken place. From these little mysteries she makes paintings of much grace and beauty.

 Until January 7. Details: 0131-624 6200.

fields.headline: The prime of Miss Emmylou Harris
fields.standfirst:
Royal Albert Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Royal Albert Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
In the wake of her superb new album Red Dirt Girl, Emmylou Harris commented: "All of a sudden, I'm in a place that I didn't even know existed before." For 30 years, Harris has been a fixture in country music, both in her own right and in partnership with an assortment of greats, from Gram Parsons and Neil Young to Willie Nelson and Johnny Cash, but has never sounded as focused and sure of herself as she does now. It's as if she suddenly has a complete vision of herself as musician and songwriter, and can put her still-evolving career into a new perspective.

Accompanied by her skilful backing trio, Spyboy, Harris built this performance on a platform of songs from the new album, but also found time to reflect on some of her career landmarks. From the Parsons era, she highlighted Love Hurts and reworked Hickory Wind into a slow, mystical reverie. The ghosts of various line-ups of her erstwhile Hot Band flitted through The Boy from Tupelo and a honky-tonkish Wheels. Poncho & Lefty was a tribute to the late Townes van Zandt.

But it was the new material that proved particularly spellbinding. Never a prolific songwriter, Harris has now managed to tap into a grippingly resonant vein of material, as though exorcising decades' worth of dreams, demons and memories - "water from a deeper well", as she sings. It's the kind of purple patch any writer would cheerfully rip off their right arm to attain, and the visionary nature of some of these songs is staggering. Hour of Gold could have been exhumed from the grave of some medieval mystic. Michelangelo resembles a particularly savage soliloquy from Macbeth. The most stunning of the lot was Bang the Drum Slowly, Harris's requiem for her father, a former Air Force pilot. Part hymn and part dirge, it could have been horribly mawkish in lesser hands, but Harris sang it like an out-of-body experience, stunning the audience. As the final chords faded away, she hummed The Last Post.

This is the prime of Miss Emmylou Harris, and we should make the most of it.

&149; Emmylou Harris plays the Royal Concert Hall, Glasgow (0141-353 8000), tomorrow, then tours.

webTitle: Working lives: Richard Reeves  on graduates who know too much

fields.headline: Jobs for the BAs
fields.standfirst:
Richard Reeves on graduates who know too much

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Richard Reeves on graduates who know too much.
fields.body:
What do you say to a sociology graduate with a job? "Can I have fries with that, please?" OK, it's an old joke. And as we move into a knowledge economy, as employers lament the lack of skilled staff, as the government pushes to increase the number of young people entering university, it's surely long past its sell-by date.

Or maybe not. Perversely, given that intellectual capital - brainpower - is supposed to be the hottest commodity around, one of the biggest problems in the contemporary workplace is overeducation. The overeducated are graduates in jobs that do not require graduate skills. They are people who have not reaped the economic or occupational rewards of higher education. They are Dankys (a near-acronym: Degree Awarded, No Cash Yet). And, according to unpublished research by Peter Dolton at Newcastle University and Mary Silles at St John's College, Oxford, there are more of them around than ever.

In a paper presented to the London School of Economics, Dolton and Silles use data on Newcastle University alumni to show that 42% of graduates go immediately into sub-graduate jobs. This is not the most troubling finding - after all, lots of students with debts to pay off and no "real" job in sight take a low-skilled job to tide them over. But the research shows that 22% of all graduates are in jobs that are "beneath" them in terms of qualifications. What's more, during the course of their career, a quarter of graduates move down the occupation ladder, from jobs requiring graduate qualifications to those that do not demand a degree.

What's going on? Who are the Dankys? There is a long list of risk factors associated with entry to the ranks of the overeducated: taking part-time work; family commitments; staying in your university town; high levels of debt; a humanities, third-class or pass degree.

Few surprises there: with more graduates around, it is clear that the ones who struggle in the lecture hall will struggle in the labour market. But there are economic questions here, too. Dankys end up paid much less than their more successful classmates - indeed, the Dolton/Silles research suggests their pay is no higher than if they had not attended university. In other words, there is no payoff financially for the student.

More importantly, there is no economic payoff for the nation. The government invests in higher education to the tune of £15,000 per student. If as many as a fifth of those contribute no more in taxes or in value added to companies than their peers who started work at 18, then the value of that investment must be in doubt. Of course, three years of study-plus-drinking-plus-sport is a wonderful opportunity for the individual, even if it has no impact on their career. But it is doubtful Gordon Brown would reckon it a good use of the exchequer's funds.

In the meantime, there are thousands of people - in school and in work - who could reap greater rewards from university than the Dankys. Dolton and Silles suggest better career counselling and more flexible working patterns are needed, but the real lesson may be much harder. Maybe some of the people not entering HE should be brought in. And maybe some of the people currently being funded through HE should not be there.

Paying ball
If you thought business schools encouraged already anally retentive people to take themselves much too seriously... you were right. A student at Insead, Europe's leading business school, offers peers his thoughts on how to price tickets for their annual ball: "We have two different products, one of which is definitively higher risk (the ball + dinner ticket) than the other... the idea is to give precedence to the riskier product. To me this makes sense only if it yields a significantly higher marginal contribution... but we need to discount the margin we make on them by a yet to be assessed 'overcapacity factor'... I can see our business model is very unstable, because once we have fixed our catering capacity we break even if and only if we sell at capacity: anything less and we make a loss... In brief, if we really think that full price ticket is our primary driver, we should make a higher margin." Boy, those MBAs certainly know how to party.

fields.bodyText: What do you say to a sociology graduate with a job? "Can I have fries with that, please?" OK, it's an old joke. And as we move into a knowledge economy, as employers lament the lack of skilled staff, as the government pushes to increase the number of young people entering university, it's surely long past its sell-by date. Or maybe not. Perversely, given that intellectual capital - brainpower - is supposed to be the hottest commodity around, one of the biggest problems in the contemporary workplace is overeducation. The overeducated are graduates in jobs that do not require graduate skills. They are people who have not reaped the economic or occupational rewards of higher education. They are Dankys (a near-acronym: Degree Awarded, No Cash Yet). And, according to unpublished research by Peter Dolton at Newcastle University and Mary Silles at St John's College, Oxford, there are more of them around than ever. In a paper presented to the London School of Economics, Dolton and Silles use data on Newcastle University alumni to show that 42% of graduates go immediately into sub-graduate jobs. This is not the most troubling finding - after all, lots of students with debts to pay off and no "real" job in sight take a low-skilled job to tide them over. What's more, during the course of their career, a quarter of graduates move down the occupation ladder, from jobs requiring graduate qualifications to those that do not demand a degree. What's going on? Who are the Dankys? There is a long list of risk factors associated with entry to the ranks of the overeducated: taking part-time work; family commitments; staying in your university town; high levels of debt; a humanities, third-class or pass degree. Dankys end up paid much less than their more successful classmates - indeed, the Dolton/Silles research suggests their pay is no higher than if they had not attended university. In other words, there is no payoff financially for the student. More importantly, there is no economic payoff for the nation. The government invests in higher education to the tune of £15,000 per student. If as many as a fifth of those contribute no more in taxes or in value added to companies than their peers who started work at 18, then the value of that investment must be in doubt. Of course, three years of study-plus-drinking-plus-sport is a wonderful opportunity for the individual, even if it has no impact on their career. But it is doubtful Gordon Brown would reckon it a good use of the exchequer's funds. webTitle: Working lives: Judith Doyle  examines the emotional appeal of the office

fields.headline: 'Leaving a job is like the break-up of a romance'
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Work researcher Judith Doyle examines the emotional appeal of the office.
fields.body:
Behind the fanfare surrounding the government's first major report on work-life balance lies another truth about the contradictions we all face juggling home and the workplace. One of the reasons balancing work and "life" is so difficult is that work, for many of us, is so appealing.

Work is a gateway to a social network, to friends, to a community. In a world of increased individualism and globalisation, many of us are seeking a sense of belonging somewhere or to someone. In politics, this desire for belonging can translate into nationalism and racism, on one hand, or environmentalism on the other. On a personal level, the search for belonging takes people to internet chat rooms and clubs, to coffee shops - and to work.

Work seems to offer a ready-made community. It is a source of friends and lovers. Psychologically speaking, it enables individuals to relate to other individuals, and to society. One in three respondents to an Industrial Society survey met most of their friends through their current or previous jobs. The survey exploded the myth that work is a domain for male-only bonding: 49% of female respondents met most of their friends at work, compared with only 19% of the men. Judi James, in her book Sex at Work, estimates that up to half of us meet our future partners through the workplace. No wonder it can seem so appealing.

Gossip sessions at the coffee machine, lazy conversations about holiday plans in the canteen - all add a social, communitarian dimension to work. Moments of shared meanings remind employees that they belong to a team, a company, something bigger than themselves - thus the workplace fulfils a fundamental human need.

There are downsides. For a start, breaking up is hard to do: as Erin Cullinane, a senior consultant at a prestigious mutual-fund company, puts it: "Leaving a job you've been in for years is emotional. It is just like the break-up of a romance."

Recent evidence from the US suggests the identification of work as family can have serious implications when a person is fired or betrayed. Ilene Philipson, a psychologist based in California, tells of a group counselling service she offers to women who have become incapacitated since they were fired or left work - women for whom work had come to mean everything. There is a single overarching narrative to their stories: "There is work that is life, connection, recognition and identity. There is betrayal. And there is the void, the sense of amputation not only from the specific job, but from human community and one's sense of place in that community."

The Industrial Society research asked respondents where they feel "most appreciated": at work, at home or equally at both. Overall, 58% of respondents felt appreciated equally at work and at home. Another 12% felt most appreciated at work. Most people are happy both at home and at work: in other words, work is not for the majority some soul-destroying prison. Twenty-eight per cent of respondents felt most appreciated at home. But - nailing another gender stereotype - women were more likely than men to feel appreciated at work. Employees feel appreciated for their skills, their competence, their knowledge, for their sense of humour, their kindness, their disposition - in other words, for themselves. Perhaps it is even a sense of being loved.

There are those whose work is a profession, a vocation, or just really interesting, where work and life merge into one, where work not only informs their identity, but their values inform the job they do. There are those for whom work provides an escape, a safe place away from unhappy or violent homes; a distraction from disappointing private lives. Whatever their reasons, some people want more work and less home.

 Judith Doyle's report, New Community or New Slavery? The Emotional Division of Labour, is published today by the Industrial Society.

fields.headline: Snake in Fridge
fields.standfirst:
Snake in Fridge
Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Snake in Fridge
Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Donna goes for walks wearing angel's wings, her mind damaged by the brother who raped her and then beat her up. Her protective sister, Caddie, dances naked every night to pay the bills, spitting venom at the men who watch.

Sweet Stacey is about to lose her sweetness and illusions as she moves in with boyfriend Randy, who's under the thumb of Violet, a net-porn entrepreneur. Corbett, grown up but with the mind of the 12-year-old who witnessed his mother blowing out her brains, grosses out on drugs and pornography and yearns for the money to pay the rent and have a penis extension.

Only Travis appears to be holding out against the lure of easy money as he labours in a restaurant kitchen to pay off his student debt for the arts degree that got him nowhere.

These are the residents of a Toronto house, a Victorian pile that was also Corbett's childhood home and that now is haunted as much by its inhabitant's individual nightmares, fears and neuroses as it is by real ghosts. Oh, and there is one other occupant: a boa constrictor that has somehow escaped from the fridge and might be living in the basement devouring corpses.

This mixture of the gothic and the offbeat, the hilarious and just plain barmy, the risible and the chilling is typical of the work of Canadian Brad Fraser, whose play Unidentified Remains and the True Nature of Love made a splash a few years ago.

Fraser may have told us about this twilight world of misfits, druggies, casual murderers and lost souls before and somewhat better, but there is no denying that he tells his fractured stories of fractured lives in a way that is compellingly theatrical. Fraser's writing is as nervy and as anxiety-ridden as his characters and he interweaves their individual stories with a filmic fluency over 80 tight, shocking scenes that show off the in-the-round auditorium of the Royal Exchange to best advantage.

It doesn't all work, and how much it works for you is likely to depend on your taste for a play that mirrors a ghost train fairground ride with its mixture of mock thrills and genuine terror. You know that the mutilated bodies swinging over your head are only dummies but you enjoy the thrill of fear anyway.

But while Fraser injects a whoosh of fear, this attempt to chart a generation in hock to loveless sex, drugs and success without effort, places too much emphasis on the symptoms and not enough on the pathology. There are too many cheap thrills for the audience and not enough genuine pain to make you give a toss about these people who are more case studies than characters.

But it is an enjoyable ride, with some scarily good performances, particularly from Kellie Bright as the over-controlling Caddie and Amy Marston as the spacey Donna.

 Until December 9. Box office: 0161-833 9833.
